warada AlmaMCa gaAriDaA (assumed tropical:) He came to the water early in the morning; in the first part of the day. (S, K. *) And Oaworada Uibilahu gaAriDFA (assumed tropical:) He brought his camels to the watering-place early in the morning; in the first part of the day. (TA.) And Oatayotuhu gaAriDFA I came to him in the first part of the day. (TA.)

UigoriyDN c
UigoriyDN The spadix of a palm-tree: syn. TaloEN; (S, K;) which some call UigoriyDapN; (TA:) as also gariyDN↓: (S, K:) or the spadix of a palm-tree (TaloE) when it bursts from its kaAfuwr [i. e. spathe, or envelope]: (IAar:) or what is in the interior of the TaloEap [or spathe of a palm-tree]: (Th:) or the thing [i. e. the spathe] from which the spadix of the palm-tree (TaloE) bursts: (Ks, A) to which a woman's garment is likened. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Anything white and fresh or juicy or moist, as also gariyDN↓: (S, K:) or anything white like milk. (Ks.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Hail: (Lth, Th:) as being likened to what is in the interior of the TaloEap (Th.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Large rain, or large drops of rain, appearing, when falling, as though it, or they, were arrow-heads, from a dissundered cloud: or the first of what falls thereof. (TA.)

magoriDN c
magoriDN The part of a camel which is like the maHozim [or place of the girth] (S, O, K) of a daAbRap, (S,) [i. e.] of a horse (O, K) and mule and ass; (O;) which is the sides of the belly, at the lower part of the ribs; for these are the places of the garoD, in the bellies of camels: (S:) and mugarRaDN↓ signifies [the same: i. e.] the place of the guroDap, (IKh, TA,) or garoD; (TA;) and also the belly: (IKh, TA:) or the former signifies the head of the shoulder-blade, in which is the muXaAX [or prominent part], beneath the cartilage: or the inner part of what is between the arm [and] the place where the XaraAsiyf [or cartilages of the ribs] end (TA:) pl. magaAriDu. (S, TA.)

mugarRaDN c
mugarRaDN: see the next preceding paragraph.

magoruwDN c
magoruwDN: see gariyDN.

guroDuwfN c
guroDuwfN and guDoruwfN [A cartilage;] any soft bone, (T, S, * O, K, TA,) such as is, or may be, eaten: (T, O, K, TA:) pl. garaADiyfu (O, K, TA) and gaDaAriyfu. (O, TA.) The maArin (O, K, TA) i. e. [the soft, or cartilaginous, part,] the firm part that is harder than flesh and softer than bone, (TA,) of the nose, (O, K, TA,) is thus called. (O.) And [Any one of] the heads of the
ribs [i. e. of the costal cartilages]. (O, K.) And The rahaAbap [or ensiform cartilage] of the chest. (O, K.) And The [fibro-cartilage or] part within the quwf [or helix] of the ear. (O, K.) And The nugoD [q. v.] of the shoulder-blade. (O, K.) And AlguroDuwfaAni signifies The borders, or extremities, of the upper parts of the two shoulder-blades of the horse; what is thin, of the hard substance (lit. of the hardness), of the bone. (TA.) And they (wahumaA [i. e. the guroDuwfaAni]) are Two sinews, or the like, (EaSabataAni, [perhaps, by a somewhat-strained license, applied here to the two tarsal cartilages,] in the borders, or extremities, of the inferior parts of the two eyes. (TA.) ― -b2- And AlguroDuwfaAni signifies [also] The two pieces of wood that are bound on the right and left between the waAsiT [or fore part] and the Mxirap [or hinder part] of the [camel's saddle called] raHol. (O, K.)

1 garafa AlmaMCa c
1. garafa AlmaMCa, (Msb, K,) or garafa AlmaMCa biyadihi, (S, O, TA,) aor.
garifa
(S, O, Msb, K) and
garufa
, (K,) inf. n. garofN; (S, O, Msb;) and Agtrfhu↓, (Msb, K,) or Agtrf minohu, (S,) or both of these; (O, TA;) He took [or laded out] the water with his hand [as with a ladle]: (K, TA:) and in like manner, biAlmigorafapi [with the ladle]. (JK.) ＝ -A2- garafa AlXRaIoCa, (S, O, K, *) aor.
garufa
, (TK,) inf. n. garofN, (TA,) He cut, or cut off, the thing. (S, O, K. *) ― -b2- And garafa naASiyatahu He clipped his forelock; (S, O, K;) i. e. a horse's. (S, O.) ＝ -A3- garafa Aljiloda, (S, O, TA,) inf. n. garofN, (TA,) He tanned the skin with garof [q. v.]. (S, O, TA.) ＝ -A4- garafa AlbaEiyra, aor.
garufa
and
garifa
, (O, TA,) inf. n. garofN, (TA,) He put upon the head of the camel a rope, or cord, called gurofap [q. v.]. (O, TA.) ＝ -A5- See also 7. ＝ -A6- garifati AlUibilu, aor.
garafa
, (S, O, K,) inf. n. garafN, (S, O,) The camels had a complaint (S, O, K) of their bellies (O, K) from eating garof [q. v.]. (S, O, K.)

5 tagarRafaniI c
5. tagarRafaniI He took everything that was with me: (K, TA:) so in the Tekmileh. (TA.)

7 Angrf c
7. Angrf It (a thing) became cut, or cut off. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And It bent, or became bent: (Yaakoob, TA:) and some say, it broke, or became broken: (TA:) [and garafa↓, inf. n. garofN, app. has both of these meanings; for] Algarofu, accord. to IAar, signifies The bending, or becoming bent; and the breaking, or becoming broken. (TA.) Angrf said of a bone means It broke, or became broken: and said of a branch, or stick, or the like, it became broken, but not thoroughly. (TA.) ― -b3- And He died. (TA.)

8 Uigotarafa
8: see 1, first sentence.

garofN c
garofN and garafN↓, (S, K,) the latter mentioned by Yaakoob, (S,) A species of trees, (XajarN,) with which one tans; (S, K;) when dry, [said to be] what are termed vumaAm: (TA: [but perhaps this statement applies particularly to garafN, which see below: and see also vumaAmN:]) accord. to A'Obeyd, called garofN and galofN [q. v.]: AHn says, the grf is a species of trees from which bows are made; [see EiDaAhN;] and no one tans with it; but Kz says that its leaves may be used for tanning therewith, though bows be made of its branches: and Aboo-Mohammad mentions, on the authority of As, that one tans with the leaves of the garaf↓, and not with its branches: El-Báhilee says that garofN signifies certain skins, not such as are termed qaraZiyRap, [i. e. not tanned with qaraZ, but] tanned, in Hejer, in the following manner: one takes for them sprigs (hadab) of the OaroTaI, and puts them in a mortar, and pounds them, then throws upon them dates, whereupon there comes forth from them an altered odour, after which a certain quantity is laded out for each skin, which is then tanned therewith; and the term garof is applied to that which is laded out, and to every quantity of skin from that mash, to one and to all alike: but Az says, the garof with which skins are tanned is well known, of the trees of the desert (AlbaAdiyap), and, he says, I have seen it; and what I hold is this, that the skins termed garofiyRap are thus termed in relation to the species of trees called the garof, not to what is laded out: As says that Algarofu, with the r quiescent, signifies certain skins that are brought from El-Bahreyn. (TA.)

garafN c
garafN, (O, K, TA,) accord. to AA, (O,) or IAar, (T, TA,) i. q. vumaAmN [Panic grass]; (O, K, TA;) not used for tanning therewith; and accord. to Az, this that IAar says is correct: AHn says that when it becomes dry, and one chews it, its odour is likened to that of camphor: (TA:) or vumaAm while green: (K:) or one of the species of vumaAm, which resembles rushes (Oasal,) of which brooms are made, and with which water-bags of leather are covered to protect them from the sun so that the water becomes cool: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) the n. un. is with p. (AHn, O.) And, (O, K,) accord. to Skr, (O,) The XavR, and TubRaAq, and naXam [thus (correctly) in the O, but in the K baXam], and EafaAr [in the CK gafAr], and Eutom, and Sawom, and Habaj, and Xadon, and HayRahal [or HayRahol], and hayoXar, and Durom [thus in the O and in some copies of the K] or Dirom [thus in other copies of the K]: every one of these is called garaf. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also garofN, in two places. ― -b3- Also The leaves of trees (K, TA) with which tanning is performed. (TA.)

garofapN c
garofapN A single act of taking [or lading out] water with the hand [as with a ladle: and in like manner also with a ladle: see 1, first sentence]. (S, * Mgh, * Msb, * K.) ＝ -A2- And A single act of cutting, or cutting off, a thing: or of clipping the forelock of a horse. (K, * TA.)

gurofapN c
gurofapN The quantity of water that is taken [or laded out] with the hand [as with a ladle]; (JK, S, * Mgh, * O, Msb, * K;) as much thereof as fills the hand; (JK;) and guraAfapN↓ signifies the same: (O, K:) before it is so taken it is not termed gurofap: (S, K:) the pl. is giraAfN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And [hence, app.,] Somewhat remaining, of milk. (IAar, TA in art. jzE.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. EuilRiyRapN; (S, O, Msb, K;) i. e. [An upper chamber; or] a chamber in the upper, or uppermost, story: (Har p. 325:) pl. gurafN and gurafaAtN (S, O, Msb, K) which latter is held by some to be a pl. pl. (Msb) and gurufaAtN and gurofaAtN. (S, O, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And Algurofapu signifies The Seventh Heaven: (S, * O, * K:) or the highest of the places of Paradise: or it is one of the names of Paradise. (Bd in xxv. 75.) Accord. to the S [and O], the phrase duwna gurofapi EaroXihi occurs in a verse of Lebeed, as applying to the Seventh Heaven: but what is [found] in his poetry is duwna EizRapi EaroXihi. (IB, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also A lock (xuSolap) of hair. (O, K.) ― -b2- And A rope, or cord, tied with a bow, or double bow, (maEoquwdN biOunoXuwTapK, O, K,) which is put upon the head, (O,) or hung upon the neck, (K,) of a camel: (O, K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

girofapN c
girofapN A mode, or manner, of taking [or lading out] water with the hand [as with a ladle]. (K.) ＝ -A2- And A sandal: pl. girafN: (K:) of the dial. of Asad. (TA.) [See also gariyfapN.]

garofiIRN c
garofiIRN applied to a siqaMC [or skin for water or for milk], (S, O, K,) and garofiyRapN applied to a mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag], (S, O,) Tanned with the species of tree called garof: (S, O, K:) Aboo-Kheyreh says that the [skins termed] grfyRp are of El-Yemen and El-Bahreyn: and accord. to AHn, one says mazaAdapN garafiyRapN↓ and qirobapN garafiyRapN; and the pl. garafiyRaAtN occurs in a verse [in which the r cannot be quiescent], cited by As. (TA.) ― -b2- mazaAdapN garofiyRapN signifies also [A leathern water-bag] full: or, as some say, tanned with dates and [the tree called] OaroTaI and salt. (TA.)

garafiyRapN c
garafiyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

giraAfN c
giraAfN A certain large measure of capacity; (S, K;) like jiraAfN; (S;) also called qanoqalN [q. v.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- And pl. of gurofapN in the first of the meanings assigned to it above. (S, Msb, K.)

garuwfN c
garuwfN A well (biYorN) of which the water is taken [or laded out] with the hand. (O, L, K.) ― -b2- And A large bucket (garobN) that takes up much water; (O, K;) as also gariyfN↓; (K;) and gariyfapN is applied [in the same sense] to a [bucket termed] dalow. (Lth, TA.)

gariyfN c
gariyfN: see what next precedes. ＝ -A2- Also i. q. qaSobaMCu [i. e. Reeds, or canes; or a collection, or bed, thereof; or a place where reeds, or canes, grow]: and [the kind of high, coarse grass called] HalofaMC [q. v.]: and i. q. gayoDapN [i. e. a collection of tangled, or confused, or dense, trees; &c.]: (AHn, O, K, TA: [but for gayoDap, which is thus in the K accord. to the TA, as well as in the O, many (app. most) of the copies of the K have gayofap, a mistranscription:]) and water [in such a collection of trees, &c., i. e.,] in an Oajamap; (S, O, K;) thus expl. by Lth; (TA;) said to have this meaning
in a verse (S, O, TA) of El-Aashà; (O, TA;) but pronounced by Az incorrect: (TA:) and numerous tangled, or confused, or dense, trees, of any kind; (S, O, K;) as also gariyfapN↓: (ISd, K:) or a dense collection (OajamapN) of papyrus-plants and of HalofaMC [mentioned above] (K, TA) and of reeds, or canes; (TA;) and sometimes of the [trees called] DaAl and salam: (AHn, K, TA:) pl. gurufN. (O.)

giroyafN c
giroyafN A species of trees, (Aboo-Nasr, S, O, K,) of a soft, or weak, kind, (Aboo-Nasr, O, K,) like the garab: (Aboo-Nasr, O:) or the papyrus-plant. (AHn, O, K.)

guraAfapN c
guraAfapN: see gurofapN, first sentence.

gariyfapN c
gariyfapN A piece of leather, about a span in length, and empty, in the lower part of the [receptacle called] qiraAb of a sword, dangling; and [sometimes] it has notches cut in it, and is ornamented. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And A sandal, (S, O, K,) in the dial. of Benoo-Asad, (S, O,) and used also by the tribe of Teiyi: (Sh, TA:) [see also girofapN:] or an old and worn-out sandal. (Lh, K.) ＝ -A2- See also gariyfN.

garRaAfN c
garRaAfN A river, or channel of running water, having much water. (O, K.) ― -b2- And A copious rain: occurring in this sense in a verse: or, as some relate it, the word is there EazRaAf [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And A horse wide in step; that takes much of the ground with his legs. (AZ, O, K. *)

gaArifapN c
gaArifapN, applied to a she-camel, Swift; pl. gawaArifu: and one says also xayolN magaArifu↓ [Swift horses; app. likened, in respect of the action of their fore legs, to men lading out water with their hands; for it is added,] kaOanRahaA tagorifu AljaroIa: and faArisN migorafN↓ [A swift horseman]. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- AlgaArifap which is forbidden by the Prophet is a word of the measure faAEilap in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlap, (O, K,) like raADiyap in the phrase EiyXapN raADiyapN, (O,) and means What a woman cuts, and makes even, or uniform, fashioned in the manner of a TurRap [q. v., but for muTarRarapF, the reading of the K given in the TA, the CK and my MS. copy of the K have muTarRazap, and thus too has the O but without the teshdeed], upon the middle of her jabiyn [here meaning forehead]: (O, K, TA:) thus says Az: (TA:) or it is an inf. n., meaning Algarof, like AllRaAgiyap (O, K, TA) and AlrRaAgiyap and AlvRaAgiyap; (O, TA;) or, accord. to Az, it is a subst. similar to raAgiyap and laAgiyap; and the meaning is, the clipping of the front hair, fashioned in the manner of a TurRap (muTarRarapF), upon the jabiyn: or, accord. to El-Khattábee, the meaning is, the clipper of her front hair on the occasion of an affliction. (TA.)

migorafN c
migorafN, and the pl. magaArifu: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence.

migorafapN c
migorafapN [A ladle; i. e.] the thing with which is performed the act of lading out (maA yugorafu bihi, S, O, Msb, K) [water &c., or] food: pl. magaArifu. (Msb.)

1 gariqa c
1. gariqa, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor.
garaqa
, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. garaqN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) He, or it, (a thing, Msb,) sank, syn. gaAra, (Mgh,) or rasaba, (TA,) fiI AlmaMCi [in water, or in the water]: (S, Mgh, O, Msb:) primarily [he drowned; i. e. he sank under water, and] the water entered the two apertures of his nose so that it filled its passages and he died. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] gariqa fiI AlbilaAdi, inf. n. as above, * He (a man) went downwards and disappeared (rasaba) in the lands, or tracts of land. (TA.) ＝ -A2- garaqa, (thus in the O,) or gariqa, like fariHa, (thus accord. to the K,) He drank a [draught such as is termed] guroqap: (O, K:) so says IAar. (O.) And garaqotu mina AllRabani, (O, and thus in copies of the K, in the CK gariqotu,) or garaqotu mina AllRabani guroqapF, (TA,) I took a [draught such as is termed] kuvobap of the milk: (O, K, TA:) so says Ibn-'Abbád. (O, TA.) ＝ -A3- And gariqa He was, or became, without want, or need. (IAar, O, K.) ＝ -A4- garoqFA used in the sense of UigoraAqFA, see under 4.

2 garRaqa
2: see 4, first sentence. ― -b2- Hence tagoriyqN became used to signify (tropical:) Any killing: the origin of its being thus used being the fact that the midwife used to drown the new-born infant in the fluid of the secundine in the year of drought, (S, O, K, TA,) whether it were a male or female, (S, O, TA,) so that it died: (S, O, K, TA:) or it is from the phrase garRaqati AlqaAbilapu Alwalada meaning (tropical:) The midwife was ungentle with the child [at the birth] so that the [fluid called] saAbiyaMC entered its nose and killed it: or, accord. to the A, garRaqati AlqaAbilapu Almawoluwda means the midwife did not remove from out of the nose of the new-born infant the mucus, so that it entered into the air-passages of the nose and killed it. (TA.) Hence the saying of Dhu-r-Rummeh,
UicaA garRaqato OarobaADuhaA vinoIa bakorapK
bitayohaMCa lamo tuSobiHo raWuwmFA saluwbuhaA
i. e. When her ropes [with which her saddle is bound] kill a youthful she-camel's second young one, [and she casts it in consequence, in a desert in which one loses his way,] she [who is bereft of it] does not become one that shows affection for her offspring, by reason of the fatigue that has come upon her: (S, O, TA:) for, as is said in the T, where this verse is cited, when the saddle is bound on the she-camel that has been ten months pregnant, sometimes the fœtus becomes drowned in the fluid of the saAbiyaMC, and she casts it. (TA.) ― -b3- gurRiqa, said of a bridle, [and of the scabbard of a sword, as also Ougoriqa↓, (see mugarRaqN,)] signifies (tropical:) It was ornamented, or was ornamented in a general manner, with silver. (TA.) ― -b4- See, again, 4. ＝ -A2- grRq AlbayoDapa He removed the giroqiY [q. v.] of the egg. (TA.)

3 gaAraqaniI kacaA c
3. gaAraqaniI kacaA (tropical:) Such a thing was, or became, near to me; drew near to me; or approached me. (TA.) And gaAraqatohu AlmaniyRapu (tropical:) [Death became near to him]. (TA.) ― -b2- And gaAraqati AlwaqoEapu (tropical:) The onslaught was, or became, obligatory. (TA.)

4 Agrqhu c
4. Agrqhu, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. OigoraAqN; (TA;) and grRqhu↓, (S, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. tagoriyqN; (TA;) [primarily, He drowned him: (see 1, first sentence:) generally expl. as meaning] he sank him, or it, (TA, [see again 1, first sentence,]) fiI AlmaMCi [in water, or in the water] (S, * O, Msb, * K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Agrq OaEomaAlahu (assumed tropical:) He annulled his [good] works, by the commission of acts of disobedience. (TA.) ― -b3- And Agrqhu AlnRaAsu (assumed tropical:) The people multiplied against him and overcame him: and in like manner, Oagoraqatohu AlsRibaAEu (assumed tropical:) [The beasts of prey multiplied against him &c.] so says IAar. (TA.) ― -b4- The saying of Lebeed, describing a horse.
yugoriqu AlvRaEolaba fiI XirRatihi
is said to mean (assumed tropical:) He outstrips the vaEolab [i. e. the fox] in his sprightliness, and leaves him behind: [see also 8:] or he causes the part of the spearshaft that enters into its iron head to disappear in him who is pierced therewith by reason of the vehemence of his running. (O, TA. *) ― -b5- Agrq AlkaOosa means (tropical:) He filled the kOs [or wine-cup]. (O, K, TA.) ― -b6- See also 2, near the end. ― -b7- Agrq fiI Alqawosi [AlsRahoma being understood] (tropical:) He (the drawer of the bow, i. e., of the string of the bow with the arrow, S, O, K, TA, or the shooter, Msb) drew the bow to the fall: (S, O, Msb, K:) accord. to ISh, AlAgrAq signifies the sending the arrow far by vehement drawing [of the bow]: accord. to Useyd El-Ghanawee, the drawing of the bow so that it brings the sinews that are wound upon the socket of the arrow, as far as the iron head, to the part that is grasped by the hand; which is termed Xurobu Alqawosi AlrRiSaAfa; and one says of him who does so, yanoziEu HatRaI yaXoraba biAlrRiSaAfi: (TA:) grRq↓, also, signifies the same, (O, K,) inf. n. tagoriyqN: (O:) and one says, grRq AlnRabola, meaning he drew the bow with the arrows to the utmost extent. (TA.) In the saying in the Kur [lxxix. 1], waQlnRaAziEaAti garoqFA↓, the last word is put in the place of the proper inf. n. of Oagoraqa, for UigoraAqFA; (Fr, * Az, O, K; *) the meaning being By those angels that pull forth the souls of the unbelievers from their bosoms with a vehement pulling. (Fr, O.) ― -b8- Hence, i. e. from Agrq AlsRahoma [or Agrq fiI Alqawosi], one says, Agrq fiI Alqawoli, (TA,) or fiI AlXRaIoCi, (Msb,) (tropical:) He exceeded the usual bounds, degree, or mode; exerted himself much, beyond measure, or to the utmost; or was extravagant, or immoderate; (Msb, TA;) in the saying, (TA,) or in the thing. (Msb.) [See also 10.]

8 Agtrq Alxayola c
8. Agtrq Alxayola (tropical:) He (a horse) mixed among the [other] horses, and then outstripped them, or outwent them. (S, O, K, TA.) And Agtrq Halobapa Alxayoli (tropical:) He (a horse) outstripped, or outwent, the collection of horses started together for a wager
that were preceding. (AO, TA.) And [hence] one says, xaASamaniI faQgotaraqotu Halobatahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) [He contended with me in an altercation, or he disputed, or litigated, with me, and] I overcame him in the altercation, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- Agtrq AltRaSodiyra, (O, K, TA,) or AlbaTaAna, (O, TA,) (tropical:) He (a camel), his belly being large, (O, K, TA,) and his sides being swollen, (O, TA,) took up the whole of the breast-girth, (O, K, TA,) or the belly-girth, (O, TA,) so that it was too strait for him; as also Astgrqhu↓. (O, K, TA.) ― -b3- And Agtrq AlnRafasa (assumed tropical:) He took in the whole of the breath in drawing it in, or back, with vehemence. (S, O, TA.) Accord. to the copies of the K, Agtrqt AlRafosu, meaning AisotawoEabat: but this is a mistake: the correct phrase is Agtrq AlnRafasa, the latter word muHarRakap [and in the accus. case]; and the explanation, AisotawoEabahu fiI AlzRafiyri. (TA.) ― -b4- And tagotariqu naZarahumo, said of a woman, (tropical:) [She engrosses their look; i. e.] she occupies them in looking at her so as to divert them from looking at other than her, by reason of her beauty: (O, K, TA:) and in like manner one says, tgtrq AlTRarofa (tropical:) [she engrosses the look]. (O, TA.) [See also what next follows.]

10 Astgrq c
10. Astgrq (tropical:) He, or it, took, took in or comprised or comprehended or included, or took up or occupied, altogether, wholly, or universally; took in the gross; engrossed; syn. AisotawoEaba. (S, O, K, TA.) Hence the phrase of the grammarians, laA liQsotigoraAqi Aljinosi (tropical:) [lA denoting the universal inclusion of the genus]. (TA.) [Hence also several other conventional usages of the word]. See also 8 [with which it is interchangeable in several cases]. ― -b2- Aisotagoraqa fiI AlDRaHiki is like, (O, TA,) or syn. with, (K,) Aisotagoraba (tropical:) [He exceeded the usual bounds, or degree, in laughing; was immoderate in laughing]. (O, K, TA.) [And in the same sense the verb is used in other cases. See also 4, last signification.]

12 Aigoraworaqato EayonaAhu c
12. Aigoraworaqato EayonaAhu His eyes shed tears (S, O, K, TA) as though they were drowned therein: (O, K, TA:) or Aigoraworaqato EayonaAhu biAldRumuwEi his eyes filled with tears but did not overflow. (ISk, Az, TA.)

Q. Q. 1 garoqaOato c
Q. Q. 1. garoqaOato, as said of a hen, mentioned in this art. in the K (as being Q. Q.) and also in the TA as said of an egg, see in art. grqO.

gariqN c
gariqN and gaAriqN↓ and gariyqN↓ part. ns. of gariqa, (S, O, Msb, K,) the first and second signifying [Drowning; or] sinking in water without dying; (S, * Msb;) and the third, [drowned; or] dead by sinking in water; (Kh, Msb;) i. q. mugoraqN or mugarRaqN; (so in different copies of the S;) and accord. to the Bari', the third may have both meanings agreeably with analogy; (Msb;) [see an instance of its usage in the former sense voce tagamogama; and the first is sometimes used in the latter sense; for] it is said in a trad. that the gariq is of those who are [reckoned as] XuhadaMC [or martyrs: see XahiydN]; (O, TA;) though it is said that gariqN signifies sinking in water [like as does gaAriqN]; and gariyqN, dead therein; or, accord. to Aboo-'Adnán gariqN signifies overcome by the water but not having yet sunk; and gariyqN, having sunk [therein]: (TA:) the pl. of gariyqN is garoqaI. (Mgh, O, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., yaOotiI EalaI AlnRaAsi zamaAnN laA yanojuw fiyhi OaHadN UilRaA mano daEaA duEaMCa Algariqi [A time will come upon men in which no one will become safe but he who prays with the praying of the drowning]; app. meaning, but he who is sincere in praying, as is he who is on the brink of destruction. (TA.) ― -b3- And maAta gariqFA fiI Alxamori, in another trad., means (tropical:) He died going to the utmost point, or degree, in the drinking of wine. (TA.) ― -b4- OaroDN gariqapN means Land in the utmost state of irrigation. (IF, A, O, K.) ― -b5- gariqN and gariyqN↓ also signify (tropical:) A man much [or deeply] in debt: and overwhelmed by trials. (TA.) ― -b6- And one says, UinRahu lagariqu AlSRawoti, meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily he is frightened so that his voice is stopped short. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)

guroqapN c
guroqapN A single draught (Xarobap [in the CK Xurobap]) of milk, &c.: (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K:) or a small quantity of milk, and of beverage, or peculiarly of the former: (TA in art. Erq:) pl. guraqN. (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K.)

giroqiYN c
giroqiYN: see art. grqO: its hemzeh is augmentative (O, K) accord. to Fr: (O, TA:) and Aboo-Is-hák [i. e. Zj] held it to be so: (IJ, MF, TA:) but in the opinion of MF, there is no probable reason for this, either on the ground of analogy or of derivation. (TA.)

gariyqN c
gariyqN: see gariqN, in two places. ― -b2- One says also, OanaA gariyqu OayaAdiyka, meaning (tropical:) [I am the drowned in the flood] of thy favours. (TA.)

giroyaAqN c
giroyaAqN A certain bird: (IDrd, O, K:) so they assert: but it is not of established authority. (IDrd, O.)

gaAriqN c
gaAriqN: see gariqN, first sentence.

gaAriyquwnN c
gaAriyquwnN, (Mgh, K,) or OagaAriyquwnN, (K,) an ancient Greek word, [ ἀγαρικὸν,] (TA,) A certain medicine; a thing [or substance] resembling OanojucaAn; [see HilotiytN;] male and female; in the bitterness of which is a sweetness: (Mgh:) or the root, or stem, (OaSol,) of a certain plant: or a certain thing [or substance] which originates in worm-eaten trees; an antidote to poisons, (K, TA,) an attenuant of turbid humour, exhilarant, (K, * TA,) and good for sciatica; and [it is said that] he upon whom it is suspended will not be stung by a scorpion. (K, TA.)

mugoraqN c
mugoraqN: see mugarRaqN.

mugorq c
mugorq, [as though mugariqN, but I think it more probable that it is correctly mugarRiqN↓,] applied to a she-camel, That casts her young one, in a perfect state or otherwise, and will not be made to incline to it, or to affect it, nor will be milked; not such as yields her milk copiously, nor [such as is termed] xalifap [q. v.]. (TA.)

mugarRaqN c
mugarRaqN, applied to a bridle, (tropical:) Ornamented, (S, O, K,) or ornamented in a general manner, (TA,) with silver; (S, O, K, TA;) as also mugoraqN↓: (K:) and likewise applied to the scabbard of a sword. (TA.)

mugarRiqN c
mugarRiqN: see mugoriq.

ramaDaAnu mugaAriqN c
ramaDaAnu mugaAriqN [The observance of Ramadán is obligatory]. (TA.)

Q. 1 garoqaOato c
Q. 1. garoqaOato, said of an egg (bayoDapN), It came forth having upon it [only] its thin integument [or pellicle, called giroqiY]. (K.) ― -b2- And, said of a hen, [in the K in art. grq [in which the hemzeh is said to be augmentative) grqOt bayoDahaA] She laid her eggs in the state described above. (K.) [But see what follows.]

giroqiYN c
giroqiYN The integument [or pellicle.] (S, K) that is beneath the qayoD [i. e. shell], (S,) adhering to the white, (K,) of the egg. (S, K.) But Fr says its C is augmentative, for it is from Algaraqu. (S.) Or The white [of the egg], which is eaten: (K:) but this explanation is of weak authority. (TA.)

garoqadN c
garoqadN A species of tree, (S, O, L, K,) of large size, (L, K,) of the kind termed EiDaAh, (L,) said by some to grow in the ground termed qufR: (O, L:) or the species of tree called Eawosaj [or boxthorn], when it has grown large: (AHn, O, L, K:) a species of thorny tree: (L:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (L, O, K.) ＝ -A2- It is said in the K to signify also The white of an egg: but as thus expl., it is app. a mistake for giroqiYN. (TA.)

Q. 1 garoqalati AlbayoDapu c
Q. 1. garoqalati AlbayoDapu The egg became rotten; (S, O;) the interior of the egg became corrupt: and thus garoqala signifies said of the biTRiyx [i. e. melon, or water-melon]: (K:) or, said of the bTRyx, it became hard. (O.) ＝ -A2- And garoqala He poured water upon his head at once; (IAar, O, K, TA;) inf. n. garoqalapN. (TA.)

giroqilN c
giroqilN The white of an egg; as also giroqiylN↓. (Az, TA.)

giroqiylN c
giroqiylN: see what next precedes.

1 garila c
1. garila, aor.
garala
, inf. n. garalN, He was uncircumcised. (Msb.)

garilN c
garilN, A man flaccid, lax, or uncompact, in make. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And A long, (K,) or an excessively long, (TA,) spear. (K, TA.)

gurolapN c
gurolapN The qulofap [or prepuce]. (S, O, Msb, K.) Hence, in a trad. of Aboo-Bekr when he was a boy, rakiba Alxayola EalaI gurolatihi, meaning He rode horses when he was small in age, before he was circumcised. (TA.)

giroyalN c
giroyalN and giroyanN signify the same; (AA, AZ, As, S, O, K;) [Silt, or alluvial deposit, left upon the ground by a torrent;] i. e. (S, O) earth, or mould, borne by a torrent, and remaining upon the ground, (AZ, S, O, K,) much cracked, (K,) whether moist or dry: (AZ, S, O, K;) or fine earth or mould, which is seen to have drive upon the ground, (As, S, O, TA,) and became much cracked, (As, TA,) when a torrent has came and remained some time upon the ground, and then sunk in and disappeared: (As, S, O, TA:) or, accord. to AA, (S, O, TA,) what remains of, or from, water, (S, O,) or of earth, or mud, (TA,) in a watering-trough: (S, O, TA:) and a pool of water left by a torrent. in which remain animal cules termed] daEaAmiyS [pl. of duEomuwSN, q. v.], and which one cannot drink. (AA, S, O, K, TA.) And The sediment remaining in the bottom of a flask, or bottle: (AA, S, O, K, TA:) and the sediment of a dye. (TA.) And (the former) Dust; syn. gubaArN. (O, K.) And The mucus of the nose of a solid-hoofed animal of any hand. (O, K.)

Oagoralu c
Oagoralu, with which Oarogalu is syn. in all of the following senses, (TA,) applied to a boy, (S, O.) i. q. Oqolafu [i. e. Uncircumcised]: (S, O, Msb, K:) fem. garolaMCu: and pl. gurolN. (Msb.) ― -b2- And EayoXN Oagoralu A life ample in its means, or circumstances. (S, O, K.) And EaAmN Oagoralu A fruitful, or plentiful, year. (K.)

1 garima c
1. garima, (JK, S, Msb, K,) aor.
garama
, (JK, K,) inf. n. guromN (JK, Msb, TA) and garaAmapN (Msb, TA) and magoramN, (TA,) He paid, or discharged (A K, S, * Msb, K, *) a thing that was obligatory upon him, (JK,) or a bloodwit, (S, Msb, K,) and a responsibility, and the like thereof, after it had become obligatory upon him: (Msb:) (or, accord. to an explanation of AlgaraAmapu in Har p. 36, he gave property against his will: or the meaning intended in the S and K (in both of which it is very vaguely indicated) may be, he took upon himself to pay, or discharge, a blood wit, &c.: for, sometimes,] guromN and magoramN and garaAmapN signify the taking upon oneself that which is not obligatory upon him: (Mgh; and the Ksh gives this explanation of magoramN in lii. 40:) [or the taking upon oneself a fine or the like: for, sometimes,] magoramN signifies AilotizaAmu guromK. (Bd in lii. 40. [See also 5, and 8.]) And you say, garimotu Eanohu maA lazimahu mina AldRiyapi [I paid for him, i. e., in his stead, what was obligatory upon him, of the bloodwit]. (Msb in art. Eql.) ― -b2- And garima fiI tijaAratihi He lost, or suffered loss, in his traffic; i. q. xasira; contr. of rabiHa. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- gurima OanofFA: see rugima [from which it is app. formed by transposition].

2 grRmhu c
2. grRmhu i. q. Agrmhu, q. v. (S, Mgh, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.] gurRima AlsRaHaAbu (assumed tropical:) The clouds rained; [as though they were made to discharge a debt that they owed;] Aboo-Dhn-eyb says, describing clouds.
wahaI xarojuhu waQsotuHiyla AlrRabaA
bu minohu waEuzRima maMCF SariyHaA
(assumed tropical:) [The clouds that were the first thereof in rising and appearing became rent, and such of them as were suspended beneath other clouds were looked at in order that it might be seen whether they moved, and they discharged clear water.] (TA.)

4 Oagoramotuhu c
4. Oagoramotuhu and garRamotuhu↓, (S Msb, K,) inf. n. [of the former UigoraAmN and [of the latter tagoriymN, (TA,) both signify the same; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. I made him to pay, or discharge, a bloodwit, and a responsibility, and the like, (see 1,)] after it had became obligatory upon him; (Msb, K: *) [or the meaning intended in the S and K (in the latter of which it is vaguely indicated and in the farmer more so) may be, I made him to take upon himself to pay, or discharge, a bloodwit, &c. for, sometimes,] grRmhu and Agrmhu signify he made him to incur the taking upon himself that which was not obligatory upon him; (Mgh:) [and sometimes the inf. ns.] UigoraAmN and tagoriymN signify the making to he final; and, to he indebted; (PS;) Oagoramotuhu UiyRaAhu in the copies of the K is a mistake for UiyRaAhu Oagoramotuhu . (TA.) ― -b2- UigoraAmN also signifies The throwing [one] into destruction. (KL.) ― -b3- And The rendering [one] eagerly desirous [of a thing; fond of it; or attached to it]. (KL.) You say, Ougorima biAlXRaIoCi He became eagerly desirous of the thing; fond of it; or attached to it; syn. OuwliEa bihi (S, Msb, TA.)

5 tgrRm c
5. tgrRm [app. He took upon himself an obligation, such as the payment of a fine. &c.]. (Ham p. 707. [See also 1, and 8.])

8 AigotiraAmN c
8. AigotiraAmN The making obligatory upon oneself what is termed garaAmap, which signifies difficulty or trouble, and damage or detriment or loss, and the giving of property against one's will. (Har p. 36. [See also 1, and 5.])

guromN c
guromN an inf. n. of garima [q. v.]. (JK, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And A thing that must be paid, or discharged; (K, TA;) and so garaAmapN↓, and mugoramN↓, (S, K, TA,) and magoramN↓: (S, TA:) accord. to Er-Rághib, a damage, detriment, or loss, that befalls a man, in his property, not for an injurious action, of his, requiring punishment (TA:) a debt, (S, TA:) a fine, or mulet: (MA:) the pl. of magoramN↓ is magaArimu, agreeably with analogy; or this is pl. of guromN, anomalously, like as maHaAsinu is of HusonN. (TA.) [See exs. voce galiqa: and see also gunomN.]

garomaI c
garomaI A woman heavy, or sluggish; syn. vaqiylapN: (K:) or, accord. to IAar, i. q. mugaADiyapN [that makes, and is made, angry: or that breaks off from, or quits, one, in anger, or enmity]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- It is also syn. with OamaA, as a word denoting an oath [or used in swearing]: one says garomaI wajadRika [Verily, or now surely, by thy grandfather, or by thy fortune or good fortune]; like as one says OamaA wajadRika: (AA, K, TA:) and EaromaI and HaromaI are dial. vars. thereof. (TA.)

garaAmN c
garaAmN A thing from which one is unable to free himself, [a thing] such as cleaves fast. (BA and Jel in xxv. 66.) Lasting evil. (IAar, S, K.) Perdition: (K:) in the Kur xxv. 66, (S, Ksh,) accord. to AO, (S,) it means perdition, (S, Ksh,) persistent, (Ksh,) and such as cleaves fast. (S, Ksh.) And Punishment, or torment; (S, K) or, accord. to Zj, the most vehement punishment or torment; and accord to Er-Rághib, hardship, or difficulty, and an affliction, or a calamity or misfortune, that befalls a man. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Eager desire [biXaIoCK for a thing]; fondness [for it]; or attachment [to it]; syn. waluwEN: (S, K:) or love that torments the heart. (Har p. 36.) [See 4, last sentence.]

gariymN c
gariymN A debtor; (S, Msb, K:) one says, xuco mino gariymi AlsRawoCi maA sabaHa Take thou from the evil debtor what has become easy of attachment, (S:) and gaArimN↓ signifies the same as gariymN; or one upon whom lies the obligation of a bloodwit or the like; or [it virtually signifies thus, but properly] it is a possessive epithet signifying cuw garaAmK or garaAmapK or tagoriymK. (TA.) And (sometimes, S) it signifies A creditor also: (S, Msb, K:) thus having two contr. meanings; (K) Kutheiyir says, * qaDaI kulRu ciI dayonK fawafRaI gariymahu * waEazRapu mamoTuwlN muEanRFI gariymuhaA [Every debtor has paid, and fully rendered to his creditor; but as to 'Azzeh, her creditor is put off, and wearied]. (S.) The pl. of gariymN is guramaMCu (I Ath, Msb, TA) and gurRaAmN, which is a strange [i. e. an anomalous] pl., (I Ath, TA;) or this is pl. of gaArimN↓ as syn. with gariymN [and thus is agree able with analogy]; or it is pl. of mugorimN↓ [signifying “ burdened with debt. ”], formed by the rejection of the augmentative letter [of the sing]. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, An adversary in contention, dispute, or litigation; an antagonist; a litigant; because, by his pressing upon his adversary [like the creditor upon his debtor], he becomes one who cleaves, or clings. (Msb.)

garaAmapN c
garaAmapN: see guromN.

gaArimN c
gaArimN: see gariymN, in two places.

magoramN c
magoramN; pl. magaArimu: see guromN, in two places.

mugoramN c
mugoramN Shackled, (K,) or burdened, (TA,) with debt; (K;) an epithet applied to a man from Alguromu and AldRayonu. (S.) See gariymN. ― -b2- And A captive of love; (K, TA;) i. e., of the love of women: (TA:) or one to whom love cleaves: (Ham p. 558:) or you say rajulN mugoramN biAlHubRi [a man to whom love cleaves, or clung to by love]; from the love of women: (S:) and huwa mugoramN biAlnRisaMCi He is one who clings to women, like as does the gariym [or
“ creditor ” to the debtor]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And mugoramN biXaIoCK Eagerly desirous of a thing; fond of it; or attached to it; syn. muwlaEN bihi; (Msb, K, TA;) and HariySN Ealayohi; (Har p. 585;) not having patience to refrain from it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also guromN.

guromuwlN c
guromuwlN The penis, (S, O, K,) in an absolute sense: (TA:) or a large and flaccid penis before its prepuce is cut off; (K;) thus says AZ: (TA:) or it is said to be of a solid-hoofed animal: but mention is made in a trad. of the garaAmiyl of men [in relation to whom, however, it may perhaps be used in this instance by way of comparison]. (TA.)

garonaqapN c
garonaqapN An amorous playing with the eyes. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)

gironaAqN c
gironaAqN: see guronayoqN, last sentence.

guronuwqN c
guronuwqN is held by the author of the K to be wrongly mentioned by J in art. grq, on the ground of the saying that the n is radical; and IJ says that Sb has mentioned guronayoqN among quadriliteral-radical words: but there is a difference of opinion on this point; for AHei asserts that the n in guronuwqN and in all its dial. vars. is augmentative. (TA.) ― -b2- See guronayoqN, in two places. ― -b3- Also sing. of garaAniqu, which signifies (assumed tropical:) Certain trees: (Aboo-Ziyád, O, K:) or, as also guraAniqN↓, sing. of garaAniyqu, which signifies the tender sprouts at the root, or lower part, of the Eawosaj [or box-thorn]: (AA, O, K:) likened to a tender youth, because of their freshness and beauty: (TA:) or guronuwqN signifies a tender and concealed plant; (K, TA;) or, accord. to one copy [of the K], a tender, spreading plant: mentioned by AHn. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A lock of hair much twisted: (Lth, O, K:) or, accord. to IAar, a forelock: so in the phrase jacaba guronuwqahu [He pulled his forelock]: and nugoruwqN signifies the “ hair of the back of the neck. ” (O, TA.)

gironawoqN c
gironawoqN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

guronayoqN c
guronayoqN (S, K) and guronuwqN↓ and gironawoqN↓ (O, K) A certain aquatic bird, (S, O, K, TA,) long in the neck (S, O, TA) and in the legs, (TA,) white, (O, K, TA,) or black: (K, TA:) [app. the white stork, ardea ciconia; or, accord. to some, the black stork, ardea nigra:] or, accord. to IAmb, the males [or male] thereof: (TA:) or the first, (O, K,) as also the second, (K,) signifies the kurokiIR [or Numidean crane, ardea virgo]: (As, O, K, TA:) or a certain bird resembling this: (ISk, O, K, TA:) pl. garaAniyqu. (O, TA.) It is related of the Prophet that [when he was reciting the words of the Kur (liii. 19 and 20), “ Have ye considered El-Lát, and El-'Ozzà, and Menáh, the other third? ”] the Devil put into his mouth the saying tiloka AlgaraAniyqu AlEulaI [Those are the most high grAnyq, as though meaning cranes, for the Numidian crane is remarkable in the East for its superlatively-high flight]; referring, as IAar says, to the idols, which were asserted to be intercessors with God, wherefore they are likened to the birds that rise high into the sky: (O, TA: *) or grAnyq may in this case be a pl. of one of the sings. expl. in what here follows [but applied to females]. (O.) ― -b2- guronayoqN (O, K, TA, and so in copies of the S) and gironayoqN↓ (IJ, TA, and so in some copies of the S in the place of the former) and guronuwqN↓ and gironawoqN↓ (S, O, K, TA) and gironiyqN↓ (K) and gironaAqN↓ and garawonaqN↓ (O, K) and guraAniqN↓ (S, K) signify (assumed tropical:) A tender youth; (S;) or a white, or fair, and comely, or beautiful, youth; (O, K;) or a youth white, or fair, tender, having beautiful hair, and comely: (TA:) pl. garaAniyqu and garaAniqapN (S, O, K) and garaAniqu, (S, K,) which last may be pl. of guraAniqN, agreeably with analogy, (IAmb, TA,) or it may be a contraction of garaAniyqu, as such used by a poet. (TA.)

gironayoqN c
gironayoqN and gironiyoqN: see the next preceding sentence.

guraAniqN c
guraAniqN, applied to a youth, (K, TA,) and to youthfulness, (TA, and so in the CK instead of a youth,) Perfect, or without defect. (K, TA.) And, applied to a woman, as also guraAniqapN, Youthful and plump. (K.) ― -b2- See also guronayoqN, last sentence. ― -b3- limRapN guraAniqapN and guraAniqiyRapN↓ [Hair descending below the lobe of the ear, or descending upon the shoulders,] sleek, such as the wind puts in motion. (Sh, O, K.) ― -b4- See also guronuwqN.

garawonaqN c
garawonaqN: see guronayoqN, last sentence.

limRapN guraAniqiyRapN c
limRapN guraAniqiyRapN: see guraAniqN.

1 garaA Aljiloda c
1. garaA Aljiloda, (K,) first pers. garawotu, (S, Msb,) aor.
garuwa
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. garowN, (TA,) He glued the skin; i. e., made it to adhere with giraMC. (S, Msb, K.) And garayotu AlsRahoma signifies the same as garawotuhu [i. e. I glued the feathers upon the arrow: see the two pass. part. ns.]. (TA.) [And accord. to present usage, garRaAhu↓, inf. n. tagoriyapN, signifies He glued it.] ― -b2- garaA AlsRimanu qalobahu, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) Fatness adhered to his heart, and covered it: (K, TA:) mentioned by ISd. (TA.) ＝ -A2- gariIa bihi It adhered to it [as glue or the like]. (Ksh and Bd in v. 17. [And used in this sense in the S and K as an explanation of lazija bihi.]) ― -b2- And [hence], aor. yagoraI, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. garFA (Abu-l-Khattáb, Msb, K, TA) and giraMCN, (K, TA,) like kisaMCN, but in the M like saHaAb [i. e. garaMCN], which J [in the S] pronounces to be a subst., (TA,) He became attached to it, or fond of it; was eagerly desirous of it; he adhered, clung, or clave, to it; or loved it; syn. OuwliEa bihi; (Msb, K, TA;) and lazimahu; (TA;) without his being incited thereto by another; (Msb, TA;) and bihi OugoriIa↓ signifies the same, (Msb, * K, TA,) as also bihi gurRiIa↓, (K, TA,) each with damm, (K,) and the latter with teshdeed, as is stated in the M. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 3. ― -b4- And gariIa fulaAnN Such a one persisted, or persevered, in his anger. (S, TA.) ― -b5- gariIa said of what is termed EidRN, [i. e. of the water thus termed,] (M, and so in some copies of the K,) or of a gadiyr, [or pool of water left by a torrent,] (so in other copies of the K [but the former is said in the TA to be the right],) It became cold, or cool, (M, TA,) or its water became cold, or cool. (K.) ＝ -A3- garawotu, (inf. n. garowN, S, * Msb,) also signifies I wondered. (S, Msb, TA.) [See garowN, below.]

2 grRAhu c
2. grRAhu: see 1, third sentence. ― -b2- [The inf. n.] tagoriyapN is syn. with taToliyapN [The daubing, smearing, or rubbing over; perhaps particularly, or originally, with giraMC i. e. glue]. (K.) ― -b3- grRAhu bihi: see 4. And gurRiIa bihi: see 1, latter half.

3 gArI bayona AlXRayoYayoni c
3. gArI bayona AlXRayoYayoni, (S, K,) inf. n. giraMCN, (S,) He made no interruption between the two things: (S, K:) mentioned by A'Obeyd, from Khálid Ibn-Kulthoom: and hence the saying of Kutheiyir,
UicaA qulota Oasoluw faADati AlEayonu biAlbukaA
giraACF wamadRatohaA madaAmiEu HufRalu
[When thou sayest, “ I will be forgetful, ” or “ unmindful, ” the eye overflows with weeping, uninterruptedly, and copious flowings of tears pour into it and replenish it]: AO says that the verb is from gariytu biAlXRayoCi. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And gArI fulaAnFA, (K, TA,) inf. n. mugaAraApN and giraMCN, (TA,) He wrangled, quarrelled, or contended, with such a one: (K, TA:) mentioned on the authority of AHeyth, who disallowed bihi gariIa↓, inf. n. grMC. (TA. [Whether AHeyth disallowed the latter in this sense or in one of the senses mentioned in the first paragraph is not stated.])

4 AgrAhu bihi c
4. AgrAhu bihi He made him to become attached to it, or fond of it; to be eagerly desirous of it; to adhere, cling, or cleave, to it; or to love it; (Msb, K;) syn. walRaEahu: (K:) one should not say bihi grRAhu↓. (TA. [But one says gurRiIa bihi: see 1.]) And OugoriIa bihi: see 1. ― -b2- He incited, urged, or instigated, him to do it. (MA, and Har p. 355.) You say, Oagorayotu Alkaloba biAlSRayodi (S) I incited, urged, or instigated, the dog, to, or against, the object, or objects, of the chase. (Kull.) ― -b3- And AgrAhu bihimo He set him upon them, or over them; or made him to have mastery, dominion, or authority, over them. (Jel in xxxiii. 60.) ― -b4- AgrI bayonahumu AlEadaAwapa (tropical:) He occasioned enmity between them: (Jel in v. 17:) he cast enmity between them, as though he made it to cleave to them: (K, TA:) a tropical phrase. (TA.) And Oagorayotu bayonahumo [in which an objective complement is understood] (S, Msb) i. q. Oafosadotu [meaning (assumed tropical:) I excited disorder, disturbance, dis-
agreement, discord, dissension, strife, or quarrel-ling, or I made, or did, mischief, between them, or among them]. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- AgrI AlXRaIoCa, said of God, He made, or rendered, the thing goodly, or beautiful. (IKtt, TA.)

6 humaA yatagaArayaAni fiI AlgaDabi c
6. humaA yatagaArayaAni fiI AlgaDabi [app. They two wrangle, quarrel, or contend, in anger]. (JK. [See 3.])

laAgarowa c
laAgarowa signifies laA Eajaba [meaning There is no case of wonder], (Msb, K, and Ham p. 603,) the enunciative of laA being suppressed, as though the saying were laAgarowa fiI AldRunoyaA [there is no case of wonder in the present world] or mawojuwdN [existing]; (Ham;) as also laA garowaI↓: (K:) or layosa biEajabK [meaning it is not a case of wonder]. (S.) One says, laA garowa mino kacaA i. e. laA Eajaba [meaning There is no case of wonder arising from such a thing, or, using grw as an inf. n., (see 1, last signification,) there is no wondering at such a thing]. (Har p. 488.) And the saying
walaA garowa Oano yaHocuw AlfataI Hacowa waAlidiho
means And it is not a case of wonder (layosa biEajabK), i. e. there is no wondering (laA Eajaba), that the [young] man should follow the example of his father, doing the like of his deed. (Har p. 86.)

garFA c
garFA: see giraMCN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The giros [q. v.] that descends [from the womb] with the child. (TA.) ― -b3- And The young one of the cow: (K, TA:) or, as some say, peculiarly, of [the species of bovine antelope called] the wild cow: dual garawaAni: and pl. OagoraMCN. (TA.) It is also applied to The young camel when just born: and, some say, it signifies a youngling that is very sappy or soft or tender: (TA:) and anything brought forth (K, TA) until its flesh becomes firm, or hard. (TA.) ― -b4- And (K, TA) [hence], by way of comparison, (TA,) as also garaApN↓, (assumed tropical:) Lean, meagre, or emaciated, (K, TA,) in a great degree: (TA:) pl. OagoraMCN. (K, TA.) Hence the trad., laA HatRFI yakobara tacobaHuwhu garaApF↓ (assumed tropical:) [Do not ye slaughter it while very lean, &c., until it become full-grown] (TA. [See 4 in art. frE.]) ＝ -A2- Also Goodliness, or beauty. (S, K. [See gariIRN.])

garaApN c
garaApN [Excitement of disorder, disturbance, disagreement, &c.;] the subst. from Oagorayotu bayonahumo [q. v.]. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also garFA, in two places.

garowaI c
garowaI: see the next paragraph: ＝ -A2- and see also laA garowa.

garaMCN c
garaMCN [A state of attachment, or fondness, &c.;] the subst. from gariIa bihi [q. v.] as meaning OuwliEa bihi: (S, Msb, TA:) or, accord. to the M, this is an inf. n.; and the subst. accord. to the K is garowaI↓. (TA.)

giraMCN c
giraMCN and garFA↓ (S, Mgh, Msb, K) [Glue;] a substance with which a thing is made to adhere, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) obtained from fish, (S, Mgh,) or made from skins, and sometimes made from fish: (Msb:) or the substance with which one smears; (Fr, K, TA;) and thus the former word is expl. by Sh: (TA:) or a certain thing that is extracted from fish: (K:) [and mucilage, which by concretion becomes gum; the former word is used in this sense in the K voce SamogN. q. v.:] and it is said that the trees [app. that produce the mucilage termed giraMC, otherwise [know not what can be meant thereby,] are [called] garFI [or garFA↓]; but AHn says that certain persons pronounce the word thus, but it is not the approved way. (TA.) ＝ -A2- rajalN giraMCN means A man who has not a beast [to carry him] (laA daAbRapa lahu). (K.)

gariIRN c
gariIRN Made to adhere; syn. muloSaqN. (TA voce EariyrN.) ― -b2- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) An adherent. (See EariyrN.) ― -b3- Hence also, Daubed, smeared, or rubbed over; as will be shown in the course of this paragraph. (See also magoruwRN.) ― -b4- ] And The goodly, or beautiful, (S, K, TA,) in respect of face, (TA,) of mankind, (S, K, TA,) and the goodly, or beautiful, of others than mankind: and [particularly] a goodly building: (K, TA:) and hence. ― -b5- AlgariyRaAni Two well-known buildings, in El-Koofeh, (K, TA,) at Eth-Thaweeyeh, where is the tomb of 'Alee, the Prince of the Faithful, asserted to have been built by one of the Kings of El-Heereh: (TA:) or two tall buildings, said to be the tombs of Málik and Akeel, the two cup-companions of Jedheemeh ElAbrash; thus called because En-Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir used to smear them (kaAna yugarRiyhimaA) with the blood of him whom he slew when he went forth in the day of his evil fortune [or ill omen, the story of which is well known], (S, TA.) ― -b6- AlgariIRu is also the name of A certain idol [or object of idolatrous worship, app. from what here follows, a mass of stone, like as AllRaAtRu is said to have been by some, and like as were several other objects of worship of the pagan Arabs], with which [probably meaning with the blood on which] one used to smear himself, and upon which one used to sacrifice [victims]. (TA.) ― -b7- And gariIRN signifies also A certain red dye. (TA.)

guraAwaI c
guraAwaI i. q. ragowapN [i. e. Froth]: (K, TA: [AlgurACIe in the CK is a mistranscription:]) app. formed by transposition; for rugaAwaI has been mentioned [in art. rgw] as syn. with ragowapN: (TA:) pl. with fet-h [i. e. garaAwaI]. (K, TA.)

huwa mugorFI bihi c
huwa mugorFI bihi, from OagoraAhu bihi [q. v.], He is made to become attached to it, or fond of it; &c. (TA.)

magoruwRN c
magoruwRN [pass. part. n. of garaA, q. v.; Glued, &c. ― -b2- Hence, for sahomN magoruwRN, lit. A glued arrow, meaning an arrow having the feathers glued upon it, i. e.] a feathered arrow. (Meyd in explanation of what here follows.) It is said in a prov., OadorikoniI walawo biOaHadi AlmugoruwRayoni, meaning [Reach thou me, though] with one of the two [feathered] arrows: or, as Th says, with an arrow or with a spear: (S:) El-Mufaddal says, there were two brothers, of the people of Hejer, a people to whom the Arabs ascribe stupidity, and one of those two rode an intractable she-camel, and the one that did not ride had with him a how, and his name was Huneyn; so the one that was riding called to him, and said, yaA hunayonu wayolaka QnoziloniI walawo biOaHadi AlmagoruwRayoni, [in which AnzlnI seems to be a mistranscription for AdrknI,] meaning, with his arrow; whereupon his brother shot at him and laid him prostrate; and his saying became a prov., applied on an occasion of necessity, or difficulty, and of the after failing of stratagem. (Meyd.) One says also qawosN magoruwRapN [A glued bow] (S, Msb, K) and magoriyRapN↓. (S, K.)

qawosN magoriyRapN c
qawosN magoriyRapN: see what next precedes.

1 garayotu AlsRahoma c
1. garayotu AlsRahoma: see 1 in art. grw.

qawosN magoriyRapN c
qawosN magoriyRapN: see magoruwRN (last sentence) in art. grw.

1 gazura c
1. gazura, aor.
gazura
, inf. n. gazaArahN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and gazorN (Mgh, L, Msb, K) and guzorN, (L, K,) or gazorN is a simple subst., (S, L, TA,) It (a thing, S, K, or water, Mgh, Msb) was, or became, much, abundant, or copious. (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) ― -b2- gazurato She (a camel, S, Msb, or a beast, K) bad much milk; abounded in milk, became abundant in milk; (S, Msb, K:) Eani AlkalaO from the herbage; (TA;) or Ealayohi [by feeding] upon it; (K;) as also Oagozarato↓: (IKtt:) and it (a well, and a spring,) abounded in water; and it (an eye) abounded in tears. (K.)

2 tagoziyrN c
2. tagoziyrN signifies The omitting a milking between two milkings, when the milk of the camel is backward. (S, K, TA,) A similar meaning is mentioned in art. grz: see 2 in that art (TA.)

3 gAzrhu c
3. gAzrhu, inf. n. mugaAzarapN, He gave him a small and mean thing in order that he might give him in return twice as much: he sought to obtain from him more than he gave. (I Aar, TA: but only the inf. n. is mentioned.)

4 Oagozara
4: see 1. ＝ -A2- Oagozara QllRehu maAlahu [God caused his camels, or sheep, or goats, to have much milk]. (TA.) ― -b2- Agzr AlmaEoruwfa He made the beneficence to be abundant. (K.) ＝ -A3- Agzr Alqawomu The people's camels, (S, K,) and their sheep or goats, (TA,) became abundant in milk. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- And The people became in the state of having much rain. (IKtt.)

gazorN c
gazorN [Abundance in milk: or abundance of milk: of camels &c.:] a subst. from gazurati AlnRaAqapu; pl. guzorN; like as juwnN is pl. of jawonN, and HuXorN of HaXorN. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also A vessel made of [the coarse grass called] HalofaMC and of palm-leaves: (IDrd, K:) a well-known Arabic word. (IDrd, TA.)

guzoraI c
guzoraI [as though fem. of Oagozaru] is applied to a she-camel by Honeyf-El-Hanátim [as meaning
Surpassingly abundant in milk]. (IAar in TA in art. bhI.)

guzoraAnN c
[guzoraAnN mentioned by Freytag as an epithet applied to camels, meaning Abounding in milk, on the authority of the K, is a mistake; it is mentioned in the K only as the name of a place.]

gaziyrN c
gaziyrN, and the fem. gaziyrapN, Much; abundant; copious: (S, Msb, K:) applied to water, (Msb,) and rain, (K,) and beneficence, (S,) and knowledge, (TA,) and anything. (S, K.) ― -b2- A she-camel, (S, Msb, K,) and a sheep or goat or other beast, (TA,) having much milk; abounding in milk: (S, Msb, K:) a well, and a spring, (K,) and a subterranean channel for water, (Msb,) abounding in water: (Msb, K:) and an eye abounding in tears: (K:) pl. gizaArN. (S, Msb.)

qawomN mugozarN lahumo c
qawomN mugozarN lahumo, in the pass. form, A people having abundance of milk; whose camels abound in milk. (K.)

magozarapN c
magozarapN, (as written in the L, [and so agreeably with analogy, as meaning A cause of abounding in milk; similar to maboxalapN and majobanapN &c.;]) or mugozirapN, (accord. to the K,) a thing [from the feeding of a beast] upon which the milk becomes abundant. (L, K.) ― -b2- And, (K, TA,) hence, (TA,) A certain plant, the leaves of which are like those of the Hurof [q. v.], (K, TA,) dust-coloured, and small, and which has a red blossom, like that of the pomegranate: (TA:) it pleases the cows (K, TA) much, (TA,) and they become abundant in milk [by feeding] upon it: (K, TA:) it is of the [season called] rabiyE; and is mentioned by AHn, who says that all cattle pasture upon it. (TA.)

migozaArN c
migozaArN [Abounding much in milk; applied to a she-camel &c.]. (The Lexicons passim.)

OaroDN magozuwrapN c
OaroDN magozuwrapN Land upon which much rain has fallen. (K.)

mugaAzirN c
mugaAzirN and musotagozirN↓ One who gives a thing in order that he may obtain in return more than he gives. (K.) One of the Tábi'ees says AljaAnibu yuvaAbu mino hibatihi Almusotagoziru↓ The stranger who seeks to obtain more than he gives shall be rewarded for his gift: meaning, when the stranger, who is not related to thee, gives thee a thing, he seeks to obtain more than it; so do thou requite him for his gift, and exceed it to him. (TA.)

musotagozirN c
musotagozirN: see mugaAzirN, in two places.

1 gazalati AlquTona c
1. gazalati AlquTona, (S, MA, O, K,) and AlkatRaAna wagayorahumaA, (TA,) or AlSRuwfa wanaHowahu, (Msb,) aor.
gazila
(S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. gazolN, (S, MA, O, KL,) She spun the cotton, (MA, KL, PS,) and the flax, &c., (TA,) or the wool, and the like; (Msb;) and Agtzlthu↓ signifies the same. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- gazila, (S, O, K, TA,) aor.
gazala
, (K, TA,) inf. n. gazalN, (S, O, TA,) He talked, and acted in an amatory and enticing manner, with a woman, or with women; he practised gazal [meaning as expl. below, i. e. the talk, and actions, and circumstances, occurring between the lover and the object of love; &c.]. (S, * O, * K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- And gazila is also said of a dog, meaning He flagged, or became remiss, in the pursuit of a young gazelle; i. e., when he had come up to it, the latter uttered a cry by reason of its fright, whereupon he turned away from it, (S, O, K, TA,) and became diverted; (S, O, TA;) or, as IAar says, when it became sensible of the presence of the dog, it became confounded, or perplexed, and clave to the ground, and he (the dog) became diverted from it, and turned away: (TA:) or he was confounded, or perplexed, in pursuing a young gazelle, by its uttering a cry in his face when he came up to it. (Meyd in explanation of a prov.: see Oagozalu, below.)

3 gaAzalahaA c
3. gaAzalahaA, (S, MA, TA,) inf. n. mugaAzalapN, (S, O, K, TA,) He talked with her, (S, O, * K, * TA,) and acted in an amatory and enticing manner with her; (S, TA;) and in like manner one says of a woman with a man: (S:) or he played, or sported, [or dallied, or wantoned,] and held amorous talk, with her. (MA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, OaToyabu mino OanofaAsi AlSRabaA UicaA gaAzalato riyaADa AlrbA (tropical:) [More pleasant, or delightful, than the breaths of the east wind (which is to the Arabs like the zephyr to us) when it has wantoned with the meadows of AlrbA, (app. AlrRubaA, the name of a place, mentioned in the K in art. rbw, there written AlrRubaI, and in the TA in that art. said to occur in poetry,) so as to have brought with it the odours of flowers]. (K.) And huwa yugaAzilu ragadFA mina AlEayoXi (tropical:) [app. meaning He plays the wanton with ampleness and easiness and pleasantness of the means of subsistence]. (TA.) ― -b3- And gAzl AlOarobaEiyna (assumed tropical:) He approached [the age of] forty [years]. (Th, K.)

4 Agzl c
4. Agzl, (K,) or Agzlt, (S, O,) He, or she, turned round, or made to revolve, [or rather twirled,] the migozal [or spindle]: (S, O, K:) [or so Agzl Almgzla, or Agzlthu, for] one says of the mgzl [or spindle], Ougozila, i. e. it was turned round [or twirled]. (Fr, S.) ― -b2- Agzlt She (a gazelle) had a young one. (S, O. [See gazaAlN.])

5 tgzRl c
5. tgzRl He affected, or attempted, as a selfimposed task, (takalRafa,) what is termed gazal [meaning as expl. below, i. e. the talk, and actions, and circumstances, occurring between the lover and the object of love; &c.]. (S, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And sometimes it means He made mention, or spoke, [generally in verse,] of what is termed gazal. (TA.) [See also XabRaba, inf. n. taXobiybN; and nasaba, inf. n. nasiybN.] One says, tgzRl biAlmaroOapi meaning He mentioned the woman [in amatory language, as an object of love,] in his poetry. (TA in art. gnI.)

6 tgAzlwA c
6. tgAzlwA [They talked, and acted in an amatory and enticing manner; or they played, sported, dallied, or wantoned, and held amorous talk; one with another: see 3]: (S, O:) from Algazalu [q. v.]. (TA.)

8 Uigotazala
8: see 1, first sentence.

gazolN c
gazolN, applied to cotton, (S, O, K, TA,) and flax, &c., (TA,) or wool, and the like, (Msb,) i. q. magozuwlN [i. e. Spun]: (S, O, Msb, K, TA:) [or rather spun thread, or yarn of any kind; for] it is an inf. n. used as a subst.: (Msb:) of the masc. gender: pl. guzuwlN. (TA.) ― -b2- And accord. to ISd, The web of the spider. (TA.) ― -b3- And gazolu AlnabaAti is applied in Egypt to The sort of food called UiToriyap. (TA in art. Trw, q. v.)

gizolu nisaMCK c
gizolu nisaMCK A follower and lover of women; as also nisaMCK gizRiylu↓: (JK:) [or both may be rendered one who talks, and acts in an amatory and enticing manner; or who plays, sports, dallies, or wantons, and holds amorous talk; with women:] gizRiylN↓ is of the measure fiERiylN in the sense of the measure mufaAEilN; like HidRiyvN and kilRiymN. (TA.)

gazalN c
gazalN, as expl. by 'Abd-El-Muttalib El-Baghdádee, in his Exposition of the naqodu AlXiEori of Kudámeh, signifies The talk, and actions, and circumstances, occurring between the lover and the object of love; differing somewhat from taXobiybN, which is a celebrating of the person and qualities of the beloved; and from nasiybN, which is a mentioning of the state, or condition, of the naAsib [himself], and of the object of the nasiyb, and of all the affairs, or events, occurring between them two, [in the prelude of an ode,] thus including the meaning of taXobiybN, and being a mentioning of gazal: accord. to Kudámeh, it signifies an inclining to foolish and youthful conduct, or a manifesting of passionate love, and becoming notorious for affections to women: (TA:) or it is the subst. from 3 [as such signifying talk, and amatory and enticing conduct, with women; or play, sport, dalliance, or wanton conduct, and amorous talk, with women]; (S, K;) as also magozalN↓: (K:) or play, sport, or diversion, with women: (ISd, TA:) or the talk of young men and [or with] young women: (Msb:) or, accord. to the leading authorities in polite literature, and those who have made the language to be their study, [or rather accord. to a loose and post-classical usage,] it signifies, like nasiybN, praise of what are apparent of the menbers of the object of love: or the mention of the days of union and of disunion: or the like thereof. (MF.)

gazilN c
gazilN [is, by, rule, the part. n. of gazila, as such signifying Talking, and acting in an amatory and enticing manner, with a woman, or with women; &c.: but it is said that it] signifies SaAHibu gazalK; (S, O;) or mutagazRilN biAlnRisaMCi; (K, TA;) by which is here meant making mention, or speaking, or one who makes mention, or who speaks, [generally in verse,] of what is termed gazal [signifying as expl. above, i. e. the talk, and actions, and circumstances, occurring between the lover and the object of love; &c.]; thus used as being a possessive epithet, [not as a part. n. of gazila, because this differs in meaning from tagazRala,] i. e. it signifies [properly] cuwgazalK: (TA:) or it means displaying amorous gestures or behaviour, and foolish and
youthful conduct such as is suitable to women, with the love, or passionate love, that he experiences for them, in order that they may incline to him: (Kudámeh, TA:) or it is applied to a man as meaning a companion of women because of his lacking strength to be otherwise: from what here follows. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- Lacking strength, or ability, to perform, or accomplish, things; (IAar, K, TA;) remiss, or languid, in respect to them. (IAar, TA.)

gazuliIRN c
gazuliIRN [Of, or relating to, spun thread, or yarn;] the rel. n. from gazolN used as a subst. (Msb.)

gazaAlN c
gazaAlN A young gazelle, waladu ZaboyapK: (Msb:) or a XaAdin [or young gazelle], (T, S, O, Msb, K, TA,) or, as some say, the female, (TA, [but see what follows,]) when it becomes active, or in motion, (T, S, O, Msb, K, TA.) and walks; (T, Msb, K, TA;) to which the girl, or young woman, is likened in [the commencing of an ode by what is termed] AltRaXobiyb, wherefore the epithet and the verb [therein] are made mase.; (TA;) after the becoming a vaniIR [q. v.]: (T, Msb:) or in the stage after that in which he is termed TalFA [q. v.]: (AHát, Msb, TA:) or from the time of his birth until he attains to the most vehement running; (K, TA;) which is when he puts his legs together, [app. meaning his fore legs together and so his hind legs,] and puts them down together and raises them together: (TA:) or i. q. ZaboIN [i. e. a gazelle, of any age]: (M in art. ZbI: for AlZRaboIu is there expl. as meaning AlgazaAlu: [but this seems to be a loose rendering:]) the female is called gazaAlapN↓; (Msb, MF, TA;) though it seems from what is said in the K [&c.] that AlgazaAlu is applied peculiarly to the male, and that the female is called only ZaboyapN, as several of the lexicologists have decisively asserted: (MF, TA:) the pl. [of pane.] is gizolapN and [of mult.] gizolAnN. (S, O, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- gazaAlu XaEobaAna A certain insect (duwayobRapN), (K, TA,) a species of the [locusts, or locust-like insects, called] janaAdib [pl. of junodabN]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- damu AlgazaAli A certain plant, resembling the Taroxuwn [or tarragon], (O, K,) which is eaten, (O,) burning, or biting, to the tongue, (O, K,) green, and having a red root, like the roots of the OaroTaAp [n. un. of OaroTFI, q. v.], (O,) with the juice of which girls, or young women, make red streaks like bracelets upon their arms: (O, K:) thus AHn was informed by some one or more of the Benoo-Asad: (O:) and Aboo-Nasr says, it is of the [kind called] cukuwr. [See also damu AlgazaAli and damu AlgizolaAni and dumoyapu AlgizolaAni voce dmN in art. dmw or dmI; and see likewise EanodamN.]

gazaAlapN c
gazaAlapN fem. of gazaAlN, q. v. ＝ -A2- AlgazaAlapu, also, signifies The sun; (S, O, K;) because it extends [what resemble] cords, [meaning its rays,] as though it were spinning: (K:) or the sun when rising; (Msb, K;) [therefore] one says TalaEati AlgazaAlapu, but not garabati AlgazaAlapu: (TA:) or the sun when high: (M, * K, TA:) or the Eayon [meaning the disk, or, as it sometimes means, the rays, or beams,] of the sun. (K.) ― -b2- And gazaAlapu AlDRuHaI means, (S, O, K,) as also gazaAlaAtuhu, (K,) [or gazaAlaAtuhaA,] The beginning of the DuHaI [or early part of the forenoon, after sunrise]; (S, O, K;) [whence] one says, jaMCa fiI gazaAlapi AlDRuHaI [He came in the beginning of the DuHaI]; and Dhu-r-Rummeh uses AlgazaAlapa, in the accus. case, as an adv. n., (S, O,) meaning in the time [or in the beginning] of the DuHaI; (O;) or, accord. to IKh, this is for TuluwEa AlgazaAlapi, meaning at the rising of the sun: (TA:) or the meaning of the phrases first mentioned in this sentence is after, or a little after, (accord. to different copies of the K,) the spreading of the son, [i. e. of the sunshine,] and its entrance upon the DuHaI: or the first part of the DuHaI, until the passing away of a fifth (or about a fifth, TA) of the day. (K.) ＝ -A3- Also (i. e. AlgazaAlapu) A certain herb, (Aboo-Nasr. O, K,) of the [kind called] suTRaAH, spreading upon the ground, with green leaves, having no thorns nor broaches; from the middle whereof comes forth a tall qaDiyb [or shoot], which is peeled and eaten, (Aboo-Nasr, O,) and it is sweet, (Aboo-Nasr, O, K,) and has yellow blossoms from its bottom to its top: and it is a pasture: (Aboo-Nasr, O:) every thing [i. e. animal] eats it: (Aboo-Nasr, O, K;) and the places of its growth are the plain, or soft, tracts. (Aboo-Nasr, O)

gazRaAlN c
gazRaAlN A vender [and a spinner] of gazol [i. e. thread,. or gave]. (TA.)

gizRiylN c
gizRiylN; see gizolu nisaMCK, in two places.

gaAzilN c
gaAzilN [act. part. n. of gazala; Spinning]. The pls. guzRalN and gawaAzilu are applied as epithets to women: (K, TA:) but the former is also applied to men, and is of a measure more usual as that of the pl. of the mase. act. part. n. than of the fem. (TA.)

Oagozalu mino EanokabuwtK c
Oagozalu mino EanokabuwtK, from the act of spinning, (Meyd,) or from the act of weaving [the web], (O.) is a prov. [meaning More practised, or skilled, in weaving than a spider]: and so mino surofapK [than a surofap, q. v.]. (Meyd.) ― -b2- And one says also, Oagozalu mini QmoriYi Alqayosi, (S, Meyd, O,) likewise a prov., meaning [More practised, or skilled,] in the celebrating of the person and qualities of the beloved in verse [than Imra-el-Keys]. (Meyd.) ― -b3- And [hence,] Oagozalu mina AlHumRaI (assumed tropical:) [More frequent in visiting, or more habitual, and more recurrent, than the fever]; a saying of the Arabs, by which they mean that it [the fever] is a frequent visiter of the sick person, recurrent to him; as though passionately loving him: thus, correctly, as in the L: in the K it is said that AlOagozalu applied to the fever (AlHumRaI [though this is fem.]) means such as is a frequent visiter of the sick person; recurrent. (TA.) ― -b4- And Oagozalu mino furoEulK [More confounded and perplexed than a young one of the hyena]; from Algazalu as signifying “ the being confounded and perplexed ” like as is the dog (Meyd, O, K) when pursuing the young gazelle; for it may be that the frEl becomes in the like state in pursuing the object of its chase: (Meyd:) or frEl was a man of ancient times, and this saying (which is a prov., Meyd) is like Oagozalu mini QmoriYi Alqayosi. (Meyd, O, TA.)

magozalN c
magozalN: see migozalN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also gazalN, latter half.

mugozalN c
mugozalN: see migozalN, in three places.

mugozilN c
mugozilN A doe gazelle having a young one. (K.)

migozalN c
migozalN and mugozalN↓ (Fr, Th, S, O, Msb, K) and magozalN↓, (Th, O, K,) the first as pronounced by [the tribe of] Temeem, the second as pronounced by [that of] Keys, and the last the most rare, (TA,) or the second as pronounced by Temeem, (Msb,) A spindle; i. e. the thing with which one spins: (S, MA, O, Msb, K. KL:) Fr says that mugozalN↓ is the original form, from Ougozila “ it was made to turn round ” or “ revolve ” [or “ was twirled ”]; (S, TA;) but the dammeh was deemed by the Arabs difficult of pronunciation, and therefore they said migozalN, and in like manner miSoHafN and mixodaEN and mijosadN and miTorafN: accord. to IAth, migozalN signifies the instrument [with which one spins]; and magozalN↓, the place of the gazol [which means the act of spinning and the span thread or yard]; and mugozalN↓, the place in which (fiyhi [or this may here mean upon which]) the gazol [i. e. spun thread or yarn] is put: (TA:) pl. magaAzilu. (MA.) OaEorI mino migozalK is a prov. [meaning More naked than a spindle]. (Meyd.) And one says, SaAHibu Algazali OaDalRu mino saAqi migozalK [The practiser of the talk and actions &c. usual between the lover and the object of love is more erring than the shank (i. e. pin) of a spindle), of which the error is its [aiding in] clothing mankind while it is [itself] naked. (A, TA.) ― -b2- It is said in a book of certain of the Jews, Ealayokumo kacaA wakacaA waruboEu Almigozali, meaning [I pon you lie as due from you such and such things and) the fourth part of what your women have spun. (TA.) ― -b3- And [the pl.] magaAzilu signifies The Eamad (O) or Eumud (K) [app. meaning the upright wooden supports of the seat] of the [machine called] naworaj [q. v.] with which the reaped grain heaped together is thrashed. (O, K.)

migozaliIRN c
migozaliIRN (MA) and magaAziliIRN↓ (S and K voce miSoramN) A parer of spindles. (MA.)

mugayozilN c
mugayozilN A slender cord (HabolN daqiyqN) [so in copies of the K, and in the CK, but in the latter Almugotazalu is put for Almugayozilu: in my MS. copy of the K, Almugayozilu jabalN daqiyqN, and this I think to be the correct reading. meaning El-Mugheyzil is a certain slender mountain]: ISd says, I think it to be likened to the migozal, because of its slenderness; adding that El-Hirmázee has mentioned it. (TA. [A verse cited by El-Hirmázee is there
given as an ex.; mentioning the day of Almugayozil, app. as the day of the separation of a lover from his beloved; and it is a common custom of the Arabs to call the day of an event the day of the place where it occurred.])

magaAziliIRN c
magaAziliIRN: see migozaliIRN.

1 gazaAhu c
1. gazaAhu, [aor.
gazuwa
,] inf. n. gazowN, He willed, or desired, it; he sought it; and he aimed at it, intended it, or meant it; syn. OaraAdahu; and Talabahu; and qaSadahu; [the first of which is often used in the same senses as the second and third;] as also AgtzAhu↓; (K, TA;) this last mentioned by ISd as syn. with qaSadahu. (TA.) One says, Earafotu maA yugozaI mino hecaA AlkalaAmi i. e. [I knew, or, emphatically, I know,] what is willed or desired (maA yuraAdu) [from this speech]. (S.) And gazowiI kacaA My aim, or intention, or meaning, is such a thing. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] gazaA AlEaduwRa, inf. n. gazowN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and gazawaAnN, (K, TA,) or, as some say, gazowaAnN, mentioned by Sb, (TA,) and gazaAwapN, (K,) [but see what is said of this last at the close of this paragraph,] He went forth, (Er-Rághib, TA,) or repaired, or betook himself, (Mgh,) to wage war, (Er-Rághib, TA,) or to fight, (Mgh,) with the enemy; (Er-Rághib, Mgh, TA;) or he went to fight with, and plunder, the enemy; (K, TA;) in the country of the latter. (Msb.) [And gazaA alone, the objective complement being understood, often signifies the same; or He engaged in a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition, or in such expeditions.] ― -b3- And gazaA Uilayohi, inf. n. as above, He tended, repaired, betook himself, or went, to, or towards, him, or it; syn. qaSadahu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- gazaAwapN, mentioned above, is of a measure which in most instances is that of an inf. n. of an intrans. verb, and it seems to be an inf. n. of which the verb is gazuwa, meaning jaAda gazowuhu [i. e. Excellent, or how excellent, is his engaging in a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition, or in such expeditions!]; and to be similar to qaDuwa meaning jaAda qaDaMCuhu, and Darubato yaduhu meaning jaAda DarobuhaA. (TA.)

2 gazRawa
2: see what next follows.

4 AgzAhu c
4. AgzAhu He fitted him out, equipped him, or furnished him, (S,) or he sent him, (Mgh, Msb,) or he urged, or incited, him, (K,) to engage in a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition, (S, * Mgh, * Msb, * K,) in the country of the enemy; (Msb;) and gzRAhu↓ signifies the same. (K.) ＝ -A2- Oagozato, said of a woman, (Mgh, K,) Her husband was absent [engaged in a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition, in the country of the enemy]; (Mgh;) or her husband went [or had gone] to fight with, and plunder, the enemy. (K.) ― -b2- And, said of a she-camel, Her impregnation was, or became, difficult. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- And AgzAhu He granted him some delay, and deferred [the exacting of] the debt that he owed. (S, K.)

8 AgtizAhu c
8. AgtizAhu: see 1, first sentence. ＝ -A2- AgtzI bifulaAnK He had such a one peculiarly to himself from among his companions: (K, TA:) like AigotazRa bihi. (TA.) A poet says,
qado yagotaziI AlhijoraAnu biAltRajarRumi
[Sometimes, or often, the cutting off from friendly intercourse has the accusation of that which is a crime, or a fault, or an offence, peculiarly assigned to it (as the cause)]: AltjrRm here meaning AidRiEaMCu Aljuromi. (TA.)

gazaApN c
gazaApN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

gazowapN c
gazowapN The act of [Algazow i. e.] repairing to fight with [or to fight with and plunder] the enemy [in the country of the latter]; as also gazaApN↓, and magozaApN↓: (Mgh:) or the first signifies a single time [or act] of Algazow [i. e. a single warring, or warring and plundering, expedition]; (Th, Msb, TA;) as also magozaApN↓: (Msb:) and gazaApN↓ is the subst. from gazawotu AlEaduwRa [as such meaning as expl. above, i. e. the act of Algazow]: (S, TA:) or this signifies [a campaign, i. e.] the work [or operations] of a year: (Th, TA:) the pl. (of gazowapN, Msb, [and of gazaApN↓, for this is originally gazawapN,]) is gazawaAtN, and (of magozaApN↓, Msb) magaAzK, (Mgh, Msb,) which latter pl. is applied to the gazawaAt of Mohammad. (TA.)

gizowapN c
gizowapN i. q. TilobapN [app. as meaning A mode, or manner, of seeking, &c.]. (TA.)

Oabuw gazowaAna c
Oabuw gazowaAna [or gazowaAnK?] The cat: because it is ever making war upon the mouse. (yagozuw AlfaOora OabadFA). (Har p. 663.)

gazowiIRN c
gazowiIRN, accord. to [many, app., of] the copies of the S; or gazawiIRN, accord. to ISd, [and so in some copies of the S,] said by ISd to be altered from the regular form [which is gazowiIRN]; (TA;) Of, or relating to, Algazow [or the making a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition]. (S, ISd, TA.)

gaziIRN c
gaziIRN: see gaAzK.

gazRaMCN c
gazRaMCN One who engages much, or often, in warring, or warring and plundering, expeditions; syn. kaviyru Algazowi. (TA.)

gaAzK c
gaAzK One going, or who goes, to fight with, and plunder, the enemy, (S, * Mgh, * Msb, K,) in the country of the latter; (Msb;) [one engaging, or who engages, in a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition: and a warrior, in a general sense:] pl. guzaApN (S, Mgh, Msb) and guzRFI (S, Msb, K, TA, in the CK guzRIe) and guzRaMCN (S) and guziIRN, (K,) [originally guzuwIN,] of the measure fuEuwlN, (TA,) and gaziIRN↓ is pl. of [the pl.] guzaApN, (S, Msb,) or [rather] a quasi-pl. n.; (K;) and gaAziyapN↓ signifies a company, or body, of guzaAp. (TA.)

gaAziypN c
gaAziypN: see what immediately precedes.

AlAgzMC c
AlAgzMC and AlmgzI [app. AlOagozaMCu and AlmagozaI↓, the former a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned, and the latter a quasi-pl. n. like Almarojalu from AlrRajulu,] The offspring (nataAYij [more properly nitaAj, which agrees with the context,]) of the [season called] Sayof, on the authority of IAar, [meaning such offspring of camels, for it is added,] which are discommended, the young camel thereof being always weak. (TA.)

magozFI c
magozFI The intended sense of a saying; the meaning thereof; syn. maqoSadN [as an inf. n. used in the sense of the pass. part. n. of its verb]. (S, K; in the CK written maqoSid.) ― -b2- See also magozaApN. ＝ -A2- And see the paragraph next preceding this.

mugozK c
mugozK [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. ― -b2- mugoziyapN A woman whose husband is absent; (Mgh;) [meaning] one whose husband has gone to fight with, and plunder, the enemy. (S, * TA.) See an ex. in a trad. mentioned voce kaAsirN. ＝ -A2- Also, mugoziyapN, A she-camel that has exceeded the year [from the time when she was covered] without bringing forth; like midoraAjN: (El-Umawee, S:) or a she-camel that has exceeded the year by a month, (K, TA,) or the like thereof, (TA,) in pregnancy: (K, TA:) so in the M. (TA.) And A she-ass that is late in bringing forth, but does then bring forth. (S.) AlmugoziI mina Alganami means Those that are late in bringing forth, by a month, or two months, after the others, of the sheep or goats, because of their having conceived at a late period. (TA.) ― -b2- And mgozK signifies A she-camel whose impregnation is difficult: mentioned by Az. (TA.)

magozaApN c
magozaApN: see gazowapN, in three places. ― -b2- Also A place of gazow [meaning making a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition]: pl. magaAzK. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlmagaAziI signifies also The memorable deeds of the guzaAp [meaning those who engage in warring, or warring and plundering, expeditions, pl. of gaAzK]: (K, TA:) in which sense, some say, it has no sing., but others say that its sing. is magozaApN or magozFI↓. (TA.)

magoziIRN c
magoziIRN [as pass. part. n. of gazaA] was used as an epithet applied to a man: it is properly with w [i. e. magozuwRN]; but there are many instances of the former kind. (TA.)

1 gasaqa c
1. gasaqa, said of the night, aor.
gasiqa
, (S, O, K,) inf. n. gusuwqN (O, K, * TA) and gasoqN and gasaqN and gasaqaAnN, (K,) It became dark; (S, O;) as also Agsq↓, (Th, O,) said by Z to be of the dial. of the Benoo-Temeem: (TA:) or both signify it became intensely dark.
