(K.) Hence, in a trad., gasaqa AllRayolu EalaI AlZRiraAbi i. e. The night poured down upon the small mountains and covered them with its darkness. (TA.) ― -b2- And, said of the moon, It lost its light, and became black and dark. (TA.) ― -b3- And gasaqato Eayonuhu, (S, O, K,) aor.
gasiqa
; (O, K;) and gasiqato, aor.
gasaqa
; (K;) inf. n. gasoqN, (S, O,) or
gusuwqN, (K,) or both, (TA,) and gasaqaAnN; (K, TA;) (assumed tropical:) His eye became dark: (S, O, K, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) shed tears: (K, TA:) or (tropical:) poured forth [tears]: (TA:) or gsqt AlEayonu means (assumed tropical:) the eye overflowed with water. (AZ, TA.) ― -b4- And gasaqa AljuroHu, inf. n. gasaqaAnN (S, O, K) and gasoqN also, (TA,) The wound had yellow water flowing from it; (S, O, K;) and so gasiqa. (K, by implication.) And gasaqati AlsRamaMCu, (O, K, TA,) aor.
gasiqa
, inf. n. gasoqN and gasaqaAnN, (K, TA,) The sky rained; or let fall a little rain, such as is termed raXRN: (O, K, TA:) and [the rain] poured forth; syn. AinoSabRat: (TA:) [and in this latter sense gasaqa is app. said of any fluid; for,] accord. to Th, (O, TA,) gasaqaAnN is syn. with AinoSibaAbN. (O, K, TA.) [Hence,] gasaqa AllRabanu, (K,) inf. n. gasoqN (TA) [and app. gasaqaAnN], The milk poured forth from the udder. (TA.)

4 Agsq c
4. Agsq: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also He entered upon the gasaq, (O, K, TA,) i. e. the beginning of the darkness. (TA.) And, said of the muWacRin, He delayed, or deferred, the [call to prayer of] sunset to the gasaq of the night. (S, O, K.)

gasaqN c
gasaqN The beginning of the darkness of night: (Fr, S, O:) or the darkness of the night: (Akh, TA:) or the darkness of the beginning of the night: (K:) or [the time] when the Xafaq [or redness in the horizon after sunset] disappears: or the time of the blending of the EiXaAMni, [see ruwaAn, last sentence,] which is when the darkness becomes confused, and obstructs [the view of] the aspects of things: or, accord. to Sh, the entering-in of the beginning of the darkness. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Refuse that is found among wheat, such as ruwaAn [or darnel-grass, &c.], and the like. (Fr, O, K.)

gasaAqN c
gasaAqN and gasRaAqN↓, (S, O, K, TA,) occurring in the Kur [xxxviii. 57 and] lxxviii. 25, accord. to different readings, (S, O, TA,) The ichor, or watery matter, (O, TA,) and thick purulent matter, (TA,) that will flow and drip (O, * TA) from the skins of the inmates of the fire [of Hell]: (O, TA:) or the washings of them: or their tears: (TA:) or, as some say, the latter of the words has the first of these meanings: (O, TA:) and the former word signifies cold, (O,) or intensely cold, (TA,) that burns by reason of its coldness (O, TA) like the hot wind: (TA:) or, accord. to Lth, stinking: (O, TA:) the latter word is expl. by I'Ab and Ibn-Mes'ood as signifying intense cold: (TA:) or both signify cold and stinking. (S, O.)

gasiyqaAtN c
gasiyqaAtN Intensely red; [applied to she-camels;] thus expl. by Skr as occurring in a verse of Sakhr [?] El-Hudhalee. (TA.)

gasRaAqN c
gasRaAqN: see gasaAqN: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph here following, near the end.

AlgaAsiqu c
AlgaAsiqu signifies The night; (Zj, TA;) and [hence] wamino XarRi gaAsiqK UicaA waqaba (in the Kur [cxiii. 3], S, O) means [And from the mischief] of the night when it cometh in; (S, O, K;) accord. to El-Hasan (S, O) El-Basree: (O:) or the beginning of the night; as El-Hasan is related to have said: (TA:) or the night when the Xafaq [or redness in the horizon after sunset] disappears: (S, O, K:) and the night is said to be so called because it is colder than the day: (O, TA:) [for] AlgaAsiqu signifies [also] the cold (AlbaAridu) [like AlgasaAqu] (TA:) or what is meant in the verse of the Kur-án cited above is the accident in the night: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or AlgaAsiqu signifies the moon; (K;) and this is said to be meant in the verse of the Kur-án; (S, TA;) so the Prophet is related to have said to Áïsheh; i. e. the verse means, [the mischief of] the moon when it is eclipsed: (Th, O, * TA:) or what is meant in that verse is, AlvRurayRaA [i. e. the asterism called the Pleiades] when it sets [aurorally (see vurayRaA)], because diseases and pestilences are frequent at that period. (O, K, TA,) and become removed at that period of its [auroral] rising [in the opposite season of the year], (O, TA,) as is related in a trad. (TA:) or the sun when it sets: or the day when it enters upon the night. or the serpent called AlOasowad when it smites, or turns over: or, accord. to Sub. Iblees when he suggests evil: (TA:) or, accord. to I'Ab and several others, from the mischief of the cakar when it becomes erect; (K, TA:) a strange explanation: and AlgasRaAqu↓ is like AlgaAsiqu; [but in what sense or senses is not said;] each is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant. (TA.) ― -b2- gaAsiqN also signifies Flowing; applied by a poet in this sense to a source, or spring; and having to relation to darkness. (Sh. TA.)

1 gasalahu c
1. gasalahu, (S, MA, O, Msb, K,) aor.
gasila
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. gasolN, (S, MA, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) and gusolN is the subst, (S, Msb,) or a subst. (Mgh, K, TA) from AlAigotisaAlu, (Mgh, TA,) or, as some say. the latter is the inf. n. and the former is the subst., (MF, TA,) He washed it; with water (biAlmaMCi): (MA:) gasolu AlXRIoCi signifies the removing of dirt, or filth, and the like thereof, from the thing, by making water to run over it. (Mgh.) You say, gasala Aljiloda kulRahu [He washed the skin, all of it], and AlmayRita [the dead body]: and gsRl↓ has the like, but an intensive, meaning. (Msb.) See also 10. ― -b2- waQgosiloniI bimaMCi AlvRaloji waAlbaradi [lit. And wash Thou me with the water of snow and of hail], in a trad. relating to [forms of] prayer, means (assumed tropical:) and cleanse Thou me from sins. (TA.) And one says, gasala QllRehu Hawobataka i. e. (assumed tropical:) May God cleanse thee from thy sin. (TA.) ― -b3- maA gasaluwA ruWuwsahumo mino yawomi Aljamali [lit. They did not wash their heads &c., as one does in cleansing himself from impurity,] means maA faraguwA and maA taxalRaSuwA [i. e., app., (assumed tropical:) they did not become free from the consequences of the Day of the Camel (the famous engagement between the forces of 'Alee and those of Áïsheh)]. (TA.) ― -b4- And one says of a horse, gusila, like EuniIa, meaning He sweated; [or became suffused with sweat;] (Sh, O, K;) as also Aigotasala↓ (K.) [See an ex. of the former in a verse cited in art. Edw, conj. 3.] ― -b5- gasala AlmaroOapa signifies (tropical:) He compressed the woman (jaAmaEahaA); (Az, Mgh, O, TA;) like EasalahaA, with E; (Az, Mgh, TA;) much or little; (TA;) and gasRalahaA↓ signifies the same: (Mgh, O, TA:) or both signify he did so much. (K.) It is said in a trad., (Mgh, O, TA,) respecting [preparation for the prayers of] Friday, (Mgh,) mano gasala waQgotasala, as some relate it, or, as others relate it, wAgtsl mn gasRala↓; the latter of which is said to mean Whose compresses his wife [before his going to the mosque]; (Mgh, O;) and El-Kutabee says that most hold this to be the meaning; i. e., lest he should see in his way anything that might divert his heart [from devotion]; (Mgh;) [and then washes himself;] and Az held gasala, without teshdeed to be correct (Mgh, O) in this sense: (Mgh:) or the meaning accord. to the reading of gsRl is, whose performs the [ablution termed] wuDuwCo fully, washing every member [of those that are to be washed] three times, (Mgh, O,) and then washes himself for the [prayers of] Friday; (Mgh;) and accord. to IAmb, it means whose washes himself after AljimaAE and then washes himself for the [prayers of] Friday; (O:) accord. to the K, AltRagosiyla↓ signifies the exceeding the ordinary bounds in washing the members: (TA:) he who explains as meaning the causing a woman to become under the obligation of performing a total ablution, biOano waTiYahaA, says what is improbable, and departs from the authorities respecting it. (Mgh.) ― -b6- One say, also, gasala AlfaHolu AlnRaAqapa, meaning (tropical:) The stallion covered the she-camel much. (K, TA.) [See also 4.] ― -b7- And gasala, aor.
gasila
. (K, TA,) inf. n. gasolN, (TA,) (tropical:) He beat, and caused to suffer pain, (K, TA,) biAlsRawoTi [with the whip]. (TA.)

2 gasRala
2: see the preceding paragraph, in four places

4 Agsl c
4. Agsl [said of a stallion, and intrans.,] (assumed tropical:) He covered much, or often; syn. Oakovara AlDRiraAba (Fr, O, K.) [See also 1, last explanation but one.]

7 Angsl c
7. Angsl said of a thing is quasi-pass. of gasalahu [i. e. it signifies It became washed, or washed off]. (O, TA.) [See gisoliynN.]

8 Agtsl c
8. Agtsl (S, O, Mgh, Msb, K) He washed [himself, i. e.] his whole person, (Mgh,) biAlmaMCi [with water]. (S, Mgh, O, K.) And Agtsl lilojumoEapi [He washed himself for the prayers of Friday]. (IAmb, O.) ― -b2- And Agtsl biAlTRiybi He daubed, or smeared, himself, or did so copiously, so as to cause a dripping, (taDamRaxa, Lh, TA,) or he sprinkled himself, (tanaDRaxa, K,) with perfume. (Lh, K.) ― -b3- Agtsl said of a horse: see 1.

10 Uisotagosala
10: It is said in a trad., AlEayonu HaqRN faUicaA Qsotugosilotumo faQgosiluwA↓ [The evil eye is a truth; so when ye are asked to wash, wash ye]: i. e., when he who was smitten by the eye of any one demanded [the performance of what is here meant], he brought to
the smiter therewith a bowl in which was water, and he [the latter] would put his hand into it, and rinse his mouth [with some of it], then spit it out into the bowl; then he would wash his face in it; then he would put in his left hand, and pour upon his right hand; then he would put in his right hand, and pour upon his left hand; [then he would put in his left hand (a clause omitted in my original),] and pour upon his right elbow; then he would put in his right hand, and pour upon his left elbow; then he would put in his left hand, and pour upon his right foot; then he would put in his right hand, and pour upon his left foot; then he would put in his left hand, and pour upon his right knee; then he would put in his right hand, and pour upon his left knee; then he would wash what is termed daAxilapu AlUizaAri [expl. in art. dxl]: and he would not put the bowl upon the ground: then he would pour that used water upon the head of the person smitten with the eye, from behind him, with one pouring; and he would be cured, with the permission of God. (TA.)

gasolN c
gasolN inf. n. of gasalahu: (S, MA, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) or, accord. to some, this and gusolN↓ have one and the same meaning; and the saying that this is the case is ascribed to Sb: (Msb:) or, as some say, the latter is the inf. n., and the former is the subst. (MF, TA.) See also the next paragraph.

gusolN c
gusolN the subst. from gasalahu [i. e. a subst. signifying A washing]: (S, Msb:) or a subst. (IKoot, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) from AlAgtsAl, (IKoot, Mgh, Msb, TA,) and [as such] signifying a complete washing [of oneself, i. e.] of the whole person: (IKoot, T, Mgh, Msb, TA:) it is in consequence of janaAbap [q. v.], and of childbirth, and for [the prayers of] Friday, and is the washing of the dead; but in other cases, the word gasolN↓, with fet-h, is used: (Ham p. 30:) and one says gusulN↓ as well as gusolN, (S, O,) the former being a dial. var. of the latter: (TA:) El-Kumeyt says, describing a wild ass,
taHota AlOalaMCapi fiI nawoEayoni mino gusulK
baAtaA Ealayohi bitasojaAlK wataqoTaAri
[Beneath the (tree called) OalaMCap, in two sorts of washing that continued during the night upon him with much pouring and much dropping]; meaning that the water that was upon the tree poured upon him at one time; and at one time, that of the rain: (S, TA:) the pl. of gusolN is OagosaAlN. (Msb.) See also gasolN. ― -b2- And see gasuwlN.

gisolN c
gisolN A preparation for washing the head, consisting of xiTomiIR [or marsh-mallows] and other things (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) of a similar kind, (Mgh, Msb, K,) [with water,] as [leaves of] the [species of lote-tree called] sidor, (Msb,) and Tiyn, (TA,) or Tiynapu AlrRaOosi, [meaning fullers' earth, which is often used in the bath and elsewhere instead of soap,] (Mgh,) and OuXonaAn [or potash]: (TA:) [and app. any wash for the head:] and gisolapN↓ signifies the same: (Mgh, K:) and also (this latter) leaves of the myrtle: and perfume; syn. TiybN: and what a woman puts into her hair on the occasion of combing and dressing it: (K:) gisolapN muTarRaApN being myrtle [-leaves] rendered fragrant with aromatic perfumes, used in combing and dressing one's hair: one should not say gasolapN. (S, O.) IAar cites the following verse (S, O) of 'Abd-Er-Rahmán Ibn-Dárah El-Ghatafánee, (O,)
fayaA layola UinRa Algisola maA dumoti OayRimFA
EalaIRa HaraAmN laA yamasRuniIa Algisolu
[And, O Leylà, (layola being a contraction of layolaI, but in the O it is yA jumolu O Juml,) verily the wash for the head, as long as thou remainest husbandless, shall be unlawful to me: the wash for the head shall not touch me]: i. e. I will not need the wash for the head by my jimaAE of other than her: [he says thus] in eager desire of taking her in marriage. (S, O.) ― -b2- See also gasuwlN. ＝ -A2- And see also gusalapN.

rajulN gasilN c
rajulN gasilN (assumed tropical:) A man who compresses his wife much. (TA.) [See also gusalapN.]

gusalN c
gusalN: see gusalapN.

gusulN c
gusulN: see gusolN.

gasolapN c
gasolapN [A single act of washing: pl. gasalaAtN]. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, banawoA hecihi Almadiynapa bigasalaAti Oayodiyhimo (assumed tropical:) [They built this city] by means of their earnings. (TA.)

gisolapN c
gisolapN: see gasuwlN: ― -b2- and see also gisolN. ― -b3- EalaI wajohihi gisolapN means His face is beautiful, with no fat, or fatness, upon it. (TA.) ― -b4- Oabuw gisolapa is an appellation of The wolf: (O, K:) and so Abw Eisolapa, with E. (TA.)

gusalapN c
gusalapN (S, Mgh, O, K) and gusalN↓ and gasiylN↓ and gisRiylN↓ and migosalN↓ (O, K) and gisolN↓, (K,) all, except the last, mentioned by Fr, (O, TA,) applied to a stallion [camel], (tropical:) That covers much: (Fr, Mgh, * O, K, TA:) or that does so much without impregnating: (Ks, S, K, TA:) and in like manner applied to a man. (K.) [See also gasilN.]

Algisoliynu c
Algisoliynu: see AlgusaAlapu. ― -b2- Algisoliynu (in the Kur [lxix. 36], TA) What is washed off of the flesh and the blood of the inmates of the fire [of Hell]; (Akh, S, O;) [for] what comes forth from any wound, or sore, when it is washed, is termed gisoliyn: (TA:) what is washed off from the bodies of the unbelievers, in the fire: (Msb:) or what flows from the skins of the inmates of the fire, (K, TA,) such as thick purulent matter &c.; thus expl. by Fr and Seer; (TA;) as though it were washed from them: (Sb, TA:) accord. to Mujáhid, a certain food of the inmates of the fire; and El-Kelbee says that it is what the fire has cooked, of their flesh, and has fallen off, and is eaten by them: (TA:) and, (K,) accord. to Ed-Dahhák, (O, TA,) a species of trees in the fire; (O, K, TA;) and so he says of AlDRariyEu: (O, TA:) and, (K,) accord. to Lth, (O, TA,) what is intensely hot: (O, K, TA:) the I and n are augmentative. (S, O, Msb.)

gasuwlN c
gasuwlN (S, O, K) and gasRuwlN↓ (O, K) and gusolN↓ (Mgh, K) and gisolN↓ and gisolapN↓ (IAth, K) Water with which one washes himself; (S, Mgh, O, K;) as also mugotasalN↓, occurring [in this sense] in the Kur xxxviii. 41: (S:) or the words preceding this signify water little in quantity, with which one washes himself: (TA:) and xiTomiIR [or marsh-mallows], (K, TA,) and OuXonaAn [or potash (see also gaAsuwlN)], and the like thereof, and certain of the [plants termed] HamoD: (TA:) or gasuwlN signifies a thing [or substance] with which the hand is washed, such as OuXonaAn &c.: (Har p. 86:) or, accord. to the M, anything with which one washes a head or a garment and the like. (TA.) [See also the pl. gasuwlaAtN voce daluwkN.]

gasiylN c
gasiylN i. q. magosuwlN↓ [i. e. Washed]; (S, O, Msb, K;) applied to a thing, (S, O,) and to a dead body; (Lh, Msb, TA;) and the former is also applied as an epithet to a fem. n., as is also gasiylapN; (S, O, K;) or this last is used after the manner of substs., like naTiyHapN and cabiyHapN; not as is said in the S [and O] after the manner of epithets: (IB, TA:) the pl. of gasiylN is gasoliI and gusalaMCu; (Lh, K, TA;) and the pl. of gasiylapN [and app. of gasiylN used a fem. epithet] is gasaAlaI or gusaAlaI. (K accord. to different copies.) Han- dhaleh Ibn-er-Ráhib was called gasiylu AlmalaAYikapi [The washed of the angels], because he died a martyr on the day of Ohod, and the angels washed him, (S, O, Msb,) accord. to the Prophet, who said that he saw them washing him. (O.) ― -b2- See also gusalapN. ― -b3- [It is now used as meaning Clothes, or the like, put together to be washed.]

AlgusaAlapu c
AlgusaAlapu, (S, O, Msb,) or gusaAlapu AlXRaIoCi, (K,) That with which one has washed the thing: (S, O, Msb:) or the water with which the thing is washed. (K.) [Hence the latter often signifies The infusion of the thing; i. e. the liquid in which the thing has been steeped, and which is impregnated with its virtues.] ― -b2- Also, the latter, What is extracted from the thing by washing. (K.) ― -b3- And AlgusaAlapu also signifies What is washed from the garment and the like; and so Algisoliynu↓. (K.)

gasowiylN c
gasowiylN A certain plant, growing in places that exude water and produce salt: (O, K:) said by IDrd to be a species of trees. (O.)

gasRaAlN c
gasRaAlN [A washer of clothes, and also of the dead: fem. with p]. (TA.) [See also gaAsilN.]

gasRuwlN c
gasRuwlN: see gasuwlN.

gisRiylN c
gisRiylN: see gusalapN.

gaAsilN c
gaAsilN A washer of the dead. (Msb.) [See also gasRaAlN.] ＝ -A2- And A species of trees. (TA.)

gaAsuwlN c
gaAsuwlN i. q. OuXonaAnN [i. e. Potash: and the plant from which it is prepared; kali, or glasswort; or mesembryanthemum nodiflorum (Forskål, Flora Ægypt. Arab. pp. lxvii. and 98), a species of glasswort]. (TA.) [See also gasuwlN.]

magosilN c
magosilN (S, O, Msb, K) and magosalN [which is anomalous] (S, O, K) and mugotasalN↓ (K) A place in which the dead are washed: (S, O, Msb, K) pl. of the first (S, Msb) and second (S) magaAsilu: (S, Msb:) and one says also magosialu AlmawotaI. (S, O, Msb. *)

migosalN c
migosalN A thing [i. e. vessel] in which (so in the M, in the K with which,) a thing is washed. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also gusalapN.

magosuwlN c
magosuwlN: see gasiylN. ― -b2- Hence one says, kalaAmuhu magosuwlN, meaning (assumed tropical:) His speech, or language, is devoid of nice, or subtile, expressions or allusions; as though it were washed from such; or deserving to be washed and obliterated: or it may mean (tropical:) trimmed, or pruned. (TA.)

mugotasalN c
mugotasalN A place in which one washes himself: (O, Msb, TA: *) dim. mugayosilN↓: and pl. magaAsiylu [which, if correct, is anomalous]. (TA.) ― -b2- And it is said to signify also what is called in Pers. HwD masiyn [or HawoD misiyn app. meaning A tank, or the like, of copper]. (Mgh.) ― -b3- See also magosilN. ― -b4- And see gasuwlN.

mugayosilN c
mugayosilN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 gasama c
1. gasama It (the night) was, or became, dark; (As, S, K;) as also Agsm↓, (JK, K,) like OagosaI. (JK.)

4 Oagosama
4: see what precedes.

gasamN c
gasamN The darkness (S, ISd, TA) of night; (ISd, TA;) like gasaqN: (S, TA:) or blackness: (Kr, K:) and (K) accord. to En-Nadr, (S,) the confusedness, or blending, of the darkness: (JK, S, K:) and the first rising of the dawn. (JK.) ― -b2- And Dust, or dust rising, or spreading, like smoke; syn. habowapN and gabarapN (K) or guborapN [which sometimes signifies the same as gabarahN]. (CK.)

gusamN c
gusamN; see OagosaAmN.

layolN gaAsimN c
layolN gaAsimN Dark night. (TA.)

fiI AlsRamaMCi OagosaAmN c
fiI AlsRamaMCi OagosaAmN and gusamN↓ In the sky are portions of clouds. (K.)

1 gasaA AllRayolu c
1. gasaA AllRayolu, (S, K,) aor. yagosuw, (S,) inf. n. gusuwRN; (S, K; accord. to some copies of the K gasowN;) and gasaI, aor. yagosiI; (IJ, TA;) and gasiIa, aor. yagosaI, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. gasFA; of which last form, gaXiIa is a dial. var.; (TA;) The night was, or became, dark; as also AgsI↓. (S, K.) [See also EasaA.]

4 Oa1o2a2a
4: see what precedes. ― -b2- AgsI also signifies He (a man) entered upon the time of, or a little after, sunset. (TA.) ― -b3- And Oagosi mina AllRayoli Journey thou not in the first part of the night, until its darkness depart. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And AgsAhu AllRayolu The night enveloped him in its darkness. (Sgh, K.)

1 gaXRahu c
1. gaXRahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
gaXuXa
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. gaXRN, (Msb, TA,) or giXRN, with kesr, (S,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb, K,) He acted towards him, or advised or counselled him, dishonestly, or insincerely: (A. Msb, K:) and he dressed up to him an affair [in false colours]: (Msb:) or he acted towards him with dissimulation: pretended to him the contrary of what he conceived in his mind: (A, K:) but this is a needless addition, for it is the same as the first explanation (TA:) as also gXRXhu↓, (K,) inf. n. tagoXiyXN: (TA) or this latter has an intensive signification: it is said to be derived from gaXaXN, signifying “ a turbid drinking-place, ” (TA:) It is said in the story of Umm-Zara, accord. to one relation, laA tamolaOu bayotanaA tagoXiyXFA↓, said by some to be from AlgiXRu, and by others to be from [a usage of] AltgXyX as signifying AlnRamiymapu [app. here meaning the embellishing speech with falsehood]: but accord. to the approved relation, it is [tagoXiyXFA] with the unpointed letter. (IAth.) [See art. EX.] ― -b2- [Also He made it to seem what it was not; falsified it; counterfeited it; adulterated it: so as used often by post-classical authors; and so, probably, in classical times also; see its pass. part n., below.] ＝ -A2- gaXRa Sadoruhu, aor.
gaXiXa
, [inf. n., probably. giXRN, q. v.,] His bosom concealed enmity and violent hatred; or bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, (TA,)

2 gaXRaRa
2: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

4 AgXRhu c
4. AgXRhu, inf. n. UigoXaAXN, He made him to fall into dishonest, or insincere, conduct, or advice or counsel; into dissimulation; or the pretending the contrary of what he conceived in his mind. (TA.) ― -b2- And OagoXaXotuhu Eano HaAjatihi I prevented him from obtaining the object of his want; syn. OaEojalotuhu. (IKtt, K.)

8 UigotaXaXa
8: see the next paragraph, in two places.

10 AstgXRhu c
10. AstgXRhu (S, K) and AgtXRhu↓ (K, TA) He reckoned him, or deemed him, dishonest, or insincere, in action, or advice or counsel; contr. of AisotanoSaHahu (S, K) and AinotaSaHahu; (K;) or, [which means the same,] i. q. EadRahu gaAXRFA: (TA:) or he imagined in him dishonest, or insincere, conduct, or advice or counsel; dissimulation; or the pretending the contrary of what he conceived in his mind. (K.) A poet says,
laka naASiHN OayaA rubRa mano tagotaXRuhu↓
wamusotanoSaHK biAlogayobi gayoru Oamiyni
[O man, many a one whom thou reckonest dishonest in action, or advice, is honest therein to thee; and (many a) one who is reckoned honest in action, or advice, in that which is beyond the reach of perception, is not faithful]. (TA)

gaXRN c
gaXRN, (K, TA,) of the measure faEolN, or it may be originally of the measure faEilN, (TA,) applied to a man, (K, TA,) i. q. EaZiymu AlXRarahi [i. e. Very greedy]; not EZym AlsRurRapi, as in some copies of the K; nor EZym AlXRirRapi, as in other copies: a rájiz says,
layosa bigaXRK hamRuhu fiymaA Oakalo
[He is not one who is very greedy; whose care, or solicitude, is in respect of what he has eaten]. (TA)

giXRN c
giXRN Dishonest, or insincere, conduct, or advice or counsel: (Msb, K:) and the embellishment of an affair [with false colours]: (Msb:) or dissimulation; pretence of the contrary of what one conceives in his mind. (K.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- And Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (K.) ― -b3- [Also Adulterating alloy in coin (See HumolaAnN.) ― -b4- And Adulterated, or counterfeit, coin. (See zagalN.)]

gaXaXN c
gaXaXN A turbid drinking-place: (Az, IAmb, Sgh, TA:) Alkadiru AlmaXuwbu in the K is a mistake: the right explanation of AlgaXaXu being AlmaXorabu Alkadiru, which is that given by Az and IAmb and Sgh. (TA.)

gaXaAXN c
gaXaAXN: see the next paragraph.

giXaAXN c
giXaAXN, applied to a drinking (XurobN), Little in quantity, (K, TA,) because of turbidness: (TA: [in which it is said to be applied in like manner to a day, ywm; but I think that this is a mistranscription for nawomN, i. e. sleep:]) or hasty. or not wholesome; (K, TA;) because the water is not clear. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And The beginning of the darkness: and the end thereof. (K.) ＝ -A3- naqiytuhu giXaAXFA, (T, S, K,) and gaXaAXFA↓, (K,) I met, or found, him, or it, in haste; (T, S, K:) and so ElI gXAX: (T, TA:) or at sunset; (Lth, K;) but Az disallows this: (TA:) or in the night; (K;) which is nearly the same as what Lth says. (TA.)

gaAXRN c
gaAXRN Acting, or advising or counselling, dishonestly, or insincerely; or acting with dissimulation; pretending the contrary of what one conceives in his mind: [see its verb;] pl. giXaXapN and [quasipl. n., like as SaHaAbapN is of SaAHibN,] gaXaAXapN (TA.)

XaIoCN magoXuwXN c
XaIoCN magoXuwXN [A thing made to seem what it is not; falsified; counterfeited; adulterated]; (S, K;) a thing that is not pure; not genuine; or not unadulterated. (K.) You say, TaEaAmu fulaAnK magoXuwXN OaEolaAhu yaAbisN waOasofaluhu maroXuwXN [The wheat of such a one is made to seem what it is not: it upper part is dry, and its lower part is sprinkled]. (A.) And labanN magoXuwXN Milk mixed with water. (Mgh, Msb.) And fiDRapN magoXuwXapN Silver mixed with copper or brass. (TA.)

1 gaXomN c
1. gaXomN signifies The acting, or treating, wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: (S, K:) or the taking another's property wrongfully, &c., or by force: and the taking a course, in journeying [&c.], at random, without direction and without knowledge. (JK.) One says of a governor, gaXama AlrRaEiyRapa, aor.
gaXima
, [accord. to the TK, the aor. of the verb in the sense here following is
gaXuma
, but this I think a mistake,] inf. n. gaXomN, He struck, or beat, with vehemence, the people under his government, wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, and took [from them] what he could. (TA.) And gaXama AlnRaAsa He asked whom he could of the people. (Z, TA.) And gaXama AlOumuwra He performed affairs, or the affairs, [in a random manner,] confusedly, without discrimination. (Ham p. 37: by implication.) ― -b2- And gaXamahu, aor.
gaXima
, He smeared him [i. e. a camel] with tar so that he left nothing [or no part of him] without tar, pouring it upon what was sound thereof and what was diseased thereof: and gaXamN↓ [perhaps as an inf. n., but accord. to the TK it is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is gaXomN,] signifies the act of so smearing. (K.) ― -b3- And gaXama (tropical:) He collected firewood by night, cutting whatever he could get, without consideration, (K, TA,) or, as in the A, without discrimination. (TA.)

gaXamN c
gaXamN: see the preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also Blackness [of night: app. a dial. var. of gasamN; or, perhaps, a mistranscription]. (Ham p. 163.)

gaXuwmN c
gaXuwmN A man who strikes, or beats, people vehemently, [and wrongfully, (see 1,)] and takes [from them] everything that he can get; as also gaXRaAmN↓ and gaAXimN↓ [except that the first and second are app. intensive epithets and the last is a simple part. n.]: and it is likewise applied to a fem., as, for ex., to a hand (yadN): and to a striking, or beating, (DarobN,) [app. as meaning wrongful,] as is also gaXamoXamN↓. (TA.) [One says,] AlHarobu gaXuwmN [War is wrongful], because it reaches other than the committer of a crime, or an offence deserving punishment. (S.) ― -b2- Also A she-camel that will not be turned back from her course, or way. (R, TA.)

gaXiymN c
gaXiymN, meaning [Ignorant of affairs,] not knowing anything, is a word of the vulgar. (TA.)

guXuwmiyRahN c
guXuwmiyRahN, meaning Ignorance of affairs, is a word of the vulgar, like that next preceding. (TA.)

gaXRaAmN c
gaXRaAmN: see gaXuwmN.

gaAXimN c
gaAXimN: see gaXuwmN.

gaXamoXamN c
gaXamoXamN: see migoXamN. Accord. to some, it signifies One who acts with much wrongfulness, injustice, injuriousness, or tyranny. (Ham p. 104.) ― -b2- naAqapN gaXamoXamapN A she-camel strong, resisting, or indomitable, in spirit. (IJ, TA.) And gaXamoXamN is applied to a he-camel as meaning haAYijN [i. e. Excited by lust]. (Meyd in explanation of the prov. here following.) ― -b3- gaXamoXamN yugaXRiI AlXRajara, i. e. This, or it or he, is a torrent [wild in its course,] that overwhelms the trees, so that it crushes them and uproots them, sayolN preceded by hecaA or huwa being meant to be supplied, is a prov. applied to a man who cares not what wrong he does. (Meyd.) ― -b4- See also gaXuwmN.

UinRahu lacuw gaXamoXamapK c
UinRahu lacuw gaXamoXamapK and gaXamoXamiyRapK Verily he is one who possesses boldness, or daringness, and penetrative energy. (K.)

OagoXamu c
OagoXamu [More, and most, wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical: &c.: see 1]. OagoXamu mina AlsRayoli [More wild in course than the torrent] is a proverb. (Meyd.) ＝ -A2- IAar cites a verse in which it is applied to a plant as meaning Dry and old; but accord. to one relation of that verse, the word is OaEoXam. (TA.)

migoXamN c
migoXamN One who goes at random, heedlessly, or in a headlong manner, without consideration, whom nothing will turn from that which he desires, (S, K,) by reason of his courage; (S;) as also gaXamoXamN↓: (S, K:) or, accord. to Aboo-Riyásh, one who performs affairs [in a random manner,] confusedly, without discrimination: or, as some say, one who, when the road is unapparent to him, goes at random, without direction and without knowledge. (Ham p. 37.)

1 gaXiyahu c
1. gaXiyahu, aor. yagoXaI, inf. n. gaXaAwapN, It covered, or concealed, him, or it; (TA;) as also tgXRAhu↓. (MA.) And one says, gaXaAniI AllRayolu, i. e. gaXiyaniI [The night covered me, or concealed me: or the meaning may be that which next follows]. (JK.) ― -b2- gaXiyahu, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) is said of an event (OamorN), [and of heat, (S and K in art. dgm,) and of cold, (K in that art.,) and of an affection of the mind or body, and of various things, sometimes in like manner of a man, and of a company of men,] in a similar sense; and so tgXRAhu↓; (K, TA;) both signifying It came upon, [or invaded, so as to surprise, and so as to over-whelm, properly meaning] as a thing that covered, him, or it. (K, * TA.) Hence, in the Kur [liii. 16], Uico yagoXaI QlsiRdorapa maA yagoXaI [When there was coming upon the lote-tree so as to cover it, or overspread it, what was so coming]. (TA.) And in the same [xx. 81], fagaXiyahumo mina QloyamRi maA gaXiyahumo [And there came upon them so as to overwhelm them, of the sea, what so came upon them]. (TA.) And in the same [viii. 11], Uico yagoXaAkumu [followed by QAlnRuEaAsu, i. e. When it (drowsiness) was coming upon you, or overcoming you]; accord. to one reading; other readings being yugoXiykumu and yugaXRiykumu [followed by QlnRuEaAsa]. (TA.) See also gaAXiyapN, in three places. ― -b3- [A somewhat similar signification of gaXiyahu will be found below.] ― -b4- One says of the night, yagoXaI biZulomatihi kulRa maA bayona AlsRamaMCi waAlOaroDi [It covers, or conceals, with its darkness, everything that is between the heaven and the earth]. (Jel in xcii. 1.) And [hence it is said that] gaXiIa AllRayolu means The night was, or became, dark; as also AgXI↓. (Msb, TA.) ― -b5- [And gaXiyahu, and gaXiIa baSarahu and gXRAhu↓, signify It, i. e. light (DawoCN), came upon him, and upon his eye, with an overpowering effect, so as to obscure, or dazzle, his sight.] ― -b6- gaXiyahu also signifies jaMCahu (S) or OataAhu (Mgh, Msb, K) [which have two meanings, i. e. He came to him, and he did it; both, perhaps, here meant, for both are well-known meanings of gaXiyahu]; and, thus used, the aor. is as above, (TA,) and the inf. n. is gaXayaAnN, (S, TA,) or giXoyaAnN, (so in one of my copies of the S,) or the subst. is giXoyaAnN↓, (Msb,) with kesr, (Mgh, Msb,) syn. with UitoyaAnN. (Mgh.) You say, gaXiIa fulaAnFA He came to such a one; syn. OataAhu; as also gaXaAhu, aor. yagoXuwhu. (K.) ― -b7- [Hence,] gaXiyahaA, (S, MA, Msb, K,) inf. n. gaXayaAnN or giXoyaAnN, (accord. to different copies of the S,) or the latter and gaXoIN, (MA,) or giXoyaAnN↓ is the subst. in this case also, (Msb,) and syn. with UitoyaAnN, metonymically used in the sense of jimaAEN, (Mgh, Msb,) (tropical:) He compressed her; (S, MA, Msb, K;) namely, a woman; (MA, K;) as also tgXRAhA↓. (MA, Msb, TA.) ― -b8- And gaXiIa Uilayohi maHojarFA He did to him (OataI Uilayohi) a forbidden action. (TA in art. Hjr.) [Hence,] giXoyaAnu↓ AlmaHaArimi [The doing of forbidden things]. (Mgh and Msb and K in art. rhq.) And gaXiIa AlXRaIoCa He occupied himself with the thing, engaged in it, or personally managed or conducted it; syn. laAbasahu and baAXarahu. (JM.) [And tgXRI↓ has a similar meaning; for it is said that] AltRagaXRiI and AlgaXoIu primarily signify AlUitoyaAnu and AlmulaAbasapu: and they took an extended range in using the former, so that one said, biAlEadoli tagaXRaAhumo↓ or biAlojawori [app. meaning He ruled them with equity or with injustice]. (Ham p. 27.) [And one says, yagoXaI AlHuruwba (see Ham p. 27), meaning He plunges into wars, or battles: see mugaAmisN, and its verb.] ― -b9- One says also, gaXiyahu biAlsRawoTi, (K, in which it is said to be like raDiyahu, and so accord. to some copies of the S, the phrase in these being gaXiyatu AlrRajula biAlsRawoTi,) or bihi gaXRaAhu↓, (accord. to other copies of the S, the verb in these being written gaXRayotu, and thus accord. to an explanation of qanRaEa raOosahu biAlsRawoTi in art. qnE in the K,) He struck him (i. e. a man, S) with the whip; he flogged him. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- guXiIa Ealayohi, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. gaXoIN, (S, Mgh, * K,) or guXoIN, (MA,) or both, (Msb,) and gaXayaAnN, (K, TA, and so in some copies of the S,) or giXoyaAnN, (so in other copies of the S,) and gaXoyapN↓, (S, Mgh,) or this last is an inf. n. of un., (Msb,) or it is the subst., (K,) He swooned, i. e. became senseless: (MA, PS:) or i. q. OugomiIa Ealayohi [q. v.]: (K, TA:) or AlgaXoIu, or AlguXoIu,
is a state of inertness (taEaTRul, Mgh, Msb) of the motive and sensitive faculties, (Mgh,) or of the motive faculties and of the sensitive will, (Msb,) on account of the weakness of the heart, (Mgh, Msb,) and the soul's becoming drawn together thereto by a cause that suppresses it (yuxofiyhi) within so that it finds not a place of passage, and of the causes thereof is a strangling [or stifling], or hurtful, cold repletion, or vehement hunger, (Mgh,) or vehement pain, (Mgh, Msb,) or cold, or excessive hunger, (Msb,) or an evil affection in some associate, or participating, organ, such as the heart and the stomach: (Mgh:) some say that it is the same as AlUigomaMCu [for which see its proper art.]; (Mgh, Msb;) thus say the scholastic theologians: (Mgh:) others (the physicians and the lawyers, Mgh) make a difference between these two terms. (Mgh, Msb.)

2 gaXRayotu AlXaIoCa c
2. gaXRayotu AlXaIoCa, (S, Msb,) inf. n. tagoXiyapN, (S,) I covered the thing; put a cover, or covering, upon it, or over it. (S, Msb.) One says, gaXRaI QllRehu EalaI baSarihi, inf. n. as above; and AgXI↓; (K, TA;) i. e. God put a covering upon, or over, his eyes. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) it is said in the Kur [xxxvi. 8], fahumo laA yuboSiruwna faOagoXayonaAhumo↓ And we have put a covering over them [so that they shall not see]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [See a usage of the inf. n. voce XiynN.] ― -b3- gXRAhu said of light; see 1, former half. ― -b4- See also 4. ― -b5- gXRAhu biAlsRawoTi: see 1, latter half. ― -b6- One says also, gaXRayotuhu sayofFA, or sawoTFA, [in my original gXyth, without any syll. sign, but app. as I have written, for I do not find any instance of gaXiIa as doubly trans., meaning I equipped him with a sword, or a whip,] like the saying kasawotuhu sayofFA, or EamRamotuhu. (TA.)

4 AgXAhu UiyRaAhu c
4. AgXAhu UiyRaAhu and gXRAhu↓ He made it to cover it; or to be a cover, or covering, upon it, or over it. (MA, * TK, and Bd * and Jel * in vii. 52, &c.) ― -b2- And [hence,] both signify He made it, i. e. an event (Oamor), to come upon, [or invade, so as to surprise, or so as to overwhelm, properly meaning] as a thing that covered, him, or it. (K, * TA,) Both of these verbs are used in this sense in the Kur-án accord. to different readings in vii. 52 and xiii. 3, and likewise (as mentioned in the first paragraph of this art., q. v.,) in viii. 11. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, the former, He made him, or it, to come to him. (S, MA, TA.) ― -b4- See also 2, in two places. ― -b5- [Hence,] AgXI AllRayolu: see 1, former half.

5 ta1a2RaRa
5: see 10: ― -b2- and see also 1, first and third sentences: ― -b3- and again, near the middle, in three places.

10 AstgXI vawobahu c
10. AstgXI vawobahu, (T, K, [agreeably with phrases in the Kur xi. 6 and lxxi. 6,]) and (K) bivawobihi, (S, K,) and bihi tgXRI↓, (S,) [see an ex. of the latter verb in a verse of El-Khansà cited in the first paragraph of art. rEI, where it is trans. without a preposition,] He covered himself with his garment (S, K) in order that he might not see nor hear: (K: [in the CK, yusomaEa and yuraI are put for yasomaEa and yaraI:]) accord. to Er-Rághib, AisotagoXawoA viyaAbahumo means they put their garments as a covering over their ears; and is a phrase denoting the refusing to hearken; or, as some say, an allusion to running, like the phrase XamRara cayolFA, and OaloqaI vawobahu. (TA.)

gaXFA c
gaXFA The whiteness of the head [or face], of a horse and of other animals, denoted by the epithet OagoXaI [q. v.]. (S.)

gaXowN c
gaXowN The nabiq [generally meaning the fruit of the lote-tree called sidor; but sometimes the tree thus called itself]: (K:) accord to the M, [the n. un.] gaXowapN signifies a sidorap. (TA.)

gaXowapN c
gaXowapN and giXowapN and guXowapN: see giXaAwapN.

gaXoyapN c
gaXoyapN an inf. n. of the verb in the phrase guXiIa Ealayohi, (S, Mgh,) or the subst, thereof, (K,) or the inf. n. un. thereof [signifying A swoon]. (Msb.) See 1, last sentence. ― -b2- gaXoyapu Almawoti is The clouding (lit. covering) of the understanding that befalls a man on the occasion of death. (TA.) ― -b3- And gaXoyapu HumRaI signifies A touch, or slight attack, of fever. (TA.)

guXoyapN c
guXoyapN: see giXaAwapN.

giXoyaAnN c
giXoyaAnN: see 1, near the middle, in three places.

giXaMCN c
giXaMCN A cover, or covering; syn. giTaMCN: (S, Msb:) or it differs from the giTaMC in being of clothing or the like: (TA in art. gTw) and giXaAwapN [q. v.] signifies the same: (Msb;) [the pl. of the former is OagoXiyapN and OagoXaMCN; the former regular; and the latter, (which occurs in this art. in the TA in an explanation of gawaAXK, pl. of gaAXiyapN.) like MdaAmN as pl. of UidaAmN.] The giXaMC of the heart is The cover, or covering, thereof; (K, TA;) the qamiyS thereof, likewise mentioned in the K as being called the gaAXiyap↓; a covering of skin, (i. e. the pericardium,] the removal of which therefrom causes death; and also called the giXaAwap↓, this being expl. as meaning the skin of the heart: (TA:) and so of the horse's saddle; (K, TA;) which is a covering of skin or other material: (TA:) [see also gaAXiyapN:] and so of the sword; (K, TA.) which is its gilaAf [a term applied to its scabbard, and also to a case, or covering, enclosing the scabbard, or enclosing the scabbard with its appertenances] (TA;) and so of other things. (K.)

giXaAwapN c
giXaAwapN (S, ISd, K) and gaXaAwapN and guXaAwapN (ISd, K) and gaXowapN↓ and giXowapN and guXowapN (S, K) and gaAXiyapN↓ and guXoyapN↓ and guXaAyapN↓ and giXaAyapN (K) signify A covering upon the eyes (S, K) and upon the heart: (K:) you say, EalaI baSarihi giXaAwapN &c. [Upon his eyes is a covering, or film, app. used only in a tropical sense], (S, K,) and EalaI qalobihi [upon his heart], (K:) thus the first of these words signifies. in relation to the eyes, in the Kur [ii. 6 and] xlv. 22, in relation to the heart, Az says that it is a [sort of] covering of rust (mino TabaEK [also termed rayon]). (TA.) See also giXaMCN, in two places.

guXaAyapN c
guXaAyapN and giXaAyapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

gaAXiyapN c
gaAXiyapN: see giXaMCN and gawaAXK.giXaAwapN is its pl. (TA:) occurring in the Kur vii. 39, meaning OagomaMCN, (K, TA,) i. e. OagoXaMCN [or Coverings, a pl. of giXaMCN]. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also [The covering, like giXaMCN, q. v.], of the horse's saddle. (S.) ― -b3- And (S,) of the [camel's saddle called] raHol, (K,) it is The iron that is above the muWaxRarap or [hinder part], (S, K, TA,) also called the daAmigap [q. v.]. (Az TA.) ― -b4- Also The skin with which the jafon [or scabbard] of a sword is covered, from the lower part of its XaArib [q. v.] to its naEol [or shoe of iron, or silver, at the lower end of the scabbard]: or the covering that is put upon the hilt, consisting of [the skins called] OasofaAn [pl. of safanN, q. v.]: (K. [for OasofaAn, which is the reading in the M, some copies of the K have OasofaAr:]) or the first part, of the sword, of what is next to thee [when holding the hilt]: and sometimes it signifies its gimod [or scabbard], also. (Ham p. 22.) ― -b5- AlgaAXiyapu (in the Kur lxxxviii. I, TA) means The resurrection; (S, K, TA;) because it will overwhelm (tagoXaI↓) with its terrors; (S, TA;) or because it will come upon mankind as a thing covering them, (tagoXaI↓ Alxaloqa,) so as to include them universally: (TA:) and, (K, TA,) some say, (TA,) the fire of Hell); (K, TA;) because it will cover, or overspread, (tagoXaI↓,) the faces of the unbelievers. (TA.) (In like manner also,] gaAXiyapN mina AlEacaAbi means Punishment that is general, or universal, in its extent. (TA.) ― -b6- And gaAXiyapN signifies also A calamity, or misfortune. (TA.) ― -b7- And A cer tain disease that attacks in the jawof [i. e. belly, or chest]. (As, S, K.) One says, ramaAhu QllRehu bigaAXiyapK [May God smite him, or afflict him, with a gaAXiyap]. (As, S.) ― -b8- Also Petitioners that come to one (K, TA) seeking, or demanding, or asking, gifts: (TA:) and visiters, and friends, that come to one time after time; (K, TA;) and that resort to one (TA:) a man's resorters; such as guests; and hangers-on, or seekers of favours; servants [or dependants]; and others. (Har pp. 95 and 467.)

OagoXaI c
OagoXaI, applied to a horse, (S, K,) and to other than a horse, (S,) Whose whole head, as distinct from his body, is white; like Oaroxamu: (S:) or whose face is covered by whiteness: (K:) or having a blaze covering his face, and wide: (M, TA;) fem. gaXowaMCu, applied to a goat. (S, K.)

magoXiIRN Ealayohi c
magoXiIRN Ealayohi Swooning; i. e. senseless; (MA, PS;) having the affection denoted by the phrase guXiIa Ealayohi [q. v.]. (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K.)

1 gaSRa c
1. gaSRa, (Msb, MF,) sec. pers. gaSiSota, (S, Msb, K,) and gaSaSota, (Msb, K,) the latter extr.,
(TA, [see 1 in art. ED,]) aor. yagaSRu, (S, Msb, K,) when the sec. pers. of the pret. is gaSiSota, (Msb,) and yaguSRu, (Msb, TA,) when the sec. pers. of the pret. is of the other form mentioned above, (Msb,) inf. n. gaSaSN, (S, K,) or gaSRN, (Msb,) or the former when the aor. is yagaSRu, and the latter when the aor. is yaguSRu, (TA,) His throat, or fauces, became choked, or obstructed, (S, K, MF,) by food: (S, Msb, MF:) [as also, app., AigotaSRa↓:] accord. to some of those skilled in the science of lexicology, you say gaSRa when it is by food, and Xariqa when it is by beverage, [or by the spittle, and water, and the like, (see art. Xrq,)] and XajiIa when it is by a bone, and jariDa when it is with spittle; but every one of these is sometimes used in the place of any other: (MF:) and [thus] you say also, gaSRa biAlmaMCi, meaning, his throat, or fauces, became choked, or obstructed, by the water; or the water stopped therein, and he was hardly able to swallow it. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] gaSRa biriyqihi [lit., His throat, or fauces, became choked by his spittle;] meaning, (tropical:) he died. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence, also, gaSRa biAlgayoZi (tropical:) [He was, or became, choked with wrath, or rage]. (Msb.) ― -b4- [And gaSRa, alone, seems to signify (assumed tropical:) He became grieved, or disquieted in mind; like as does XajiIa (q. v.): and it seems to be indicated in the CK that AgtSR↓ signifies the same: see guSRapN.] ― -b5- [Hence also,] gaSRato binaA AlOaroDu (assumed tropical:) The land became straitened [as though it were choked] by us. (TA.) And gaSRa Almajolisu biOaholihi (assumed tropical:) [The sitting-place became straitened, or choked, or choked up, by its people]; as also AgtSR↓. (TA.)

4 AgSRhu c
4. AgSRhu, (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. UigoSaASN, (TA,) He (a man, S, Msb) caused his throat, or fauces, to be choked, or obstructed, (S,) by food; (Msb;) syn. OaXojaAhu [which has the above-mentioned meaning and also another to he found below]. (TA.) [And It (food &c.) choked him.] ― -b2- Hence, AgSRhu biAlgayoZi (tropical:) [He (a man) caused him to become choked with wrath, or rage]. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] AgSRhu biriyqihi [lit., He caused his throat, or fauces, to become choked by his spittle;] meaning, (assumed tropical:) He caused him to become grieved, or disquieted in mind; (A, TA;) [like OaXojaAhu: and it seems to be indicated in the CK that AgSRhu without any addition signifies the same: see guSRapN.] ― -b4- [Hence also,] AgSR EalayonaA AlOaroDa (assumed tropical:) He made strait to us the land. (K, TA.)

8 UigotaSaSa
8: see 1, in three places.

guSRapN c
guSRapN A thing lying across in the throat, or fauces, so as to cause a choking, or an obstruction, thereof; (IDrd, A, * K;) a thing by which one has his throat, or fauces, choked, or obstructed; (TA;) food by which one has his throat, or fauces, choked, or obstructed; (Msb;) i. q. XajFA; (S, K;) [which has another meaning that will be found below; and both these meanings may be intended by it in the S; but in the K, the latter only seems to be intended; for there, between it and the explanation which is here first given, we find intervening the pl., and also, in the CK, the words waqado AagoSaSotuhu fAgotaSRa;] a thing by which one is choked (XajFA yugaSRu bihi, Lth, JK, TA) in the Haroqadap [meaning the head of the windpipe], (Lth, TA,) or in the throat, or fauces: (JK:) pl. guSaSN. (S, Msb, K.) It is said in the Kur [lxxiii. 13], waTaEaAmFA caA guSRapK (TA) And food that sticks fast, (Bd,) or by which one is choked, (Jel,) in the throat, or fauces. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) Choking wrath or rage. (Msb.) ― -b3- [And (assumed tropical:) Grief, or disquietude of mind; a signification often occurring; and app. intended by the explanation XajFA in the K. See what is said on this point above.] ― -b4- Hence also, guSaSu Almawoti [The chokings, or strangulations, of death: the deathrattles: or (assumed tropical:) the agonies of death]. (TA.)

gaSRaAn c
gaSRaAn: see what next follows.

gaASRN c
gaASRN A man having his throat, or fauces, choked, or obstructed, (S, Msb, * K,) by food; (S, Msb;) as also gaSRaAn↓. (S [in two copies of which it is written gaSRaAnu], K [in two copies of which it is written gaSRaAnN], Msb [in my copy of which, as well as in the TA, it is without any final syll. sign].) ― -b2- And [hence,] gaASRN biAlqawomi (assumed tropical:) An abode, or a place of alighting, filled [and as it were choked up] with the company of men; (S, A, K;) and in like manner a mosque; as also mugotaSRN↓. (A.)

mugotaSRN c
mugotaSRN: see what next precedes.

1 gaSabahu c
1. gaSabahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
gaSiba
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. gaSobN; (S, Mgh, Msb;) and AgtSbhu↓; (S, Msb, K;) He took it wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously; (S, A, Mgh, K;) or by force; (Mgh, Msb;) minohu and Ealayohi [i. e. from him], both meaning the same. (S.) AlgaSobu repeatedly occurs in the traditions, signifying The taking another's property wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or by violence. (L.) But as employed in law, it means The taking property that has a price and is forbidden, without the permission of its owner, without stealthiness: therefore it does not rightly apply in the case of an animal that has died a natural death or not been slaughtered according to the law, because it is not property; nor in the case of the free person, in like manner; nor in the case of the wine of the Muslim, because it has not a price; nor in the case of the property of him with whom one is at war, because it is not forbidden; the saying “ without the permission of the owner ” precludes the trust, or deposit; and the saying “ without stealthiness ” excludes theft. (KT.) ― -b2- One says also, gaSabotuhu maAlFA and gaSabotu minohu maAlFA I took property from him [wrongfully, &c., or] by force. (Msb.) ― -b3- And gaSabahaA nafosahaA (Msb, TA) and nfshA AgtSbhA↓ (Msb) (tropical:) He violated her; forced her; had connection with her against her will; (TA;) or constuprated her by force. (Msb.) ― -b4- And gaSaba fulaAnFA EalaI AlXRaIoCi (K, TA) and AgtSbh↓ (TA) He compelled such a one by force to do the thing. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And gaSaba Aljiloda, (K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He removed from the skin its hair and its fur by plucking and peeling, without subjecting it to the process termed EaTonN, in the tan, and without UigomaAl [i. e. burying it] in moist earth, (K, TA,) or [soaking it in] urine [to loosen the hair and fur], and without folding it up: so Az heard it expl. by the Arabs. (TA.)

3 gASbhu UiyRaAhu c
3. gASbhu UiyRaAhu, accord. to Freytag, signifies He took it from him by violence: but for this he has not named any authority.]

8 UigotaSaba
8: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- One says also, of a woman, AugotuSibato nafosahaA, meaning (tropical:) She was constuprated by force; (A, Mgh, Msb;) as also AugotuSibato EalaI nafosihaA. (Msb.)

gaSobN c
gaSobN and magoSuwbN↓ A thing taken wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, (S, Mgh,) or by force: (Mgh, Msb:) the former originally an inf. n. (Msb.)

gaASibN c
gaASibN One taking, or who takes, a thing wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, (TA,) or by force: pl. guSRaAbN. (Msb.)

magoSuwbN c
magoSuwbN: see gaSobN. ― -b2- magoSuwbN lahu and minohu A man from whom a thing has been taken [wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or] by force. (Msb.)

1 gaSanahu c
1. gaSanahu, aor.
gaSina
, (K, TA,) inf. n. gaSonN, (TA,) He drew it to him, or towards him; namely, a guSon [or branch]: (K, TA:) from El-Kanánee. (TA.) ― -b2- And He took it; namely, a thing: (K, TA:) or he cut it off: (S, K:) or it signifies also he cut it off, namely, a guSon, and took it. (TA.) ― -b3- And gaSana fulaAnFA Eano HaAjatihi, (K, TA,) aor.
gaSina
and
gaSuna
, (TA,) He turned, or turned away, and withheld, such a one from the object of his want: (K, TA:) Az says that it was thus read to him by El-Mundhiree in the “ Nawádir ” of IAar; but that, accord. to Sh, it is [gaDana, i. e.] with D; and this is correct: (TA:) the former is a mistake. (TA in art. gDn.)

2 gaSRana
2: see the next paragraph.

4 AgSn AlXRajaru c
4. AgSn AlXRajaru, (A in art. frX,) inf. n. UigoSaAnN, The trees put forth branches. (KL.) ― -b2- And AgSn, and gSRn↓, said of a bunch of grapes (Eunoquwd), It was, or became, large (kabura, thus in some of the copies of the K, in other copies kavura, but the former is the right, TA) in its berries: (K:) or somewhat large therein. (TA.)

guSonN c
guSonN A branch from the stem [or from another branch] of a tree; of the slender thereof as well as of the thick: (K:) [sometimes signifying a twig, or shoot:] pl. [of pauc.] OagoSaAnN and [of mult.] guSuwnN and giSanapN. (S, K.)

guSonapN c
guSonapN [A branchlet; and a small twig or shoot;] a small guSon. (K.)

OagoSanu c
OagoSanu A bull having a whiteness in his tail. (K.)

1 gaDRa Tarofahu c
1. gaDRa Tarofahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yaguDRu, (Msb, * TA,) [and yagoDuDo may be used, in the dial. of El-Hijáz, instead of its contracted form yaguDRa,] imp. guDRa, (S, A,) in the dial. of Nejd, (S,) and AugoDuDo, in the dial. of El-Hijáz, (S,) inf. n. gaDRN (Msb, K) and giDaADN, with kesr, (A, K,) and gaDaADN and gaDaADapN, with fet-h, (K,) He lowered his eye, or eyes; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also gaDRa mino Tarofihi; (Msb;) [the mn being redundant, accord. to some; but see what is said on this point below:] and he contracted his eye, or eyes; syn. kasarahu; [so as to wrinkle the lids;] or he blinked; i. e. he contracted his eyelids, or drew them near together, and looked: [this signification is very common:] and he contracted (kasara) his eye, or eyes, and looked towards the ground, not opening his eye [or eyes]: and sometimes it indicates a state of abasement. (TA.) Also gaDRa alone, inf. n. gaDaADapN, He contracted his eyelids; like OagoDaI: he looked languishingly. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xxiv. 30], qulo lilomuWominiyna yaguDRuwA mino OaboSaArihimo, in which some of the grammarians hold mn to be redundant; but the meaning is obvious, i. e. [Say thou to the believers] that they shall abridge their look, or view, from what is prohibited to them: (Sgh:) or that they shall restrain somewhat of their look, or view. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) He bore with forgiveness and silence what was disagreeable, or hateful, or evil. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- gaDRa Sawotahu, (Msb,) or mino Sawotihi, (S, TA,) or both, (Msb,) in like manner signifies He lowered his voice. (S, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [xxxi. 18], waQgoDuDo mino Sawotika, (S, A,) i. e. And lower thy voice: or diminish the loudness of thy voice. (TA.) ― -b4- gaDRa mino lijaAmi farasihi He lowered the rein of his horse, in order to lessen his sharpness of temper. (A, TA. *) ― -b5- gaDRa minohu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yaguDRu, (S, TA,) inf. n. gaDRN (Msb, TA) and gaDaADapN, (Msb,) He lowered and lessened his estimation, dignity, or rank: (S, K, TA:) or he detracted from his reputation; or attributed or imputed to him, charged him with, or accused him of, a vice, fault, or the like: (Msb:) and, inf. n. gaDaADapN, he disdained it, or scorned it; as also minohu AgtDR↓. ('Alee Ibn-Hamzeh, TA.) ― -b6- Also gaDRahu, (K,) aor. as above, inf. n. gaDRN, (TA,) He lessened it, diminished it, or made it defective or deficient; (K, TA;) and so gaDogaDahu↓, (K,) inf. n. gaSogaDapN. (TA.) You say gaDaDotu AlsRiqaMCa I lessened, diminished, or made defective or deficient, [the contents of] the skin. (Msb.) And AlmaMCa gaDogaDotu↓ I lessened, &c., the water. (S.) And fulaAnN baHorN laA yugaDogaDu↓ Such a one is a sea, or great river, that will not be lessened, &c.: (S:) or that will not become exhausted. (Har p. 418.) [See also R. Q. 1 below, and R. Q. 2.] And [you make the former verb doubly trans., saying,] maA gaDaDotuka XayoYFA I have not abridged thee, deprived thee, or defrauded thee, of anything. (TA.) And laA OaguDRuka dirohamFA I will not abridge thee, deprive thee, or defraud thee, of a dirhem. (TA.) You also say, gaDRa mina AlXRaEari He shortened the hair. (M in art. qSr.) And [in like manner] one says, gaDRa mino raOosihi, i. q. TamRa raOosahu. (K voce TamRa, q. v.) ― -b7- Also He broke it (i. e. a branch, or stick, or the like,) but did not break it thoroughly; (L, K, TA;) and so gDRDhu↓. (L, TA.) ― -b8- And gaDaDotuhu also signifies I withheld, restrained, or prevented, it; whatever it were. (S.) [Hence the phrase in the Kur xxiv, 30, accord. to an explanation given above.] You say gaDRa AlEacola, or AlmalaAmapa, aor. as above, inf. n. gaSRN, He withheld blame. (Lth.) And you say to a rider, in asking him to stop a little where you are, guDRa saAEapF, (TA,) and AugoDuDo liI saAEapF, (A, TA,) i. e. Restrain for me thy beast, and stop, or pause, where I am, a while. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- gaDRa, [first pers. gaDaDotu,] aor. yagiDRu; (Msb;) or the first pers. is gaDiDotu and gaDaDotu, (S, K,) and the aor. of each is yagaDRu; (K;) or, accord. to the T, some say gaDiDota, aor. tagaDRu, and some say gaDaDota, aor. tagaDRu: (IB, TA;) but the latter of these requires consideration; (TA;) inf. n. guDuwDapN (IAar, S, K) and gaDaADapN; (S, K;) or the former only, accord to Alee Ibn- Hamzeh; but the saying baDaADapN and buDuwDapN, to denote the quality of that which is termed baDRN, strengthens what J says [in the S] with respect to gaDaADapN; (IB;) It (a thing) was, or became, fresh, juicy, sappy, moist, not flaccid. (S, Msb:) or flourishing and fresh; or luxuriant: (IAar:) or beautiful and bright: (K:) and gaDRato, aor. tagiDRu and tagaDRu, inf. n. gaDaADapN and guDuwDapN, said of a woman, (tropical:) she was, or became, fine-skinned, or thin-skinned, so that the blood appeared [through the skin]. (Lh, TA.)

2 gDRD c
2. gDRD: see 1, latter half. ＝ -A2- Also, inf. n. tagoDiyDN, He ate what is termed gaDR, (K, TA,) i. e. the TaloE [or spadix of a palm-tree]: (TA:) or he became thin-skinned, and plump, and soft, or tender: (O, K:) or he became affected with languor and abasement; (K, TA;) or, as in the Tekmileh, with softness, or tenderness. (TA.)

7 AngDR AlTRarofu c
7. AngDR AlTRarofu i. q. AnogamaDa: (S, TA:) [or the former more probably signifies The eye, or eyes, became contracted: and the latter, the eye, or eyes, became closed.]

8 UigotaDaDa
8: see 1, near the middle.

R. Q. 1 gaDogaDahu c
R. Q. 1. gaDogaDahu, inf. n. gaDogaDapN: see 1, near the middle, in three places. ＝ -A2- EaDogaDa [inf. n. as above] is also intrans. (TA.) See R. Q. 2. ― -b2- It likewise signifies It (for instance a sea, or a large river, TA) became scanty, or little in quantity, and sank into the earth, or disappeared in the earth; or became scanty, or little in quantity; or decreased: (K, TA:) or went away. (TA.) In the TS, the inf. n. is expl. by gayoZ, which is an abominable mistake for gayoD. (TA.) ― -b3- And gaDogaDapN also signifies A man's speaking indistinctly. (TA.) ― -b4- And The boiling of a cooking-pot. (IKtt, TA.)

R. Q. 2 tgaDogaDa c
R. Q. 2. tgaDogaDa It (water, and a sea, or great river, S) decreased, diminished, lessened, or became defective, or deficient; (S, K;) as also gaDogaDa↓, (TA,) inf. n. gaDogaDapN. (Msb.) You say, maAta fulaAnN bibiTonatihi lamo yatagaDogaDo minohaA XaIoCN Such a one died with his property abundant, (S,) or complete; nothing thereof having been given away by him; a prov. relating to the death of the niggard. (A 'Obeyd.) And 'Amr Ibn-El-'As said, alluding to the death of Ibn-'Owf. xarajota mina AldRunoyaA bibiTonatika walamo tatagaDogaDo minohaA XayoYFA, meaning Thou hast died with thy religion unimpaired: (A 'Obeyd:) i. e. he had not been occupied with any office of authority or administration where by his recompense might be diminished. (Az.) You say also maTarN laA yatagaDogaDu Rain that will not cease (TA.)

gaDRN c
gaDRN Fresh; juicy; sappy: moist; not flaccid; (S, Msb, K;) applied to a thing, (S, Msb,) whatever it be; (TA;) as also gaDiyDF↓. (S. K,) Hence the trad. mano sarRahu Oano yaqoraOu AlquroMna gaDRFA kamaA nazala faloyaqoraOo qiraMCapa Qboni OamRi EabodK [He who is rejoiced or pleased, to read the Kur-an freshly, who as it descended, let him read according to the reading of Ibn-Umm-'Abd]. (TA.) ― -b2- A calf recently born: pl. giDaADN. (K.) ― -b3- Anything (S) beautiful and bright; (S, K;,) as (assumed tropical:) youth, and the like: (S;) or gaDRN applied to youth, and gaDRapN applied to a woman, (tropical:) i. q. baDRN and baDRapN thinskinned, or fine-skinned, and plump: &c. j: (A:) or the latter, applied to a woman, (tropical:) thin-shinned, or fine-skinned, so that the blood appears [though the skin]; (Lh:) and gaDiyDapN↓ also is thus applied like gaDRapN. (TA.) You say also, XaIoCN baDRN gaDRN, and baADRN gaADRN↓ A thing fresh, &c., and beautiful and bright; [in a flourishing condition;] not changed, or altered [for the worse]. (TA.) And nabotu gaDRN A [fresh and flourishing and] tender plant. (TA.) And ZilRN gaDRN (assumed tropical:) Shade which the sun has not reached; like a plant which the sun has not reached. (TA.) ― -b4- The spadix of a palm-tree; syn. TaloEN; as also gaDiyDN↓: (IAar:) or both signify a tender TaloE: (K:) or a tender TaloE when it appears: (TA:) or the latter, a TaloE when it appears: (As, S:) or the same, fruit when it first comes forth. (TA.)

guDRapN c
guDRapN: see gaDaADapN. ＝ -A2- Also A sufficiency of the means of subsistence; like gubRapN. (TA in art. gb.)

gaDiyDN c
gaDiyDN, applied to an eye, or eyes, (Tarof,) Lowered: (A, TA:) contracted: having the lids contracted, or drawn near together, and so looking: contracted, and looking towards the ground: (TA:) languishing: (K, TA:) and so magoDuwDN↓, in all these senses: (TA:) and the former, so
applied, [and app. the latter also,] having the eyelids relaxed, or flaccid. (TA.) You say, ZaboIN gaDiyDu AlTRarofi A gazelle having languishing eyes. (S.) And UinRaka lgaDiyDu AlTRarofi naqiIRu AlZrofi, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Verily] thou art faithful, not treacherous; by AlZRarof being meant wiEaAWuhu. (TA.) ― -b2- [Lowered and lessened in estimation, dignity, or rank: (see gaDRa minohu:)] defective or deficient [in good qualities]; (K;) and, in consequence thereof, (TA,) low, mean, or vile: (A, K:) pl. OagiDRapN (K) and OagiDRaMCu. (TA.) ― -b3- Lessened; diminished; made defective or deficient. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also gaDRN, in three places.

gaDaADapN c
gaDaADapN, [an inf. n., of which the verb is not mentioned in senses agreeing with those here following,] (S, A, K,) and gaDiyDapN↓ and magaDRapN↓ (IAar, K) and guDRapN↓, (Ibn- 'Abbád, K,) A defect, an imperfection, a fault, a vice, or the like: and lowness, meanness, or vileness: (S, A, Mgh, K:) and the first, [or all,] languor, or want of power. (TA.) You say, layosa Ealayoka fiI hecaA AlOamori gaDaADapN There is not, or will not be, charged against thee, in, or with respect to, this affair, lowness, &c.; or any defect, &c.; (S, TA;) or languor, or want of power. (TA.) And maA Oaradotu bidelika gaDiyDapa↓ fulaAnK, and magaDRatahu↓, I desired not, or meant not, thereby, to attribute any defect, imperfection, fault, vice, or the like, to such a one. (IAar.)

gaDiyDapN c
gaDiyDapN: see gaDaADapN, in two places.

gaADRN c
gaADRN: see gaDRN.

magaDRapN c
magaDRapN: see gaDaADapN, in two places.

magoDuwDN c
magoDuwDN: see gaDiyDN.

1 gaDiba Ealayohi c
1. gaDiba Ealayohi, (S, Msb, K,) [aor.
gaDaba
,] inf. n. gaDabo (S, Msb, K *) and magoDabapN, (S, K, *) He was angry with him; (MA, K, * PS, &c.;) and tgDRb↓ Elyh signifies the same. (Msb.) [See AlgaDabu below.] And gaDiba mino laAXaIoCK i. e. [He was angry] for nothing; meaning, for no cause. (Msb. [lAXIC, in a case of this kind, is regarded as one word, and is therefore as above, not laA XaIoCi: see p. 1626, third col.]) ― -b2- gaDiba lahu (meaning He was angry with another person for his sake, or on his account, TA) is said when the person [on whose account the anger is excited] is living: and gaDiba bihi, when he is dead: (S, A, Msb, K:) so says El-Umawee, and El-Ahmar says the like. (S.) ― -b3- [And you say, gaDiba fiI QllRehi He was angry for the sake of God.] ― -b4- And gaDibati Alfarasu EalaI AllRijaAmi (tropical:) The mare champed upon the bit. (TA.) Abu-n-Nejm says,
tagoDabu OaHoyaAnFA EalayA llRijaAmi
kagaDabi AlnRaAri EalaI AlDRiraAmi
(tropical:) [She champs, sometimes, upon the bit, like the fierce burning of the fire upon the quickly-kindling fragments of firewood]. (A, TA.) [See also 5, last sentence.] ＝ -A2- guDiba, like EuniIa [pass. in form]; and gaDiba; (K, TA;) the former of which is the more usual; (TA;) He had the disease termed guiDaAb [q. v.]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And gDbt Eayonuhu, with fet-h and kesr [i. e., app., gaDibato; or “ with fet-h and kesr ” may be a mistranscription for “ with damm and kesr, ” so that the verb may be guDibato; His eye had in it what are termed guiDaAb]. (TA.)

3 gaADabotuhu c
3. gaADabotuhu I made him angry, he also making me angry. (K.) ― -b2- And I broke off from him, or quitted him, in anger, or enmity. (S, K.) cahaba mugaADibFA, in the Kur [xxi. 87], means He went away, breaking off from his people, or quitting them, in anger, or enmity. (S.)

4 AgDbhu c
4. AgDbhu He angered him, or made him angry. (S, * Msb, * K.)

5 tgDRb c
5. tgDRb He became angered or angry: (S:) or he was angry somewhat after [having been so] somewhat. (Ham p. 522.) See also 1, first sentence. ― -b2- And tgDRbt Alqidoru (tropical:) The cooking-pot boiled fiercely EalaI AllRaHomi [upon the flesh-meat]. (TA.)

gaDobN c
gaDobN (S, K) Red (S) intense in redness: (S, K:) you say OaHomaru gaDobN: so says ISk: (S:) or gaDobN signifies OaHomaru gaDobN (K) i. e. red that is dense, or deep: (TK:) or OaHomaru [i. e. red], applied to anything: and galiyZN [i. e. thick, &c.]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, and gaDobapN↓, A hard rock (K, TA) set, or fixed, in a mountain, and differing therefrom: (TA:) or the latter signifies thus: or a hard, round, rock. (O.) ＝ -A3- And AlgaDobu signifies The lion: and the bull: as also [in the latter sense, or perhaps in both senses,] AlgaDuwbu↓. (K.)

gaDabN c
gaDabN an inf. n. of gaDiba [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) AlgaDabu is The contr. of AlrRiDaI: (K, TA:) it is variously defined: some say that it is a state of excitement of the blood of the heart for the purpose of revenge: some say that pain on account of anything reparable is gaDab; and for anything irreparable, Oasaf: some say that it [is a passion which] includes all that is evil; wherefore the Prophet, to a man who asked of him a precept, said, laA tagoDabo: and some say that AlgaDab is [a passion] accompanied by an eagerness to obtain revenge; and AlgamR is accompanied by despair of obtaining it: (TA: [see also gayoZN:]) there is a gaDab that is commended, and a gaDab that is discommended; the former being that which is for the sake of religion and truth, or right; and the latter being that which is in a wrong case: and the gaDab of God is his disapproving of the conduct of him who disobeys Him, and whom He will therefore punish. (Ibn- 'Arafeh, TA.)

gaDibN c
gaDibN: see gaDobaAnu.

gaDobapN c
gaDobapN A single fit of gaDab [or anger]. (O.) ＝ -A2- See also gaDobN. ― -b2- Also An [eminence of the kind termed] Oakamap. (L, TA.) ― -b3- And A baxaSap (K, TA, in the CK baxoSap), or protuberance [of flesh], above, or beneath, the eyes, in the form of a flatulent tumour, (TA,) or in the upper eyelid, produced by nature: (K, TA:) so in the M. (TA.) ― -b4- And A thing resembling a daraqap, (K, TA,) i. e. a shield, (TA,) of the hide of the camel, (K, TA,) one part of which is folded over another. (TA.) ― -b5- And A [garment of the kind called] jubRap made of the hides of camels, and worn for fighting. (O.) ― -b6- Also The skin of a mountain-goat advanced in age. (K.) The skin of a fish. (K.) The skin of the head. (K.) And The skin of the part between the horns of a bull. (K.) ― -b7- And A patch of the small-pox: so in the saying, OaSobaHa waAHidapF mina AljudariIRi jiloduhu gaDobapF [His skin became one patch of the small-pox]: (O:) like gaDonapN. (S in art. gDn.)

guDabapN c
guDabapN: see gaDobaAnu.

gaDobaI c
gaDobaI fem. of gaDobaAnu [q. v.]: (S, Msb, K:) and pl. thereof. (S.) [See also gaDuwbN.] ＝ -A2- It is also said by J, (K, TA,) and [before him] by EzZejjájee, and also [after him] by ISd, (TA,) to be a name for A hundred camels, and not to have tenween, nor the article Al: but this is a mistake for gaDoyaA. (K, TA.)

AlquwRapu AlgaDabiyRapu c
AlquwRapu AlgaDabiyRapu [The irascible faculty]. (KT, in explanation of AltRahawRuru.)

gaDobaAnu c
gaDobaAnu (S, Msb, K) [and, in the dial. of BenooAsad, as is implied by the fem. in that dial. mentioned in what follows, gaDobaAnN,] and gaDibN↓ and gaDuwbN↓ [which is both masc. and fem.] and guDubRN↓ (K) and guDubRapN↓ (S, K) and gaDubRapN↓ and gaDabRapN↓, (K,) or the last, accord. to MF, is guDabapN↓, (TA,) are epithets applied to an angry man: (K:) [the first seems often to signify simply Angry, like gaDibN; but accord. to SM,] all these epithets signify quickly, or soon, angry [as guDubRapN is said in the S to signify, on the authority of As]: (TA:) the fem. of the first word is gaDobaI, (S, Msb, K,) and (in the dial. of Benoo-Asad, S) gaDobaAnapN, (S, K,) which is seldom used; (K;) and gaDuwbN is also used as a fem. epithet [as stated above], (K,) and has an intensive signification: (TA:) pl. (of the first word, Msb) giDaAbN (Msb, K) and (likewise of the first) gaDobaI (S) and guDaAbaI (S, K) and gaDaAbaI. (Msb, K.)

guDubRN c
guDubRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

guDubRapN c
guDubRapN and gaDubRapN and gaDabRapN: see gaDobaAnu.

giDaAbN c
giDaAbN and guDaAbN Motes (qacFI) in the eye: (K, TA:) or, as in one copy of the K, [and in the O,] in the eyes. (TA.) ― -b2- And A certain disease; (K, TA;) or so the latter word; (O;) an eruption in the skin; but not small-pox: (TA:) or (so accord. to the TA, but in the CK “ and ”) small-pox. (K, TA.)

gaDuwbN c
gaDuwbN: see gaDobaAnu. ― -b2- Also Stern, or austere,
in look, or countenance; applied to a woman: (S, O, K:) and in like manner applied to a she-camel: (O, K:) or thus applied to a she-camel: and also signifying a company of women. (TA.) ― -b3- And A malignant serpent. (O, K.) ― -b4- See also gaDobN.

guDaAbiIRN c
guDaAbiIRN A man (TA) perturbed (kadirN) in social intercourse and in comportment. (K. [For waAlmuxaAlafapi in some copies of the K, I read waAlmuxaAlaqapi, as in other copies.])

AlOagoDabu c
AlOagoDabu The part between the penis and the thing. (K.)

magoDuwbN Ealayohi c
magoDuwbN Ealayohi [An object of anger]. By AlmagoDuwbi Ealayohimo in the Kur [ch. i. last verse], are meant The Jews. (O, TA.) ＝ -A2- magoDuwbN also signifies Having [the disease called giDaAb, i. e.] the smallpox. (O, TA.)

1 gaDura c
1. gaDura, aor.
gaDura
, inf. n. gaDaArapN, It (anything) was, or became, soft, or tender. (TA. [See also the inf. n. below; and see the part. n., gaDiyrN; and gaDirN.]) ― -b2- And gaDira, aor.
gaDara
, inf. n. gaDarN, He (a man) became rich, wealthy, or abounding in property. (Msb.) You say, gaDira biAlmaAli, (K. TA,) and in like manner, biAlsRaEapi waAlOaholi, aor.
gaDara
, inf. n. gaDarN and gaDaArapN: (TA;) as also guDira, like EuniIa; (IKtt, TA;) He (a man, TA) had abundance of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; (K, TA;) [or he was, or became, rich in wealth and family;] after having been poor. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- gaDarahu QllRehu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
gaDura
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. gaDorN, (Msb, K,) God made him to be rich, wealthy, or abounding in property: (Msb:) to enjoy a pleasant life: (S:) or to have abundance of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- gaDira, with kesr, said of a place, It had in it red clay or earth: so says Az. (O.) ＝ -A4- gaDara Eanohu, aor.
gaDira
, (S, O, K, TA,) inf. n. gaDorN [and magoDarN↓ likewise, accord. to a verse of Ibn-Ahmar as cited in the O and TA, but accord. to the reading of that verse in my copies of the S, it is magoDirN↓, app., if correct, a n. of place]; as also gaDira; (TA;) He turned aside or away, or deviated, from it, or him; (S, O, K, TA;) and so tgDRr↓. (O, K.) One says, maA gaDarotu Eano SawobiI I did not deviate from my course. (TA.) ― -b2- gaDara Ealayohi, (K. TA,) aor.
gaDira
, inf. n. gaDorN, (TA,) i. q. EaTafa (K, TA) [app. as meaning He turned against him, for it is added] and maAla. (TA.) ― -b3- And maAgaDara Eano XatomiIa He did not hold back, or refrain, from reviling me. (TA.) ＝ -A5- And gaDarahu, (S, K, TA,) aor.
gaDira
, inf. n. gaDorN, (TA,) It, or he, withheld, or prevented, him. (S, K, TA.) One says, Oaradotu Oano Mtiyaka fagaDaraniI OamorN [I desired to come to thee, and] an affair withheld, or prevented, me. (TA.) ＝ -A6- And gaDara AlXRaIoCa He cut off the thing, (K, TA,) lahu [for him]. (TA.) You say, gaDara lahu mino maAlihi He cut off a portion for him from his property. (K.) ＝ -A7- And gaDara Aljiloda He tanned well the skin. (TA.)

2 Hamala famaA gaDRara c
2. Hamala famaA gaDRara He charged, and was not cowardly, and did not fall short of what was requisite. (TA.)

5 tagaDRara
5: see the first paragraph.

8 AugotuDira c
8. AugotuDira he died being a youth, or young man, in a sound state: (K, TA:) like AuxotuDira. (TA.) [See also 8 in art. grD.]

Q. Q. 1 gaDowara c
Q. Q. 1. gaDowara He (a man, TA) was angry. (O, K.)

maA naAma liguDorK c
maA naAma liguDorK is expl. as meaning He hardly, or scarcely, slept; but is said to be with E and S, and has been thus mentioned before [in art. ESr]. (TA.)

gaDirN c
gaDirN: see gaDiyrN. ― -b2- One says also EayoXN gaDirN maDirN An easy and a plentiful life: (K, * TA:) mDr being here an imitative sequent to EDr. (TA.) ― -b3- And gaDiru AlnRaASiyapi applied to a man, (O, K,) and gaDirapu AlnRaASiyapi applied to a beast (dRaAbRap), (O, Msb, K,) Blest, fortunate, or abounding in good or advantage or utility. (O, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- See also gaDoraMCu, in two places.

gaDorapN c
gaDorapN A certain plant. (K, TA.) Hence the prov. yaOokulu gaDorapF wayarobiDu HajorapF [He eats ghadrah, and lies down aside]. (TA. [See also HajorapN.])

gaDoraMCu c
gaDoraMCu: see gaDaArapN, in six places. ＝ -A2- Also Earth, or land, (OaroDN, K,) or a piece, or portion, of clay or earth, (TiynapN, S, Msb,) good, or fertile. (TayRibapN, K,) green, or of a dark or an ashy dust-colour: (xaDoraMCu EalikapN: S, Msb, K:) and land in which is clay, or soil, of a good kind, without sand, or without salt earth; (K, TA;) as also gaDiyrapN↓ or gaDirapN↓, accord. to different copies of the K, the latter accord. to the L. (TA:) or, accord. to IAar, gaDirN↓ [in the TA gaDoraMCu, which is a mistranscription,] signifies a place having in it red clay or earth. (O.) One says, OanobaTa fulaAnN biYorahu fiI gaDoraMCa(S, TA) i. e. Such a one produced the water of his well by digging in land of soft and good earth of which the water was sweet. (TA.) ― -b2- And Land in which palm-trees will not grow until it is dug, (K, TA,) the upper part thereof consisting of white [soft stones, like dry pieces of clay, such as are termed] kacRaAn. (TA.)

gaDaArN c
gaDaArN Clay that is cohesive, and OaxoDar [i. e. green, or of a dark or an ashy dust-colour], (K,) or (O) of a good kind, without sand, or without salt earth; (O, K;) and so gaDaArapN↓: (K:) or the latter signifies such clay itself: (Sh, O:) and the former signifies baked clay (Sh, O, K, TA) made of gaDaArap, (Sh, O,) green, or of a dark or an ashy dust-colour, (OaxoDaru, O, TA,) which is suspended upon a human being as a preservative from the [evil] eye. (O, K, * TA. *)

gaDowarN c
gaDowarN Sticky clay, (K, TA,) that adheres to the foot, which will hardly, or in nowise, go into it [app. by reason of its compactness]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And A species of trees [or plants], (K, TA,) dustcoloured, that grow large: n. un. with p, (TA.) And (TA) A certain plant, (S, O, TA,) resembling the vumaAm [or panic grass], (TA,) or of the species of Oasal [or rushes], not beneficial, nor causing increase in the cattle; (AHn, O;) it is said that the cattle pasturing upon it do not form fat thereby, (O, TA, *) and that it does not dissolve in their stomachs: (O:) n. un. with p. (AHn, O.)

gaDiyrN c
gaDiyrN Soft, or tender; (TA;) applied to a plant, or herbage; as also gaDirN↓, and gaADirN↓; (O, TA;) all in this sense: (TA:) or so the first, applied to anything: (O, K, TA) or this signifies moist, juicy, or fresh: (AA, O:) and i. q. xaDiyrN [syn. with OaxoDaru i. e. green]. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also gaDoraMCu.

gaDaArapN c
gaDaArapN an inf. n., of gaDura and of gaDira. (TA.) [Used as a simple subst.,] Ease, comfort, and affluence; easiness of life: ampleness of the conveniences of life, or of the means of subsistence; plenty; (K, * TA;) prosperity; (TA;) plenty and prosperity; (S;) a plentiful and pleasant and easy state of life: (TA:) and gaDoraMCu↓ signifies the same. (S.) One says, UinRahumo lafiI gaDaArapK mina AlEayoXi and mn AlEyX fI gaDoraMCi↓, Verily they are in a plentiful and prosperous condition [of life]. (S.) Accord. to As, one should not say OabaAda QllRehu xaDoraMCahumo, but AbAd AllReh gaDoraMCahumo↓, meaning May God put an end to their prosperity, and their plentiful condition: (S:) but Ahmad Ibn- 'Obeyd says that both of these phrases mean may God destroy the collective body of them: and another says, their clay of which they were created. (TA. [See also xaDoraMCu, voce OaxoDaru.]) One says also, EayoXK UinRahu lafiI gaDoraka↓ and xaDoraMCi EayoXK i. e. Verily he is in a plentiful condition of life. (TA.) And mino xayorK UinRahu lafiI gaDoraMCa↓ [Verily he is in an ample state of prosperity]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And, (O, K,) accord. to Lth, (O,) AlgaDaArapu is an appellation of The qaTaAp [or sand-grouse]; (O, K;) but As disapproved this: (O:) [or] the qaTaAp is called AlgaDoraMCu↓; and the pl. is AlgaDaAriIRu. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- See also gaDaArN. ＝ -A4- Of gaDaArapN meaning A certain utensil, IDrd says, I do not think it to be genuine Arabic: (O, TA:) it signifies a large [bowl such as is termed] qaSoEap: [app. from the Pers. gadaAraho:] pl. gaDaAYiru. (Mgh.)

gaDaAriIRN c
gaDaAriIRN A species of locust; also called the jaraAd mubaArak: a word of uncertain derivation. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also pl. of gaDoraMCu mentioned near the end of the next preceding paragraph. (Msb.)

AlgaDawRara c
AlgaDawRara The lion. (Sgh, K.)

gaADirN c
gaADirN: see gaDiyrN. ＝ -A2- Also Withholding, or preventing. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And A skin well tanned. (AHn, S, O, K.) ＝ -A4- And One who occupies himself early in the morning in the accomplishment of the objects of his want, or in his needful affairs. (AA, O, K.)

magoDarN c
magoDarN and magoDirN: see the first paragraph.

mugoDirN c
mugoDirN: see the following paragraph.

magoDuwrN c
magoDuwrN A man enjoying a pleasant life: (S:) blest; fortunate; abounding in good, or advantage, or utility: (Msb, K:) or in a state of ease, comfort, and affluence; or of plenty, or prosperity; (O, K, TA;) and of happiness: (TA:) as also mugoDirN↓: (K, TA:) pl. of the former magaADiyrN, as well as magoDuwruwna. (TA.)

guDoruwfN c
guDoruwfN is syn. with guroDuwfN, (S and K &c. in art. grDf, q. v.,) in [all of] its meanings: (K:) pl. gaDaAriyfu. (O and TA in art. grDf.)

1 gaDafahu c
1. gaDafahu, (S, O, K,) aor.
gaDifa
, (K,) inf. n. gaDofN, (TA,) He broke it, namely, a branch, or stick, or the like, (S, O, K, TA,) and a thing, (TA,) but not thoroughly. (S, O, TA.) [See also 2.] ― -b2- And gaDafa Oucunaha, (S, O, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, O,) He (a dog) relaxed his ear, and folded, or creased, it: (S, O, K, TA:) [see, again, 2:] or gaDafa Oucunaha, inf. n. gaDofaAnN and gaDafaAnN, he (a dog) twisted his ear: and in like manner one says of the wind, [gaDafatohaA,] i. e. it twisted it. (TA.) And gDaf AlwisaAdapa He folded the pillow [so as to make creases in it]. (Ham p. 785. [But perhaps this is correctly gDRf↓: comp. its quasi-pass., 5.]) ― -b3- gaDafato said of [wild] she-asses, (O,) or of a she-ass, (K,) aor. as above, (O, TA,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) signifies Oaxacati AljaroIa OaxocFA [as though meaning They, or she, restrained the running, i. e. their, or her, running; agreeably with what here follows]: (O, K, TA:) gaDafa, [for gaDafa mina AljaroIi,] said of a horse &c., means he lessened, lit. took from, the rate of the running, (Oaxaca mina AljaroIi,) without reckoning: (L, TA:) Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee- 'Áïdh El-Hudhalee says,
yaguDRu wayagoDifona mino rayRiqK
