(O, TA) meaning He (the ass) withholds somewhat of his running, (yakufRu baEoDa jaroyihi,) and they (the she-asses) lessen, lit. take from, the [or rather a] first, or former, rate of their running, (yaOoxucona OaxocFA mino OawRali jaroyihinRa,) without reckoning: (Skr: see Kosegarten's “ Carmina Hudsailitarum, ” p. 189:) Skr says, in explanation of the citation above from Umeiyeh, that gaDofN signifies the act of taking and lading out [with the hand] (OaxocN and garofN); and on one occasion he says, the taking easily; [adding,] one says, gaDafa fulaAnN mino TaEaAmK layRinK [Such a one took, or laded out with his hand, from soft food]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- gaDafa AlEayoXu, inf. n. guDuwfN, The life was soft, or easy, and plentiful. (TA.) ＝ -A3- gaDifa, [aor.
gaDafa
, inf. n. gaDafN,] He (a dog, S) was, or became, relaxed, or flabby, in the ear. (S, K, TA.) And gaDifati AlOucunu, inf. n. gaDafN, is said to mean The ear was, or became, long and relaxed or flabby: or it advanced upon the face: or it retired towards the head: or its extremities folded upon the inner part thereof: or, in a dog, it turned towards the back of the neck: or it became folded, or creased, naturally. (TA.) [See also gaDafN, below: and see 7.] ― -b2- gaDifa AllRayolu: see 4.

2 gDRfhu c
2. gDRfhu, inf. n. tagoDiyfN, He broke it. (TA.) [See also 1, first signification.] ― -b2- tagoDiyfN signifies also The making [a thing] to hang down. (O, K.) ― -b3- See also 1, third signification.

4 AgDf AllRayolu c
4. AgDf AllRayolu The night became dark and black; (S, O, K;) as also gaDifa↓, inf. n. gaDafN. (S.) ― -b2- AgDft AlsRamaMCu The sky became clouded, and prepared to rain. (O, * K, * TA.) ― -b3- AgDft AlnRaxolu The palm-trees had many branches, and bad fruit: (K, TA:) or became laden, or heavily laden, with fruit; or abounded therewith. (O, K, TA.) ― -b4- And AgDf AlEaTanu The usual abidingplace of camels, or cattle, or their place of lying down at, or around, the water or watering-trough, had many thereof. (K.)

5 tgDRf c
5. tgDRf It broke, or became broken; as also AngDf↓. (TA.) ― -b2- And tagaDRufN signifies The being, or becoming, creased, or wrinkled; (O, K, TA;) like tagayRufN. (TA.) And tagaDRafa He, or it, inclined, and bent, and became folded, or creased, much, or in several places, syn. maAla, and tavanRaI, and takasRara, (S, O, K, *) Ealayohi upon him, or it. (S, O.) And tgDRft AlHayRapu The serpent twisted, or coiled, itself. (O, K.) ― -b3- ngDRft AlbiYoru The sides of the well fell in ruins, or became demolished: (S, O, K:) the well collapsed, or broke down, EalaI fulaAnK upon such one, who had descended into it; (O;) as also AngDft↓. (O, K.) ― -b4- tgDRf EalayonaA AllRayolu The night covered us. (O, K.) ― -b5- tgDRft EalayonaA AldRunoyaA The world became abundant to us in its good things; and favourable to us. (O, K.)

7 UinogaDafa
7: see 5, in two places. ― -b2- AngDft Oucunuhu His ear became folded, or creased, not naturally. (TA.) [See also 1, near the end.] ― -b3- AngDf AlDRabaAbu The DbAb [or thin clouds, like smoke,] overlay one another. (TA.) ― -b4- AngDfwA fiI AlgubaAri They entered into the dust, or raised and spreading dust. (S, O, K.)

gaDofN c
gaDofN: see gaDafN.

guDofN c
guDofN [written by Golius guDufN]: see gaDafapN.

gaDafN c
gaDafN [inf. n. of gaDifa (q. v.): and, as a simple subst.,] Laxness, or flabbiness, in the ear: (S, O, K:) or, as in the T, a laxness, or flabbiness, of the upper part [of each] of the two ears, upon, or over, the concha thereof, by reason of its width and its largeness: (TA:) Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee says, after citing a verse of Abu-n-Nejm, describing a lion, that it signifies a twisting, in the ear, backwards: accord. to ISh, it is, in the lion, a laxness, or pendulousness, of the upper eyelids, upon the eyes; arising from anger and pride: (O:) and he says that, accord. to some, it is, in the lion, abundance of the fur, and a folding, or creasing, of the skin. (TA.) And one says, [app. in relation to the lion,] fiI OaXofaArihi gaDofN↓ and gaDafN [app. In the edges of his upper eyelids is a laxness, or pendulousness]; both meaning the same. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Softness, or easiness, and plentifulness, of life: (S:) like gaTafN. (O in art. gTf.) ＝ -A2- And A species of tree in India, exactly like the palm-tree, (Lth, O, K,) except that (K) its fruit-stones are divested of covering, without a liHaMC [or pulpy pericarp], and from its lowest to its uppermost part it has green saEaf [or branches like those of the palm-tree], (Lth, O, K,) covered [thereby]: (Lth, O:) AHn says, it is a plant resembling the palm-tree exactly, (O, L, TA,) but not growing tall, (TA,) having many saEaf, and prickles, and [leaves such as are termed] xuwS, of the hardest sort, whereof are made large [receptacles of the kind called] jilaAl [pl. of julRapN], that serve for sacks, goods being carried in them by land and by sea; (O, L, TA;) it produces from its head unripe dates of disagreeable flavour, not eaten; and, he says, of its xuwS are made mats like carpets, (L, TA,) called simaAm, pl. of sumRapN [q. v.], (L,) one of which may be spread for twenty years. (L, TA.) ＝ -A3- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

gaDafapN c
gaDafapN A certain bird: or a qaTaAp [or sandgrouse]: (IDrd, O, K:) or the qaTaAp termed juwniyRap: pl. gaDafN↓ [or rather this, if correct, is a coll. gen. n.]: J says that AlgaDafu↓ [thus in the TA, but in my and other copies of the S AlguDofu↓, for which Golius appears to have found AlguDufu,] signifies AlqaTaA Aljuwnu; but IB says that it is correctly AlqTA AljuwniIRu. (TA. [See juwniIRN: and particularly what is said at the end of the paragraph thus headed.]) ＝ -A2- Also An [eminence of the kind called] Oakamap. (O, K, TA. [For Akmp, in this case, the TK has most strangely substituted Akmh, meaning Oakomahu, for it explains it as signifying “ blind from the birth; ” and this, though an obvious mistake, Freytag asserts to be the right reading and explanation.])

gaADifN c
gaADifN: see OagoDafu, in two places. ― -b2- Also [applied to a man] Soft, or easy, and plentiful, in his circumstances. (S, O, K.)

OagoDafu c
OagoDafu, applied to a dog, Relaxed, or flabby, in the ear; pl. guDofN; (S, O, K;) occurring in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh, cited voce EacabN; (O, TA;) and the fem. gaDofaMCu is applied [to a bitch, and] to an ear: (TA:) or a dog having the upper part of his ear folded, or creased, backwards; and gaADifN↓ when it is forwards. (IAar, O, K.) And hence [the pl.] guDofN, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, is used as an appellation for Dogs of the chase. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a lion, Having the ear folded, or creased; (Hr, O, K;) denoting a quality that renders him more abominable: (Hr, O:) or relaxed, or pendulous, in the ears: (O, K:) or
whose upper eyelids are lax, or pendulous, upon his eyes, by reason of anger or pride; (K, TA;) so says ISh. (TA.) And accord. to Lth, A beast of prey whose upper part of his ear is folded, or creased, and the lower part thereof relaxed, or pendulous. (TA.) And the fem., gaDofaMCu, A she-goat whose extremities of her ears descend low, by reason of their length. (IA.) ― -b3- Also Anything bending, folding, or creasing, and relaxed, flabby, or pendulous: fem. as above. (TA.) And mugoDifN↓ is like OagoDafu, (TA.) ― -b4- And AlOagoDafu is one of the names of The lion (TA.) ― -b5- sahomN OagoDafu An arrow of which the feathers are thick; (S, O, K;) contr. of OaSomaEu, (S, O.) ― -b6- layolN OagoDafu A night that is dark (S, O, K) and black; (S, O;) covering with its dark ness. (TA.) ― -b7- EayoXN OagoDafu A soft, or an easy, and plentiful, life; as also gaADifN↓ (S, O, K:) like OagoTafu. (S and O in art. gTf) And sanapN gaDofaMCu A fruitful, or plentiful, year. (TA.)

mugoDifN c
mugoDifN: see OagoDafu, latter half. ― -b2- Applied to palm-trees (naxolN), Having many branches, and bad fruit; (O, TA;) thus without p; (O;) and also with p. (TA. [See also its verb.]) ― -b3- And vamarapN mugoDifapN A fruit that has become flaccid, but not completely ripe: (O:) or nearly, but not yet, ripe: (Sh, TA:) or whereof the goodness has not become apparent: or, accord. to AA, hanging upon its tree, flaccid. (TA.)

Q. 1 gaDofara c
Q. 1. gaDofara He (a jade, or hackney, TA) was, or became, heavy, or sluggish. (K, TA.)

gaDofarN c
gaDofarN: see the next paragraph; the former, in two places.

guDaAfirN c
guDaAfirN: see the next paragraph; the former, in two places.

gaDanofarN c
gaDanofarN Big, thick, or rude, in body or person; (S, K;) as also gaDofarN↓, which is the original form; the n in the former being augmentative: (Az, TA:) or simply, big, thick, or rude: applied to a man: (Lth, TA:) or rude, or coarse, [in disposition or in make,] and big, or thick: (TA:) as also ganaDofarN↓ and gaDofarN↓; (K;) applied to a man: (TA:) or big, or thick, (AA, TA.) in make, (TA,) and wrinkled; (AA, TA;) applied to a lion. (TA.) You say also OucunN gaDanofarapN, meaning, A big, or thick, fleshy, ear. (AO, L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlgaDanofaru The lion; (Lth, S, K;) as also AlguDaAfiru↓. (TS, K.)

gaDanofarN c
gaDanofarN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 gaDanahu c
1. gaDanahu, (S, K,) aor.
gaDina
and
gaDuna
, (K,) inf. n. gaDonN, (S,) He, or it, (a man, and a thing, S,) withheld, restrained, hindered, or diverted, him. (S, K.) One says, maA gaDanaka EanRaA What withheld, hindered, or diverted, or has withheld, &c., thee from us? (S.) In the “ Nawádir ” of IAar, this verb, which is correctly thus, with D, is erroneously with S. (TA.) ＝ -A2- gaDanato biwaladihaA, and gaDRnt↓, She (a camel) cast her young one, or fœtus, in an imperfect state, (K, TA.) before the hair had grown upon it and its make had become [perfectly apparent. (TA. [See also xadajato.]) [This is what is meant in the S where, after the mention of a signification of AltRagoDiyn↓ which will be found below, it is said that this word signifies also AlrRijaAEu (an inf. n. of rajaEato, q. v.): hence, app., (though referring to the K as his authority,) Freytag has given to gDRnt, as said of a she-camel, besides the signification mentioned above, another, which is also assigned to rajaEato; i.e., she falsely indicated her being pregnant, by raising her tail, &c.] ＝ -A3- See also 5, in form places: ＝ -A4- and see 4

2 gaDRanotuhu c
2. gaDRanotuhu, inf. n. tagoDiynN, I wrinkled, shrivelled, or puckered, it syn. of the inf. n. taXoniyjN. (S.) One says. daxalotu Ealayohi fagaDRana liI mino jabohatih [I went in to him and be wrinkled to me a portion of his forehead.] (TA) ― -b2- See also 5 ＝ -A2- and see 1 in two places ＝ -A3- and 4

3 AlmagaADanapu c
3. AlmagaADanapu signifies mukaAsarapu AlEayonyoni [The contracting of the eyes so as to wrinkle the lids], (S, K, TA,) by reason of doubt, or suspicion. (TA.) One says, gaADana AlmaroOapa, meaning gaAzalahaA bimukaAsarapi AlEayonayoni [i. e. He talked, or act, with the woman, in an amatory and enticing manner, with the contracting of the eyes so as to wrinkle the lids] (A. TA.)

4 AgDnt AlsRamaMCu c
4. AgDnt AlsRamaMCu The sky rained continually; (S, TA;) as also gDnt [perhaps gaDanat↓, but more probably, I think, gaDRanat↓] (TA.) And gDnt AlsRaHaAbapu [The cloud rained continually]. (S and TA in explanation of rayRamat.) ― -b2- And AgDn Ealayohi AlHumRaI The fever continued upon him persistently. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- AgDn Ealayohi AllRayolu The night became dark upon him. (TA.)

5 tgDRn c
5. tgDRn It was, or became, wrinkled, shrivelled, or puckered; syn. taXanRaja; (S, MA, TA;) as also gaDina↓, inf. n. gaDanN [and app. guDuwnN, like qubuwlN as an inf. n. of qabila. though this requires consideration, as will be shown by what follows]. said of the face as having this signification, or as signifying it was, or became, wrinkled and speckled; (MA;) [and so, perhaps, gDRn↓, for] AltgDyn [if not a mistranscription for AltRagaDRunu], as also AlguDuwnu↓, is syn. with AltRaXanRuju; and one says fiI jabohatihi rajulN cuw guDuwnK↓ meaning takasRurK [i. e. a man having a wrinkling in his forehead; but guDuwn may be here used as pl. of gaDonN, and thus meaning wrinkles]: and gaDanN↓ signifies a bending (tavanRK and talawRK) of a branch or twig or the like. (TA.) One says also, tagaDRanati AldRiroEu EalaI laAbisihaA The coat of mail became folded, [or it hung, or sat, with folds,] upon its wearer. (TA.)

gaDonN c
gaDonN and gaDanN↓ A wrinkle, crease, fold, ply, plait. or pucker, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) of the skin, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and of anything, (Msb,) or in a garment, and in a skin, (K,) and in a coat of mail, (S, K,) &c. (S:) pl. guDuwnN, S Mgh, Msb, K,) occurring in a verse cited in art. XOb (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, kaAna celika fiI guDuwni kacaA [lit. That was within the folds, meaning in the midst, of such a thing, or such an affair or event]; like fiI OavonaMCi kcA (TA in art. vnI ― -b3- guDuwnu AlOucuni means The places of fold the case; syn. mavaAniyhaA. K, TA. in the CK [erroneously] manAbituhA.) ＝ -A2- Also (i.e. gaDonN and gaDanN↓. TA) Difficulty, distress, or trouble, and fatigue or weariness. (K, TA.) The Arabs say to a man, in threatening him, laOuTiylanRa gaDonaka or gaDanaka↓ i. e. [I will assuredly make] thy difficulty &c., [to be long (AZ, A, TA)]

gaDanN c
gaDanN an inf. n. of gaDinu. (MA [See 5, in two places.]) ― -b2- See also gaDonN, in three places, ― -b3- gaDanu AlEayoni signifies The exterior, or apparent jilodap [app. meaning tunic i. e. the sclerotic tunic,] of the eye. (S, TA.)

gaDonahN c
gaDonahN [A patch of the smallpox] One says of a person whose skin has became covered, or wholly covered, (Oulobisa,) with the smallpox, OuSobaHa jiloduhu gaDonapF waAHidapF [His skin has became one patch of the smallpox]: and some say gaDobap (S,)

giDaAnN c
giDaAnN the subst from the verb in the phrase gaDanato biwaladihaA [i. e. a subst. signifying The act denoted by that phrase. q. v.] (K)

gaDiynN c
gaDiynN A she-camel's young one or fœtus, cast in an imperfect state, before the hair has grown upon it and its make has become [perfectly] apparent. (TA.)

OagoDanu c
OagoDanu Contracting his eye so as to wrinkle the lids, naturally, or by reason of enmity, or from pride. (K.)

1 gaDaA c
1. gaDaA, aor. yagoDuw; and gaDaI, aor. yagoDaI: see 4; the former, in three places. ＝ -A2- gaDaA, (K, TA, aor. yagoDuw, thus in the M, (TA,) inf. n. guDuwRN. (K, * TK,) He, i. e. a man, [and app. it. i. e. a thing,] was, or became, such as is termed gaADK [q. v.]. (K, TA. [In the TK it is mentioned only as said of a thing but the context in the K indicates that it is said of a man, and app. of a thing also.]) ＝ -A3- [See also guDuwRN below] ＝ -A4- gaDiyati AlUibilu, inf. n. gaDFA, The camels had a complaint (M, K, TA) of their bellies (K, TA) from eating of the trees called gaDFA. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- And gaDiyati AlOaroDu The land abounded with the trees called gaDFA. (IKtt, TA.)

4 AgDI c
4. AgDI, (K,) inf. n. UigoDaMCN, (S,) He contracted his eyelids; drew them near together; (S, K;) like gaDRa; (TA in art. gD;) [and] so AgDI Eayonahu; said of a man: (Msb:) or he closed his
eyelids upon his iris; so in the M; as also gaDaA↓, a dial. var. of AgDI, likewise mentioned by ISd; and gaDaI↓, aor. yagoDaI, is also a dial. var. thereof: (TA:) or he made one of his eyelids to cleave to the other, that he might not see a thing, by reason of shame: (Har p. 19:) or he put one of his eyelids upon the other from dislike of a thing. (Id. p. 492.) [See also 6.] ― -b2- Hence it is used in relation to forbearance: so that one says, OagoDaI EalaI AlqacaI He held, or refrained, notwithstanding annoyance, spontaneously, without being asked, or without constraint: (Msb, TA:) or AgDI EalaI qacFI he bore annoyance patiently. (M, TA.) And AgDI Eanohu He feigned himself neglectful of it; [he closed his eyes from it;] he connived at it; as also AgmD Enh. (TA in art. gmD.) And [sometimes] AlUigoDaMCu means The abstaining from proceeding to extremities. (Mgh in art. jwz.) ― -b3- Hence also, AgDI EalaI AlXRaIoCi He was silent respecting the thing; and so gaDaA↓, aor. yagoDuw. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And AgDI Eanohu Tarofahu means He closed, or turned away, from him, or it, his eye, or eyes; syn. sadRahu [in the CK XadRahu], or SadRahu: (K, TA:) so in the M. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AgDI AllRayolu The night was, or became, dark; (S, Msb, K;) and covered everything (K, TA) with its darkness; from ISd; (TA;) as also gaDaA↓, aor. yagoDuw. (K, TA. [See also guDuwRN.])

6 tgADI c
6. tgADI He contracted, or put together, his eyelids, that he might not see an evil, or unseemly, thing. (Har p. 473. [See also 4.]) ― -b2- And [hence,] tgADI Eanohu i. q. tagaAfala [i. e. He was, or he feigned himself, unmindful, &c., of him, or it]: (K, TA:) like tagaAbaI Enh: mentioned by Az. (TA. [See, again, 4.])

gaDFA c
gaDFA, said by Th to be written [thus] with A but ISd says, I know not why this is; (TA;) [the latter, it seems, holding its last letter to be originally I, not w;] A species of trees, (S, Msb, K,) well known, (K,) the wood of which is of the hardest of wood, and therefore there is hardness in its charcoal; (Msb;) it is of the plants of the sands, and has [sprigs, or foliage, of the kind termed] hadab [q. v.], like that called OaroTFI; (TA;) and its fire is of long continuance: (Har p. 60:) [see also rimovN: Mr. Palgrave (in his Travels, i. 38,) describes it as a shrub believed by him to be peculiar to the Arabian Peninsula, “ of the genus Euphorbia, with a woody stem, often five or six feet in height, and innumerable round green twigs, very slender and flexible, forming a large feathery tuft, not ungraceful to the eye, while it affords some kind of shelter to the traveller, and food to his camels: ”] the sing. [or rather n. un.] is gaDaApN: (K:) and AHn says that sometimes gaDaAtN is a pl. [of the n. un.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, ciYobu gaDFA [A wolf of trees, or shrubs, called gaDFA]; (S, K;) or, as in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeyà ciYobu AlgaDaA; and such is the most abominable, or malignant, or noxious, of wolves; for he comes not into close proximity to men save when he desires to attack: or this means the wolf of the covert of trees: for ― -b3- gaDFA signifies also A covert of trees: (TA:) and a gayoDap [i. e. thicket; or collection of tangled, or confused, or dense, trees; &c.]. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Oaholu AlgaDaA is an appellation of the people of Nejd, (K, TA,) because of the abundance of [the trees called] gDA there. (TA.)

baEiyrN gaDK c
baEiyrN gaDK A camel having a complaint of his belly from eating of the trees called gaDFA: and UibilN gaDiyapN and gaDaAyaA [camels having such a complaint]; (S, K;) like ramivapN and ramaAvaI. (S.)

gaDoyaA c
gaDoyaA: see gaDoyaMCu. ― -b2- Also, (K, TA,) determinate, and imperfectly decl., like [its syn.] hunayodapu, (TA,) A hundred camels: (IAar, K, TA:) held by ISk to be so called as being likened to a place producing [an abundance of] gaDFA [i. e. the trees thus called]: AA has mentioned it with the article Al, saying that AlgaDoyaA signifies a hundred. (TA.)

gaDoyaMCu c
gaDoyaMCu A land (OaroDN) abounding with the trees called gaDFA. (S, K.) ― -b2- And, as also gaDoyaA↓, A place in which is a collection of the trees called gaDFA; (K, TA;) a place where they grow. (TA.) ― -b3- And the former, Rugged land or ground. (TA.)

guDuwRN c
guDuwRN Intense darkness of the night. (IKtt, TA. [Perhaps in this sense an inf. n. of which the verb is gaDaA: see 4, last sentence.]) ― -b2- And The eating of the trees called gaDFA. (IKtt, TA. [App. in this sense an inf. n. of which the verb is gaDaA.]) ＝ -A2- And A state of muchness, abundance, copiousness, fulness, or completeness, or a thing. (K. [See also 1, second sentence.])

rajulN gaDiIRN Eani AlxanaA c
rajulN gaDiIRN Eani AlxanaA or Eani AlfaHoXaMCi [A man who refrains from taking notice of that which is foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene,] may be from gaDaA; or it may be from OagoDaI, similar to OaliymN and wajiyEN; but the former derivation is the better. (TA.)

gaDawiIRN c
gaDawiIRN a rel. n. from AlgaDaA [the trees thus called], and applied to a camel [app. as meaning That is fond of, or wont to feed upon, the trees called gaDFA]. (S.)

gaDoyaAnapN c
gaDoyaAnapN A herd of camels of generous race: (K, TA:) mentioned by Az, from AA. (TA.)

gaADK c
gaADK Dark; applied to night (layol); as also mugoDK↓, but this latter is rare: (S, Msb:) and so gaADiyapN, (S, K,) applied to a night (layolap): (S:) or, thus applied, accord. to Az, intensely dark. (TA.) ― -b2- And gaADiyapN signifies also Bright, or shining brightly; (S, K;) applied to a night, (thus in one of my copies of the S,) or to fire (naAr): (so in other copies of the S and in the TA:) thus having two contr. meanings. (S, K.) ― -b3- And Great; applied to a fire (nAr): a signification said by Az to be taken from the fire of the tree called gaDFA, which is of the best of firewood. (TA.) ＝ -A2- baEiyrN gaADK A camel that eats the trees called gaDFA: and UibilN gaADiyapN and gawaADK [camels that eat those trees]. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- XaIoCN gaADK A thing that is much in quantity, abundant, copious, full, or complete. (K.) ― -b2- And rajulN gaADK A man having food and clothing; or having a good state, or condition, in respect of food, and having clothing; sufficed, or satisfied. (K.)

mugoDK c
mugoDK: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 gaTRahu fiI AlmaMCi c
1. gaTRahu fiI AlmaMCi, aor.
gaTuTa
, (S, Msb, K,) and
gaTiTa
, (K,) [the latter contr. to analogy,] inf. n. gaTRN, (S, Msb,) He immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him, or it, in the water: (S, Msb, K:) he made him to plunge, or dive, in, or into, the water: (S:) [Golius adds, as from Ibn-Maaroof, head-downwards; but it is not so in my copy of the KL:] and gatRahu signifies the same. (TA in art. gt.) ― -b2- And gaTRahu, inf. n. gaTRN, He pressed, or squeezed, him, or it, (EaSarahu,) vehemently; and i. q. kabasahu [q. v.]. (TA.) [And gatRahu, q. v., has a similar meaning.] ＝ -A2- gaTRa, aor.
gaTiTa
, inf. n. gaTiyTN, said of a he-camel, (S, Msb, K,) He brayed; syn. hadara: (K:) or he brayed, (hadara, AZ, S,) or made a sound, (SawRata, Msb,) in the XiqoXiqap [or bursa faucium]: when not in the XqXqp, it is termed hadiyrN: you say of the she-camel, tahodiru; not tagiTRu; (AZ, S, Msb;) because she has no XqXqp: (AZ, S:) or, as some say, he brayed, but not in the XqXqp. (L.) ― -b2- gaTRa, aor. as above, (Msb, K, *) and inf. n. as above (S, Msb, K *) and gaTRN, (TA,) said of a person sleeping, (S, Msb, K,) and of one strangled, or throttled, (S, K,) and of an animal slaughtered, (K,) He emitted a sound; (K;) in which sense it is also said of a lynx, and of a leopard, and of a bustard: (TA:) or snored, or snorted: (S, TA:) or sent back his breath up to his fauces so that it was heard by persons around him: (Msb:) or emitted a sound with his breath, reiterating his breath where he found not an easy passage [for it]. (TA.) ― -b3- gaTRati Alburomapu The stone cooking-pot boiled audibly. (TA.) ― -b4- See also gatRa, near the end of the paragraph.

3 gATR HuwtFA c
3. gATR HuwtFA He vied, or contended, with a fish in plunging, or diving. (JK in art. qms.)

6 tgATR Alqawomu c
6. tgATR Alqawomu The people, or company of men, vied, or contended, one with another, in plunging, or diving, (tamaAqaluwA,) in the water. (S.) And AlSRiboyaAnu yatagaATRuwna fiI AlbaHori The children vie, or contend, one with another, in plunging, or diving, (yataqaAmasuwna,) in the sea or great river. (A in art. qms.)

7 AngTR fiI AlmaMCi c
7. AngTR fiI AlmaMCi He (a man, TA) became immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, in the water; or he plunged, or dived, in the water. (S, Msb, TA.)

R. Q. 1 gaTogaTa AlbaHoru c
R. Q. 1. gaTogaTa AlbaHoru [inf. n. gaTogaTapN] The
waves of the sea became high (Ealato), so in some copies of the K, or estuated (galato); so in other copies of the K, and in the L; (TA;) as also tagaTogaTa↓. (O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And gaTogaTati Alqidoru [The contents of the cooking-pot] made a sound: or boiled vehemently. (K.) ― -b3- And gaTogaTa Ealayohi, said of sleep, It overcame him. (L, K, TA.)

R. Q. 2 tagaTogaTa c
R. Q. 2. tagaTogaTa: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also It (a thing) became separated, or dispersed. (Sgh, K, TA.)

gaTaATN c
gaTaATN The [bird called the] qaTaA [i. e. the sandgrouse]: (M, K:) or a species thereof, (S, K,) or, as some say, a species of bird not of the qTA, (TA,) dust-coloured in the backs and the bellies (S, K, TA) and the bodies, (S, TA,) black in the inner sides of the wings, (S, K, TA,) long in the legs and the necks, and slender, not collecting in flocks, two or three at most being found together: (S, TA:) n. un. with p: (S, K:) it is said that the qTA compose two species: the short in the legs, yellow in the necks, black in the primary feathers of the wings, of a white hue tinged with red (Suhob) in the tertials, are the kudoriyRap and the juwniyRap: and the long in the legs, white in the bellies, dust-coloured in the backs, wide in the eyes are the gTAT: AHát says that in the OaxodaEaAni [by which is here meant, as in some other instances, the places of the two veins so called in the neck] of the gaTaATap are what resemble two decorations, two lines, black and white; and it is slender, [but] exceeding the mukRaMC: accord. to Skr, it is a bird resembling the qTA. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the paragraph here following.

guTaATN c
guTaATN The commencement of the dawn: (S, K:) or a remaining portion of the blackness of the night: (S, * K:) or the commingling of the darkness of the last part of the night with the light of the first part of the day: (TA:) and (K) the saHar [or period a little before daybreak; as also gaTaATN↓. (Th, K, TA.)

gaTogaTapN c
gaTogaTapN a word imitative of The cry of the [bird called the] qaTaA: (S, K:) ― -b2- and of The sound of the [vehemently-boiling] cooking-pot. (TA.)

qidorN mugaTogiTapN c
qidorN mugaTogiTapN A cooking-pot vehemently boiling. (S.)

Q. 1 gaTorafa c
Q. 1. gaTorafa He (i. e. God) made persons to be [gaTaAriyf i. e. chiefs, &c., (pl. of giToriyfN,) or] noble. (Ham p. 793.) ― -b2- [And He treated violently, unjustly. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)] ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

Q. 2 tagaTorafa c
Q. 2. tagaTorafa He sought chiefdom, or lordship; [&c.;] from giToriyfN meaning sayRidN. (O.) ― -b2- And He magnified himself, or was proud: (El-Ahmar, O, K:) [and so, app., gaTorafa↓, for] gaTorafapN and tagaTorufN and tagatorufN signify takabRurN: (S:) [or] he was proud, haughty, or self-conceited, in walk (IAar, O, K) especially. (IAar, O)

gaTorafapN c
gaTorafapN [app. an inf. n. of gaTorafa, q. v.; and, used as a simple subst., signifying Self-magnification, or pride: (see Q. 2:) or] pride, haughtiness, or self-conceit: and play, or sport; or such as is vain, or unprofitable. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

giToraAfN c
giToraAfN: see giToriyfN, in two places.

guToruwfN c
guToruwfN: see the following paragraph.

giTorawofN c
giTorawofN: see the following paragraph.

giToriyfN c
giToriyfN The hawk, or falcon; syn. baAzK: this is said to be the primary signification: (Ham p. 793:) or the young one thereof (Ibn-'Abbád, S, O, K:) or the hawk, or falcon, (baAzK,) that has been taken from its nest: as also giToraAfN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- And A sayRid [i. e. chief, or lard, &c.]: (S:) or a sayRid that is high-horn, or noble, (Lth, O, K,) or generous: said to be so called as being likened to the hawk, or falcon: (Ham ubi suprà:) and liberal, bountiful, generous, noble, and youthful: (ISk, O, K:) or a goodly, or comely, youth or young man. (TA:) and giToraAfN↓ signifies the same: (ISk, O, K:) pl. gaTaArifapN (O, K, TA) and gaTaAriyfu and gaTaArifu. (TA.) Also Goodly, or beautiful; and so guToruwfN↓ and giTorawofN↓: (Ibn- 'Abbád, O. K:) or the last of these signifies a youth, or young man, such as is Zariyf [i. e. excel-lent, or elegant in mind, manners, and address, or speech, and in person. &c.]. (AA, O, K.) ― -b3- Also The common fly: syn. cubaAbN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) ― -b4- And EunuqN giToriyfN A wide neck. (O, TA.:) as also xiToriyfN (TA.)

1 gaTasahu c
1. gaTasahu, (S, A, K,) aor.
gaTisa
, (S, TA,) inf. n. gaTosN; (S;) or gTRshu↓, (Msb,) inf. n. tagoTiysN; (TA;) or both: (A. TA;) He immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him or it, in water. (S, A, Msb * K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] gaTRasaniI↓ fiI baHori QnoEumihi He overwhelmed me in the sea of his benefits, or favours]. (A.) ＝ -A2- gaTasa, aor.
gaTisa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. gaTosN, (Msb,) He, or it, became immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, in water or he immersed, or immerged himself, plunged, or dived, in water (Msb, * K) ― -b2- gaTasa fiI AlUinaMCi He put his mouth into the vessel and so drank. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A3- gaTasato bihi AllRujamu Death took him away: (Sgh, K:) a dial. var. of EaTasato [q. v.]. (TA.)

2 gaTRasa
2: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

6 tgATsA c
6. tgATsA They two vied, or contended, each with the other, in plunging, or diving, (A, K,) in water; (K;) syn. tamaAqalaA (A, K) and tagaATRaA (A) and tagaAmasaA. (TA.) And tgATswA They vied, or contended, one with another, in plunging, or diving, in water; syn. tagaATRuwA. (TA.) ＝ -A2- tgATs He feigned himself negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless, not being really so; (Sgh, K;) and tgATX is a dial. var. of the same: both are from Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer (TA.) You say, tgATs Eanohu He feigned himself negligent of it, &c.; (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA in art. gTX;) and [app. in like manner] tgATshu. (IAar, TA in art. EmX.)

gaTRaAsN c
gaTRaAsN One who dives to the bottom of water to fetch the shells that contain pearls, &c. (TA.)

layolN gaATisN c
layolN gaATisN Dark night: as also gaATiXN. (IDrd.)

magoTisN c
magoTisN A place in which one plunges, or dives. (TA.)

magonaTiysN c
magonaTiysN and its variations, here mentioned in the S and L and K, see in art. mgnTs.

1 gaTaXa c
1. gaTaXa, aor.
gaTiXa
, (A, K,) inf. n. gaToXN, (TK,) [or perhaps gaTaXN, q. v.,] It (the night) became dark; (A, K;) as also OagoTaXa↓: (S, K:) or gaTaXN is syn. with sadafN; and hence AllRayolu AgTX↓ [app. meaning the night became dark, or black]. (As, A, TA.) [See gaTaXN, below.] ＝ -A2- gaTiXa, (S, TA.) [aor.
gaTaXa
,] inf. n. gaTaXN, (TA,) He had an affection resembling weakness of the sight, with a shedding of tears at most times. (S, TA.) And gaTiXa AlbaSaru [The eye, or sight, became weak, and affected with a shedding of tears at most times] and so AgTAXR↓, like AHmArR [in measure] (TA and Eayonuhu tgTRXt↓ His eye became dark, or dim, (IDrd, K,) and weak-sighted. (IDrd.)

4 AgTX c
4. AgTX: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- AgTXwA They entered into, or upon, the darkness [of night]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AgTX QllRehu AllRayola God made the night dark, (Fr. S, A, * K)

5 tagaTRaXa
5: see 1. last sentence.

6 tgATX Eanohu c
6. tgATX Eanohu He feigned himself negligent, or heedless, of it; (Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer, K;) namely, a thing, or an affair; as also tgATs; (Aboo-Sa'eed;) and [app. in like manner] tgATXhu: (IAar, TA in art. EmX:) or he feigned himself blind to it; either in the eyes or intellectually; syn. tEAmI. (TA.) You say also, mararotu bihi fatagaATaXa [I passed by him and he feigned himself heedless, or blind]. (A.)

11 UigoTaAoXRa
11: see 1, last sentence.

gaTaXN c
gaTaXN i. q. sadafN [app. meaning The darkness, or blackness, of night]: (As, A, TA:) Aboo-Turáb, (L,) or AZ, (TA,) makes it to be after the gabaX: (L, TA:) and guTaAXN↓ also signifies the darkness and confusedness of night. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Weakness of sight, with a shedding of tears at most times: (K:) or an affection resembling this. (S, TA.)

gaTiXN c
gaTiXN: see OagoTaXu, in two places.

falaApN gaToXaI c
falaApN gaToXaI, (As, A 'Obeyd, Kr, S, A,) or gaToXaMCu, (O, K,) if from gaTaXa AllRayolu. originally [and properly] like EamoyaMCu, but by poetic license it is made perfectly decl., [with tenween,] but if gaToXaAnu occurred, as meaning “ dark, ” it would
be a fem., written [gaToXaI,] with I (O, TA,) or both forms, without and with medd, (TA,) A desert, or waterless desert, that is dark: (Kr:) or of which the ways through it are obscure; (As, A 'Obeyd,. A, TA;) where one cannot find the right way. (As, A 'Obeyd, S, K, TA.) You say, rakibonaA falaApF gaToXaI wanaHonu karimaAlihaA EaToXaI [We travelled upon a desert, or waterless desert, of which the ways through it were obscure, and we were like its sands thirsty]. (A.)

guTaAXN c
guTaAXN: see gaTaXN.

gaATiXN c
gaATiXN: see what next follows.

OagoTaXu c
OagoTaXu Dark; applied to night; as also gaATiXN↓ and gaTiXN↓: [fem. gaToXaMCu: see gaToXaI:] and tagoTiyXN↓, an inf. n. [of gaTRaXa] used as an epithet, signifies the same, applied to sight. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A man having the affection of the eyes termed gaTaXN; (S, TA;) as also gaTiXN↓: (TA:) fem. of the former gaToXaMCu. (S, TA.)

tagoTiyXN c
tagoTiyXN: see the next preceding paragraph.

mutagaATiXN c
mutagaATiXN Feigning blindness to a thing. (S.) [See 6.]

gaTafN c
gaTafN Ampleness of the means, or circumstances, of life: (S, O, K:) like gaDafN. (O.) ＝ -A2- And Length, and a folding, (O, K,) in the edges of the eyelids, (O,) or of the edges of the eyelids: (K:) or length, and then a bending [app. upwards] of the eyelashes: occurring in a trad., and, as some relate it, with E; but Er-Riyáshee knew not this, and thought it to be gaTaf: (TA:) or abundance of the hair of the eyebrow: (K:) said by ISh to be syn. with waTafN: (TA:) but by IDrd said to be the contr. of waTaf, and signifying paucity of the hair of the eyebrows: (O, TA:) and it is said to be sometimes used as meaning paucity of the eyelashes. (TA.) [See also gaDafN.]

gTfAn c
[gTfAn, in a note to “ Abulf. Ann. ” i. 194, thought by Reiske to be the name of a bird, is app. a mistake for some word relating to the cry of the bird called gaTaAT.]

gaATuwfN c
gaATuwfN A miSoyadap [or snare, trap, gin, or net]: a dial. var. of EaATuwfN [q. v.]. (TA.)

OagoTafu c
OagoTafu A life (EayoXN) ample in its means, or circumstances: like OagoDafu. (S, O.) ＝ -A2- And syn. with OawoTafu in relation to the edges of the eyelids [Having what is termed gaTafN as meaning waTafN]. (TA.)

1 gaTalati AlsRamaMCu c
1. gaTalati AlsRamaMCu (JK, O, K) yawomanaA hecaA, (JK, O,) and OagoTalat↓, (JK, O, K,) The sky has [by its becoming overcast] concealed the light of the sun [in this our day]: (JK:) or its dajon [or shade of the clouds in a rainy day, or its abundant rain, or its covering of clouds full of moisture, and dark, but containing no rain,] has overspread. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- And gaTila AllRayolu, aor.
gaTala
, (K, TA,) inf. n. gaTalN, (TA,) The darkness of the night became confused. (K, TA.)

4 OagoTala
4: see the preceding paragraph.

Q. Q. 1 gaToyala c
Q. Q. 1. gaToyala, (O, K, TA,) with the T before the I, (K, * TA,) He was, or became, abundant in his property, or cattle, and his dependents, or relations and household, or servants, (O, K, TA,) and his weal. (O, TA.) ＝ -A2- And gayoTala, (O, TA,) thus correctly in the following senses, accord. to the K gaToyala, but this is a mistake, (TA,) He made his traffic to be in beasts of the bovine kind, bulls or cows, (O, K, TA,) which are termed gayoTalN. (TA.) ― -b2- And gayoTala Alqawomu fiI AlHadiyvi The people, or party, pushed on, pressed on, or were copious or profuse, in discourse; or entered into it; and their voices became high: (K, * TA:) on the authority of El-Hejeree. (TA.) [Accord. to the K gaToyala, which is said in the TA to be a mistake.]

Q. Q. 4 AigoTaOalRa c
Q. Q. 4. AigoTaOalRa It became heaped up, or it mounted, one part upon another: (A 'Obeyd, O, K, TA:) and so AigoZaOalRa, mentioned by IKtt: (TA:) the former verb occurs in a verse of Hassán Ibn-Thábit, said of the sea. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And, said of the heat, It rose, or became raised. (R, TA.)

gayoTalN c
gayoTalN is pl. of gayoTalapN↓, [or rather a coll. gen. n. of which the latter is the n. un.,] signifying Numerous dense or tangled trees: (S, O:) or the latter word signifies thus: (K:) or it (the latter) signifies also dense, or tangled, trees: (S, O:) or both signify thus: and also anything confused, or mixed: (Ham p. 213:) or the latter has this last meaning: and signifies also a collection of trees and of herbs; (AHn, TA;) and a collection of [the common tamarisks, called] TarofaMC; (K, TA;) as AHn says on one occasion. (TA.) ― -b2- And [the former, or perhaps both words,] The light of the dawn when mingling with the darkness of the night. (Ham p. 213 [q. v.].) ― -b3- And gayoTalu AlDRuHaI signifies Hayovu takuwnu AlXRamosu mino maXoriqihaA kahayoYatihaA mino magoribihaA waqota AlZRuhori, (JK, O, and so in copies of the K,) or baEoda AlZRuhori, (accord. to the text of the K in the TA,) or waqota AlEaSori: (so in some copies of the K, as mentioned in the TK:) [the last is evidently the right reading; and the meaning, The period of the earlier part of the forenoon, after sunrise, when the sun is distant from its place of rising like as it is from its place of setting at the time of the EaSor (q. v.): AlZhr is probably an old mistranscription.] ＝ -A2- Also Beasts of the bovine kind, bulls or cows. (TA.) [See also gayoTalapN, last explanation.] ― -b2- And The cat: (K, TA:) as also xayoTalN: on the authority of Kr. (TA.)

gayoTalapN c
gayoTalapN: see gayoTalN. ― -b2- Also A company, or collection, (Th, K, TA,) of men: (K, TA:) or the assembling of men, and their becoming in a dense, or confused, state. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- And Darkness; as also gayoTuwlN↓; (K;) or the latter signifies confusedness of darkness; (IDrd, O;) or signifies also dense (lit. accumulated) darkness. (K. [The Arabs describe thick darkness as “ darknesses one above another: ” see Kur xxiv. 40.]) And The intricate and confused blackness of night: (S, O, K:) or gayoTalapu AllRayoli signifies the confusedness and denseness of the darkness [of night]: and the pl. is gayaATilu. (TA.) ― -b4- Also A confusion, or mixture, of cries or shouts or noises; (S, * O, * K;) and so gayoTuwlN↓: (IDrd, O, K:) gayoTalaAtN, pl. of the former, signifies clamours of men: and the sing., the numerous cries or shouts or noises, and the dust, of war, or battle. (TA.) ― -b5- And The overpowering influence of drowsiness: (O, K:) [or so gayoTalapu nuEaAsK: pl. gayaATilu:] one says, rayRavatohu gayaATilu AlnRuEaAsi meaning gawaAlibuhu [i. e. The overpowering influences of drowsiness retarded him, or made him late]. (A, TA.) ― -b6- And The means of happiness of the present world or state of existence: (K:) or gayaATilu AldRunoyaA means those means of happiness: (O:) or this latter phrase means the consecutive means of happiness of the present world. (TA.) And The eating and drinking and rejoicing, with security. (Fr, O, K.) ― -b7- And AlgayoTalapu (accord. to Fr, as is said in the O and TA,) signifies AlmaAlu AlmuTogiI [as though most probably meaning Property that causes extravagance]: (O, K, TA:) [but from what SM remarks respecting it, I can only infer that he holds AlmuTogiI to be an epithet applied to the cow as signifying “ having a youngling, ” which is termed TagoyaA or TugoyaA, (like AlmuEojilu signifying “ having a calf, ” which is termed EijolN, and several other epithets of the same form,) and in like manner applied to a collective number of cows, though I do not find it mentioned in this sense; i. e., that he understands; and would explain, AlmaAlu AlmuTogiI as signifying The cattle, meaning cows, having younglings: but his derivation of it seems to be far-fetched; and perhaps he may have been led to assign this meaning to it by another explanation of gayoTalapN with which it is agreeable, and which will be found in the next sentence:] it is not [he says] from TagaA, aor. yaToguw, signifying Oasorafa fiI AlZRulomi, as it seems to be at first sight; but from Tagato said of the baqarap waHoXiyRap, signifying SaAHato, the like of which is also said of the vawor. (TA.) ― -b8- gayoTalapN signifies also Such as has milk, of gazelles, or antelopes, and of beasts of the bovine kind [perhaps meaning of the wild species, i. e. bovine antelopes]; (S, O, K;) pl. gayaATilu: (S, O:) accord. to AO, the baqarap waHoXiyRap [or bovine antelope]: (S, O:) Th says that it signifies the baqarap [or beast of the bovine kind, bull or cow], not particularizing the wild species. (TA.) [See also gayoTalN, last explanation but one.]

gayoTuwlN c
gayoTuwlN: see gayoTalapN, first quarter, in two places.

guwTaAlapN c
guwTaAlapN i. q. rawoDapN [generally meaning A meadow]. (IAar, O, K.)

XajarN mugoTaYilRN c
XajarN mugoTaYilRN Dense, or tangled, trees. (JK.
[See also gayoTalN.]) And guSuwnN Soft, or tender, branches, (O, TA,) having dense leaves. (TA.)

giTamRN c
giTamRN A great sea, (S, K, TA,) abundant in water; (S, TA;) and giToyamRN↓, (K, TA,) like qiroXabRu, (TA,) [in the CK gaTiyom,] signifies the same; as also gaTamoTamN↓: (K, TA:) one says baHorN giTamRN. (S.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A man large (S, K) in disposition (S) or dispositions; (K;) [i. e.] liberal, or bountiful: (TA:) one says rajulN giTamRN. (S.) ― -b3- And A numerous company, or collective body: (K, TA:) one says jamoEN giTamRN. (S, TA.) And EadadN giToyamRN↓, like qiroXabRN, A large number. (TA.) [See also guTaAmiTN, in art. gTmT.]

giToyamRN c
giToyamRN: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

gaTamuTamN c
gaTamuTamN: see the first paragraph.

gayoTamRN c
gayoTamRN Thick milk. (K, TA.)

Q. 1 gaTomaTapN c
Q. 1. gaTomaTapN [an inf. n. of which the verb is gaTomaTa] The dashing together of the waves of the sea; as also tagaTomuTN↓: (K:) you say, tagaTomaTa↓ Ealayohi Almawoju The waves dashed together upon him so as to cover him. (TA.) ― -b2- And The sea's being great in the waves, and abundant in the water; as also giTomaATN; each an inf. n. (IDrd, K, TA: but omitted in the CK.) ― -b3- And The boiling of a cooking-pot: (K:) [or its boiling vehemently; for] you say, gaTomaTati Alqidoru meaning The cooking-pot boiled vehemently; as also tagaTomaTat↓: (TA:) and tagaTomuTN↓ signifies also the sounding of the boiling of a cooking-pot. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And The sounding of a torrent in a valley. (K.)

Q. 2 tagaTomaTa c
Q. 2. tagaTomaTa, and its inf. n.: see the preceding paragraph, in four places. ― -b2- The inf. n. signifies also The making, or sending forth, a sound (S, K) with which, (S,) or in which, (K,) is a roughness. (S, K.)

giTomaATN c
giTomaATN (originally an inf. n., mentioned above: TA:) Waves (mawojN) dashing together. (K, TA.)

guTaAmiTN c
guTaAmiTN (S, K) and gaTomaTiyTN↓ (IDrd, K) The sound of the sea when the waves are great and the water is abundant: (so accord. to copies of the K:) or the sound of the boiling of the sea; (so [the former] in a copy of the S; TA;) or of the boiling of the cooking-pot, and of the waves of the sea: (so in other copies of the S: TA:) and ↓the latter word, also, the sound of water. (IDrd, TA.) ＝ -A2- And baHorN guTaAmiTN and gaTawomaTN↓ and gaTomaTiyTN↓ A sea great in the waves, and abundant in the water. (K.) guTaAmiT is applied in a verse of Ru-beh to a number of men [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) Multitudinous]. (TA voce giToyamRN, by which it is followed.)

gaTawomaTN c
gaTawomaTN: see the next preceding paragraph.

gaTomaTiyTN c
gaTomaTiyTN: see guTaAmiTN, in three places. [Accord. to J, the m in the words of this article is augmentative.]

1 gaTaA AlXRaIoCa c
1. gaTaA AlXRaIoCa, (K, TA,) first pers. gaTawotu, aor.
1a2u2a
, (Msb,) inf. n. gaTowN; (TA;) and gaTaI AlXRaIoCa, (K, TA,) first pers. gaTayotu, aor.
1a2i2a
(S, Msb,) inf. n. gaToIN; (S, TA;) and gaTaI Ealayohi; (K;) and gTRAhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. tagoTiyapN; (S;) or this has an intensive signification; (Msb;) [but it is very often used in the sense of gaTaAhu without teshdeed;] and AgTAhu↓; (Msb, K;) He, or it, covered, or concealed, the thing; (K and TA in explanation of all;) and came, or became, upon it, or over it. (K and TA in explanation of all except the first.) Ealayohi AlmiXomalapa gaTRaI↓, a phrase used by Lh, is thought by [Sd to mean He covered [or enveloped] him with the [garment called] mXmlp, i. e. gaTRaAhu bihaA. (TA in art. Xml.) ― -b2- gaTaIa AllRayolu fulaAnFA means The night clad [or covered] such a one with its darkness; as also gTRI↓ (K.) [And the former is also said of the night as though intrans.; an objective complement being app. understood: thus,] gaTaI AllRayolu, (S, K,) aor.
1a2i2a
(S, TA;) as also gaTaA, aor.
1a2u2a
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. gaTowN and guTuwRN; (K, TA;) signifies The night was, or became, dark: (S, K, TA;) [and Freytag states that AgTI↓ is used in this sense in the Deewán of Jereer; like AgDI;] or covered, or concealed, everything with its darkness: (Msb:) or as some say, rose, and covered, and clad, everything. (TA.) ― -b3- AallRehumRa QgoTi EalaI qalobihi is a saying of the Arabs, meaning OagoXi [i. e. O God, put Thou a covering upon, or over, his heart]. (TA.) ― -b4- And one says, gaTaAhu AlXRabaAbu. inf. n. gaToIN and guTiIRN, [but the latter I think doubtful, for it is of a measure extr. as that of an inf. n. of a trans. v.,] meaning Oalobasahu [i. e. Youthfulness, or young manhood, clad him, or invested him as with clothes]; as also gTRAhu↓. (TA.) And [using the former v. as intrans., one says,] gaTaI AlXRabaAbu, (S, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AlXRAbRu,]) aor.
1a2i2a
, inf. n. gaToIN (S, K) and guTiIRN, thus in the S and accord. to ISd and IKtt and Sgh, but accord. to the K guToIN, (TA,) meaning AimotalaOa [i. e. The sap, or vigour, of youth or young manhood became full, or mantled, in a person]. (S, * K, TA.) ― -b5- And gaTati AlXRajarapu The tree had long branches, spreading over the ground, (K, TA,) so that it covered what was around it; (TA; mentioned in art. gTI;) like OagoTat↓. (K, TA.) ― -b6- And gaTaA AlmaMCu, (S, K, TA,) and gaTaI, (TA,) The water rose, or rose high, (S, * K, TA.) and became abundant. (TA.) And gaTaA EalaI AlXRaIoCi is said of anything as meaning It rose, and became high, upon, or over, the thing. (S, TA.) And gaTayaAnu AlbaHori signifies The overflowing of the sea, or great river. (TA.) ― -b7- And gaTati AlnRaAqapu, (K, TA,) inf. n. gaToIN, (TA,) The she-camel proceeded in her course, (K, TA,) and stretched forth. (TA.) ― -b8- And faEala bihi maA gaTaAhu is mentioned in the M as meaning saMCahu [i. e. He did to him that which occasioned evil to him; or that which displeased, grieved, or vexed, him]: but this may be a mistranscription, for EaZaAhu, which is mentioned in the K in this sense: or the two verbs may be dial. vars. (TA. [See also a similar explanation of gaTaAhu in the first paragraph of art. XrI.])

2 1a2RaRa
2: see the preceding paragraph, in four places.

4 Oa1o2a2a
4: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- AgTI Alkaromu The grape-vine had the sap running in it, (K, TA,) and increased. (TA.)

5 tgTRI bihi c
5. tgTRI bihi (S, MA) He was, or became, covered with it; [or he covered himself with it; namely, his garment [&c.]; (MA;) [and so AgtTI↓; for] AgtTI signifies the same as tgTRI. (K.)

8 Ui1ota2a2a
8: see what next precedes.

UinRahu lacuwgaTawaAnK c
UinRahu lacuwgaTawaAnK Verily he is one possessing might, and power of resistance, in his people, or party; and possessing abundance [of defenders, or of the means of defence &c.]. (K.)

giTaMCN c
giTaMCN A cover, or covering; i. e. a thing by which, or with which, a thing or person is covered, or concealed: (Msb, K: *) or a thing by which or with which, thou art covered, or coverest thyself: (S:) or a thing by which, or with which, thou art covered or another thing is covered: so in the M: accord. to Er-Rághib, a thing that is put upon, or over, a thing, such as a Tabaq [meaning cover, or lid,] and the like thereof, like as the giXaMC is of clothing and the like thereof; (TA:) or the cover, or lid. of a cooking-pot or the like: (MA:) pl. OugoTiyapN: (Msb, TA;) it is [said to be] from the phrase gaTaIi AllRayolu. (Msb.) ― -b2- And it is metaphorically applied to denote (tropical:) Ignorance: whence [accord. to some] the saying in the Kur [l. 21], fakaXafonaA Eanoka giTaMCaka fabaSaruka Qloyawoma HadiydN (tropical:) [But we have removed from thee thine ignorance; and thy sight, or thy mental perception, to-day, is sharp, or piercing: see HadiydN]. (TA.)

giTaAyapN c
giTaAyapN A thing, of the stuffing of clothes, with which a woman has covered herself, (K, TA,) beneath her clothes, (TA,) such as the gilaAlap [q. v.] and the like: (K, TA:) [it is said that] the I therein is substituted for w. (TA.)

gaATK c
gaATK [act. part. n. of 1, Covering, or concealing, &c. ― -b2- And hence,] layolN gaATK Dark night: or night rising, and covering, and clothing, everything. (TA.) ― -b3- And XajarapN gaATiyapN A tree having long branches, spreading over the ground, so that
it covers what is around it. (TA.) ― -b4- And maMCN gaATK Abundant water. (TA.)

gaATiyapN c
gaATiyapN [as a subst.] A grape-vine covering the ground: (IB in art. Ejb:) occurring in a verse cited in that art.: so called because of its high growth and its spreading: (TA in the present art.:) or a grape-vine having many nawaAmK, i. e. branches. (T and TA in art. nmI.)

magoTiIRN c
magoTiIRN A thing covered, or concealed, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, huwa magoTiIRN AlqinaAEi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He is obscure in respect of reputation. (TA.)

mugaTRaApN c
mugaTRaApN i. q. mugabRaApN [meaning A pitfall covered over with earth]. (TA in art. gbI, q. v.)

5 tgfRfhu c
5. tgfRfhu He took the gufRap [i. e. what was sufficient for his subsistence] thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

8 AgtfRt Alfarasu c
8. AgtfRt Alfarasu, (S,) or AldRaAbRapu, (O, K,) inf. n. AigotifaAfN, (S,) The mare, or the beast, obtained what was sufficient for its subsistence of the [herbage called] rbiyE; (S, O, K;) as also tgfRft↓: (TA:) or [in the K “ and ”] acquired somewhat of fatness: (S, O, K:) each of these meanings is mentioned as on the authority of Ks: (S:) AZ mentions the phrase AgtfRt AlmaAlu, (S,) or AgtfR AlmAl, (O,) and says that the meaning is [the cattle obtained] middling pasture, and middling fatness. (S, O.) And AigotifaAfN signifies also The taking [with the mouth] fodder, or provender. (TA.) [See also 8 in art. gv.] ＝ -A2- Aigotafafotuhu I gave him somewhat, little in quantity. (O, K.)

gafRN c
gafRN Such as has become dry of the leaves of ruTob [or juicy herbage (in the CK raTob)]: (O, K:) as also qafRN. (TA.)

gufRapN c
gufRapN A sufficiency of the means of subsistence: (S, O, K:) like guvRapN and gubRapN. (O in art. gv.) See an ex. in a verse cited voce TabaEN. ― -b2- And A thing [or portion of pasture or fodder] that a camel takes with his mouth in haste. (Sh, O, K.) ― -b3- And Old, and wasted or withered, such as is the worst, of pasture or herbage. (TA.) ― -b4- And A portion remaining of the contents of a vessel and of an udder. (TA.) ― -b5- And The mouse; because it is sufficient food for the cat. (IDrd, * O, * K.)

gafiyfapN c
gafiyfapN Such as is beautiful and bright, in full maturity and in blossom, of herbs, or leguminous plants. (K.)

jaMCa EalaI gifRaAnihi c
jaMCa EalaI gifRaAnihi He came at the time thereof: (O, K:) so says Ibn-'Abbád: (O:) or (K) it is correctly EifRaAnihi, with the unpointed E (O, K,) originally UifRaAnihi. (O.)

1 gafarahu c
1. gafarahu, aor.
gafira
, (K,) inf. n. gaforN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He covered, veiled, concealed, or hid, it; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) i. e., anything. (TA.) This is the primary signification. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence] gafar AlXRayoba biAlxiDaAbi He covered, or concealed, the white, or hoary, hair with dye; (K;) as also Oagofarahu↓. (TA.) ― -b3- And gafara AlmataAEa, (S, K,) fiI AlwiEaMCi, (K,) He put the goods, or utensils, into the bag, or receptacle, and concealed them; (K;) as also Agfrhu↓. (K.) ― -b4- [Hence also] gafara lahu canobahu, (S, Msb, * K,) aor.
gafira
, (K,) inf. n. magofaripN, (S, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and guforaAnN and gaforN (S, Msb, K) and gufuwrN (Lh, K) and gafiyrN and gafiyrpN, (K,) He (God) covered, his sin, crime, or offence; (K;) forgave it; pardoned it; (Msb, K;) as also canobahu Agtfr↓, (S,) or Agtfr lahu maA SanaEa he forgave him what he had done: (Msb:) or guforaAnN and magofirapN, on the part of God, signify the preserving a man from being touched by punishment: and sometimes gafara lahu signifies [he forgave him, or pardoned him: and also] he forgave him, or pardoned him, apparently, but not really; and thus it is used in the Kur xlv. 13, accord. to the B. (TA.) As an ex. of the last of the inf. ns. mentioned above on the authority of the K, the following saying, of a certain Arab, is cited: OasoOaluka Algafiyraho waAlnRaAqapa Algazyiraho waAlEizRa fiI AlEaXiyraho faUinRahaA Ealayoka yasiyraho [I beg of Thee (O God) forgiveness, and a she-camel abounding in milk, and might among the kinsfolk, or in the tribe, for they are to Thee things easy]. (TA.) [See also the paragraph commencing with gafiyrapN.] ― -b5- In the following saying of Zuheyr, the verb is used tropically:
OaDaAEato falamo tugofaro lahaA gafalaAtuhaA
meaning [She lost her young one, and] her acts of negligence with respect to her young one were not forgiven her, by the wild beasts, so they ate it. (TA.) ― -b6- gafara AlOamora biguforatihi↓, (S, * K,) and bigafiyratihi↓, (K,) aor.
gafira
, (S,) [lit. He covered the affair with its cover,] means (assumed tropical:) he rectified the affair with that wherewith it was requisite that it should be rectified. (S, K.) [And Agtfrhu↓ perhaps signifies the same: see murotaOabN, in art. rOb.] ＝ -A2- gafira, aor.
gafara
, (S, K,) inf. n. gafarN, (S,) It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became villous; as also AgfArR↓, (S, K,) inf. n. AigofiyraArN. (S.) ＝ -A3- gafara, (S, K,) aor.
gafira
, inf. n. gaforN, (S,) It (a wound) became recrudescent; or reverted to a bad, or corrupt, state; (S, K;) as also gafira, [of which see another meaning in what follows,] aor.
gafara
, inf. n. gafarN. (S.) And in like manner the former is said of a sick person: (S:) [i. e.] gafara signifies likewise He (a sick person) relapsed into disease, after convalescence; as also gufira: (K, TA:) and in like manner one says of a wounded person. (TA.) And [hence, app.,] it is also said of an excessive lover, meaning He experienced a return of his desire, (K, TA,) after consolation. (TA.) ― -b2- gafira said of a wound signifies also It healed: thus having two contr. meanings. (IKtt, TA.) ＝ -A4- gafara Aljalabu AlsRuwqa, (K, TA,) aor.
gafira
, inf. n. gaforN, (TA,) means raxRaSahaA [more correctly OaroxaSahaA i. e. The beasts, or other things, brought thither for sale, made the market cheap]. (K, TA.)

2 gfRrhu c
2. gfRrhu He said gafara QllRehu lahu [May God cover his sins, &c.; may God forgive him, or pardon him]. (TA, from a trad.)

4 Agfr c
4. Agfr: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- Oagofarato It (land) produced somewhat of gafar, meaning small herbage: (TA:) [i. e.] it produced herbage like the nap of cloth. (O, L, TA. *) ― -b2- And It (land) produced its magaAfiyr [pl. of mugofuwrN, q. v.]. (IAth, O, L, TA.) And Agfr It (the [species of tree, or shrub, called] rimov, S, and the EurofuT, [&c.,] TA) exuded, or produced, its magaAfiyr. (S, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also, i. e. Agfrt, [from guforN, q. v.,] She (a mountaingoat) had a young one, or young ones. (O, TA.) ＝ -A4- And Agfr AlnRaxolu The palm-tress had, upon their unripe dates, what resembled bark, or crust; (O, K, TA;) which the people of El-Medeeneh term AlgafaA [or AlgafaI]. (O, TA.)

5 tgfRr c
5. tgfRr and tamagofara↓ He gathered what is called migofar and mugofuwr [see the latter of these two words]. (S, K.) He who says mugofuwr says xarajonaA natamagofaru↓, and he who says migofar says xrjnA natagafRaru, We went forth to gather mgfwr, or mgfr, from its trees. (S.)

6 tgAfrA c
6. tgAfrA They two prayed for the covering of sins, &c., or for forgiveness, or pardon, each for the other. (TA.)

8 Uigotafara
8: see the first paragraph, in two places.

10 Astgfr QllReha c
10. Astgfr QllReha, (Msb,) and Astgfr AllReh mino canobihi, (S, K,) and licanobihi, (S,) and canobahu, (K,) He begged of God forgiveness, or pardon; (Msb;) he sought of God the covering, or forgiveness, or pardon, of his sin, crime, or offence, (K, TA,) by word and by deed; for so God requires one to do; not with the tongue only. (TA.)

11 UigofaAorRa
11: see the first paragraph.

Q. Q.2 tamagofara c
: see 5, in two places.

gaforN c
gaforN: see gafarN, in two places. ＝ -A2- See also guforN. ＝ -A3- Also The belly. (K.) ＝ -A4- And A certain thing like the [sack called] juwaAliq. (K.) ＝ -A5- And Algaforu is the name of The star [ λ] in the left foot of Virgo: (Kzw in his Descr. of Virgo:) or three obscure stars, (Kzw in his Descr. of the Mansions of the Moon,) or three small stars, (S, K,) [most probably, I think, (not φ and ι and κ, as supposed by Freytag, who refers to Ideler's “ Untersuch. ” pp. 169 and 288, but) ι and κ and λ of Virgo, though said to be] belonging to Libra: (S:) one of the Mansions of the Moon, (S, K,) namely, the Fifteenth. (Kzw in his Descr. of the Mansions.)

guforN c
guforN The young of the mountain-goat; (S, K;) as also gaforN↓; but the former is the more common; (K;) the latter, rare: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OagofaArN and [of mult.] gifarapN (S, K) and gufuwrN: (Kr, K:) the female is termed guforapN: and it is said that guforN is an appellation of one and of a pl. number: the
phrase guforN kaviyrN is mentioned [as meaning many young ones of the mountain-goat]. (TA.)

giforN c
giforN The young of the cow [probably meaning of the bovine antelope called the wild cow]. (ElHejeree, K.) ― -b2- And A certain duwayobRap [by which may be meant a small beast or creeping thing, or an insect]: (IDrd, O, K:) so, says IDrd, they assert. (O.)

gafarN c
gafarN (S, K, TA) and gaforN↓ (S, TA) and gufaArN↓ (S, K, TA) Hair like down, such as is upon the shank of a woman, and upon the forehead, and the like thereof: (S, TA:) or the hair of the neck, and of the jaws, and of the back of the neck; (K, TA;) as also gafiyrN↓ accord. to the copies of the K, but accord. to the L and other lexicons gaforN: and the small, short, hairs of the body. (TA.) ― -b2- And gafarN signifies also The growth of hair in the place of the mane of a horse or similar beast. (TA.) ― -b3- And The nap, or villous substance, upon the surface of a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, K, TA,) and the like thereof; (TA;) and gaforN↓ signifies the same: (K, TA:) n. un. gaforapN [and app. gafarapN]: and gafarN is also expl. as signifying the hudob [app. here meaning likewise nap, or pile, or perhaps the unwoven end,] of a garment, or piece of cloth, and [particularly] of the thin and soft sorts of what are termed xamaAYiS and quTuf [pls. of xamiySapN and qaTiyfapN]; but not the extremities of Oarodiyap and malaAHif [pls. of ridaMCN and miloHafapN]. (TA.) ― -b4- And Small herbage; (K:) [or] a sort of small, sprouting herbage, of the [season called] rabiyE, growing in plain, or soft, land, and upon the [eminences termed] MkAm [pl. of OakamapN]; when green, resembling green passerine birds standing; and when it has dried up, resembling such as are red, not standing. (L, TA. *)

huwagafiru AlqafaA c
huwagafiru AlqafaA means He is one who has [hair such as is termed] gafar upon the back of his neck: and hiIa gafirapu Alwajohi, she is one who has gafar upon her face. (AHn, K, * TA.)

guforapN c
guforapN A cover; a thing with which another thing is covered. (S.) [Hence] one says, gafara AlOamora biguforatihi (S, K) and bigafiyratihi↓ (K) expl. above: see 1.

giforapN HasanapN c
giforapN HasanapN A good manner of covering, forgiving, or pardoning, sins, &c. (Lh, K.)

gufaArN c
gufaArN: see gafarN, first sentence.

gifaArN c
gifaArN A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon the cheek [app. of a camel]. (TA.)

gafuwrN c
gafuwrN: see gaAfirN, in three places.

jamRaMCu gafiyrN c
jamRaMCu gafiyrN A helmet that encloses and embraces the whole head. (K.) AO says, in his “ Book on the Coat of Mail and the Helmet, ” that bayoDapN is a general name for a helmet, which has plates like the bones of the skull, fastened together, edge to edge, by nails. (TA.) ― -b2- jaAWuwA jamRaMCa gafiyrFA, and AljamRaMCa Algafiyra, (S, K,) and jamRaMCa Algafiyri, and jamRFA gafiyrFA, and AljamRa Algafiyra, and jamRa Algafiyri, and jamRaMCa AlgafiyraI↓, and jamRaMCa gafiyrapF↓, and AljamRaMCa Algafiyrapa↓, and jamRaMCa Algafiyrapi↓, and jamRa Algafiyrapi↓, and bijamRaMCi Algafiyri, and bijamRaMCi Algafiyrapi↓, (K,) are phrases meaning They came all together, high and low, none of them remaining behind, and they being many: (S, K:) accord. to Sb, (K,) it (AljmRMC Algfyr, S, which is the only form that he mentions, TA, [or rather the former of these two words,]) is a subst., (S, K,) put in the place of an inf. n., (K,) i. e. put in the accus. case like an inf. n. of the same meaning, (TA,) i. e., [as when you say] mararotu bihimo jumuwmFA kaviyrFA [I passed by them they being very many]: (K:) it is not a verb, [by which is here meant, as in many other instances, an inf. n.,] but is put in the accus. case like an inf. n. of the same meaning, as when you say jaAWuwniI jamiyEFA, and qaATibapF, and TurRFA, and kaAfRapF, [They came to me all together,] and the article Al is prefixed like as it is prefixed in the saying OaworadahaA AlEiraAka, meaning OaworadahaA EiraAkFA [He brought them (the camels) to the water all together]: (S:) Sb says that it is one of those denotatives of state which have the art. Al prefixed, and is extr.; and that Algfyr is an epithet inseparable from AljmRMC; meaning that you do not say AljmRMC and then be silent: (TA:) others hold it to be an inf. n.: IAmb allows it to be in the nom. case, on the condition that hum is understood [before it; i. e., the complete phrase being jaAWuwA humu AljamRaMCu Algafiyru]: and Ks says that the Arabs put AljmRAC Algfyr in the accus. case fiI AltRamaAmi [i. e. in the case of its occurring after a proposition rendered complete by the mention of the agent. as when you say jaMCa Alqawomu AljamRaMCa Algafiyra], and in the nom. case fiI AlnRuqoSaAni [i. e. in the case of its occurring when what precedes it is not a complete proposition, and is only rendered complete by it as the agent, as when you say jaMCa AljamRaMCu Algafyiru]. (K.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad., that Mohammad, being asked by Aboo-Dharr, what was the number of the apostles, answered valevumiAYapK waxamosapa EaXara jamRa Algafiyri, meaning, Three hundred and fifteen: a great number. (Nh, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also gafarN, first sentence.

gifaArapN c
gifaArapN: see migofarN, in three places. ― -b2- Also A piece of rag worn beneath the miqonaEap [q. v.], by which a woman preserves it from the oil or grease [on her head]: (S: [accord to one of my copies of the S, “ preserves her head: ”]) or a piece of rag by which a woman preserves her ximaAr [q. v.] from the oil or grease: (K:) or a piece of rag with which a woman covers the fore part and the hind part (but not the middle) of her head. (TA.) ― -b3- [And A cloth that is spread upon the camel-litter. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)] ― -b4- And A patch (ruqoEap) that is put upon the notch, (S, K,) or a piece of skin which is upon the head, (TA,) upon which runs the string, of the bow. (S, K, TA.) ― -b5- And A cloud (S, K) that is as though it were (S) above another cloud. (S, K.) ― -b6- And The head of a mountain. (K.)

gafiyrapN c
gafiyrapN: see guforapN, and 1. ― -b2- maA fiyhimo gafiyrapN [There is not in them any disposition to forgive;] means they do not forgive any one a sin, a crime, or an offence. (S, K.) And maAEinodahumo EaciyrapN walaA gafiyrapN [They have not a disposition to excuse nor a disposition to forgive;] means they do not excuse nor do they forgive a sin, a crime, or an offence, of any one. (TA.) The rájiz (Sakhr-el-Ghei, L) said, (on seeing his companions, with whom he was journeying, fly from the Benu-l-Mustalik, whom they chanced to meet, L,)
yaA qawomi layosato fiyhimu gafiyraho
faQmoXuwA kamaA tamoXiI jimaAlu AlHiyraho
[O my people, there is not in them any disposition to forgive: therefore march ye as march the camels of El-Heereh]: (S, L:) he mentioned particularly the camels of El-Heereh because they carry burdens; and meant, march ye heavily, and defend yourselves, and do not fly. (L.) ＝ -A2- Also Abundance, and increase, in family and cattle or other property. (TA, from a trad.) ＝ -A3- See also gafiyrN, in five places.

gafiyraI c
gafiyraI: see gafiyrN.

gafRaArN c
gafRaArN: see the next paragraph.

gaAfirN c
gaAfirN (TA) and gafuwrN↓ (S, K, TA) and gafRaArN↓ (K, TA) are epithets applied to God. (K, TA,) the second and third of which are intensive; (TA;) meaning, [the first,] Covering and forgiving the sins, crimes, and offences, of his servants; [or simply forgiving; and the second and third, covering and forgiving much the sins, &c., of his servants; or very forgiving.] (S, * K, * TA) The pl. of gafuwrN↓ is gufurN. (S.) And gafuwrN↓ is also applied to a woman, without p. (TA.)

gawofarN c
gawofarN The autumnal biTRiyx [i. e. melon or water-melon]: (K:) or a species thereof (Sgh, K, TA) It is said that the biTRiyx and the gawofar are of those things in the cases of which the giving of the tithe is not incumbent. (Mgh.)

Oagofaru c
Oagofaru [Having the quality of covering, or the like, in a greater, or in the greatest, degree]. One says AuSobugo vawobaka bAlsRawaAdi faUinRahu Oagofaru liwasaxihi Dye thou thy garment, or piece of cloth, with black; for it has the quality of bearing and concealing its dirt in the greatest degree. (S, * TA.)

mugofurN c
mugofurN: see mugofuwrN, in two places.

mugofirN c
mugofirN, (O, TA,) or mugofirapN, (S,) or the latter also, (O, TA,) A she-goat of the mountain having a young one or young ones: (S, * O, * TA:) pl. mugofiraAtN. (S, TA.)

migofarN c
migofarN What is worn beneath the helmet: (Mgh, Msb:) or a piece of mail, (zaradN, S K,) woven (S) from the diroE [or coat of mail], (S, K,) according to the size of the head, (S,) worn beneath the [kind of cap called] qalanosuwap; (S, K;) as also migofarapN↓ and gifaArapN↓: (K:) or the raforaf [or pendent appertenance] of the helmet: (TA:) or a piece of mail,
(HalaqN, or HilaqN, as in different copies of the K,) which an armed man, (K,) or a man, accord. to some lexicons, (TA,) wears in the manner of a qinaAE (yataqanRaEu bihaA); as also migofarapN↓ and gifaArapN↓: (K:) accord. to ISh, the migofar is a piece of mail (HalaqN) which a man puts beneath the helmet, hanging down upon the neck: and sometimes, he says, it is like the qalanosuwap, except that it is more ample; a man throws it upon his head, and it reaches to the coat of mail; then the helmet is put on over it; and this mgfr hangs down upon the shoulders: sometimes, also, the mgfr is [a covering for the head] made of diybaAj [i. e. silk brocade], and of [the cloth called] xazR [q. v.], beneath the helmet: accord. to “ the Book of the Coat of Mail and the Helmet, ” by AO, migofarN and gifaArapN↓ are names applied to a portion of mail [forming a headcovering], which is also called tasobigapN [q. v.]; and sometimes the rings are exposed to view; and sometimes they line them within, and cover them externally, with diybaAj or xazR or [the kind of silk stuff called] bizoyawon; and they stuff it with something (HXRwhA bmA kAn); and sometimes they make above it a qawonas [or tapering top] of silver &c.: (TA:) the term migofar is also applied to the helmet itself. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- See also mugofuwrN, in three places.

migofarapN c
migofarapN: see migofarN, in two places.

migofaArN c
migofaArN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

mugofuwrN c
mugofuwrN (AA, T, S, K, &c.) and migofarN↓ (Ks, T, S, K) and mugofarN↓ and migofaArN↓ and migofyrN↓ (K) i. q. mugovuwrN; (T, S, K;) [A kind of manna;] a produce of the [species of tree, or shrub, called] rimov and sometimes of the EuXar and the EurofuT and the vumaAm and the salam and the TaloH &c.; (S;) the gum of the rmv and ErfT; (T;) the gum that is found upon the rmv, which is sweet, and is eaten; (AA;) a thing that flows, or exudes, from the ends of the twigs of the rmv, resembling dibos in its colour; (ISh, in explanation of the pl. magaAfiyru;) a gum that flows, or exudes, from the ErfT, not of pleasant odour; (IAth;) a gum resembling [the kind of sweetmeat called] naATif, exuded by the ErfT, which is put into a piece of cloth, then sprinkled with water, and drunk: accord. to Lth, migofaArN↓ is applied to the gum of the UijRaASap: and some say that migofarN↓ is applied to gum of a round shape; SuEoruwrN to that which is in shape like a finger; and cawobN to that which flows upon the ground: and migofarN↓ is also applied to a twig of a gum-tree, from which [for bihi (with which), in the TA, I read minohu,] is wiped a white fluid, whereof is made a sweet beverage: (TA:) pl. [of mugofuwrN and migofaArN and migofiyrN] magaAfiyru, (T, S, K,) and [of migofarN and mugofurN] magaAfiru: (K:) it is also said that magaAfiyru is applied to a kind of sweet honey, like rubR, except that it is white. (TA.) [Hence the saying,]
hecaA AljanaI laA Oaono yukadRa Almugofuru↓
[This is gathering, not the scraping off mgfr]: a prov. alluding to the preference of a thing; said to him who obtains much good. (K.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 874.]

migofiyrN c
migofiyrN: see the next preceding paragraph.

OaroDN magofuwraMCu c
OaroDN magofuwraMCu Land containing [trees producing] magaAfiyr. (IDrd, K.) [See mugofuwrN.]

3 gAfShu c
3. gAfShu, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. mugaAfaSapN and gifaASN, (TA,) He came upon him suddenly, or unexpectedly; (A, Msb, K;) he took him at unawares, (S, Msb, K,) and did an evil action to him. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, (Msb,) Oaxacotuhu mugaAfaSapF (A, Msb, TA) I took it (a thing, Msb) striving to overcome. (Msb, TA.)

gaAfiSapN c
gaAfiSapN A sudden, or an unexpected, calamity, of time, or fortune: (Sgh, * K, * TK:) pl. gawaAfiSu. (A.) You say, waqaAka QllRehu gawaAfiSa AldRahori [May God preserve thee from the sudden, or unexpected, calamities of time, or fortune]. (A.)

1 gafala Eanohu c
1. gafala Eanohu, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
gafula
, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. gufuwlN (S, O, Msb, K) and gafolapN, (S, O, Msb,) or the latter is a simple subst., (K,) or it is a simple subst. as well as an inf. n., and so may be gufolaAnN, said in the K to be a simple subst.; and MF says that gafila, aor.
gafala
, of which gafalN, mentioned in the K as a subst. syn. with gafolapN, may be the inf. n., has been mentioned by some as a dial. var. of gafala, but had not been found by him in any of the lexicological works notwithstanding much research, so that its correctness requires consideration; (TA;) He was, or became, unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, or heedless, of it, or inadvertent to it; (Msb;) namely, a thing: (S, O, Msb:) or he neglected it; and was, or became, unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, or heedless, of it, or inadvertent to it: (K:) and sometimes it is used as meaning he neglected it [intentionally], leaving it, and turning away: (Msb:) and Agflhu↓ signifies the same as gafala Eanohu: or gafala signifies SaAragaAfilFA [he became unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent]: and gafala Eanohu and Agflhu↓ signify waSRala gafolatahu Uilayohi [which is app. said merely for the purpose of showing that the former verb is made trans. only by means of Eano, and the latter is trans. without any prep.; for waSRala AlfiEola UilaI mafoEuwilhi and OawoSalahu Uilayohi, which latter phrase is the more usual, mean “ he made the verb transitive ”]: (K:) or Agflhu↓ signifies he neglected it (i. e. a thing) though remembering it. ('Eyn, Sb, S, O, Msb.) It is said in a trad., mani QtRabaEa AlSRayoda gafala i. e. He who pursues the object of the chase has his mind busied and possessed by it so that he becomes unmindful [&c. of other things]. (TA.)

2 gfRlhu c
2. gfRlhu, inf. n. tagofiylN, He made him to become unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- AltRagofiylu signifies [also] The sufficing one's companion [in respect of an affair] when he who is the object thereof is unmindful, unoccupied [in mind, or actually,] by anything. (ISk, K, TA.) [You say, gfRl SaAHibahu meaning He sufficed his companion in respect of an affair when he (the latter) was unmindful, &c.] ＝ -A2- And gfRlhu, (Mgh, O, K, but in my copy of the Mgh written without tesh-deed,) inf. n. as above, (O, K,) He concealed it, (Mgh, O, K,) namely, a thing. (Mgh, O.)

3 gAflhu c
3. gAflhu [app. He acted with him in the manner of him who is unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent]. (TA voce saAhaAhu, q. v., in art. shw.)

4 Agflhu c
4. Agflhu: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, maA Oagofalahu Eanoka XayoYFA [app. lit. signifying How unmindful of thee is he as to anything! and therefore virtually] meaning dismiss doubt [from thee respecting him as to anything]. (TA. [See further explanations of it voce XaIoCN.]) ― -b3- And Agflhu Eanohu He made him to be unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, or heedless, of it, or inadvertent to it; (S, * O, TA;) namely, a thing. (S.) [Or] Agflhu signifies He, or it, smote him, or lighted on him, he (the latter) being gaAfil [i. e. unmindful, &c.]: or he made him to be gaAfil: or he called him, or named him, gaAfil: and in like manner gfRlhu↓, inf. n. tagofiylN: (TA:) or tagofiylN signifies the calling [one] unmindful, &c.: and the rendering [one] stupid, or foolish. (KL.) ― -b4- And Agflhu signifies also He asked him [for, or respecting, a thing] in the time of his occupation, not waiting for the time of his freedom therefrom. (TA.) ― -b5- And Agfl AldRaAbRapa He left the beast unbranded; did not brand it. (S, O.)

5 tgfRl c
5. tgfRl as intrans.: see 6, in two places. ＝ -A2- tgfRlhu He watched for his unmindfulness, forgetfulness, negligence, heedlessness, or inadvertence; (S, Mgh, O, Msb;) as also Eanohu tgAfl↓, (S, O,) and Astgflhu↓: (TA:) tgAfl [as trans.] in this sense [without a prep.] is a mistake. (Mgh.)

6 tgAfl c
6. tgAfl He feigned himself unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent; not being so really. (Msb.) [And] He was intentionally, or purposely, unmindful, forgetful, &c.; as also tgfRl↓: (K:) or the former has this meaning: but tgfRl↓ signifies he was deceived, or circumvented, in a state of unmindfulness, forgetfulness, &c. (TA.) tgAfl Eanohu: see 5. It means [also] He was unmindful, &c., of him, or it: or he feigned himself unmindful, &c., of him, or it. (MA.)

10 Astgflhu c
10. Astgflhu: see 5.

gufolN c
gufolN Land without cultivation: (K:) or without any way-mark: (Msb:) or without any waymark and without cultivation: (S, O:) or not rained upon: (Ks, S, O:) or unknown; in which is no known trace; or vestige: and, accord. to the
M, a desert, or waterless desert, that causes one to lose his way, wherein is no sign, or mark: (TA:) pl. OagofaAlN, (S, TA,) syn. with mawaAtN [q. v.]; (S:) and Lh mentions the phrase OaroDN OagofaAlN, as though they made every portion thereof to be what is termed gufolN: and bilaAdN OagofaAlN, meaning [tracts of country] wherein are no way-marks by which to be directed. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A road, or way, &c., in which is no sign, or mark, whereby it may be known. (K.) ― -b3- And A gaming-arrow (qidoHN) upon which is no mark [or notch to distinguish it]; (K;) such as has no portion assigned to it, and no fine: (O, K:) [or,] accord. to Lh, one says qidaAHN gufolN, using the sing. form [of the epithet] meaning [gaming arrows] in which are no notches, and to which is assigned no portion and no fine: they used to be added to give additional weight to the collection of arrows from fear of occasioning suspicion [of foul play], i. e. to increase the number: and they were four; the first [called] AlmuSadRaru; the next, AlmuDaERafu; the next, AlmaniyHu; and the next, AlsRafiyHu. (TA.) ― -b4- And A beast (daAbRapN) having no brand upon it: (S, O, K:) and a she-camel that is not branded, in order that the poor-rate may not be [considered as] incumbent for her: and gufulN↓ is a dial. var. thereof, or is used by poetic license: the pl. is OagofaAlN. (TA.) The pl. (OagofaAlN) is also applied to Camels, or cattle, (naEamN,) that yield no milk. (TA.) ― -b5- And A muSoHaf [or copy of the Kur-án] bare of the [signs called] EawaAXir [pl. of EaAXirapN q. v.] and the like of these. (TA.) ― -b6- And A book, or writing, [that is anonymous,] of which the author is not named. (TA.) And Poetry of which the author is unknown. (K.) And A poet unknown (K, TA) and unnamed [or anonymous]: pl. OagofaAlN. (TA.) ― -b7- Also A man inexperienced in affairs. (S, O, Msb, TA.) One whose beneficence is not hoped for, nor his evilness feared; (K, TA;) he being like the shackled that is neglected: pl. as above. (TA.) And One having no grounds of pretension to respect or honour: (K, TA:) or, as some say, of whom one knows not what he possesses. (TA.) ― -b8- And The fur (lit. furs, or soft portions of hair, OawobaAr, [perhaps because long left unshorn,]) of camels. (AHn, K, TA.)

gafalN c
gafalN: see gafolapN. ― -b2- Also [Such as is] abundant and high [in estimation, app. of the means of subsistence]; syn. kaviyrN rafiyEN: (O, K: [or the latter word is correctly rafiygN, (so in the TK,) i. e. ample, and pleasant or good, as applied to the means of subsistence:]) and a state of ampleness of the means of subsistence: (O, K:) thus in the saying, huwa fiI gafalK mino EayoXihi [He is in a state of ampleness in respect of his means of subsistence: app. thus termed as being a cause of unmindfulness, or heedlessness]. (O.)

gufulN c
gufulN: see gufolN, latter half.

gafolapN c
gafolapN the subst. from gafala, (ISd, K,) or it is an inf. n. (S, O, Msb, TA) and also a simple subst., (TA,) or the subst. is gafalapN↓, with fet-h to the f to distinguish it from the inf. n.; (Msb;) as also gafalN↓, (ISd, K,) or this may be the inf. n. of gafila, mentioned above as a dial. var. outweighed in authority; (TA;) and gufolaAnN↓, (K,) or this may be an inf. n. like kuforaAnN, and it may be a simple subst.; (TA;) Unmindfulness, forgetfulness, neglectfulness, heedlessness, or inadvertence; (Msb, K;) [the state in which is] absence of a thing from the mind of a man; and unmindfulness, or forgetfulness: and sometimes, intentional neglect: (Msb;) or gafolapN signifies the forgetting, neglecting, or being unmindful, of a thing: (Abu-l-Bakà, TA:) or the want of requisite knowledge or cognizance of a thing: (El-Harállee, TA:) or, accord. to Er-Raghib, negligence occurring from littleness of consideration and of vigilance; or, as some say, the following the soul in that which it desires, (TA.) [fiI gafolapK In a state of unmindfulness &c., and Eano gafolapK in consequence of unmindfulness &c., may often be rendered at unawares.]

gafalapN c
gafalapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

gafolaAnN c
gafolaAnN, or gafolaAnu: see gaAfilN.

gufolaAnN c
gufolaAnN: see gafolapN.

gafuwlN c
gafuwlN A she-camel that does not take fright and flee, (K, TA,) nor hold back from a young one that she suckles, nor care who milks her. (TA.)

gaAfilN c
gaAfilN [and gafolaAnN↓, or gafolaAnu, Unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent: and the former, sometimes, intentionally neglecting: pl. of the former gufuwlN and gufRalN]. (K.)

mugofilN c
mugofilN Possessing camels not branded. (TA.)

magofalapN c
magofalapN The Eanofaqap [or tuft of hair beneath the lower lip]; (O, K, TA;) so says Th, (O,) or Ez-Zejjájee: (TA:) not the two sides thereof as it is said to signify by J: (K:) so called because many men neglect [the washing of] it. (TA.)
