It is said in a trad., Ealayoka biQlomagofalapi [Keep thou to the washing of the tuft of hair beneath the lower lip]: meaning that one should use heedfulness in washing it, in the performance of the ablution termed wuDuwC. (TA.)

mugafRalN c
mugafRalN [lit. Made unmindful, &c.; see its verb: and hence, a simpleton; or] devoid of intelligence, sagacity, skill, or natural understanding. (IDrd, Mgh, O, Msb, K.)

1 gafaA c
1. gafaA, and gafiIa: see 4. ― -b2- gafaA, (K, TA,) inf. n. gafowN and gufuwRN, (TA,) also signifies It (a thing, TA) floated upon the water (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- gafaI AlTRaEaAma, aor.
1a2i2a
, (K, TA,) inf. n. gafoIN, (TA,) He cleared the wheat of what is termed gafFI, i. e. a thing such as [the noxious weed called] zuWaAn [q. v.], (K, TA,) and other refuse; (TA;) or the straw; as also AgfI↓. (K, TA,)

4 AgfI c
4. AgfI, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. UigofaMCN; (S, Msb;) and gafaA↓, (K,) first pers. gafawotu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. gafowN and gufuwRN; (K;) the latter verb said by ISd to occur in the trads., (TA,) but disallowed by ISk (S, Msb, TA) and by others, (Msb,) and said by Az to be rare; (Msb, TA;) He slept: (S, K:) or he slept a light sleep: (Msb, TA;) or he was, or became, drowsy, or heavy with sleepiness; as also gafiIa↓, aor.
1a2a2a
, inf. n. gafoyapN. (K.) ― -b2- And AgfI He (a man, TA) slept upon what is termed gafFI, i. e. the straw, in the place in which the grain thereof was trodden out: (K:) mentioned as from IAar by Az, and by Sgh as from AA. (TA.) ― -b3- And AgfI AlTRaEaAmu The wheat was abundant in its nuxaAlap, accord. to the copies of the K, but more properly its nufaAyap [i. e. refuse]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 1. ＝ -A2- AgfI AlXRajaru The trees hung down their branches. (IKtt, TA.)

7 AngfI c
7. AngfI. It (a thing, TA) became broken. (K, TA.)

gafowN c
gafowN and gafowapN↓ and gafoyapN↓ (K, TA) and gufoyapN↓ and gifoyapN↓ (Sgh, TA) A zuboyap [or hollow dug in the ground], (K, TA,) in which a sportsman lurks: the first and second mentioned by Lh. (TA.)

gafFI c
gafFI The refuse that is taken forth from wheat, and thrown away, (Fr, S, TA,) such as [the noxious weed called] zuWaAn [q. v.]; (S;) a thing that is in wheat, such as zWAn, (K, TA,) and other refuse: (TA:) or the straw [thereof]; (K, TA;) accord. to IAar, the bad, that is thrown away, of wheat; as also gafaMCN↓. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (thus accord. to ISd in all the senses here following in this paragraph that are found in the K, as is said in the TA, and thus in some copies of the K,) or gufaMCN↓, (thus in the copies of the K followed in the TA,) i. q. guvaMCN [i. e. The rubbish, or small rubbish, or particles of things, or refuse, and scum, and rotten leaves mixed with the scum, of a torrent]. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And Fragments, or broken portions, of wheat: (K, TA;) or the stalks thereof. (TA.) ― -b4- And A blight incident to palm-trees, like dust falling upon the unripe dates, preventing their becoming ripe, (S, K, TA,) and rendering them tasteless. (S [in which the word thus expl. is gafFI] and TA.) And A thick crust that comes upon unripe dates: [see 4 in art. gfr:] or, as some say, bad dates, that become [app. in the skin] thick, or coarse, and like the wings of locusts. (TA.) ― -b5- And A disease incident to straw, rendering it bad. (TA.) ― -b6- Also Such as they drive away, or expel, of their camels. (K, TA.) ― -b7- And gafFI signifies also The bad of anything. (TA.) ― -b8- And The low, vile, mean, or sordid; or the lower, viler, &c.; or the refuse, or rabble; of mankind. (TA.)

gafowapN c
gafowapN A light sleep: occurring in the traditions. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also gafowN.

gafoyapN c
gafoyapN and gufoyapN and gifoyapN: see gafowN.

gafiyapN c
gafiyapN, like fariHapN [in measure], in the phrase xTp gfyp, [in which, app., the former word is xuTRapN, and the meaning of the phrase An affair, or a case, or a dubious, or momentous, and difficult affair, in which is something evil, or to be rejected,]
is a possessive epithet, signifying fiyhaA gafFI. (TA: immediately after gafFI expl. as meaning the “ bad ” of anything.)

gafaMCN c
gafaMCN and gufaMCN: see gafFI, first and second sentences.

AlgufaMCapu c
AlgufaMCapu [in the CK AlgufApu] The whiteness upon the Hadaqap [or iris of the eye], (K, TA,) i. e., that covers the Hdqp. (TA.)

UigofaMCapu AlSRuboHi c
UigofaMCapu AlSRuboHi The sleep of daybreak, or the first part of the day. (TA.)

1 galRahu c
1. galRahu, (S, O, K, *) aor.
galula
, (S,) inf. n. galRN, (K,) He made it, or caused it, to enter, (S, O, K, * [in the CK Audoxila is erroneously put for Oadoxala,]) fiI XaIoCK into a thing; (O, K;) as also galogalahu↓, (K, * TA,) inf. n. galogalapN; or this last word signifies the making, or causing, a thing to enter a thing so as to become confused with, and a part of, that into which it enters: (TA:) ― -b2- and galRa, (S, O, K,) aor. as above, (S) and so the inf. n., (TK,) signifies also It entered [into a thing]; (S, O, K;) being intrans. as well as trans.; (S, O;) and so does AinogalRa↓, (S, O, K,) and tglRl↓, and tagalogala↓; (K, TA;) said of [what are termed by logicians] substances and of [what are termed by them] accidents. (TA.) ― -b3- yagulRu said of a ram means Penem suum inserit (yudoxilu qaDiybahu) non sublatâ caudâ. (S, O, * TA.) And galRa signifies also Inivit (HaXaOa, in some copies of the K without the hemzeh,) feminam: (K, TA; in which latter is added wlA ykwn AlRA mn DaxomK [app. meaning that this is not said of any but such as is big, or bulky]:) mentioned by IAar. (TA.) ― -b4- galRa AldRuhona fiI raOosihi He made the oil to enter amid the roots of the hair of his head. (K.) And galRa XaEarahu biAlTRiybi He made the perfume to enter amid his hair. (TA.) ― -b5- And galRahu lahu He made it to be unapparent to him (dasRahu lahu), he [the latter] having no knowledge of it. (TA: in which the pronoun affixed to the verb relates to a dagger, and to a spear-head.) ― -b6- galRa AlmafaAwiza He (a man) entered into the midst of the deserts, or waterless deserts. (S, O.) ― -b7- galRa AlmaMCu bayona AlOaXojaAri, (S, O, K,) aor.
galula
, (S, O,) The water ran amid the trees. (S, O, K.) And AlmaMCu fiI AlXRajari tagalogala↓ The water entered amid the breaks, or interspaces, of the trees. (S.) ― -b8- galRa AlgilaAlapa He clad himself with, or wore, the glAlp [q. v.] (K, TA) beneath the [other] garments; because he who does so enters into it. (TA.) And AlvRawoba Aigotalalotu↓ [in like manner] signifies I clad myself with, or wore, the garment beneath the [other] garments. (K.) ― -b9- galRa fulaAnFA, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He put upon the neck, or the hand, of such a one, the gulR [i. e. ring, or collar, of iron, for the neck, or pinion or manacle for the hand]. (K, TA.) And gulRa He had the gulR put upon him. (S, * TA.) And galalotu yadahu UiliI Eunuqihi [I confined his hand to his neck with the gulR]. (S, O.) And galRa OasiyrFA bigulRK mino qidRK waEalayohi XaEarN [He confined a captive with a gulR of thongs upon which was hair]. (TA.) One says, maA lahu OulRa wagulRa, (S, O, K, TA, [in some copies of the S and K, which have misled Golius and Freytag, mAlh OulRN wagulRN,]) a form of imprecation, (K, TA,) meaning [What ails him?] may he be thrust, or pushed, in the back of his neck, and become possessed, or insane, (IB, TA in the present art. and in art. Al,) and therefore have the gulR put upon him. (TA in the present art.) And gulRato yaduhu UilaI Eunuqihi [sometimes] means (assumed tropical:) His hand was withheld from expenditure. (TA.) ＝ -A2- gulRa, (S, K,) aor. yugalRu, inf. n. galalN, said of a man, (S,) He was, or became, thirsty; or vehemently thirsty; (K, TA;) or affected with burning of thirst, (S, TA,) little or much; (TA;) or with burning of the inside, (K, TA,) from thirst, and from anger and vexation. (TA.) ― -b2- And galRa said of a camel, (S, O, K,) originally galila, (MF, TA,) aor. yagalRN; and AgtlR↓ also; He was, or became, thirsty; or vehemently thirsty; or affected with burning of the inside: (K:) or he did not fully satisfy his thirst; (S and O in explanation of the former, and TA in explanation of both;) and galRato is said of camels in like manner, agreeably with this last explanation: (K:) and AigotalRato↓ is also said of sheep or goats, (K, TA,) signifying they thirsted. (TA.) ＝ -A3- galRa Sadoruhu, aor. yagilRN, (S, O, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, yagalRu,]) with kesr, (S, O,) inf. n. gilRN, with kesr, (O,) His bosom was, or became, affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: (S, O, K:) and with dishonesty, or insincerity. (S, O.) [See also gilRN, below.] It is said in a trad., valaAvN laA yagilRu EalayohinRa qalobu AlmuWomini i. e. [There are three habits, (xiSaAl being understood, these, as is said in the O, being “ the acting sincerely towards God, ” and “ giving honest counsel to those in command, ” and “ keeping to the community ” of the Muslims,)] while conforming to which the heart of the believer will not be invaded by rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, causing it to swerve from that which is right; (S, * O;) a saying of the Prophet; thus related by some: accord. to others, yugilRu↓, (S, O,) with damm to the I, (O,) which is from the meaning expl. in the next sentence here following. (S, * O.) ＝ -A4- galRa, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor. yagulRu, (S, O,) inf. n. guluwlN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) He acted unfaithfully; as also AglR↓: (S, O, Msb, K:) or thus the latter, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) accord. to ISk (S, Msb) and A'Obeyd, (S,) in a general sense; (Mgh, Msb;) and he became unfaithful: (TA:) but the former verb is used only in relation to spoil, or booty; (S, Mgh, O, * Msb, K;) you say, galRa mina Almagonami meaning xaAna [i. e. He acted unfaithfully in taking from the spoil, or booty]; (S, O;) or meaning he acted unfaithfully in relation to the spoil, or booty: (Mgh:) or galRa, (IAth, Mgh, TA,) aor. as above, (Mgh,) inf. n. guluwlN, (IAth, TA,) or galRN, (Mgh, [thus in my copy, accord. to which it is trans., as will be shown by what follows,]) signifies also he stole; and was unfaithful in respect of a thing privily; and such conduct is termed guluwlN because, in the case thereof, the hands, or arms, have the gulR [q. v.] put upon them: (IAth, TA:) or it signifies also he took a thing and hid it amid his goods; and it occurs in a trad. as meaning he took a Xamolap privily. (Mgh.) It is said in the Kur [iii. 155], wamaA kaAna linabiIRK Oano yagulRa and Oano yugalRa↓, accord. to different readers; the former meaning [And it is not attributable to a prophet] that he would act unfaithfully; and An yugalRa↓ meaning, [agreeably with an explanation of OagalRa fulaAnFA in the K,] that unfaithful conduct should be imputed to him; or that there should be taken from his [share of the] spoil, or booty; (S, O, TA;) [or this may mean, that he should be found to be acting unfaithfully; for, accord. to the TA, AglR AlrRajula means wajadahu gaAlRFA;] but IB says that a pass. aor. is seldom found in the language of the Arabs in a phrase of this kind. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. walaA UisolaAla laA UigolaAla↓ i. e. There shall be no acting unfaithfully nor stealing: or there shall be no act of bribery [nor stealing]: (S, O:) or, as some say, there shall be no aiding another to act unfaithfully [&c.]. (TA.) ＝ -A5- galalotu lilnRaAqapi I fed the she-camel with galiyl i. e. date-stones mixed with [the species of trefoil called] qitR. (S, * O, TA.) ＝ -A6- galRa AlUihaAba: see OagalRa fiI AlUihaAbi. ＝ -A7- galRa EalaI AlXRaIoCi, inf. n. galRN; and AglR↓; He was silent at the thing: and also he was intent upon the thing. (TA.)

2 glRlhu c
2. glRlhu, (K,) or glRl liHoyatahu, (S, O,) biAlgaAliyapi, (S, O, K,) inf. n. tagoliylN, (K,) He perfumed him, (K,) or daubed, or smeared, his beard, much, (O,) the teshdeed denoting muchness, (S, O,) with gaAliyap: (S, O, K:) and bAlgAlyp tglRl↓ and AgtlR↓ and tagalogala↓ He perfumed himself with gAlyp: (K:) Lh mentions tagalRaI biAlgaAliyapi, which is either from the word gaAliyap or originally tagalRala, in the latter case being like taZanRayotu for taZanRanotu, but the former is the more agreeable with analogy: accord. to Fr, one says, bAlgAlyp tagalRalotu↓, and not tagalRayotu: (TA:) As held tagalRalotu↓ from AlgAlyp to be allowable if meaning I introduced the gAlyp into my beard or my mustache; (S, O;) and the like is the case with respect to galRalotu bihaA liHoyatiI: (S:) accord. to Lth, one says, from AlgAlyp, galRalotu and galRafotu and galRayotu. (TA. [See also 1 in art. glf; and see art. glI.])

4 AglR Uibilahu c
4. AglR Uibilahu, (K,) inf. n. UigolaAlN, (TA,) He watered his camels ill, so that they did not satisfy their thirst: (K, TA:) or he brought, or sent, them back from the water without satisfying their thirst: (O, TA:) thus expl. by Az, who says that it is incorrectly mentioned by A'Obeyd, on
the authority of AZ, [in this sense,] with the unpointed E. (TA. [But see 4 in art. El.]) ― -b2- And AglR signifies also AgtlRt ganamuhu (O, K) [accord. to the TA as meaning His sheep, or goats, thirsted: but this I think doubtful: see 8]. ＝ -A2- AglR and its aor. and inf. n. as relating to unfaithfulness, see in the latter half of the first paragraph, in five places. ＝ -A3- AglRt AlDRayoEahu, (Mgh, Msb, K, [in the CK galRat,]) and AlDRiyaAEu, (S, O, K,) from AlgalRapu, (S, O,) [The estate, and estates, consisting of land, &c.,] became in the condition of having galRap [or proceeds, revenue, or income, accruing from the produce, &c.]: (Mgh, Msb:) or yielded galRap: (K, TA:) i. e. yielded somewhat, the source thereof remaining. (TA.) ― -b2- And AglR Alqawomu meaning balagato galRatuhumo [i. e. The galRap of the people, or party, arrived; as expl. in the PS and TA; or the people, or party, had their glRp brought to them]. (S, O, K.) And The people, or party, became in [or entered upon] the time of the galRap. (TA.) ― -b3- And fulaAnN yugilRu EalaI EiyaAlihi Such a one brings the galRap to his family, or household. (S, O.) ＝ -A4- AglR AlwaAdiI The valley gave growth to what are termed gulRaAn, (S, O, K,) pl. of gaAlRN. (TA.) ＝ -A5- AglR fiI AlUihaAbi, (S, O,) He (a butcher) left some of the flesh sticking in the hide, in stripping it off: (S, O:) or he took some of the flesh and of the fat [in the hide] in the skinning: (K:) and AlUihaAba glR↓ he left somewhat [of the flesh, or of the flesh and of the fat,] remaining in the hide on the occasion of the skinning: a dial. var. of OagalRa. (TA.) ― -b2- And accord. to AA, AlUigolaAlu signifies The milking of the she-camel when milk remains [app. afterwards] in her udder. (O.) [Perhaps the meaning is The leaving some remaining in the udder on the occasion of milking.] ＝ -A6- AglR AlxaTiybu The orator, or preacher, said, or spoke, what was not right, or correct. (TA.) ＝ -A7- AglR baSarahu, (S, O,) or AlbaSara, (K,) He (a man, S, O) looked intensely, or intently. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence. ＝ -A8- UigolaAlN signifies also The making an overt, or open, hostile, or predatory, incursion. (TA.) ＝ -A9- And The clothing oneself with, or wearing, a coat of mail. (TA.)

5 tagalRaRa
5: see 1, first sentence: ＝ -A2- and see also 2, in three places.

7 Uinogalala
7: see 1, first sentence.

8 Aigotalalotu AlvRawoba c
8. Aigotalalotu AlvRawoba: see 1, former half. ＝ -A2- Aigotalalotu AlXRaraAba I drank the beverage. (K.) ＝ -A3- lahu OurayoDapN yagotalRuhaA: see 10. ＝ -A4- AgtlR said of a camel, and AigotalRato said of sheep or goats: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph. (See also the next sentence but one.) ＝ -A5- AgtlR biAlgaAliyapi: see 2. ＝ -A6- AigotalRato said of sheep or goats, They became affected with the disease termed galal [q. v.]. (O, K.)

10 AisotigolaAlN c
10. AisotigolaAlN signifies The desiring, or demanding, or [tasking a person,] to bring galRap [i. e. proceeds, revenue, or income, accruing from the produce, or yield, of land, &c.]. (PS.) One says, AstglR Eabodahu, meaning He tasked his slave to bring galRap to him. (S, O, K. [In the explanation in the CK, yagulRa is erroneously put for yugilRa.]) ― -b2- And The taking, or receiving, [or obtaining,] of galRap: (PS:) or the bringing of galRap from a place [or an estate]. (KL.) One says, AstglR AlmusotagalRaAti↓ He took the galRap of the mstglRAt [i. e. of the lands, or estates, from which glRp is obtained]. (S, O, K.) And lahu OurayoDapN yagotalRuhaA↓ like yasotagilRuhaA [i. e. To him belongs a small portion of land of which he takes, or receives, or obtains, the galRap]. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence] one says of a hard man, laA yusotagalRu minohu XaIoCN (assumed tropical:) [Nothing, meaning no profit or advantage, is reaped, or obtained, from him]. (L and TA in art. mrs: see 5 in that art.)

R. Q. 1 galogala c
R. Q. 1. galogala, inf. n. galogalapN: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- galogala risaAlapN UilaI SaAHibihaA [He conveyed a message, or letter, to the person to whom it pertained: see the pass. part. n., below]. (Ham p. 500.) ＝ -A2- And galogalapN signifies also A breaking [of the bone of the nose, and of the head of a flask or bottle], like garogarapN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- [See mugalogilapN.I do not find any instance of the usage of galogala otherwise than as trans.: but in the TK, and hence by Freytag, galogalapN in a sense in which it is expl. below is regarded as an inf. n., and consequently the verb is said to signify He went quickly; which is a meaning of R. Q. 2.]

R. Q. 2 tagalogala c
R. Q. 2. tagalogala: see 1, first quarter, in two places. qado tagalogalota yaA EaduwRa QllRehi, said to the muxanRav Heet, when he described a woman, as is related in a trad., is expl. as meaning Thou hast reached, in thy looking, of the beauties of this woman, a point which no looker, nor any one having close communion, nor any describer, has reached [beside thee, O enemy of God]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He went quickly: (K, * TA:) one says, tagalogaluwA famaDawoA [They went quickly, and passed, or passed away]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- tglgl biAlgaAliyapi: see 2.

gulRN c
gulRN A ring, or collar, of iron, which is put upon the neck: (Msb:) a shackle for the neck or for the hand: [i. e. a ring, or collar, for the neck, or a pinion or manacle for the hand:] (MA:) or a [shackle of the kind called] jaAmiEap, (TA, and so in the S and K in art. jmE,) of iron, (TA,) collecting together the two hands to the neck: (S in art. jmE; and Jel * in xxxvi. 7:) [sometimes, a shackle for the neck and hands, consisting of two rings, one for the neck and the other for the hands, connected by a bar of iron: (see zamRaArapN:)] and a shackle with which the Arabs used to confine a captive when they took him, made of thongs, upon which was hair, so that sometimes, when it dried, it became infested with lice upon his neck: (TA:) the pl. is OagolaAlN: (S, O, Msb, K:) which repeatedly occurs in the Kur-án and the Sunneh as meaning (assumed tropical:) difficult tasks and fatiguing works [as being likened to shackles upon the necks]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence] the Arabs apply it metonymically to denote (tropical:) A wife. (TA.) And gulRN qamilN [lit. A lousy shackle for the neck &c.] is an appellation of (assumed tropical:) a woman of evil disposition; originating from the fact that the gulR used to be of thongs, upon which was hair, so that it became infested with lice. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also, and gulRapN↓, (S, O, K,) and galalN↓, (K,) or this is the inf. n. of gulRa, (S,) [and accord. to analogy of galRa as originally galila,] and galiylN↓, (S, O, K,) Thirst: or vehement thirst: (K, TA:) or the burning of thirst; (S, O, TA;) little or much: (TA:) or burning of the inside, (K, TA,) from thirst, and from anger and vexation (TA.)

gilRN c
gilRN and galiylN↓ Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: (S, O, Msb, K, TA:) or latent rancour &c.: (JK in explanation of the former:) and envy; so each signifies; (TA;) [and so the former in the Kur vii. 41 and xv. 47:] and enmity: (TA in explanation of the latter:) and the former signifies also dishonesty, or insincerity. (S, O.)

galRapN c
galRapN Proceeds, revenue, or income, (Mgh, Msb, K, TA, [in the CK, AldRaxalapu is put for AldRaxolu,]) of any kind, (Mgh, Msb,) accruing from the produce, or yield, of land, (Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) or from the rent thereof, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) [in which sense magalRN↓ is also used, as a subst., pl. mugalRaAtN,] or from seed-produce, and from fruits, and from milk, and from hire, and from the increase of cattle, and the like, (TA,) and from the rent of a house, (K, TA,) and from the hire of a slave, (Mgh, K, TA,) and the like; (Mgh, Msb;) [generally meaning corn, or grain; i.e.] wheat and barley and rice and the like; (KL;) the galRap of the slave is the payment imposed by the master, and made to him: (TA voce DariybapN:) pl. galRaAtN (S, O, Msb, TA) and gilaAlN. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Also Dirhems [or pieces of money] that are clipped (muqaTRaEap), in a single piece thereof [the quantity clipped being] a qiyraAT or a TasRuwj or a grain; of which it is said in the “ Eedáh, ” that one's lending galRap in order to have such as are free from defect returned to him is disapproved: (Mgh:) or dirhems [or pieces of money] that are rejected by the treasury of the state, but taken by the merchants. (KT. [Freytag has given this latter explanation, but has erroneously assigned it to gulRapN.])

gulRapN c
gulRapN A thing in which one hides himself. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- See also gilaAlapN, in two places: ― -b3- and galalN. ＝ -A2- And see gulRN, last sentence.

galalN c
galalN Water amid trees: pl. OagolaAlN. (S, O. [See an ex. voce EacobN.]) And Water having no current, only appearing a little upon the surface of the earth, disappearing at one time and appearing at another: (AA, S, O:) or, accord. to AHn, a feeble flow of water from the bottom of a valley or water-course, amid trees. (TA.) Aboo-Sa'eed says,
laA yacohabu kalaAmunaA galalaA
[Our speech shall not pass away as a feeble flow of water]: meaning that it ought not to be concealed from men, but should be made public. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A strainer, or clarifier: occur-
ring in a verse of Lebeed, cited voce raAziqiIRN: where it means the fidaAm (S, O, TA) on the heads of the OabaAriyq, (S,) or on the head of the Uiboriyq: (O, TA:) or, as some relate the verse, the word is gulalN, pl. of gulRapN↓; (S, O, TA;) which signifies [the same, i. e.] a piece of rag bound on the head of the Abryq [to act as a strainer]. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A3- And The flesh that is left upon the thumb when one skins [a beast]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- See also gulRN, last sentence. ＝ -A5- Also, (O, K,) and galaAlapN↓, (O, and so in copies of the K,) or gulaAlapN↓, (so in other copies of the K, and accord. to the TA,) A certain disease that attacks sheep, or goats, (O, K, TA,) in the orifice of the teat, occasioned by the milker's not exhausting the udder, but leaving in it some milk, which becomes blood, or coagulates and is mixed with a yellow fluid. (TA.)

galuwlu AlXRayoxi c
galuwlu AlXRayoxi The food of the old man, which he ingests into his belly [or stomach]: (S, O, K:) and likewise the beverage drunk by him. (TA.) One says, niEoma galuwlu AlXRayoxi hecaA [Excellent, or most excellent, is this food of the old man &c.!]. (S, O, K.)

galiylN c
galiylN: see gulRN, last sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] sometimes, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The burning of love, and of grief. (K, TA.) ― -b3- See also gilRN. ＝ -A2- And see magoluwlN. ＝ -A3- Also Date-stones mixed with [the species of trefoil called] qatR, (S, O, K, TA,) and in like manner with dough, (TA,) for a she-camel, (S, O, K, TA,) which is fed therewith. (S, O, TA.) ＝ -A4- See. also gaAlRN.

galaAlapN c
galaAlapN, or gulaAlapN: see galalN, last sentence.

gilaAlapN c
gilaAlapN A garment that is worn next the body, beneath the other garment, (S, O, K,) and likewise beneath the coat of mail; (S, O;) also called gulRapN↓: (K, TA:) pl. [of the former] galaAYilu and [of the latter] gulalN. (TA.) ― -b2- And A piece of cloth with which a woman makes her posteriors [to appear] large, (O, * K, * TA,) binding it upon her hinder part, beneath her waist-wrapper; (TA;) as also gulRapN↓, of which the pl. is gulalN. (IB, TA.) ― -b3- And The pin that connects the two heads of the ring [of a coat of mail]: (O, K:) pl. galaAYilu. (TA.) And galaAYilu signifies Coats of mail: or the pins thereof that connect the heads of the rings: or linings, or inner coverings, that are worn beneath them, (K, TA,) i. e. beneath the coats of mail: and [it is said that] the sing. thereof is galiylapN↓. (K, TA.)

galiylapN c
galiylapN: see what next precedes.

galRaAnN c
galRaAnN (S, O, K) and gaAlRN↓, (K,) applied to a camel, (S, O, K,) Thirsty: (K: *) or vehemently thirsty: (S, O, K: *) or affected with burning of the inside: (K: *) and gaAlRapN↓, and its pl. gawaAlRu, camels not having fully satisfied their thirst. (TA.)

gaAlRN c
gaAlRN; and its fem., with p: see the next preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also Low, or depressed, ground, in which are trees, and places of growth of [the trees called] salam and TaloH: one says gaAlRN mino salamK, like as one says EiyoSN mino sidorK and qaSiymapN mino gaDFA: (AHn, S, O:) or, as also galiylN↓, a place of growth of [the trees called] TaloH: or a low, or depressed, valley or torrent-bed in the ground, (K, TA,) in which are trees: (TA:) pl. gulRaAnN. (K.) ― -b2- And A certain plant, (S, O, K,) [said to be] well known: (K: [but I have not found it to be now known:]) pl. gulRaAnN. (S, O, K.)

gaAlRapN c
gaAlRapN [as a subst.] A part broken off from the shore of the sea and become collected together in a place. (TA.) [Expl. by Freytag as signifying “ Pars maris, quæ in litore abrupta est: ” and as being a word of the dial. of El-Yemen: on the authority of IDrd.]

glgl c
glgl, [thus in my original,] applied to the root (Eiroq) of a tree, Extending far into the earth: pl. galaAgilu. (TA.)

galogalapN c
galogalapN A quick rate of going. (S, O, K, * TA.) [App. a simple subst.; but perhaps an inf. n., of which the verb is galogala, q. v.]

gulogulapN c
gulogulapN Clamour and confusion of voices. (TA.) [Like the Pers. gulogul and gulogulah.]

mugalRN c
mugalRN, as a subst., pl. mugalRaAtN: see galRapN.

mugilRN c
mugilRN A man cleaving to rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (TA.) ― -b2- An unfaithful man; one who acts unfaithfully. (S, * Mgh, O, * TA.) Hence the saying of Shureyh, layosa EalaI AlmusotaEiyri gayoriAlmugilRi DamaAnN, (S, Mgh, O, TA,) walaAEalaI AlmusotawodaEi, (TA,) i. e. [There is no guaranteeship to be imposed upon the asker of a loan, except the unfaithful, nor upon him who is asked to take charge of a deposit, meaning], except in the case of him who has been unfaithful in respect of the loan and the deposit: or, as some say, by the mugilR is here meant the musotagilR↓ [i. e. the person employed to bring the galRap]: but IAth says that the former is the right explanation. (TA.) ＝ -A2- mugilRapN, applied to a garden (janRap), as in a verse cited voce Harada, (S, O,) or to an estate (DayoEap), (Mgh, TA,) Having, (Mgh,) or yielding, (TA,) galRap [q. v.; fruitful, or productive]. (Mgh, TA.)

magoluwlN c
magoluwlN, applied to a man, Having the [shackle called] gulR put upon him. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [v. 69], waqaAlati Qloyahuwdu yadN QllRehi magoluwlapN [And the Jews said, The hand of God is shackled], meaning, withheld from dispensing. (O.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) applied to a man, (S,) and galiylN↓, and mugotalRN↓, (K,) Thirsty; or vehemently thirsty; (K, TA;) or affected with burning of thirst, (S, TA,) little or much; (TA;) or with burning of the inside, (K, TA,) from thirst, or from anger and vexation. (TA.)

mugotalRN c
mugotalRN: see what next precedes. ― -b2- [Hence,] OanaA mugotalRN Uilayohi (tropical:) I am yearning, or longing, for him, or it. (K, TA.)

risaAlapN mugalogalapN c
risaAlapN mugalogalapN A message, or letter, conveyed from town to town, or from country to country. (S, O, K.)

mugalogilapN c
mugalogilapN, with kesr to the second g, Hastening; syn. musoriEapN [which is trans. and intrans.; but generally the latter, like sariyEN]. (TA.)

musotagalRN c
musotagalRN A place [or land or an estate] from which galRap is obtained: (KL:) [thus used, as a subst., it has for its pl. musotagalRaAtN:] see 10.

musotagilRN c
musotagilRN: see mugilRN.

1 galabahu c
1. galabahu, (S, Msb,) [and galaba Ealayohi,] aor.
galiba
, (Msb,) inf. n. galabN and galobN, (S, K, TA,) the former of which is the more chaste, (TA,) or the latter is an inf. n. and the former is a simple subst., (Msb,) and galabapN, (S, K, TA,) [the most common form,] or this is a simple subst. like galabN, (Msb,) which is perhaps formed from it by the elision of the p, (Fr, S,) and magolabN and magolabapN, (K, TA,) which last is rare, (TA,) and galaAbiyapN and [in an intensive sense] gulubRaI and gilibRaI (K, TA) and gulubRapN (Lh, K, TA, said in the S to be syn. with galabapN) and galubRapN, with fet-h to the g, (K, TA, in the CK glabRap,) and gilibRaMCu, (Kr, TA,) He, or it, overcame, conquered, subdued, overpowered, mastered, or surpassed, him, or it; gained ascendency or the mastery, prevailed, or predominated, over him, or it; or was, or became, superior in power or force or influence, to him, or it. (A, MA, K, PS, TK, &c.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- One says, galabotuhu Ealayohi meaning [I overcame him in contending for it; i. e.] I took it, or obtained it, from him [by superior power or force]. (A.) And guliba fulaAnN EalaI AlXRaIoCi Such a one had the thing taken from him by superior power or force. (Mgh.) Hence the saying, laA tugolabuwA EalaI SalaApK qabola TuluwEi AlXRamosi waqabola guruwbihaA Be not ye overcome and anticipated by others in performing prayer before the rising of the sun and before its setting, so that the opportunity for your doing so escape you. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And galabahu EalaI nafosihi He forced him, or constrained him against his will. (A, TA.) ― -b4- [And galabahu AlOamoru The affair overcame, defeated, or baffled, him.] ― -b5- And galabahu biAlxawofi He exceeded him in fear. (S in art. xwf.) ― -b6- And galaba EalaI fulaAnK Alkaramu Generosity was, or became, the predominant quality of such a one. (TA.) ― -b7- And galaba Oano yuxoTama [He refused to have the xiTaAm (or leading-rope) put upon him]; said of a camel. (TA in art. xTm.) ― -b8- And Oayugolabu OaHadukumo Oano yuSaAHiba AlnRaAsa maEoruwfFA meaning OayaEojizu [i. e. Is any one of you unable to associate with men kindly?]. (A.) ＝ -A2- galiba, aor.
galaba
, (K, TA,) inf. n. galabN, (S, * TA,) He was, or became, thick-necked: (K, TA:) or thick and short in the neck: or thick
and inclining in the neck: from disease or other cause. (TA.)

2 galRabotuhu Ealayohi c
2. galRabotuhu Ealayohi, inf. n. tagoliybN, [I made him to overcome, conquer, subdue, overpower, master, or surpass, him, or it; &c.: see 1: and] I made him to gain the mastery over it, or to obtain possession of it, (namely, a town, or country,) by [superior power or] force. (S.) ― -b2- And gulRiba EalaI SaAHibihi He (a poet) was judged to have overcome his fellow. (TA.) [See mugalRabN.] ― -b3- [galRaba lafoZaFA EalaI lafoZK Mxara, a conventional phrase of the lexicologists, means He made a word to predominate over another word; as in AlqamaraAni for AlXRamosu waAlqamaru; and sironaA EaXorFA for sironaA EaXora layaAlK biOayRaAmihaA: of the former instance you say, fiyhi tagoliybu Alqamari EalaI AlXRamosi In it is the attribution of predominance to the moon over the sun; and in the latter, fyh tagoliybu AllRayoli EalaI AlnRahaAri In it is the attribution of predominance to the night over the day. See more in Kull p. 115.]

3 gAlbhu c
3. gAlbhu [He vied, contended, or strove, with him, to overcome, conquer, subdue, overpower, master, or surpass, &c., (see 1,) or for victory, or superiority], inf. n. mugaAlabapN and gilaAbN. (S, Msb, TA.) You say, gaAlabotuhu fagalabotuhu [I vied, contended, or strove, with him, to overcome, &c., and I overcame him. &c.]. (O.) And Kaab Ibn-Málik says,
hamRato saxiynapu Oano tugaAliba rabRahaA
walayugolabanRa mugaAlibu AlgalRaAbi
[Sakheeneh (a by-name of the tribe of Kureysh) proposed to themselves to contend for victory with their Lord: but he who contends for victory with the very victorious will assuredly be overcome]. (TA.)

5 tglRb EalaI baladi kacaA c
5. tglRb EalaI baladi kacaA He gained the mastery over such a town, or country, or obtained possession of it, by [superior power or] force. (S, K, *)

6 tgAlbwA EalaI Albaladi c
6. tgAlbwA EalaI Albaladi [They vied, contended, or strove, one with another, against the town, or country, to take it]. (A.)

10 Astglb Ealayhi AlDRaHiku c
10. Astglb Ealayhi AlDRaHiku Laughter became vehement in its effect upon him. (TA.)

12 Aglwlb AlEuXobu c
12. Aglwlb AlEuXobu The fresh, or green, herbage attained to maturity, and became tangled and luxuriant, or abundant and dense: (S:) or became compact and dense. (TA.)

galabapN c
galabapN an inf. n. of galaba, (S, K, TA,) or a simple subst. (Msb.) [It is much used as a subst., signifying The act of overcoming, conquering, subduing, &c.; (see 1;) victory, conquest, ascendency, mastery, prevalence, predominance, superiority. or superior power or force or influence; success in a contest; or the act of taking, or obtaining, by superior power or force.] ＝ -A2- And pl. of gaAlibN. (TA.)

gulabapN c
gulabapN: see what next follows.

gulubRapN c
gulubRapN and galubRapN and galabRapN: see what next follows.

gulubRaI c
gulubRaI and gilibRaI: see what next follows.

galRaAbN c
galRaAbN (S, O) and gulabapN↓ (O) and gulubRapN↓ and galubRapN↓ (O, TA) and galabRapN↓ (O) and gulubRaI↓ and gilibRaI↓, (Fr, O,) [all of which except the first and second, and app. the fifth, are originally inf. ns.,] A man who overcomes, conquers, subdues, overpowers, masters, or surpasses, much, or often, (S, O, TA,) and quickly; (O;) [very, or speedily, or very and speedily, victorious:] or the third, accord to As, signifies a man who overcomes, or conquers, &c., quickly: (S:) pl. of the first galRaAbuwna. (TA.)

rajulN gaAlibN c
rajulN gaAlibN A man who overcomes, conquers, subdues, overpowers, masters, or surpasses; or overcoming, &c.: pl. galabapN. (TA.) ― -b2- AisomN gaAlibN A noun [used predominantly in one of its senses,] such as daAbRapN applied to “ a horse, ” and maAlN applied to “ camels. ” (TA in art. snh.) And SifapN gaAlibapN [i. e. gaAlibapN QsomiyRatuhaA, or galabato EalayohaA AlAisomiyRapu,] An epithet [in which the quality of a substantive is predominant,] such as HaAjibN applied to “ a doorkeeper. ” (TA in art. Hjb.) ― -b3- [And AlgaAlibu signifies also The most, or the most part; and the generality: whence, gaAlibFA and fiI AlgaAlibi meaning Mostly, or for the most part: in which sense fI AlOgolabi↓ is sometimes used: and generally. ― -b4- And What is most probable: whence, gaAlibFA and fiI AlgaAlibi meaning Most probably.]

Oagoalabu c
Oagoalabu [More, and most, overcoming or conquering &c.: fem. galobaMCu: and pl. gulobN]. One says qabiylapN galobaMCu A [most overcoming or] mighty, resistive, tribe. (K.) And EizRapN galobaMCu [Most overpowering might]. (S.) ― -b2- See also gaAlibN. ＝ -A2- Also Thick-necked, (S, TA,) applied to a man: (S:) [or thick and short in the neck: or thick and inclining in the neck: (see 1, last sentence:)] fem. galobaMCu, applied to a she-camel: and pl. gulobN. (TA.) And Thick, applied to a neck. (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] HadiyqapN galobaMCu (tropical:) [A garden, or walled garden, &c.,] of tangled and luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees: (S:) or of compact and dense trees; as also mugolawolibapN↓. (K, TA.) In the phrase HadaAYiqa gulobFA in the Kur [lxxx. 30], the epithet is expl by Bd as meaning (tropical:) Large. (TA.) And the fem. is applied to a [mountain, or hill, such as is termed] haDobap, (S, TA,) meaning (tropical:) Lofty and great. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlOagolabu means The lion [app. because of the thickness of his neck]. (K.)

magolabapN c
[magolabapN A place where one is overcome, or conquered. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]

mugalRabN c
mugalRabN Overcome, conquered, &c., repeatedly, several times, or many times; (S, A, K, TA;) applied to a poet: (A:) and (so applied, S, A, TA) judged to have overcome (S, A, * K, TA) his fellow, (S, TA,) much, or often: (A:) thus having two contr. significations: (S, K:) an epithet of praise as well as of dispraise: (O:) or, when the Arabs say of a poet that he is mugalRab, the meaning is that he is overcome; but if they say, gulRiba fulaAnN, the meaning is, such a one has [been judged to have] overcome: thus they say, gulRibato layolaI AlOaxoyaliyRapu EalaI naAbigapi baniI jaEodapa, for she overcame him, and he ([En-Nábighah] El-Jaadee) was mugalRab. (Mohammad Ibn-Selám, TA.)

magoluwbN c
magoluwbN [pass. part. of galaba, Overcome, conquered, subdued, &c. ― -b2- And] part. n. of guliba in the phrase guliba fulaAnN EalaI AlXRaIoCi expl. above: [see 1:] (Mgh: [and the like is said in the A:]) a poet says,
fakunotu kamagoluwbK EalaI naSoli sayofihi
[And I was like one whose blade of his sword has been taken from him by superior power or force; or who has had his blade of his sword taken from him &c.]. (Mgh.)

mugolanobK c
mugolanobK One who overcomes, conquers, or subdues, another; who gains ascendency, or the mastery, over him: (K, TA:) it is quasi coordinate to [muHoranojimN, part. n. of] AiHoranojama [which is from Harojama]. (TA.)

HadiyqapN mugolawolibapN c
HadiyqapN mugolawolibapN: see Oagolabu.

1 galata c
1. galata, aor.
galuta
, (TK,) inf. n. galotN, (I Aar, O, K,) He rescinded, or annulled, a purchase or sale. (I Aar, O, K, TK.) ＝ -A2- galita, [aor.
galuta
,] (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. galatN, (S, O, K,) i. q. galiTa [He made a mistake, or committed an error, &c.]: (As, I Aar, S, O:) or the former means in reckoning, or computation; and the latter, in speech, (AA, T, S, O, Msb, K,) i. e. he said a thing by mistake meaning to say another thing; (AA, S, O;) or the latter means in reckoning and in speech. (Lb, TA.) It is said in a trad., laA galata fiI AlUisolaAmi [There shall he no galat in El-Islám], meaning, [for instance,] a man's saying “ I bought of thee this garment, or piece of cloth, for a hundred deenárs ” and thy then finding that he bought it for less. (O.)

5 tglRthu c
5. tglRthu He took him in a state of inadvertence, or heedlessness; (K, TA;) the doing of which (i. e. AltRagalRutu) is said in a trad. to be not allowable; (TA:) as also Agtlthu↓. (K, TA.)

8 Uigotalata
8: see what next precedes.

Q. Q. 3 AigolanotaI Ealayohi c
Q. Q. 3. AigolanotaI Ealayohi He set upon him, or assailed him, or overcame him, with reviling and beating and violence: (AZ, S, O, K:) like AigoranodaI (AZ, S, O.) [See AisoranodaI.]

Algalotapu c
Algalotapu, (K,) or galotapu AllRayoli, (O,) The beginning, or first part, of the night. (O, K.)

gulotapN c
gulotapN a subst. from [the inf. n.] galatu [meaning A mistake, or an error, &c.], (O, K.)

galuwtN c
galuwtN One who makes mistakes, or commits errors, much, or often, whether in reckoning, or computation, or in speech. (O, * TA.)

1 galava c
1. galava, aor.
galiva
, inf. n. galovN, (S, O, Msb,) which is like EalovN in its meanings, (K, TA,) for the most part, (TA,) He mixed one thing with another; as wheat with barley. (S, O, Msb.) ＝ -A2- galava AlsRiqaMCa: see Ealava, with the unpointed E. ＝ -A3- galiva, [aor.
galava
,] (S,) inf. n. galavN, (S, K,) [like Ealiva,] He fought vehemently. (S, K.) And galiva bihi He kept, or clave, to him, fighting him. (S, O.) [And perhaps, as may be inferred from an explanation of mugaAlivN, one says in like manner gaAlavahu↓, or gAlv bihi; to which latter, Golius assigns a meaning similar to this, or to that which here next follows, as on the authority of J; but I do not find it in the S.] And galiva AlcRiYobu biAlganami [like Ealiva] The wolf kept to the sheep, or goats, seizing them, and breaking their necks. (S, O.) ＝ -A4- And galiva, aor.
galiva
, (K,) inf. n. galavN, (TA,) said of a zanod, It failed to produce fire; as also Agtlv↓. (K.) [See also 1 in art. Elv.] ＝ -A5- And galiva said of a bird, It vomited from its crop something which it had swallowed. (O, TA.)

2 UinRiI laOajidu fiI nafosiI tagoliyvFA c
2. UinRiI laOajidu fiI nafosiI tagoliyvFA means Verily I find, or experience, in myself, disorder, or disturbance. (O.) [See also mugalRivN: and see 2 in art. Elv.]

3 gaAolava
3: see the first paragraph above.

5 fulaAnN yatagalRavu biI c
5. fulaAnN yatagalRavu biI Such a one devotes himself to me, or clings to me with devotion. (L.) [See also tElRv, with E.]

8 Uigotalava
8: see 1. ＝ -A2- Agtlv zanodFA He chose a znd from a tree without knowing whether it would produce fire or not; (TA;) i. q. AEtlvhu [q. v.]. (K, TA.) And fulaAnN yagotalivu AlzRinaAda signifies the same as yaEotalivuhaA expl. in art. Elv. (TA in that art.) ＝ -A3- Agtlv Alqawoma gulovapF↓ He told the people, or party, a lie, or falsehood, whereby he effected his escape, or safety. (TA.)

Q. Q. 3 AigolanovaI Ealayohimo c
Q. Q. 3. AigolanovaI Ealayohimo [like AigolanotaI] He set upon them, or assailed them, or overcame them, with beating and reviling (O, K) and violence. (O.) [See AisoranodaI.]

galovu AlHulomi c
galovu AlHulomi A thing that one sees in sleep, that is not a true dream. (TA.)

galavN c
galavN What is mixed: as wheat mixed with barley. (Msb.) [In the present day, it is used as signifying What is mixed with wheat &c., of those things that are taken forth and thrown away; like EalavN. See also galiyvN.] ― -b2- [And its pl.] OagolaAvN is mentioned by Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilá- bee as a term applied to Several sorts of plants, (O, TA,) not baqol nor HamoD nor EiDaAh, (O,) among which are the EikoriX and HalofaMC and HaAj and yanobuwt and laSaf and EiXoriq and sanaA and Oasal and barodiIR and HanoZal and tanRuwm and xirowaE (O, TA) &c. (O.) [See also EalavN.]

galivN c
galivN and mugaAlivN↓ (S, O, K, TA) and gaAlivN↓ (TA) A man who fights vehemently, (S, O, K, TA,) cleaving to him whom he pursues [for bloodrevenge or the like: see EalivN]. (TA.) ― -b2- And the first, Possessed, or insane. (O, K.) ― -b3- And One in whom is an odour arising from food and wine or beverage, and an inclining of the body from side to side, and a languor, or languidness, from drowsiness. (O, K.)

gulovapN c
gulovapN: see 8.

galovaI c
galovaI A certain bitter tree, (K, TA,) with which one tans; mentioned by Kr: (TA:) or, accord. to Az, a certain tree, the fruit of which, if given to beasts of prey, or to vultures, kills them. (O.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

galiyvN c
galiyvN and magoluwvN↓ Mixed. (S, O.) Wheat (S, O, K) mixed, (S, O,) or adulterated, (K,) with barley; (S, O, K;) as also EaliyvN. (AZ, TA in art. Elv.) ― -b2- Also, the first, (Msb,) and second, (S, O, Msb,) Wheat mixed with pieces of dry clay and with [the weed called] zuWaAn [q. v.]. (S, O, Msb.) ― -b3- And the first, [as also EaliyvN,] Bread made of barley and wheat. (S, O.) ― -b4- And Food having poison mixed with it, by which vultures are killed; (O, K, TA;) as also galovaI↓, (O and TA in art. Elv,) and EalovaI; (TA in that art.;) and so lagiyvN. (O.)

gaAlivN c
gaAlivN: see galivN.

mugalRivN c
mugalRivN A moderate pain, that does not cause the patient to lie on his side, and of which the source is not known. (L.) [See also 2 in this art. and in art. Elv.]

magoluwvN c
magoluwvN: see galiyvN. ― -b2- Also A [skin such as is termed] siqaMC tanned with dried dates (tamor), or with [unripe dates in the state in which they are termed] busor. (ISk, S, K.) [But see Ealava AlsRiqaMCa, in art. Elv.]

mugaAlivN c
mugaAlivN: see galivN.

2 glRs c
2. glRs, (Msb, K,) inf. n. tagoliysN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He, or it, (a company of men, Msb, K,) journeyed in the galas, or darkness of the last part of the night: (S, K:) or went forth in the galas. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- glRswA, (K,) or glRswA AlmaMCa, (S,) They came to the water in the galas, or darkness of the last part of the night, (S, K,) or beginning of daybreak: and in like manner you say of birds of the kind called qaTFA, and of [wild] asses. (TA.) ― -b3- glRs biAlSRalaApi He performed the prayer [of daybreak] in the galas. (S, * Mgh, Msb.)

4 Agls c
4. Agls He, or it, (a company of men, K,) entered upon the galas, or darkness of the last part of the night. (A, K.)

galasN c
galasN The darkness of the last part of the night, (S, A, Msb, K,) when it becomes mixed with the light of the dawn: (TA:) or the beginning of the dawn, until it spreads in the tracts of the horizon: as also gabasN: both signify blackness mixed with whiteness and redness; like the dawn. (Az, TA.) bigalasK In a period of the darkness so called. (S, Msb, K.) [See also gabaXN.]

galiysN c
galiysN, (Sgh, K,) or gulayosN, (JK,) a proper name for An ass; [meaning a wild ass;] (JK, Sgh, K;) because he is Oagolas in colour. (JK.)

Oagolasu c
Oagolasu [Of the colour termed galasN; i. e., black mixed with whiteness and redness: see galiysN]. (JK.)

waqaEa fiI tugulRisa c
waqaEa fiI tugulRisa, (TA, and so in a copy of the S,) or fiI waAdiI tugulRisa, (K, TA, and so in another copy of the S,) and tugalRisa, (TA,) imperfectly decl., like tuxuyRiba (S, K) and tuhulRika, (K,) He fell into calamity, (AZ, S, TA,) or into an abominable calamity, (K, TA,) and that which was vain, unreal, nought, or the like: (AZ, S, TA:) originating from the fact that gaAraAt [or hostile, or predatory, incursions] (K, TA) generally (TA) took place early, bigalasK. (K, TA.)

Q. 1 galoSamahu c
Q. 1. galoSamahu, (S, TA,) inf. n. galoSamapN, (K, TA,) He cut, or severed, his galoSamap [here app. meaning larynx, or upper part of the windpipe: compare Haloqamahu]. (S, K, * TA.) ― -b2- And He took hold of, or laid hold upon, or seized, his galoSamap [here, likewise, app. meaning as expl. above: see the pass. part. n., below]. (K, TA.)

galoSamN c
galoSamN: see the next paragraph.

AlgaloSamapu c
AlgaloSamapu [The epiglottis: and also, app. by extension of the primary signification, the larynx, or upper part of the windpipe:] the thing that rises up in the uppermost part of the throat, and is said to throw the meat and drink into the œsophagus, or gullet: (Zj, in his “ Khalk-el-Insán: ”) the piece of flesh [or cartilage] that is between the head and the neck: or the Eujorap [or projecting thing] that is upon the place where the uvula and gullet meet: (K:) or [by an extended application] the head of the Huloquwm [or windpipe], (S, Msb, K,) with its [ducts called] XawaArib [q. v. voce XaAribN] and its Haroqadap [app. meaning pomum Adami]; (K;) i. e. the projecting place [or part] in the Haloq [here app. meaning, as it does in many cases, throat]: (S, Msb:) or the root, or base, of the tongue: (K:) or the place where the Huloquwm [or windpipe, i. e. the head thereof,] becomes in conjunction with the Haloq [or fauces] when the eater swallows a mouthful and it descends from [over] the Huloquwm: (TA:) pl. galaASimu. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The chiefs, lords, nobles, or men of distinction: and the congregated or collective body [of a people], or the mass [thereof]; syn. AljamaAEapu: (K:) pl. as above. (TA.) And [hence] one says, huwa fiI galoSamapK mino qawomihi i. e. fiI XarafK waEadadK [meaning (assumed tropical:) He is among (such as are distinguished by) nobility and number, of his
people], (ISk, K, TA,) [or] meaning, accord. to As, he is among the chief portion of his people, and the nobility thereof: (TA:) [and in the same sense galoSam↓ is used, without p, but perhaps only by poetic license:] Abu-n-Nejm says,
OabiI lujayomN waQsomuhu miloCu Alfami
fiI galoSami AlhaAmi wahaAmi galoSami
[(assumed tropical:) My father is, or was, Lujeym, and his fame (a tropical rendering) is what fills the mouth; one among the chief portion and the nobility of the headmen, and among headmen of a chief portion and of nobility]. (TA.)

mugaloSamN c
mugaloSamN pass. part. n. of Q. 1. ― -b2- mugaloSamaAtN means Women having the necks bound. (K, TA.) A poet says,
gadaApa EahidotuhunRa mugaloSamaAtK
lahunRa bikulRi maHoniyapK laHiymu
[In the morning when I met with them having their necks bound, (app. as captives,) they having in every bend of a valley or the like some one slain]. (TA.)

1 galiTa c
1. galiTa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
galaTa
, (S, K,) inf. n. galaTN (S, M, Msb, K) and OugoluwTapN, (JK,) He made a mistake; committed an error; or missed, or erred from, the right way or mode or manner: (Msb:) or he was unable to find the right way, (JK, M, K,) and knew it not: (M, K:) in an affair; (S;) in anything; (JK;) in reckoning, or computation, &c.: (K:) or in his speech, (S, Msb, K,) in particular; (K;) and galita in reckoning, or computation: (S, and so in some copies of the K:) but some of the Arabs make these two verbs to be syn. dial. variants. (S.)

2 glRThu c
2. glRThu, (Msb,) inf. n. tagoliyTN, (S, K,) He said to him galiTota [Thou hast made a mistake, &c.]: (S, Msb, K:) or he attributed or imputed to him the having made a mistake. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 4.

3 gAlThu c
3. gAlThu, inf. n. mugaAlaTapN (S, K) and gilaATN, (K,) [He vied, or contended, with him, each endeavouring to cause the other to make a mistake: a signification well known, indicated in the TA, and agreeable with modern usage.]

4 AglThu c
4. AglThu, (S, TA,) inf. n. UigolaATN, (TA,) He caused him to fall into the making of a mistake; (S, * TA;) as also glRThu↓, inf. n. tagoliyTN. (TA.)

galaTN c
galaTN [an inf. n. used as a simple subst., Mistake; error; in speech; or in that and also in reckoning, or computation, &c.;] has for its pl. OagolaATN; and ISd says, “ I see that IJ has made gilaATN its pl.; but I know not the reason of that. ” (TA.) magolaTapN↓ also signifies the same in the saying, waqaEa fulaAnN fiI AlmagolaTapi [Such a one fell into mistake, or error]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also magoluwTN.

galoTapN c
[galoTapN A single mistake, or error, in speech, or in speech &c.: pl. galaTaAtN.]

rajulN galoTaAnu c
rajulN galoTaAnu [A man making a mistake, or committing an error, in speech, or in speech &c.]. (TA.)

galuwTN c
galuwTN: see migolaATN: ― -b2- and see also OugoluwTapN.

galuwTapN c
galuwTapN: see OugoluwTapN.

galRaATN c
galRaATN: see migolaATN.

OugoluwTapN c
OugoluwTapN (S, K) and galuwTapN↓ and magolaTapN↓ (K) A question by which one causes to fall into the making of a mistake: (S:) or kalaAmN yugolaTu fiyhi [which may be rendered both language in which one makes a mistake, and language in which one is caused to fall into a mistake]: (K:) and all, (K.) or the first and second, (TA,) also signify a question by which a person. (K, * TA,) a man of learning, (TA,) is vied, or contended, with, in the endeavour to cause him to make a mistake, (K, TA,) in order that he may become lowered: and by which his judgment, or opinion, is sought to be made erroneous: (TA:) you say, masoOalapN galuwTN↓; but when you make the latter word a subst., you add the p: (El-Khattábee:) the pl. of OugoluwTapN is OugoluwTaAtN and OagaAliyTu (S) and galuwTaAtN, which is formed from the first of these pls. by the suppression of the hemzeh, and is not, as some have said, pl. of galuwTapN. (Hr.) Mohammad forbade OugoluwTaAt, (S, TA,) or galuwTaAt, (TA.) because they are unprofitable with respect to religion, and there is scarely, or never, in them aught save what is unprofitable. (El-'Otbee, TA.)

magolaTapN c
magolaTapN [properly, or originally, A cause of falling into mistake: similar to maboxalapN and majobanapN &c.]: see OugoluwTapN: ― -b2- and galaTN.

magolaTaAniIRN c
magolaTaAniIRN One who vies, or contends, with others, endeavouring to cause them to make mistakes in their reckoning, or computation. (TA.)

mugalRaTN c
mugalRaTN: see magoluwTN.

migolaATN c
migolaATN One who makes mistakes, or commits errors, much, or frequently; expl. by kaviyru AlgalaTi; (K;) as also glRaATN↓ (TA) and galuwTN↓. (O in art. glt.)

magoluwTN c
magoluwTN A book, or writing, having a mistake, or mistakes, made in it; and in like manner, a reckoning, or computation, as also galaTN↓ and mugalRaTN↓. (TA.)

1 galuZa c
1. galuZa, aor.
galuZa
; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) and galaZa, aor.
galiZa
; (Sgh, K;) inf. n. [of the former] gilaZN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and gilaAZapN↓ and giloZapN↓ (S, * O, K, * TK) and guloZapN↓ and galoZapN↓, (O, K, * TK,) all are inf. ns. of galuZa, (O,) or the last three, the second and third of which are mentioned in the Bári', on the authority of IAar, are simple substs.; (Msb;) and perhaps galoZN may be an inf. n. [of the latter verb]; (ISd, TA;) It (a thing, Msb) was, or became, thick, gross, big, bulky, or coarse; (Mgh, Msb, K;) it (a thing) became glRiyZ; as also AstglZ↓. (S.) You say, galuZa jisomuhu His body was, or became, thick, &c. (Mgh.) And AlzRaroEu AstglZ↓ i. q. galuZa, (Jel in xlviii. 29,) The seed-produce became thick: (Bd:) or strong: (Msb:) or well grown and thick: and in like manner one says of any plant or tree: (TA:) and galuZati AlsRunobulapu, and AstglZt↓, the ear of corn produced grain. (K.) [And galoZa AlvRawobu The garment, or piece of cloth, was thick, or coarse.] And galuZati AlOaroDu, inf. n. gilaZN, and perhaps galoZN may be also an inf. n. [of this verb, or, more probably, of galaZat], The land was, or became, rough, or rugged. (ISd. TA.) [In this sense, also, galuZa is used in relation to various things.] ― -b2- [Said of a colour, It was dense, or deep: see galiyZN.] ― -b3- Also (tropical:) He was, or became, characterized by giloZap, the contr. of riqRap, in manners, disposition, action or conduct, speech, life, and the like; (TA;) i. e., rough; coarse; rude; unkind; hard; churlish; uncivil; surly; hard to deal with; incompliant; unobsequious; evil in disposition; illnatured; or the like (S, by its explanation of giloZapN and gilaAZapN; and Msb: *) and in like manner, [as meaning it was, or became, hard, or difficult, and the like, (see galiyZN,)] it is said of an affair: (TA:) and tglRZ↓ is said of a crime; meaning it was gross, or great; but this is accord. to analogy only; not on the authority of hearsay. (Mgh.) It is said in the Kur [ix. 74, and lxvi. 9], wQgoluZo Ealayohimo And use thou roughness towards them: (Bd in lxvi. 9:) and some read waQgoliZo, with kesr to the l. (TA.) [See also giloZapN, below.]

2 glRZ AlXRaIoCa c
2. glRZ AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. tagoliyZN, He made, or rendered, the thing galiyZ [in the proper sense, i. e., thick, gross, big, bulky, or coarse; &c.: ― -b2- and also, and more commonly, in a tropical sense, i. e., (tropical:) hard, or difficult, and the like]: (TA:) and glRZ Ealayohi AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. as abuse, (tropical:) [he made the thing hard, or difficult, or the like, to him;] and hence diyapN magalRaZapN, which see below. (S, TA,) [Hence also,] galRaZotu Alyamiyna, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) I made the oath strong, or forcible; I confirmed, or ratified, it: (Msb;) [and so OagolaZotuhaA↓; for you say,] Halafa biUigolaAZi Alyamiyni (tropical:) [He swore, making the oath strong, &c.]. (TA.) And galRaZotu Ealayohi fiI Alyamiyni, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) I was hard, rigorous, or severe, to him in the oath. (Msb.) ― -b3- tagoliyZN in pronunciation: see tafoxiymN.

3 mugaAlaZapN c
3. mugaAlaZapN is similar to muEaAraDapN (assumed tropical:) [The act of mutually opposing, and app. with roughness, coarseness, or the like]: (TA:) and signifies a state of mutual enmity or hostility. (IDrd, K.) See giloZapN, below, last sentence.

4 AglZ AlvRawoba c
4. AglZ AlvRawoba He found the garment, or piece of cloth, to be thick, or coarse: (K:) or he bought it thick, or coarse: (S, K:) the former is the more correct: (O:) or the former only is correct. (TS.) ― -b2- AglZt Alyamiyna: see 2. ＝ -A2- AglZ [is also
intrans., and signifies] He (a man, Ibn-'Abbád) alighted, or alighted and abode, in a rough, or rugged, tract of land. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- AglZ lahu fiI Alqawoli (S, Mgh, Msb, K) (tropical:) He was, or became, rough, harsh, coarse, rude, uncivil, or ungentle, to him in speech: (Mgh, Msb, K:) one should not say glRZ. (TA.)

5 tagalRaZa
5: see 1, near the end.

AstglZ c
AstglZ: see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- AstglZhu He saw it to be, regarded it as, or esteemed it, thick, gross, big, bulky, or coarse. (Msb.) He abstained from purchasing it (namely a garment, or piece of cloth, S) because of its thickness, or coarseness. (S, K.)

galoZN c
galoZN Rough, or rugged, land or ground; (ISd, K;) mentioned on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád; and by AHn, on the authority of En-Nadr; but it has been repudiated: and is said to be correctly gilaZN↓: ISd says, of the former word, “ I know not whether it be [properly] syn. with galiyZN, or whether it be an inf. n. used as an epithet: ” accord. to Kr, it signifies hard land without stones: Ks says that galoZN is syn. with gilaZN↓. (TA.)

gilaZN c
gilaZN: [see 1: ― -b2- and] see galoZN, in two places.

galoZapN c
galoZapN: see what next follows.

guloZapN c
guloZapN: see what next follows.

giloZapN c
giloZapN and guloZapN↓ and galoZapN↓: see 1: these three forms are mentioned by Zj, (TA,) and in the Bári', (Msb, TA,) on the authority of IAar, (Msb,) and by Sgh; but the first of them [only] is commonly known: (TA:) they are substs. from galuZa; and signify Thickness, grossness, bigness, bulkiness, or coarseness. (Msb.) [And Roughness, or ruggedness.] ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Contr. of riqRapN, in manners, disposition, action or conduct, speech, life, and the like; (TA;) i. e. roughness, coarseness, rudeness, unkindness, hardness, churlishness, incivility, surliness, roughness in manners, hardness to deal with, incompliance, unobsequiousness, evilness of disposition, illnature, or the like: (S, Msb: *) and in like manner, hardness, or difficulty, of an affair. (TA, as shown by an explanation of galiyZN.) You say, rajulN fiyhi giloZapN (tropical:) A man in whom is roughness, coarseness, rudeness, &c.; (S, Msb; *) as also gilaAZapN↓. (S.) And it is said in the Kur [ix. 124], waloyajiduwA fiykumo giloZapN, in which the last word is pronounced in the three different ways shown above, accord. to different readers; meaning (tropical:) [And let them find in you] hardness, or strength, or vehemence, and superiority in fight: (TA:) or hardness, or strength, or vehemence, and patient endurance of fight: (Bd:) or hardness, or strength, or vehemence, in enmity and in fight and in making captives. (Mgh.) And you say, bayonahumaA giloZapN (tropical:) Between them two is enmity, or hostility; as also mugaAlaZapN↓. (IDrd, K.)

gulaAZN c
gulaAZN: see what next follows.

galiyZN c
galiyZN (S, &c.) Thick, gross, big, bulky, or coarse; (Mgh, Msb, K;) as also gulaAZN↓: (K:) fem. of the former with p: (TA:) and pl. gilaAZN. (Msb, TA.) Applied [to a body, &c.; and, as meaning Thick, or coarse,] to a garment, or piece of cloth. (Mgh, K.) You say also, OaroDN galiyZapN Rough, or rugged, land. (ISd, TA.) [And in this sense, of rough, or rugged, galiyZN is used in relation to various things.] ― -b2- Applied to a colour [Dense, or deep: see gaDobN]. (K in art. gDb.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a man, (tropical:) Characterized by giloZap, the contr. of riqRap, in manners, disposition, action or conduct, speech, life, and the like; rough, coarse, rude, unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, surly, rough in manners, hard to deal with, incompliant, unobsequious, evil in disposition, illnatured, or the like: (Msb, * TA:) and so galiyZu AljaAnibi; [contr. of layRinu AljaAnibi:] (O and K in art. fZ:) and galiyZu Alqalobi hard-hearted; (Bd in iii. 153;) evil in disposition, or illnatured. (TA.) Applied also to an affair, meaning (tropical:) Hard, or difficult. (TA.) And to punishment, [in the Kur xi. 61, &c.,] meaning (tropical:) Vehement, or severe; (Mgh;) intensely painful. (Msb.) And [in like manner] to slaying and wounding. (TA.) And to a compact, or covenant, [in the Kur iv. 25, &c.,] meaning (tropical:) Strong, confirmed, or ratified. (Mgh, TA.) And to water, meaning (tropical:) Bitter. (TA.)

gilaAZapN c
gilaAZapN: see 1, first sentence; and giloZapN.

OagolaZu c
OagolaZu comparative and superlative of galiyZN [in all its senses]. (IJ.)

diyapN mugalRaZapN c
diyapN mugalRaZapN (assumed tropical:) [A bloodwit, or fine for bloodshed, made hard, rigorous, or severe;] one which is incumbent for what is like an intentional homicide; (S;) or for a homicide purely intentional, and for that which is intentional but committed in mistake, and for that which is committed in the sacred territory, and for the slaughter of a kinsman; (EshSháfi'ee;) consisting of thirty camels of the description termed HiqRap, and thirty of that termed jacaEap, and forty between the vaniyRap and the baAzil, all pregnant. (Esh-Sháfi'ee, K.) And yamiynN mugalRaZapN (assumed tropical:) [An oath made strong or forcible, or confirmed, or ratified.] (S.) ― -b2- AlEaworapu AlmugalRaZapu: see EaworapN.

musotagolaZu c
musotagolaZu [The thick part of the fore arm]. (TA.)

1 galafa c
1. galafa, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
galifa
, (Msb,) inf. n. galofN, (O, Msb, TA,) He put a bottle, or flask, (S, O, K, TA,) or a knife, (Msb,) &c., (TA,) into a gilaAf [q. v.]; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) as also Aglf↓, (S, Msb,) inf. n. UigolaAfN; (Msb;) or glRf↓, inf. n. tagoliyfN: (K, TA:) or ↓the second signifies, (Msb,) or signifies also, (S,) he furnished it with a gilaAf; (S, Msb;) or glRf↓ signifies thus: (TA:) AlqaAruwrapa Oagolafotu↓ is said by Lth to be from AlgilaAfu; and so galRafotuhaA↓, inf. n. tagoliyfN. (O.) ― -b2- And accord. to Lth, (O,) one says, galafa liHoyatahu biAlgaAliyapi, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) aor.
galifa
, (Msb,) inf. n. galofN, (S,) meaning He daubed, or smeared, his beard with [the perfume called] gaAliyap [q. v.], (Mgh, TA,) and likewise with other perfume, and with HinRaMC; (TA;) and galRafahaA↓: (Mgh, TA:) but accord. to IDrd, the vulgar say so: (O, Msb, TA:) he says that the correct phrase is galRaAhaA (Mgh, O, Msb, TA) bAlgAlyp, (O,) and galRalahaA: (Mgh, O, Msb:) in a trad. of 'Aacute;ïsheh, however, liHoyapa rasuwli QllRehi kunotu OugalRifu↓ occurs as meaning I used to daub, or smear, the beard of the Apostle of God with gAlyp, doing so abundantly: (TA:) and one says, of a man, tglRf↓ (Lth, Th, S, O, TA) biAlgaAliyapi (Th, S, TA) wasaAYiri AlTRiybi (Th, TA) [i. e. He daubed, or smeared, himself, or his beard, with gAlyp and the other sorts of perfume]; and [in like manner,] Agtlf↓ (Lth, O, TA) mina AlgaAliyapi (Lth, O) or mina AlTRiybi: (TA:) but accord. to the saying of IDrd [mentioned above], these are wrong, and should be only tagalRaI and tagalRala, and AigotalaI and AigotalRa: (O:) or, accord. to Ibn-El-Faraj, one says bAlgAlyp tglRf↓ when it is external; and tglRl bihaA when it is internal, at the roots of the hair. (O, TA. [See also 2 in art. gl.]) ＝ -A2- galifa, aor.
galafa
, inf. n. galafN, He was uncircumcised. (Msb.)

2 galRafa
2: see 1, first sentence, in three places. You say also, galRafotu AlsRaroja [I put a gilaAf upon, or to, the horse's saddle] and AlrRaHola [the camel's saddle: see also its pass. part. n., below]. (O.) ― -b2- And AlHinRaMCu yugalRifu AlrRaOosa The HnRMC [q. v.] covers the head. (Mgh.) See also 1, second sentence, in two places.

4 Oagolafa
4: see 1, first sentence, in three places.

5 tglRf c
5. tglRf, said of a raHol [or camel's saddle, (in some copies of the K erroneously rajul,) and in like manner of other things], It had a gilaAf [q. v.], (K, TA,) of leather or the like; (TA;) as also Agtlf↓. (K, TA. [See 2, of which the former is quasi-pass.]) ― -b2- See also 1, latter half, in two places.

8 Uigotalafa
8: see 5: ― -b2- and see also 1, last quarter.

galofN c
galofN A species of trees, (S, O, K, TA,) with which one tans, (TA,) like [accord. to some meaning the same as] the garof [q. v.]: (S, O, K, TA:) some say that one does not tan therewith unless together with the garof. (TA.)

galafN c
galafN inf. n. of galifa [q. v.]: (Msb:) [as a simple subst.,] The state of being uncircumcised. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- [Also, of the heart, (assumed tropical:) The state of being Oagolaf: so, app., accord. to the TA: in the L written galafap.] ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Ample abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (TA.)

galifN c
galifN A certain plant, which is eaten, peculiarly, by the apes, or monkeys: mentioned by AHn. (TA.)

gulofapN c
gulofapN i. q. qulofapN (Mgh, O, Msb, K) and gurolapN; (Msb;) i. e. [The prepuce;] the little piece of skin which the circumciser cuts off from the gilaAf [or sheath] of the head of the penis. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And AlgulofataAni signifies The two extremities of the two halves of the mustache, next to the SimaAgaAni [or two sides of the mouth which are the places where the lips conjoin]. (TA.)

gilaAfN c
gilaAfN A thing well known; (K, TA;) i. e. a receptacle used as a repository; and a covering, or an envelope, of a thing: (TA:) it is of a sword [i. e. the scabbard, or sheath; and also a case, or covering, enclosing the scabbard, or enclosing the scabbard with its appertenances]; (S, O;) and of a knife and the like [i. e. the sheath]; (Msb;) and of a flask or bottle [i. e. the case thereof]; (S, O;) and [likewise] of a bow; (S, O, K;) and of a camel's saddle (K, TA) and of a horse's saddle, [i. e. a covering] of leather and the like; (TA;) and is such as the enclosing membrane (qamiyS) of the heart; [gilaAfu Alqalobi signifying the pericardium;] and the pellicle (giroqiY) of the egg; and the calyx of a flower; and the [imaginary] saAhuwr [q. v.] of the moon: (TA:) pl. gulufN (O, Msb, K) and gulofN (K) and gulRafN. (O, * K.) In the phrase in the Kur [ii. 82], waqaAluwA quluwbunaA gulufN, as some read it, and, accord. to one reading gulRafN, the last word means (assumed tropical:) receptacles for knowledge: (O, TA:) but others read gulofN, which is pl. of Oagolafu↓; (S, * O, * TA;) meaning (assumed tropical:) covered from hearing and accepting the truth; (TA;) or (assumed tropical:) as though they were covered from that to which thou invitest us. (O.)

Oagolafu c
Oagolafu [Enclosed] in a gilaAf [q. v.]; applied in this sense to a sword, as also [the fem.] galofaMCu to a bow; (S, O, K;) and likewise to anything. (S, O. [See also mugalRafN.]) ― -b2- And A man having upon him a sort of garment from beneath which he has not put forth his fore arms. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, L, TA.) ― -b3- And, applied to a man, i. q. Oaqolafu; (S, Mgh, O, K;) i. e. (Mgh) Uncircumcised: (Mgh, Msb:) fem. galofaMCu [see baZorN]: and pl. gulofN. (Msb.) ― -b4- Applied also to a heart, meaning (assumed tropical:) As thought it were covered with a gilaAf, so that it does not learn; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) or covered from hearing and accepting the truth. (TA.) See also gilaAfN. [And see mugalRafN.] ― -b5- OaroDN galofaMCu (assumed tropical:) A land that has not been depastured, so that there is in it every sort of small and large herbage. (Sh, O, K.) And sanapN galofaMCu (assumed tropical:) A year in which is abundance of herbage; (S, O, K, TA;) and so EaAmN Oagolafu. (TA.) And EayoXN Oagolafu (assumed tropical:) Life that is ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, and easy, or pleasant. (S, O, K, TA.)

mugalRafN c
mugalRafN, applied to a horse's saddle and to a camel's saddle, Having upon it a gilaAf [or covering] of leather or the like. (TA.) ― -b2- And applied also to a heart as meaning [As though it were] covered. (TA.) [See also Oagolafu.]

1 galaqa c
1. galaqa as syn. with Oagolaqa: see the latter. ＝ -A2- Also, inf. n. galoqN, He went away. (TA.) ― -b2- And galaqa fiI AlOaroDi, aor.
galiqa
, inf. n. galoqN, He went far into the land; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, * TA;) as also falaqa, aor.
galiqa
, inf. n. faloqN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA.) ＝ -A3- galiqa said of a door: see 7. ― -b2- [Hence,] galiqa AlrRahonu, aor.
galaqa
, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. galaqN, (S, O, Msb,) or guluwqN, (IAar, TA,) or both, (Sb, TA,) (tropical:) The pledge was, or became, a rightful possession [i. e. a forfeit] to the receiver of it (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) when not redeemed within the time stipulated; (S, O, K;) or so galiqa AlrRahonu fiI yadi Almurotahini: (Sb, TA:) or galiqa AlrRahonu means the pledge remained in the hand [or possession] of the receiver of it, the pledger being unable to redeem it; (IAar, TA;) accord. to the Bári', it is when a man pledges a commodity and says, “ If I do not pay thee within such a time, the pledge shall be thine for the debt. ” (Msb.) This is forbidden in a trad. (S, Mgh, O, Msb, &c.) It is said in a trad. of the Prophet on this subject, laA yagolaqu bimaA fiyhi laka gunomuhu wuEalayoka guromuhu [meaning It shall not become a forfeit to the receiver with what is involved in it: (or, accord. to an explanation of the first clause in the Msb, it shall not become a rightful possession to the receiver for the debt for which it was pledged:) to thee shall pertain the regaining of it, and its increase, and growth, and excess in value, if such there be, and upon thee shall be the obligation of the debt belonging to it, and the bearing of any unavoidable damage that it may have sustained]: (O:) or lahu gunomuhu waEalayohi guromuhu i. e., accord. to A 'Obeyd, to him (the owner) it shall return, and to him shall pertain its increase [if there be any], and if it have become defective, or have perished, [unavoidably,] he shall be responsible for it and shall pay the debt to him to whom it is owed without being compensated by [the remission of] aught of the debt: (Msb:) or laka gunomuhu waEalayohi guromuhu, which means to thee (the pledger) shall pertain the increase of it (the pledge), and its growth, and its excess in value, [if it have any,] and upon him (the receiver of it) shall be the responsibility [to make compensation] for it if it perish [through his fault, in his possession], (O. [There are other, somewhat different, readings and explanations of this trad. in the Mgh &c.; but what I have here given, from the O and Msb, appear to me to be the most approvable. See also gunomN: and see art. rhn.]) Zuheyr says,
wafaAraqatoka birahonK laA fakaAka lahu
yawoma AlwadaAEi faOamosaI AlrRahonu qado galiqaA
(assumed tropical:) [And she separated herself from thee with a pledge for which there is nothing wherewith it may be redeemed, on the day of valediction, so the pledge has become a forfeit to its receiver]: (S, Mgh, O, TA:) he means that she received his heart as a pledge, and went away with it. (Mgh, TA.) The saying of Ows Ibn-Hajar
Oabuw galaqK fiI layolatayoni muWajRali
means (assumed tropical:) The owner of a pledge that has become a rightful possession [or forfeit] to its receiver, the period for the release of which is two nights: to this he likens a captivated heart. (TA.) ― -b3- One says also, of a slave who has received permission to traffic, galiqato raqabatuhu biAldRayoni (assumed tropical:) His raqabap [meaning person] has become a rightful possession [or a forfeit to his creditor or creditors] by reason of debt, when he is unable to free it. (Mgh.) ― -b4- And galiqa signifies also (assumed tropical:) He was unransomed, or unredeemed; said of a captive, and of a criminal. (TA.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) He, or it, stuck fast: (S, O, TA:) thus in the saying, galiqa qalobuhu fiI yadi fulaAnapa [His heart stuck fast in the possession of such a woman or girl]: (TA:) and AiHotadRa fagaliqa fiI HidRatihi [He became excited by sharpness of temper, and stuck fast in his sharpness of temper]: (S, O. TA:) and galiqa is said of anything that sticks fast in a thing, and cleaves to it: thus one says, galiqa fiI AlbaATili [He stuck fast in that which was vain, or false]: and the saying of El-Farezdak
walawo kaAnuwA OuwliI galaqK sigaAbaA
means Had they been persons who had stack fast in poverty and hunger, cleaving thereto. (Sh, TA.) ― -b6- Also, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. galaqN, (Mgh, Msb,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, disquieted, (Mgh,) or disquieted by grief; (Mgh, Msb;) or angry, (Msb, TA.) and excited by sharpness of temper. (TA.) Hence yamiynu Algalaqi (assumed tropical:) The oath of anger; said by some of the lawyers to be so called because he who swears it closes thereby against himself a door preventing him from advancing or drawing back. (Msb.) And hence UiyRaAka waAlgalaqa (assumed tropical:) Beware thou of, or avoid thou, the being disquieted, or disquieted by grief [or anger]: or, as some say, the meaning is, AltRaToliyqaAtu HatRaI laA yaboqaI minohaA laA yugolaqu↓ XaIoCN (assumed tropical:) [i. e. The sentences of divorce shall not be closed, or concluded, at once, by one's saying “ Thou art trebly divorced, ” so that there shall not remain of them aught]; for one should divorce agreeably with the sunRap: (Mgh:) [or, accord. to the TA, UiyRaAka waAlgalaqa app. means beware thou of, or avoid thou, the state of straitness:] and Algalaqu signifies also the being in a state of perdition: (TA:) and contractedness of the mind or bosom, (Mbr, JK, TA,) and paucity of patience. (Mbr, TA.) ― -b7- One says also, galiqati AlnRaxolapu, (O. K, TA,) inf. n. galaqN, (TA,): The palm-tree had worms in the bases of its branches and was thereby stopped from bearing fruit; (O, K, TA;) and so Eani AlUivomaAri Ougoliqato↓. (TA.) ― -b8- And galiqa Zahoru AlbaEiyri, (S, O, K, TA,) inf. n. galaqN, (S, O, TA,) (tropical:) The back of the camel became galled with galls not to be cured; (S, O, K, TA;) the whole of his back being seen to be two portions of cicatrized skin, the results of galls that had become in a healing state, and the two sides thereof glistening: ISh says that in the case of the worst galls of the camel, the furniture, or saddle and saddle-cloth, cannot be [partially] raised from contact with him [so as to be bearable by him]. (TA.)

2 galRaqa
2: see 4, former half, in three places.

3 mugaAlaqapN c
3. mugaAlaqapN signifies (assumed tropical:) The contending for a bet, or wager; syn. muraAhanapN; (O, K;) originally, in the game called Almayosir: whence, in a trad., the phrase AirotabaTa farasFA liyugaAliqa EalayohaA (assumed tropical:) [He tied up a mare in order that he should contend upon her in a race for a stake or stakes]. (O.)

4 Aglq AlbaAba c
4. Aglq AlbaAba, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. UigolaAqN, (Mgh, K, &c.,) He made the door fast with a galaq, so that it could not be opened unless with a key; (Msb;) [i. e.] he locked the door; or bolted it: or he closed, or shut, it: (MA:) contr. of fataHahu: (O, K: *) and galaqahu↓, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
galiqa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. galoqN, (S, O, Msb,) signifies the same; (S, O, Msb, K;) mentioned by IDrd, on the authority of AZ; but rare; (Msb;) or a mispronunciation; (K;) or bad, (S, O, K,) and rejected; (S;) and galoqN is [said to be] the subst. from Oagolaqa; (S, Mgh, K;) whence the saying of a poet,
wabaAbK UicaA maA maAla lilogaloqi yaSorifu
[And a door that, when it turns to be locked, or closed, creaks]: (S, O, Mgh: *) and one says, AlOabowaAba galRaqotu↓ [I locked, or closed, the doors]; the verb being with teshdeed to denote multiplicity [of the objects]; (Sb, S, TA;) [and] it is so to denote muchness [of the action] or intensiveness, (O,) [for] one says also, AlbaAba glRq↓, a chaste phrase; El-Isbahánee says that galRaqotu↓ signifies I locked, or closed, (Oagolaqotu,) many doors, or a door several times, or a door well or thoroughly; (TA;) and one says also Oagolaqotu AlOabowaAba; (S, O, TA;) said by Sb to be a good Arabic phrase; (TA;) but this is rare; (O;) El-Farezdak says,
maA zilotu OafotaHu OabowaAbFA waOugoliquhaA
HatRaI Oatayotu OabaA Eamoriw bona EamRaAri
[I ceased not to open doors and to close them until I came to Aboo-'Amr Ibn-'Ammár], meaning, as AHát says, Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà. (S, O, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, Ougoliqa Ealayohi AlOamoru (assumed tropical:) The affair was [as though it were closed against him; i. e., was made] strait to him. (TA. [See also 10.]) ― -b3- And [hence] UigolaAqN signifies (assumed tropical:) The act of constraining: (Mgh, O, TA:) whence the saying in a trad., laA TalaAqa walaA EataAqa fiI UigolaAqK (assumed tropical:) [There is no divorcement of a wife, nor liberation of a slave, in a case of constraint]; (Mgh, * O, TA;) for the agent is straitened in his affair, (Mgh, TA,) as though the door were locked, or closed, against him, and he were imprisoned. (TA.) One says, Oagolaqahu EalaI XaIoCK (assumed tropical:) He constrained him to do a thing. (IAar, Mgh, TA.) ― -b4- See also 1, last quarter, in two places. ― -b5- One says also, Aglq AlrRahona (tropical:) He made, or declared, the pledge to be due [or a forfeit to its receiver]. (IAar, TA.) And in like manner one says of the arrows termed magaAliq, [pl. of migolaqN,] tugoliqu AlxaTara i. e. (tropical:) They make the stake, or wager, or thing playedfor, to be due [or a forfeit] to the player (O, TA) who wins, or is successful. (TA.) ― -b6- And Aglq AlqaAtila (assumed tropical:) He delivered, or surrendered, the slayer to the heir, or next of kin, of the slain, that he might decide respecting his blood as he pleased. (O, TA.) And Ougoliqa fulaAnN bijariyratihi (assumed tropical:) [Such a one was delivered, or surrendered, to be punished for his crime]. (TA.) And El-Farezdak says,
OasaAraI HadiydK Ougoliqato bidimaMYihaA
(assumed tropical:) [Captives in bonds of iron, delivered, or surrendered, to be punished for their bloods that they had shed]. (TA.) ― -b7- And Ougoliqa fulaAnN (assumed tropical:) Such a one was angered. (TA.) ― -b8- And AlUigolaAqu [or rather UigolaAqu Zahori AlbaEiyri] signifies (assumed tropical:) The galling of the back of the camel by heavy loads: (K, TA:) whence the phrase mano Oagolaqa Zahorahu [meaning (assumed tropical:) Such as has heavily burdened his back with sins], applied, in a trad., to one of those for whom the Prophet will intercede; the sins that have burdened the back of the man being likened to the weight of the load of the camel: [but] it is also said that AlUigolaAqu was a practice of the Time of Ignorance; that when the camels of any one of them amounted to a hundred, OagolaquwA baEiyrFA, i. e. (assumed tropical:) They displaced the sanaAsin [pl. of sinosinN, q. v.] of one of the vertebræ of a camel, and wounded his hump, in order that he might not be ridden, and that no use might be made of his back; and that camel was termed muEanRFI [q. v. in art. Enw]. (TA.)

6 tgAlqwA c
6. tgAlqwA They contended, one with another, for bets, or wagers. See 3.]

7 Anglq c
7. Anglq; (MA, TA;) and galiqa↓, (TA,) inf. n. galaqN; (KL;) and Astglq↓; (KL, TA;) said of a door, (MA, KL, TA,) It was, or became, locked, or bolted; or closed, or shut; (MA, KL;) or difficult to be opened: (TA:) Anglq is the contr. of AnftH. (Msb.) ― -b2- See a verse cited voce rawiyoYapN, in art. rwO. [And see also 10.]

10 Uisotagolaqa
10: see 7. ― -b2- [Hence] one says, Aisotagolaqato raHimu AlnRaAqapi falamo taqobala AlmaMCa (assumed tropical:) [The she-camel's womb became closed so that it did not admit the seminal fluid]. (Lth, K in art. rbE.) ― -b3- And Astglq Ealayohi AlkalaAmu (tropical:) Speech was as though it were closed against him, (S, O, K, TA,) so that he [was tongue-tied, or] spoke not: accord. to the A, it is said of one who is straitened, and required against his will to speak. (TA.) ― -b4- And Astglq AlOamoru (assumed tropical:) i. q. OaEoDala, q. v. (S and O in art. EDl.) ― -b5- And Astglq Alxabaru (assumed tropical:) i. q. Aisotabohama, q. v. (Msb in art. bhm.) ― -b6- And AisotagolaqaniI fiI bayoEiI, (ISh, O,) or fI bayoEatihi, (K,) (tropical:) He made me to be without the option of returning [in the selling to me, or in his sale]: (ISh, O, K, TA:) ― -b7- and Aisotagolaqato EalaIRa bayoEatuhu (ISh, O, K) (tropical:) His sale was to me without the option of returning. (K, TA.)

galoqN c
galoqN is [said to be] the inf. n. of galaqa as syn. with Oagolaqa: (S, O, Msb:) and (S, K) the subst. from the latter verb [q. v.].
