(S, Mgh, K.) ＝ -A2- As an epithet, (O, K,) applied to a man, or to a camel, (K,) or to each of these, (O,) Old, or advanced in age, and lean, meagre, or emaciated: (O, K, TA:) accord. to the “ Nawádir, ” it is applied to an old man [app. as meaning lean, meagre, or emaciated]: (TA:) or red; (K;) or in this sense applied to a man, and to a skin for water or milk, and to leather: (Ibn-'Abbád, O:) or, accord. to AA, applied to a skin for water or milk, vitiated, or rendered unsound, in the tanning. (O.)

maAlN giloqN c
maAlN giloqN (assumed tropical:) Unlawful property: (JK:) or property to which there is no access; (TA voce ritojN;) i. q. maAlN ritojN. (K and TA ibid.) One says HalaAlN TaloqN: [see art. Tlq:] and [in the contr. sense] HarAamN giloqN (assumed tropical:) [Unlawful, inaccessible]. (TA.)

galaqN c
galaqN [A lock;] a thing by means of which a door is made fast, (S, * O, * Msb, K, *) not to be opened save with a key; (S and K voce mizolaAjN;) a thing that is closed and opened with a key; (Mgh;) pl. OagolaAqN, (Sb, Msb, TA,) its only pl.: (Sb, TA:) and migolaAqN↓ is syn. therewith; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) pl. magaAliyqu: (Msb:) so too is migolaqN↓: (Msb, TA:) and so mugoluwqN↓: (S, O, K:) and so galaAqN↓. (TA.) El-Farezdak has used its pl. metaphorically, [in a sense sufficiently obvious,] saying,
fabitona bijaAnibaIRa muSarRaEaAtK
wabitRu OafuDRu OagolaAqa AlxitaAmi
meaning xitaAma AlOagolaAqi, the phrase being inverted by him. (TA.) ― -b2- Also i. q. ritaAjN, meaning A great door: whence the phrase mafaAtiyHu OagolaAqihaA, by which are meant [the keys of] the [great] doors thereof. (Mgh.)

galiqN c
galiqN [part. n. of galiqa primarily signifying Being, or becoming, locked, or bolted; or closed, or shut. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) A pledge being, or becoming, a rightful possession [i. e. a forfeit] to the receiver of it, not having been redeemed within the time stipulated. (TA. [See also the verb.]) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A captive, and a criminal, unransomed, or unredeemed. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A narrow, or strait, place. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A man evil in disposition: or much, or often, in anger; thus expl. by Aboo-Bekr: or narrow in disposition, difficult to be pleased. (TA.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) Speech, or language, [difficult to be understood,] dubious, or confused. (S, K, TA.) ― -b7- And naxolapN galiqapN (tropical:) A palm-tree having worms in the bases of its branches and thereby stopped from bearing fruit. (TA.) ― -b8- And galiqN applied to the back of a camel, (tropical:) Having incurable galls; the whole of it being seen to be two portions of cicatrized skin, and the two sides thereof glistening. (TA.)

guluqN c
guluqN, applied to a door, [Locked; or bolted: or closed, or shut:] i. q. mugolaqN↓; (S, O, K;) of which magoluwqN↓ is a dial. var., but bad, (S, O,) and rejected. (S, TA.)

galoqapN c
galoqapN, (S, O, K,) thus as heard by AHn from El-Bekree and others, (O,) and giloqapN↓ (O, K) as heard by him from one of the Desert-Arabs of Rabee'ah, the former the more common, (O,) and galoqaI↓, (K,) A certain tree [or plant] with which the people of Et-Táïf prepare hides for tanning by the treatment termed EaTonN: (ISk, S, TA: [see EaTana Aljiloda:]) accord. to information given to AHn by an Arab of the desert, (O,) a certain small tree, [or plant,] (O, K, TA,) resembling the EiZolim [q. v.], (O, TA,) bitter (O, K, TA) in an intense degree, not eaten by anything: it is dried, then bruised, and beaten, with water, and skins are macerated in it, in consequence of which there remains not upon them a hair nor a particle of fur nor a bit of flesh; this being done when they desire to throw the skins into the tan, whether they be of oxen or of sheep or goats or of other animals; and it is bruised, and carried into the various districts or towns for this purpose: (O, TA:) it is found in El-Hijáz and Tihámeh: (K, TA:) AHn says, it is a tree [or plant] not to be endured for pungency; the gatherer of it fears for his eyes from its exhalation or its juice: (TA:) it is of the utmost efficiency for tanning: (K, TA:) Lth says, (O, TA,) it is a bitter tree [or plant]; (O;) and it is a poison; a mixture being made with its leaves for wolves and dogs, which kills them; and it is used also for tanning therewith: (O, TA:) and AHn says, (TA,) the Abyssinians poison weapons with it, (K, TA,) cooking it, and then smearing with it the weapons, (TA,) and it kills him whom it smiles. (K, TA.) [Accord. to Forskål, (Flora Ægypt. Arab. p. lxvi.,) the names of “ Harmal Hrml, and Ghalget ed dib glqt Aldyb, ” by which he means Haromal and galoqap AlcRiYob, are now applied to Peganum harmala.]

giloqapN c
giloqapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

galoqaI c
galoqaI: see the next preceding paragraph.

galaAqN c
galaAqN: see galaqN. ＝ -A2- It is also a subst. from the verb in the phrase Ougoliqa fulaAnN bijariyratihi [q. v.]: 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd says,
wataquwlu AlEudaApu OawodaI EadiIRN
wabanuwhu qado OayoqanuwA biAlgalaAqi
[And the enemies say, “ 'Adee has perished, and his sons have made sure of being surrendered ”]. (TA.)

UigoliyqN c
UigoliyqN [like UiqoliydN, which is more common,] A key; pl. OagaAliyqu. (TA.) [OagaAliyqu may also signify Locks, as a pl. pl., i. e. as pl. of OagolaAqN, which is pl. of galaqN.]

mugolaqN c
mugolaqN: see guluqN.

migolaqN c
migolaqN: see galaqN. ― -b2- Also, (S, O, K, TA,) and migolaAqN↓ is a dial. var. thereof in this sense, (TA,) An arrow, (K,) i. e. any arrow, (S, O,) used in the game called Almayosir: (S, O, K:) or, (K,) accord. to Lth, (O,) Almigolaqu signifies AlsRahomu AlsRAbiEu fiI muDaERafi Almayosiri [i. e. the seventh arrow, app. belonging to the class, of the arrows of the game of Almysr, to which manifold portions are assigned; for AlmuDaERafu as used in relation to the game called Almysr I do not find expl. otherwise than as an appellation of “ the second of the arrows termed Algufol, to which are assigned no portion; ” (see art. DEf, and see also safiyHN;) and this cannot be here meant, as the seventh arrow (which is commonly called AlmuEalRaI) has seven portions assigned to it: therefore it seems that muDaERaf is here used, if not mistakenly, in a sense which, though admissible, is unusual in a case of this kind]: (O, K:) pl. magaAliqu: (S, O, K: in the CK [erroneously] magaAliyqu:) or AlmugaAliqu is one of the epithets applied to the winning arrows, and is not one of their [particular] names; (O, K;) they being those that make what is played-for to be a forfeit to the player (tugoliqu AlxaTara liloqaAmiri): so accord. to Az, who says that Lth has made a mistake in his explanation. (O.)

migolaAqN c
migolaAqN: see galaqN. [Hence] one says, fulaAnN mifotaAHN liloxayori migolaAqN lilXRarRi (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is a key to that which is good, a lock to that which is evil]. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. mirotaAjN [A thing with which a door is closed, or made fast, (app. a kind of latch,) affixed behind the door, in the part next to the lock]. (TA.) [See art. rtj: and see miEolaAqN, which seems to have the same, or a similar, meaning.]) ― -b3- And rajulN migolaAqN. (Msb,) and qawomN magaAliyqu, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A man, and a company of men, by means of whom (EalaI yadayohi, Msb, and EalaI Oayodiyhimo, TA,) the pledge is made a forfeit (yugonaqu). (Msb, TA.) And cuw migolaAqK means AalRaciI tugolaqu EalaI yadihi qidaAHu Almayosiri (assumed tropical:) [app. One by means of whom the arrows in the game called Almysr are withheld from the rest of the players; i. e. by his winning]: or, accord. to Z, yugoliqu AlHujRapa EalaI AlxaSomi (assumed tropical:) [app. one who closes the argument against the adversary in a dispute]. (TA in art. Elq.) ― -b4- See also migolaqN.

magoluwqN c
magoluwqN: see guluqN. ＝ -A2- Also A hide in which [the plant called] galoqap [q. v.] is put, when it is prepared for tanning by the treatment termed EaTonN: (ISk, S, TA:) or a hide tanned with galoqap. (O, K.)

mugoluwqN c
mugoluwqN: see galaqN.

1 galima c
1. galima, aor.
galama
, inf. n. galamN (Msb, K, TA) and gulomapN; (K, TA;) and Agtlm↓, (Msb, K,) only the latter of which, accord. to As, is said of other than man, though sometimes said of a man; (Msb;) He was, or became, excited by lust, or appetence: (TA:) or overcome thereby: (M, K, TA:) said of a man; and in like manner one says of a girl, or young woman: (TA:) or he was, or became, vehemently affected with lust, or carnal desire. (Msb.) And Agtlm↓ said of a camel; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and [accord. to some, contr. to an assertion mentioned above,] galima, (S, K,) inf. n. gulomapN; (S;) He was, or became, excited (S, Mgh, Msb, K) by lust, (S, K,) or by vehement lust, (Mgh, Msb,) to cover. (S, Msb, K.)

4 Aglmhu c
4. Aglmhu It (a thing) excited his lust, or appetence. (K, * TA.) And Aglm said of a beverage, It strengthened in the venereal faculty. (TA in art. Awl.) ＝ -A2- See also 8, in two places.

8 Agtlm c
8. Agtlm: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also He (a boy) attained to the limit of what is termed Alguluwmap [app. meaning the seventeenth year]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b3- Said of a beverage, or wine, (tropical:) It was, or became, strong in its influence upon the head. (Mgh, TA. *) ― -b4- Said of the sea, † It became stirred up, in a state of commotion, or tumultuous; its waves dashing together: as also Oagolama↓. (TA.) ― -b5- And AlAigotilaAmu and AlUigolaAmu↓ signify (assumed tropical:) The exceeding the prescribed limit, of good or of evil. (TA.)

galimN c
galimN, (Msb, K, TA,) and gilRiymN↓, (S, K, TA,) but this has an intensive signification, (S, TA,) and migoliymN↓, (K, TA,) [but this also has an intensive signification,] Excited by lust, or appetence: (TA:) or overcome thereby: (K, TA:) or vehemently affected with lust, or carnal desire (Msb:) [or the first may generally be better rendered in a state of excitement, or of vehement excitement, by lust and the second and third, lustful, or vehemently lustful:] the epithets applied to a female are galimapN and mugotalimapN↓ and gilRiymapN↓ and gilRiymN↓, (K, TA,) this last being applied to a male and to a female, (Az, TA,) and [particularly] applied to a he-camel, (TA,) and mgolymapN↓ and migoliymN↓, (K, TA,) the last [which is omitted in the CK] being, like gilRiymN, applied to a male and to a female: (Az, TA:) and gayolamN↓ likewise is applied to a girl, or young woman. in the sense of mugotalimapN. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., xayoruAlnRisaMCi Algalimapu EalaI zawojihaA [The best of women is the appetent to her husband]. (TA.)

gulumN c
gulumN, with two dammehs, [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] is expl. by IAar as signifying maHobuwsuwna [Persons confined, restricted, imprisoned, &c.]. (TA.)

gulomapN c
gulomapN, (S, Msb, K, TA, &c.,) written by some gilomapN, [like a pl. of gulaAmN,] is expl. by a number of authors as signifying Lust, appetence, or carnal desire: and the desire, or eager desire, of [i. e. experienced by] gilomaAn [meaning young men]: (TA:) or it signifies vehement lust or appetence: (Msb:) it is also of women, (K and TA in art. trj,) meaning their lust, or appetence: (TA ibid.:) [and] it is used [also] in relation to a camel, signifying his lust to cover. (S, K, TA.) [See also 1, where it is mentioned as an inf. n. In the K, voce qaEirapN, it is used as meaning The gratification of venereal lust.]

gulaAmN c
gulaAmN [A young man, youth, boy, or male child:] one whose mustache is growing forth or has grown
forth: (Mgh, K:) or one from the time of his birth until he attains to the period termed XabaAb [meaning young manhood (see guluwmapN)]: (K:) or i. q. AibonN SagiyrN [meaning a son that has not attained to puberty]: (Msb:) and also applied to (tropical:) such as is termed kahol [i. e. one of middle age, or between that age and the period when his hair has become intermixed with hoariness]: (IAar, Msb, K:) Az states his having heard the Arabs call thus the new-born child and also the kahol: (Msb:) the female is [sometimes] termed gulaAmapN; (S, K;) [i. e.] gulaAmapN occurs in poetry, applied to a jaAriyap: (Msb:) the pl. of gulaAmN is gilomapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) a pl. of pauc., (Msb,) and OagolimapN, (K,) [also a pl. of pauc.,] or of these two pls. they used only the former, (S, IAth, TA,) or some of them did so, (M, TA,) and gilomaAnN, (S, Mgh, K,) [a pl. of mult.,] or this is pl. of gilomapN: (Msb:) the dim. of gulaAmN is gulayRimN↓; (TA;) and that of gilomapN is OugayolimapN↓, as if it were the dim. of OagolimapN though [it has been said that] they did not use this last word; but some of them said gulayomapN↓, agreeably with analogy. (S, TA.) ― -b2- It is also used as meaning (tropical:) A male slave; like as jaAriyapN is used as meaning “ a female slave: ” ― -b3- and as meaning (tropical:) A hireling [or servant]. (Mgh.)

guluwmapN c
guluwmapN and guluwmiyRapN↓ (S, K) and gulaAmiyRapN↓ (K) The state, or condition, of such as is termed gulaAm: (S, K: *) the second is expl. by Mohammad Ibn- Habeeb as meaning the period from birth to the seventeenth year. (TA voce XabaAbN.)

gulayomapN c
gulayomapN dim. of gilomapN pl. of gulaAmN, q. v. (S, TA.)

gulaAmiyRapN c
gulaAmiyRapN: see guluwmapN.

guluwmiyRapN c
guluwmiyRapN: see guluwmapN.

gulayRimN c
gulayRimN dim. of gulaAmN, q. v. (TA.)

gilRiymN c
gilRiymN, and its fem., see galimN, in three places.

gayolamN c
gayolamN: see galimN. ― -b2- Also A beautiful woman. (TA.) ― -b3- And A youth, or young man, broad, (K, TA,) in the M large, (TA,) in the place of the parting of the hair of the head, having much hair; (K, * TA;) as also gayolamiIRN↓. (Lth, K, TA.) ― -b4- maA biAldRaAri gayolamN means [There is not in the house] any one. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also The tortoise: (TA:) or the male tortoise. (S, K, TA. [In the Msb said to be, in this sense, galiym, like zabiyb.]) ― -b2- And The frog. (K.) [Or so EayolamN.] ＝ -A3- And The place whence issues the water in wells. (K. [See also EayolamN.]) ＝ -A4- The word signifying “ a comb, ” and “ a [thing with which the head is scratched, called] midorFI, ” is fayolam, with f, but has been mistranscribed [gayolam], (K, TA,) by Lth, as has been notified by Az. (TA.)

gayolamiIRN c
gayolamiIRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

Oagolamu c
Oagolamu [More, and most, exciting to lust]. It is said that Oagolamu AlOalobaAni labanu Alxaliqapi [The most exciting to lust, of milks, is the milk of the pregnant camel, or such as has completed a year after bringing forth and has then been covered and has conceived]; i. e., to him who drinks it. (TA.)

OugayolimapN c
OugayolimapN a dim. of gilomapN pl. of gulaAmN, q. v. (S, TA.)

magolamapN c
magolamapN A cause [of lusting, or] of vehemence of lusting: such is said to be the drinking of the milk of the OayRil [or UiyRal i. e. mountain-goat]. (TA.)

migoliymN c
migoliymN, and with p: see galimN, in three places.

mugotalimN c
mugotalimN: see its fem. voce galimN. ― -b2- siqaMCN mugotalimN, (Mgh, TA,) and xaAbiyapN mugotalimapN, (TA,) (tropical:) [A skin, and a jar,] of which the beverage, or wine, is strong in its influence upon the head. (Mgh, TA. *) ― -b3- The xaArijiIR is called maAriqN mugotalimN (assumed tropical:) [A deviater from the true religion,] an exceeder of the prescribed limit. (TA.)

1 galaA c
1. galaA, aor. yagoluw, primarily signifies He, or it, exceeded the proper, due, or common, limit; was excessive, immoderate, or beyond measure; but the inf. n. differs in different cases, as will be shown in what follows: (Er-Rághib, TA:) it is said of anything as meaning it exceeded, or was excessive. (Msb.) ― -b2- You say, galaA fiI AlOamori, (S, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. guluwRN (S, K, TA) and galaAniyapN; as also bihi tgAlI↓; (K * and TA in art. glI; [but belonging to the present art., as is said in the TA;]) He exceeded the proper, due, or common, limit, in the affair; was excessive, or immoderate, therein. (S, K, TA.) And galaA fiI AldRiyni, aor. as above, inf. n. guluwRN, He acted, or behaved, with forced hardness, or strictness, or rigour, in religion, so that he exceeded the proper, due, or common, limit: whence the usage of the verb in the Kur iv. 169 and v. 81: (Msb, TA:) accord. to IAth, AlguluwRu fiI AldRiyni is the investigating of the intrinsic states, or circumstances, of things, [in religion,] and [applying oneself to] the discovery of their causes, and of the abstrusities relating to the rites and ceremonies thereof. (TA.) [See also 3.] ― -b3- And galaA biAlsRahomi, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. galowN (S, Er-Rághib, Mgh, Msb, K) and guluwRN; (K;) and bihi gAlI↓, (Mgh, K,) and gAlAhu↓, (K,) inf. n. gilaMCN (Mgh, K) and mugaAlaApN; (K;) He shot the arrow to the furthest distance (S, Mgh, Msb) that he was able to attain: (S, Mgh:) or he raised his arms with the arrow, desiring [to attain with it] the furthest limit. (K, * TA.) And galaA AlsRahomu The arrow rose in its course, and exceeded the [usual] limit; (K, TA;) and in like manner, AlHajaru the stone. (TA.) ― -b4- And galaA AlsRiEoru, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) aor. as above, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. galaMCN, (S, Mgh, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) The price, or rate, at which a thing was to be sold, was, or became, high; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) or exceeded the usual limit; (Er-Rághib, TA;) contr. of raxuSa. (K.) ― -b5- And galaA bihaA EZm [i. e. EiZamN, lit. Bigness exceeded the usual limit in her;] meaning she became plump, or fat: (TA:) one says, glA biAljaAriyapi EZm, and biAlgulaAmi, [the girl, or young woman, became plump, or fat, and the boy, or young man,] in the case of their quickly attaining to young womanhood and young manhood. (TA in another part of this art.) ― -b6- And galaA is said of anything as meaning AirotafaEa [i. e. It rose in degree; as is shown by the following ex.]: Dhur-Rummeh says,
famaA zaAla yagoluw HubRu mayRapa EinodanaA
wayazodaAdu HatRaI lamo najido maA naziyduhaA
[And the love of Meiyeh ceased not to rise in degree with us, and to increase, so that we found not what more we might give to her]. (TA.) ― -b7- See also 8. ― -b8- And see 6.

2 galRawa
2: see art. glI.

3 gAlI fiI Oamorihi c
3. gAlI fiI Oamorihi, inf. n. mugaAlaApN, signifies [the same, or nearly the same, as galaA fiyhi; i. e.] He exceeded the usual, or proper, bounds, or degree, in his affair; acted immoderately therein; or strove or laboured, or exerted himself or his power or efforts, or the like, therein; syn. baAlaga [q. v.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 1, near the middle, in two places. ― -b3- gaAlaI bihi, and gAlAhu, (S, Msb, K,) which latter is used by a poet for gAlI bh, (S,) He bought it at a high, or an excessive, price, namely, flesh-meat; (S, Msb;) as also bihi AglI↓; (S;) and AglAhu↓, i. e. water, and flesh-meat [&c.]: (IKtt, TA: [see an ex. in a verse of Lebeed cited in art. dkn:]) or he exceeded what was usual in purchasing it, or in offering it for sale, and mentioning the price. (M, K, TA.) A poet says,
nugaAliI AllRaHoma liloOaDoyaAfi niyoYFA
wanuroxiSuhu UicaA naDija Alquduwru
[We purchase at a high price flesh-meat, for the guests, raw; and we make it to be low-priced when the contents of the cooking-pots are thoroughly cooked]: he has suppressed the b [after ngAlI], meaning it [to be understood]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- And gAlI fiI AlSRidaAqi He made the dowry, or the gift to, or for, a bride, high, or excessive, in amount; [he was excessive, or exorbitant, therein;] whence the saying of 'Omar, laA tugaAluwA fiI SaduqaAti AlnRisaMCi [Be not ye excessive, or exorbitant, in respect of the dowries of women]. (TA. [See also 6.]) ― -b5- And gAlAhu, inf. n. mugaAlaApN, signifies also He contended with him for superiority in tallness or in beneficence; syn. TaAwalahu. (TA.)

4 Oagolawa
4: see 3, in two places. ― -b2- AglAhu also signifies He (God) made it to be high, or excessive, (S, Msb, K, TA,) namely, the price, or rate, at which a thing was to be sold; (S, Msb, K, * TA; *) contr. of OaroxaSahu. (TA.) ― -b3- And He found it [a thing] to be high-priced: or he reckoned it to be so; as also AstglAhu↓. (TA.) ― -b4- And He lightened, or thinned, somewhat, its
leaves, (K, TA,) namely, those of a grape-vine, in order that it might grow high, and become [more productive, or] in good condition. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 6.

5 tagalRawa
5: see art. glI.

6 tagaAolawa
6: see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- tgAlwA fiI AlSRadaAqi They were excessive, or exorbitant, one towards another, in respect of the dowry, or the gift to, or for, a bride; contr. of tasaAhaluwA and tayaAsaruwA. (TA in art. ysr. [See also 3, last sentence but one.]) ― -b3- tgAlI said of a plant, or herbage, It grew high; (M, K, TA;) it became tall. (M, TA.) And, said of the same, It became tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and large; as also galaA↓, and AglI↓, and AigolawolaI↓; (K;) or this last is said of a grape-vine, signifying its leaves became tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and its branches, or its shoots upon which were the bunches of grapes, or the buds of its leaves and berries, (nawaAmiyhi,) became abundant, and it became tall. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, said of the flesh of a beast, It rose, or went away, (AirotafaEa,) and became upon the heads of the bones: and it fell away on the occasion of preparing for racing, or the like, by scanty feeding &c.: (T, TA:) or, said of the flesh of a she-camel, it went away; syn. cahaba; (K;) or AirotafaEa and cahaba. (S.)

8 AgtlI c
8. AgtlI He was, or became, quick, or swift; he sped, or went quickly; (S, K, TA;) said of a camel: (K, TA:) and he rose [in the degree of celerity] (AirotafaEa) so as to exceed goodness of rate, or pace; and in like manner one says [Agtlt] of any beast (daAbRap); as also galat↓, inf. n. glw [app. guluwRN]. (TA.)

10 Uisotagolawa
10: see 4.

12 AglwlI c
12. AglwlI: see 6.

galowapN c
galowapN The limit, or utmost extent, of a shot or throw; (S, Mgh; *) [i. e.] any maromaAp: (K:) [generally, a bow-shot; i. e.] the measure, space, or extent, of a single shooting of an arrow: (Har p. 234:) [or the utmost measure of a bow-shot; i. e.] a shot of an arrow to the utmost possible distance; also termed gaAyapN: (Msb:) said to be from three hundred to four hundred cubits: (Mgh, Msb:) the twenty-fifth part of a complete farosax [q. v.]: (ISd, Z, Mgh, TA:) or it is reckoned by some as four hundred cubits, and by others as two hundred cubits: (Msb voce miylN [q. v.]:) pl. galawaAtN (Msb, K, TA) and gilaMCN. (S, * K, TA.) Hence, (TA,) it is said in a prov., jaroIu AlmucakRiyaAti gilaMCN, (S, K, TA,) or, as some relate it, gilaAbN. (TA. See art. ckw.) [Thus] galowapN is sometimes used in relation to horse-racing. (TA.)

galowaI c
galowaI i. q. gaAliyapN. (K.) See the latter in art. glI.

gulawaMCu c
gulawaMCu (S, K) and gulowaMCu, (K,) the latter mentioned by AZ, and app. a contraction of the former, (TA,) [and Freytag adds guluwaMC, for which I find no authority,] Excess, or exorbitance; (TA;) syn. with [the inf. n.] guluwRN. (S, K, TA.) One says, xafRifo Eano gulawaAYika [Alleviate thine excess, or exorbitance]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The quickness, or haste, or hastiness, and the first stage or state, of youth, or young manhood; (AZ, S, K;) as also gulowaAnN↓. (ISd, K, TA.) One says, faEalahu fiI gulawaMCi XabaAbihi and XabaAbihi gulowaAni↓ [He did it in the quickness, or haste, &c., of his youth, or young manhood]. (TA.) ― -b3- And gulawaMCu signifies also The rising, or rising high, and increasing, of a plant, or of herbage. (Mz 40th nwE.)

gulowaAnN c
gulowaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

galaMCN c
galaMCN the subst. from galaA AlsRiEoru; [as such signifying A high price, or rate, at which a thing is to be sold;] (Msb;) or it is an inf. n. (S, Mgh, K.) [See 1, latter half.] ＝ -A2- Also, [i. e.] like samaMCN [in measure], (K,) but in the copies of the M galRaMCN↓, with teshdeed, (TA,) A man who shoots the arrow far. (K.) ＝ -A3- And A certain small, or short, fish, (K, accord. to different copies,) about a span [in length]: (TA:) pl. OagoliyapN. (K.)

galiIRN c
galiIRN: see gaAlK, in three places.

galRaMCN c
galRaMCN: see galaMCN.

gaAlK c
gaAlK [act. part. n. of galaA: and hence, Acting, or behaving, with forced hardness, or strictness, or rigour, in religion, so that he exceeds the proper, due, or common, limit: (see 1:) and particularly] an extravagant zealot of the class of innovators: pl. gulaApN. (TA in art. sbO.) ― -b2- And Shooting, or one who shoots, the arrow to the furthest distance. (Msb.) ― -b3- And High, or excessive, (S, * Msb, K, TA,) applied to a price, or rate, at which a thing is sold; (S, Msb, K, TA;) as also galiIRN↓. (K, TA.) Hence one says, biEotuhu biAlgaAliI and biAlgaliIRi↓ I sold it, or bought it, at what was a high, or an excessive, price, or rate. (K, TA.) A poet says,
walawo OanRaA nubaAEa kalaAma salomaI
laOaEoTayonaA bihi vamanFA galiyRaA↓
[And if we were sold the speech, or discourse, of Selmà, we would give for it a high, or an excessive, price]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also Fat flesh-meat. (K.)

gaAliyapN c
gaAliyapN: see art. glI.

OagolaI c
OagolaI More, or most, high [or excessive] in price: hence the saying, OafoDalu AlrRiqaAbi OagolaAhaA vamanFA [The most excellent of slaves is the highest thereof in price]. (Mgh.)

migolFI c
migolFI [in the CK migolaAC] An arrow with which one raises the arm [in shooting] in order to exceed with it the usual limit, or nearly to do so: (K, * TA:) or, accord. to the M, that is used in striving to exceed the usual limit: also termed migolaApN↓: pl. magaAlK. (TA.)

migolaApN c
migolaApN: see what next precedes. ― -b2- naAqapN migolaApu Alwahaqi A she-camel that goes quickly when her feet of her fore legs and of her hind legs fall in one place: (S: [it is there expl. by tagotaliI followed by the words UicaA tawaAhaqato OaxofaAfuhaA which I have here rendered accord. to an explanation in art. whq in the O: but the phrase mglAp Alwhq is there mentioned as an ex. of Alwahaq as signifying “ the lasso; ” whence it appears that the phrase lit. means that exceeds the limit of the lasso; agreeably with the explanation of Golius, “ rapide currens, et fugiens laqueum sibi injiciendum: ”]) or [the meaning is a she-camel that steps far in vying, or keeping pace, with another; for], in explaining the phrase migolaApu Alwahaqi, IB says that AlmigolaApu applied to the she-camel signifies AalRatiI tuboEidu AlxaTowa; and Alwahaqu signifies AlmubaAraApu and AlmusaAyarapu. (TA voce hirojaAbN.)

OaroDN mugolawoliyapN c
OaroDN mugolawoliyapN A land having abundant, and dense or luxuriant, herbage; and with E also; i. q. mugimRapN and migamRapN. (TA in art. gm.)

1 galati Alqidoru c
1. galati Alqidoru, aor. tagoliI, inf. n. galoIN and galayaAnN, (S, MA, Msb, K,) The cooking-pot boiled; (MA, &c.;) and galiyat, aor. tagolaI, is an unusual dial. var. thereof, the former being the more chaste; (Msb;) or galiyat is not allowable. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence galaI said of a liquor, It estuated: it effervesced: it fermented: see nabiycN ― -b3- And hence] yagoliI damuhu [as though meaning (assumed tropical:) His blood is fit to be shed] is a phrase like raAba damuhu, [q. v.], said of one who has exposed himself to slaughter: his blood being likened to milk that has become thick, and fit to be churned. (A in art. rwb.) ― -b4- And galiIa AlrRajulu, like raDiIa in measure [but see what has been said of this form of the verb above], (tropical:) The man became vehemently angry. (IKtt, TA.)

2 galRaIa
2: see 4, in two places. ＝ -A2- glRI AlrRajula, inf. n. tagoliyapN, He rubbed the man over, or perfumed him, with gaAliyap. (TA.) And glRI liHoyatahu (Mgh, O,) Msb, all in art. glf) biAlgaAliyapi (O, ibid.) He daubed, or smeared, his beard with gaAliyap; as also galRalahaA. (Mgh, O, Msb, ibid. [See 1 in art. glf.]) ＝ -A3- And tagoliyapN signifies also The saluting from afar, and making a sign. (K.)

4 AglI Alqidora c
4. AglI Alqidora, (S, MA, K,) and glRAhaA↓, (K,) He made the cooking-pot to boil. (S, * MA, K. *) IDrd mentions, among some of the sayings of the people of former ages, OunRa maMCF wagalRihi↓ [Pour thou out water, and make it to boil]. (TA.) And one says, Oagolayotu AlzRayota wanaHowahu [I made the olive-oil and the like to boil], inf. n. UigolaMCN. (Msb.)

5 tglRI c
5. tglRI (S, Msb, K) biAlgaAliyapi (S, Msb) He (a man, S, Msb) perfumed himself, (S, * Msb, K,) or rubbed himself over, (K,) with gaAliyap; (S, Msb, K;) and AgtlI↓ signifies the same; (IDrd, O
in art. glf;) as also tagalRala, (Msb, and O in art. glf,) and AigotalRa. (O in that art.)

6 tagaAolaIa
6: in all its sense, belongs to art. glw, q. v.

8 UigotalaIa
8: see 5.

galaAniyapN c
galaAniyapN, mentioned in the K in this art., belongs to art. glw, being an inf. n. of the verb in the phrase galaA fiI AlOamori. (TA.)

galRaAyapN c
galRaAyapN A vessel of copper [or brass], in which water is heated; thus called by the people of Syria; the same that is called miHamRN [q. v.] and qumoqumN and qumoqumapN. (Msb voce qumoqumN.)

gaAliyapN c
gaAliyapN [Galia moschata,] a sort of perfume, (S, K,) well known; (K;) a certain compound of perfumes; (Msb;) musk mixed or boiled [with other perfumes]; (MA;) or a perfume composed of musk and ambergris and camphor and oil of ben: (KL:) it is said that the first who called it thus was Suleymán Ibn-'Abd-El-Melik; (S, TA;) and he did so because it is a compound boiled together upon the fire: or it was thus named by Mo'áwiyeh; the case being, that 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Jaafar went in to him, and the odour of perfume was diffusing itself from him; so he said, “ What is thy perfume, O 'Abd-Allah? ” and he answered, “ musk and ambergris combined with oil of ben; ” whereupon Mo'áwiyeh said, gaAliyapN, meaning highpriced: (TA:) [hence some hold the word to belong to art. glw; and their opinion is strengthened by the fact that] galowaI signifies the same. (K in art. glw.)

1 gamRahu c
1. gamRahu, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
gamuma
, (Msb,) inf. n. gamRN, (Msb, TA,) He covered it, (S, Msb, K, TA,) veiled it, or concealed it; (TA;) namely, a thing: (Msb, K, TA:) this is the primary meaning. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, gumRa AlhilaAlu (S, Msb, K, TA) EalaI AlnRaAsi, (S, TA,) inf. n. gamRN, (TA,) The new moon was veiled, or concealed, (S, Msb,) to the people, (S,) by clouds, or otherwise, (S, Msb,) or was intercepted by thin clouds, (K, TA,) or otherwise, (TA,) so that it was not seen. (S, Msb, TA.) It is said in a trad., faUino gumRa Ealayokumo faOakomiluwA AlEidRapa, (Mgh, * Msb, TA,) i. e. And if it [the new moon] be veiled, &c., to you, then complete ye the reckoning of Shaabán, thirty [days], in order that the entering upon the fast of Ramadán may be with [inferential] knowledge. (Msb.) Az says that gumRa and OugomiIa and gumiIa all signify the same: (TA:) and all three occur in the trad. above mentioned accord. to different relations thereof. (Mgh.) [See also 1 in art. gmI.] ― -b2- And [hence] gamRa Alqamaru AlnRujuwma The moon concealed the stars: or almost concealed the light of the stars. (TA.) ― -b3- And gumRa Ealayohi Alxabaru The information, or narration, was dubious, confused, or vague, to him; such as to be difficult to be understood; or such as not to be understood; (S, K;) like OugomiIa: (S:) or was obscure, or unapparent, to him. (Msb.) ― -b4- And gamRahu, (S, K, TA,) aor.
gamuma
, inf. n. gamRN, (TA,) It (i. e. hamR [here meaning “ grief, ” see gamRN below,]) covered [or was as though it covered] his heart: (Har p. 637:) or [accord. to common acceptation] it, or he, grieved him; or caused him to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy; syn. OaHozanahu. (K, and Har p. 422. [See also 4.]) ― -b5- gamRahu, in which the pronoun relates to an ass, &c., (S, K, TA,) aor.
gamuma
, inf. n. gamRN, (TA,) means He put [as a covering] to his mouth and his nostrils the gimaAmap↓, (S, K, TA,) which is a thing like the kiEaAm [or muzzle], (so in the S and CK,) or a thing like the fidaAm [which seems to be here similar in meaning to kEAm]: (so in other copies of the K:) or he put [as a covering] to his mouth a nose-bag, or the like, to prevent his feeding; and this is termed a gimaAmap↓: (TA:) [the verb that I have rendered “ put to ” in these explanations is Oaloqama, of which I do not find in its proper place any signification that would be exactly apposite in this case:] or gimaAmapN↓ signifies a sort of bag for the mouth of a camel and the like, (K, TA,) his mouth being put into it: (TA:) pl. gamaAYimu: (S, TA:) and one says, gamRahu biAlgimaAmapi [he covered his mouth with the gmAmp], aor. and inf. n. as above. (TA.) ― -b6- gamRa AlXRaIoCa, aor.
gamuma
, also signifies EalaAhu [app. as meaning It rose upon, or above, the thing, as though forming a covering over it]: mentioned on the authority of IAar, who cites [as an ex.] the saying of En-Nemir Ibn-Towlab, [app. describing a rawoDap, or meadow,]
OunufN yagumRu AlDRaAlu nabota biHaArihaA
[Not depastured, the trees called DAl rising upon, or above, the herbage of its fertile tracts, or its tracts near to water]. (TA.) See also 8. ＝ -A2- [gamRa is also intrans.: one says,] gamRa yawomunaA, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. gamRN and gumuwmN; (TA;) and OagamRa↓; Our day was, or became, [sultry, or] intensely hot, (S, K, TA,) so that it took away, (S,) or almost took away, (TA,) the breath: (S, TA:) or both verbs, said of a day, and of the sky, mean it brought gamR [or distress that affected the breath or respiration], arising from closeness of heat, or clouds. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- gamRa AlXRaxoSu, of the class of taEiba, [the first pers. being gamimotu,] inf. n. gamamN, The person's hair of his head flowed down so that his forehead and the back of his neck were narrowed. (Msb.) [See also gamamN below.]

3 gaAmamotuhu c
3. gaAmamotuhu signifies gamamotuhu wagamRaniI [I grieved him, or caused him to mourn or lament &c., and he grieved me, or caused me to mourn or lament &c.; or I grieved him &c., being grieved &c. by him]. (K.)

4 AgmRt AlsRamaMCu c
4. AgmRt AlsRamaMCu The sky became clouded: (K, as indicated by the context:) or i. q. tagayRarat [i. e., became altered]: thus in the S; but some say that it is correctly tagayRamat [agreeably with the former of the explanations above]. (TA.) See also 1, near the end. ＝ -A2- maA OagamRaka liI and UilaIRa is [an expression of wonder, meaning How great grief, or sadness, dost thou occasion to me!] from AlgamRu signifying AlHuzonu. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Accord. to the TK, OagamRahu signifies OaHozanahu; like gamRahu: but this I think a mistake. ― -b3- And Freytag explains OagamRa as occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees signifying “ Demersit: ” but in which of its senses he uses this word he does not specify.]

6 tgAmR c
6. tgAmR He made a show of gamR [or grief, &c.,] without its being in the heart. (Har p. 126.)

7 AngmR c
7. AngmR It (a thing, K) was, or became, covered, (S, K, TA,) veiled, or concealed. (TA.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

8 AgtmR c
8. AgtmR He was, or became, grieved, or caused to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy; (S, * K;) as also AngmR↓: (K:) both mentioned by Sb. (TA.) ― -b2- And, said of a plant, or herbage, It was, or became, tall, (K, TA,) and tangled, or luxuriant, (TA,) and abundant: (K, TA:) as also AEtmR. (TA.) [And in like manner gamRa↓ is expl. by Freytag as occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, said of a plant, meaning It was tall and luxuriant.] ― -b3- And, said of a man, He withheld himself from going out, or forth. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 gamogama c
R. Q. 1. gamogama, [inf. n. gamogamapN, He (a bull) uttered a cry, or cries, in fright; as also tagamogama↓: see gamagomapN below. ― -b2- And] He (a courageous man) raised his voice conflict with his antagonist; (Har p. 531;) [as also tagamogama↓: see, again, gamogamapN below.] ― -b3- And He [a man] spoke while taking a thing into his fauces, so that the hearer, or listener, did not understand what he was saying; (Har ubi suprà;) [or spoke indistinctly; agreeably with an explanation of gamogamapN below; as also tagamogama↓. ― -b4- And, said of a bow, It produced a sound; agreeably with another explanation of gamogamapN below.] ― -b5- Also, said of an infant, inf. n. gamogamapN, He wept over the breast, desiring the milk: [and the inf. n. is used as a simple subst., and therefore pluralized:] IAar cites as an ex.,
UicaA AlmuroDiEaAtu baEoda OawRali hajoEapK
samiEota EalaI vudiyRihinRa gamaAgimaA↓
[When the suckling women, after the first light sleep in the beginning of the night, are in such a condition that thou hearest cryings over their breasts]; meaning, as he says, that the milk of these women is little in quantity, so that the sucking child weeps over the breast when sucking it. (TA.)

R. Q. 2 tagamogama c
R. Q. 2. tagamogama: see R. Q. 1, in three places: and see its inf. n. voce gamogamapN, below, in two places. ― -b2- Said of one drowning (gariyq) beneath the water, it signifies He uttered a cry, or cries: or, as is said in the T, he was pressed upon by the waves above him: a poet uses it of Pharaoh when he was overwhelmed [in the sea]. (TA.)

gamRN c
gamRN [an inf. n. used as an epithet in which the
quality of a subst. predominates,] Grief, mourning, lamentation, sorrow, sadness, or unhappiness; syn. HuzonN; (Msb, K;) so called because it covers happiness and forbearance; (Msb;) or gamR in the heart is thus called because it veils, or precludes, happiness: (Ham p. 21:) [it may therefore be rendered gloominess of mind:] or i. q. karobN, (K,) which signifies Huzon, (K in art. krb,) or gamR, (S, in that art.,) [that affects the breath or respiration, lit.] that takes away the breath; (S and K in that art.;) as also gamRaMCu↓ (K) and gumRapN↓, (S, K,) the last [expl. in the S as syn. with kurobapN, which is syn. with karobN, and] mentioned by Lh: (TA:) [see also SaqaEN:] it is karob [or grief, &c.,] that befalls the heart because of what has happened; differing from hamRN, which is krb that befalls because of annoyance, or harm, that is expected to happen: or, as some say, both are one [in meaning]: the differing is asserted by 'Iyád and [many] others: (TA:) [see also gaSabN:] the pl. of gamRN is gumuwmN. (S, K.) ― -b2- It is also an inf. n. used as an epithet in the phrase yawomN gamRN (S, TA) i. e. A day that is [sultry, or] intensely hot, so that it [almost] takes away the breath; and layolapN gamRN [such a night], i. e. gaAmRapN↓: (S:) or one says yawomN gamRN and gaAmRN↓ and migamRN↓, (K, TA,) the last with kesr to the m, (TA,) [in the CK mugimRN↓,] meaning a day of heat, (K,) or of intense heat: (TA:) or a day of gamR [i. e. grief, &c.]: and [in a similar sense, as is implied by the context immediately preceding,] layolapN gamRN and gamRapN and gamRaI↓: (K:) [but] A'Obeyd mentions, on the authority of AZ, layolapN gamRaI↓ and layolapN gamRapN↓ as meaning a night in which there is over the sky [a covering of clouds, or] what is termed gamoIN [a word belonging to art. gmI, being in measure] like ramoIN; (S;) and [in the like sense] yawomN gamRN. (So in one of my copies of the S.) ― -b3- And one says, kaAna EalaI AlsRamaMCi gm [app. gamRN, but this, I think, requires confirmation, for which I have searched in vain,] and gmI [app. gamRaI↓, or perhaps gamoIN, a word mentioned above,] meaning There was over the sky a collection [or an expanse] of thin clouds, or a DabaAbap [i. e. mist, or the like], faHaAla duwna AlhilaAli [and it intercepted the new moon]: and hecihi layolapu gamRaI↓, and some say gumRaI↓, This is a night [of a covering of clouds, or] of a DabaAbap [or mist, or the like], intervening between the new moon and men; so that the new moon is not seen: (Msb:) and [hence] SumonaA lilogamRaI↓, and lilogumRaI↓, (S, Msb, K,) both mentioned by ISk on the authority of Fr, (S,) and lilogamRaMCi↓, (S, K,) and lilogumRiyRapi↓, (K, TA, but omitted in the CK,) and lilogumRapi↓, (TA,) [i. e. We fasted after, or from the time of, the covering of clouds, or the mist, or the like, that concealed the new moon; (the prep. li being here used in the sense of baEoda, or mino waqoti, as in the Kur xvii. 80;) virtually] meaning [we fasted] without a sight [of the new moon]: (Msb, TA:) a rájiz says,
TaAmisK hilaAluhaA layolapa gumRaI↓
OawogalotuhaA wamukorapN UiyogaAluhaA
[In a night of a covering of clouds, or of a mist, or the like, having its new moon effaced: I journeyed quickly and far in it, (OawogalotuhaA) being used, app. by poetic license, for Oawogalotu fiyhaA,) and disliked was the journeying so therein]: (S, TA:) and it is said that layolapu gmRI [i. e. gamRaI↓ and gumRaI↓] signifies also the last night of the [lunar] month; being so called because the case thereof is veiled to people so that it is not known whether it be of the coming [month] or of the past. (TA.)

gamRapN c
gamRapN fem. of gamRN, q. v., used as an epithet.

gumRapN c
gumRapN: see gamRN, first sentence: ― -b2- and also in the latter half. ― -b3- Also, (assumed tropical:) Perplexity, and dubiousness, or confusedness: pl. gumamN: one says, huwa fiI gumRapK (assumed tropical:) He is in a state of perplexity, and dubiousness, or confusedness: (Msb:) and huwa fiI gumRapK mino Oamorihi (assumed tropical:) He is in a state of perplexity and darkness [in respect of his case or affair]; from AlgamRu signifying “ the act of covering ” [a thing]. (Ham p. 320.) [See also gimRapN and gamRaMCu.] And one says OamorN gumRapN (assumed tropical:) A dubious, confused, or vague, case or affair. (S, K. *) [See also gumRaI.] It is said in the Kur [x. 72], vumRa laA yakuno Oamorukumo Ealayokumo gumRapF i. e. (tropical:) [Then let not your case be to you one of] darkness, and straitness, and anxiety: (A'Obeyd, S, TA:) or, as some say, covered, veiled, or concealed. (TA.) And OaroDN gumRapN means (assumed tropical:) A strait, or narrow, land. (TA.) ― -b4- Also The bottom of the interior of a skin for clarified butter (S, K) &c. (S.) [See also the first sentence in art. gml.]

gimRapN c
gimRapN i. q. lbsp [app. lubosapN, meaning (assumed tropical:) Obscureness, confusedness, or dubiousness: see also gumRapN]. (TA.)

gamamN c
gamamN is the inf. n. of 1 in the last of the senses expl. above: (Msb:) or it signifies The flowing down of the hair so that the forehead, (S, K, TA,) or as in the M, the face, (TA,) and the back of the neck, are narrowed: (S, K, TA:) or the hair that veils, or conceals, the jabiyn [generally meaning the part above the temple, but sometimes it means the forehead,] and the back of the neck. (Har p. 21.) Z says that they dislike what is thus termed, and like what is termed nazaEN [i. e. baldness of the two sides of the forehead]. (TA.)

gamaAmN c
gamaAmN Clouds: (S, Msb, K:) or white clouds: (K:) or thin clouds: (Jel in ii. 54:) and gamaAmapN↓ signifies one thereof: (S, Msb, K:) the former being pl. of the latter, as also is gamaAYimu: (K:) [or rather gamaAmN is a coll. gen. n., of which gamaAmapN is the n. un.:] they are so called because they veil the sky, or because they veil the light of the sun. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] HabRu AlgamaAmi signifies Hailstones, or hail. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. An, p. 109.]

gumaAmN c
gumaAmN i. q. zukaAmN [A rheum, such as is termed coryza]. (K.)

gumuwmN c
gumuwmN [a pl. of which no sing. is mentioned,] Small stars, such as are faint, or indistinct. (K.)

gamiymN c
gamiymN i. q. gamiysN, (S, K,) i. e. Fresh herbage (kalaON) beneath such as is dried up; (S, TA;) or green herbage beneath such as is dry. (TA.) ― -b2- And Milk heated until it thickens: (S, K:) because it becomes covered over. (TA.)

gamaAmapN c
gamaAmapN: see gamaAmN. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Herbage: so in the saying, OaHomaI fulaAnN gamaAmapa waAdiI kacaA i. e. (tropical:) [Such a one made to be prohibited to the public] the herbage that was the growth of such a valley: thus called [because produced by the water of the clouds,] in like manner as it is called samaMCN. (TA.)

gumaAmapN c
gumaAmapN: see the next paragraph.

gimaAmapN c
gimaAmapN: see 1, near the middle, in three places. ― -b2- Also A thing with which the eyes of a she-camel are bound, or with which her muzzle is bound: (K:) or a piece of cloth with which the nose of a she-camel is stopped (yusadRu) [or bound (yuXadRu)] when she is made to incline to the young one of another: pl. gamaAYimu. (A'Obeyd, TA.) [See also darojapN: and SiqaAEN.] ― -b3- And (by way of comparison [thereto], TA) (tropical:) The prepare of a boy; as also gumaAmapN↓. (K, TA.)

gamRaI c
gamRaI: see gamRN, in six places. ― -b2- Also Dust; syn. gabarapN. (K.) ― -b3- And Darkness. (K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Hardship, or difficulty, or distress, [as though] covering [or overwhelming] a party in war, or battle. (K.) See also the next paragraph.

gumRaI c
gumRaI: see gamRN, latter half, in four places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A calamity, or misfortune; and so gamRaMCu↓; (K, TA;) and gumRaMCu↓, likewise, is said to be allowable. (TA. [But this last I think doubtful.]) And (assumed tropical:) A hard, or difficult, affair or case, in relation to which one knows not the right course to pursue; as also gamRaI↓, (K, TA,) and gamRaMCu↓. (TA.)

gamRaMCu c
gamRaMCu [fem. of OagamRN, q. v.: ― -b2- and also used as a subst.]: see gamRN, first sentence: ― -b3- and also in the latter half: ― -b4- and see also gumRaI, in two places. ― -b5- UinRahumo lafiI gamRaMCa mina AlOamori means [Verily they are in a state of dubiousness, or confusedness, in respect of the case, or affair; or] in a dubious, or confused, case or affair. (TA.) [See also gumRapN and gimRapN.]

gumRaMCu c
gumRaMCu: see gumRaI.

gumRiyRapN c
gumRiyRapN: see gamRN, latter half.

gaAmRN c
gaAmRN, and its fem. gaAmRapN: see gamRN, former half.

gamogamapN c
gamogamapN [mentioned above as an inf. n. (see
R. Q. 1), used as a simple subst.,] signifies The cries [or cry] of bulls [or wild bulls] in fright: (S, K, TA:) and of courageous men in conflict: (S, Mgh, K, TA:) and so tagamogumN↓: pl. of the former, in both senses, gamaAgimu. (TA.) See also an ex. of the pl. voce gamogama. ― -b2- And Indistinct speech; (K;) as also tagamogumN↓: (S, K:) gamogamapN is when one hears the voice but does not distinguish the articulation of the words; and when speech resembles that of the Eajam. (T, in TA, voce rutRapN.) ― -b3- Also The sound of bows. (TA.)

rajulN OagamRN c
rajulN OagamRN, (S,) and OagamRu Alwajohi waAlqafaA, (S, Msb, K,) A man whose hair flows down so that the face and the back of the neck are narrowed: (S, Msb, K:) and in like manner [the fem.] gamRaMCu is applied to a woman. (Msb.) ― -b2- gamRaMCu applied to the forelock (naASiyap) of a horse means Excessively abundant in the hair: and such is disliked. (S.) ― -b3- And saHaAbN OagamRN means (tropical:) Clouds in which is no gap, or interstice. (K, TA.)

mugimRN c
mugimRN and migamRN: see gamRN, former half. ― -b2- OaroDN mugimRapN (K, TA) and migamRapN (TA) A land having abundant (K, TA) and dense or luxuriant (TA) herbage. (K, TA.)

mugamRimN c
mugamRimN, applied to clouds (gayom), and to a sea, Abounding with water: (K:) and in like manner, without p, to a well (rakiyRap), that fills everything, and submerges it: (IAar, TA:) and to what is termed HisoIN [q. v.], (IAar, S, TA,) meaning covering. (IAar, TA.)

magomuwmN c
magomuwmN [pass. part. n. of gamRahu, i. e. Covered, &c.]. ― -b2- [Applied to unripe dates (accord. to the TA to ruTab, a mistranscription for busor), like magomuwlN,] Put into a jar, and covered over until they have become ripe. (TA.) ― -b3- Applied to a new moon, Veiled, or concealed, by clouds, or otherwise, (Msb,) or intercepted by thin clouds, (K,) so as not to be seen. (Msb.) ― -b4- Applied to a man, Grieved, or caused to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy. (TA.) ― -b5- And Affected with the malady termed gumaAm. (K.)

1 gamatahu c
1. gamatahu, aor.
gamita
, (S, O, K,) inf. n. gamotN, (S, O,) It (i. e. food) was, or became, heavy upon his heart [or stomach], (Ks, S, O, K,) he having eaten much thereof so that it caused him to suffer indigestion, (Ks, O,) and it rendered him like one intoxicated: (K:) or, accord. to Sh, it (i. e. grease) rendered him like one intoxicated, (O, TA,) in consequence of indigestion. (TA.) ― -b2- And He covered it; (O, K;) namely, a thing. (K.) ― -b3- And gamatahu fiI AlmaMCi i. q. gaTRahu [i. e. He immersed, or plunged, him, or it, into the water; like gatRahu]. (IDrd, O, K.) ― -b4- And gamata nafasFA He made a sign, or motion, with' his head, (O,) or he raised his head, (K,) [for the purpose of taking breath,] in drinking. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- gamita He became like one intoxicated, by grease [in his stomach]: (Sh, O:) or he suffered from the heaviness of food upon his heart [or stomach] so that he became like one intoxicated. (K.)

1 gamadahu c
1. gamadahu, aor.
gamida
and
gamuda
, inf. n. gumodN; and Agmdhu↓, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UigomaAdN; (Msb;) mentioned by AO, (S,) or by A'Obeyd, (L, TA,) as two chaste forms; (S, L, TA;) He put it (i. e. a sword, S, Msb, K, or the like, Msb) into its gimod [i. e. scabbard, or sheath; he sheathed it]: (S, Msb, K:) or he made for it, or furnished it with, a gimod. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, gamadahu bikacaA (tropical:) He covered him, or it, with such a thing; as though he made the latter a gimod to the former. (A.) ― -b3- See also 5, in two places. ＝ -A2- gamada, inf. n. gumuwdN, said of a tree of the species called EurofuT, (assumed tropical:) It had its branches abounding with leaves so that one could not see its thorns; (L, K;) as though they were sheathed. (L.) ― -b2- gamadati AlrRakiyRapu, (L, K,) aor.
gamuda
, inf. n. gumuwdN, (L,) (tropical:) The well lost its water. (L, K.) ― -b3- And gamidat, (L, K,) aor.
gamada
, (K,) inf. n. gamadN, (L,) (tropical:) It (a well) had much water: (As, L, K:) or it had little water. (AO, L, K.)

2 gamRada
2: see 5, in two places.

4 Oagomada
4: see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] Agmd AlOaXoyaMCa (tropical:) He put the things one within another. (K.) ― -b3- And Agmd AlHilosa (tropical:) He put the [cloth called] Hilos beneath the camel's saddle, to preserve the animal's back from being galled by the saddle. (Akh, A, * L.)

5 tgmRd AlvRawoba c
5. tgmRd AlvRawoba (tropical:) He put the garment, or piece of cloth, beneath him, to conceal it from the eyes of others. (A.) ― -b2- And tgmRdAlrRajula, (JK, L,) and gmRdhu↓, (L,) (assumed tropical:) He took the man beneath him (taHotahu, thus in the JK, in the L bixatolK [by deceit, or guile]), to cover him over, or conceal him. (JK, L.) ― -b3- And tgmRd fulaAnFA, (S, L, K,) and gmRdhu↓, (K,) (tropical:) He concealed, as with a veil, what had proceeded from such a one, or what such a one had done. (S, L, K.) ― -b4- And tgmRdhu QllRehu biraHomatihi, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) and bihaA gamadahu↓ and fiyhaA gamadahu↓, (L,) (tropical:) God covered him with his mercy, (A'Obeyd, S, A, L, Msb, K,) as with a veil; veiled him therewith; (A'Obeyd, A, L, Msb;) clad him, or invested him, therewith. (A'Obeyd, L.) ― -b5- tgmRd AlOaEodaMCa (assumed tropical:) He threw himself upon the enemies; or came upon them, or over them; and overwhelmed them. (L.) ― -b6- And tgmRdhu (tropical:) He filled it, (A, K,) namely, a measure of capacity, (A,) or a vessel. (K.)

8 Agtmd AllRayola c
8. Agtmd AllRayola (tropical:) He (a man, S, L) entered into [the darkness of] the night; (S, A, L, K;) as though it became as a gimod to him; like as one says AidRaraEa AllRayola: (S, L:) and simply Agtmd he ventured upon, encountered, or braved, the night, (rakibahu,) to seek food for his family. (S, L.)

10 Aisotagomadati AlsRamaMCu fiI AlsRaHaAbi Alkaviyri c
10. Aisotagomadati AlsRamaMCu fiI AlsRaHaAbi Alkaviyri (assumed tropical:) [The sky became obscured amid the many clouds]. (TA in art. Tnfs.)

gimodN c
gimodN (S, L, Msb, K, &c.) and gumudRaAnN↓, (L, K,) but the latter is not of established authority, (IDrd,) of a sword, (S, L, Msb, K,) and the like, (Msb,) The scabbard, or sheath; [this is well known to be the correct meaning; it is shown to be so in the S, voce qiraAbN; and is the meaning obtaining in the present day;] syn. gilaAfN, (S, O,) or jafonN: (L, K:) [both of these words have the signification mentioned above; but not that only; for glAf has a wider application; and it is said in the S, voce qiraAbN, that the jfn of a sword is a case, or receptacle, in which is (put) the sword together with its gimod and suspensory belt or cord:] the pl. is OagomaAdN [a pl. of pauc.] (O, Msb, K) and gumodaAnN, (O,) or gumuwdN. (K.)

gumudRaAnN c
gumudRaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

rakiIRN gaAmidN c
rakiIRN gaAmidN, a phrase like EiyXapN raADiyapN, [gaAmidN meaning magomuwdN,] (tropical:) Wells having their water covered by earth, or dust; contr. of rakiIRN mubodK. (A.) And gaAmidapN (tropical:) A well (biYorN) filled up, or choked up, with earth, or dust. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And gaAmidapN and gaAmidN (assumed tropical:) A ship (safiynapN) filled, or laden; (K, TA;) as also MmidapN (TA) and MmidN. (K, TA.)

mugomadN c
mugomadN: see what here follows.

magomuwdN c
magomuwdN and mugomadN↓ A sword [or the like] put into its gimod [meaning scabbard, or sheath; i. e. sheathed]. (S, A.)

1 gamura c
1. gamura, as in some lexicons, or gamara, aor.
gamura
, accord. to all the copies of the K [consulted by SM], (TA,) or gamira, [aor.
gamara
,] (as in the CK and my MS. copy of the K,) inf. n. gamaArapN and gumuwrapN, [agreeably with analogy if gamura be the form of the verb, which is therefore most probably correct,] (K,) It (water) was, or became, much in quantity, abundant, copious, [or deep,] (K, B, TA,) so that it concealed its bottom. (B, TA.) You say maA OaXadRa gumuwrapa hecaA AlnRahori How great is the abundance of the water of this river! (S.) ― -b2- [And (tropical:) He abounded in beneficence.] You say rajulN bayRinu Algumuwrapi (tropical:) A man bearing evidence of abounding in beneficence. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- gamarahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
gamura
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. gamorN, (Msb, K,) It (water, S, K, or the sea, Msb) [overflowed,] came over, or rose above, (S, Msb,) or covered, (K,) and concealed, (TA,) him, or it; (S, Msb, K;) as also Agtmrhu↓: (K:) and he (a man) veiled, concealed, hid, or covered, him, or it. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, gamarahu Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The people rose above him, or surpassed him, in eminence, (S, TA,) and in excel-lence. (TA.) ― -b3- And raOayotuhu qado gamara AljamaAjima biTuwli qawaAmihi (assumed tropical:) [I saw him to have overtopped the heads of others by the tallness of his stature]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- gamira Sadoruhu EalaIRa, aor.
gamara
, (S, Msb, K, *) inf. n. gamarN (Yaakoob, S, Msb) and gimorN, (Yaakoob, S,) [or the latter is a simple subst.,] His bosom bore con-
cealed enmity and violent hatred, or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against me. (S, Msb, K.) ＝ -A4- gamirato yaduhu, (S, K,) aor.
gamara
, (K,) inf. n. gamarN, (TA,) His hand was, or became, foul with the smell of flesh-meat, (S, K,) and with the grease thereof adhering to it. (K.) ＝ -A5- gamura, aor.
gamura
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. gamaArapN, (S, [in my copy of the Msb written gamaAr, probably by a mistake of the copyist,]) He was inexperienced in affairs: (S, Msb:) Benoo-'Okeyl say gamira, aor.
gamara
. (Msb.) You say fiyhi gamaArapN and garaArapN [In him is a want of experience in affairs]. (TA.)

2 gmRrt wajohahaA c
2. gmRrt wajohahaA, inf. n. tagomiyrN, She (a woman) smeared her face with gumorap [q. v.]; (S;) as also biAlgumorapi Agtmrt↓, (K,) and tgmRrt↓. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- gumRira, inf. n. tagomiyrN, He (a man) was deemed ignorant. (TA.) ＝ -A3- gmRr farasahu, inf. n. as above, He gave his horse water to drink in a cup, (K,) in the small cup called gumar, (TA,) because of the scarcity of water. (K.) IAar mentions the phrase gmRrhu OaSoHunFA He gave him to drink some bowls of water: making the verb doubly transitive. (TA.)

3 gAmr fiI AlqitaAli c and gAms fiyhi
3. gAmr fiI AlqitaAli gAms fiyhi signify the same [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He plunged, or threw himself, into the midst of fight, or conflict]. (TA in art. gms.) [See also mugaAmirN.] ― -b2- And gAmrhu (assumed tropical:) He engaged with him in fight, or conflict, not caring for death. (S, O.) ― -b3- And gAmr signifies also (assumed tropical:) He contended in an altercation, or a dispute. (O.)

5 tgmRrt c
5. tgmRrt: see 2. ＝ -A2- tgmRr He drank from a small cup such as is called gumar: (K:) he drank a small quantity of water: (TA:) he drank less than would satisfy his thirst: (S:) he drank the smallest draught, less than would satisfy his thirst: (TA:) he did not satisfy his thirst with water; (K, * TA;) said of a camel, (K,) and of an ass. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And tgmRrt AlmaAXiyapu The cattle ate what is termed gamiyr [q. v.]. (K.)

7 Angmr c
7. Angmr He immerged, dipped, or plunged, himself, or he became immerged, dipped, or plunged, (S, K,) in water, (S, TA,) and in a thing; (TA;) as also Agtmr↓. (K.)

8 Uigotamara
8: see 1: ＝ -A2- and 7: ＝ -A3- and 2.

gamorN c
gamorN Much, abundant, copious, [or deep,] water; (S, K;) as also gamiyrN↓: (K:) or much, abundant, copious, [or deep,] water, that drowns, or submerges: (ISd, TA:) or that covers over him who enters into it: (IAth, TA:) [also used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, meaning much, abundant, copious, or deep, water;] and gamorapN↓ signifies the same as gamorN [when thus used; or a submerging deep, a deep place, or an abyss, of water]: (TA:) pl. gimaArN and gumuwrN. (S, K.) You say baHorN gamorN An abundant sea: and [in the pl.] biHaArN gimaArN, and gumuwrN. (S.) And of a thing that has become much, you say, hecaA kaviyrN gamiyrN↓ This is much. (AZ.) [See also Algamari.] ― -b2- The main of the sea: (K:) pl. as above. (TA.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) Liberal in disposition: (K, * TA:) pl. as above: (TA:) and in like manner, gamoru Alxuluqi: (TA:) or this last, and gamoru Albadiyhapi, signify (tropical:) abounding in beneficence: pl. as above: (S, K: [see also ridaMCN:]) and gamoru Albadiyhapi (tropical:) a man who takes by surprise with large bounty. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A horse fleet, or swift, or excellent, in running. (S, * K, * TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A garment ample, or full. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- (assumed tropical:) A mixed crowd of men, (K,) and their thronging, pressing, or pushing, and multitude; (TA;) as also gamarN↓ and gamorapN↓ and gumaArN↓ and gamaArN↓: (K: [in the TA, instead of the last two words, I find gumaArapN and gamaArapN, as from the K, and gumaArN and gamaArN are afterwards there added: but most probably these only (without p) are correct:]) and gamorapN↓ and gumaArN↓ and gamaArN↓ signify a crowding, or pressing, of men, (S, Msb,) and of water: (S:) the pl. of gamorapN↓ is gimaArN. (S.) You say AlnRaAsi daxalotu fiI gumaAri↓, and gamaArihimo↓, (S, Msb, TA,) and gamarihimo↓, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) I entered among the crowding, or pressing, of the people, (S, Msb, TA,) and their multitude: (S, TA;) as also fI xamarihimo [and xumaArihimo &c.] (TA.) And Oakuwnu fiI gumaAri↓ AlnRaAsi, meaning I shall be among the dense congregation of the people, occurs in a trad. (TA.) ＝ -A4- See also gumorN. ＝ -A5- layolN gamorN means Intensely dark night. (TA.)

gumorN c
gumorN (S, Msb, K) and gumurN↓ (S, ISd) and gamorN↓ and gimorN↓, accord. to the K, but this last is unknown, (TA,) and gamarN↓ (K) and gamirN↓, (TA,) originally, A boy devoid of intelligence: and hence, (Msb,) a man (S, Msb) inexperienced in affairs: (S, Msb, K:) ignorant: (TA:) inexperienced in war and in counsel; not rendered firm, or sound, in judgment, by experience: (L:) one in whom is no profit nor judgment: (ISd, TA:) one in whom is no good nor profit with respect to intelligence or judgment or work: (AZ, Msb:) and mugamRarN↓ signifies the same as gumorN; (S, TA;) or deemed ignorant: (TA:) the fem. of gumorN is with p; (S, Msb;) and so is that of gamirN↓: (TA:) and the pl. of gumorN is OagomaArN; (S, Msb, TA;) and this may also be pl. of gamarN↓, like as OasobaAbN is pl. of sababN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also gumorapN.

gimorN c
gimorN Concealed enmity and violent hatred, or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (S, Msb, K.) [See also gamira.] ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Thirst: (S, Msb:) pl. OagomaArN. (S.) El-'Ajjáj says,
HatRaI UicaA maAbalRati AlOagomaAraA
(tropical:) [Until, when they damped their thirst]. (S.) balRati AlUibilu OagomaArahaA means (tropical:) The camels drank a little. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also gumorN.

gamarN c
gamarN A drowning; being drowned: so in the phrase mawotu Algamari Death by drowning. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also gamorN. ＝ -A3- The foul smell of flesh-meat, (S, Mgh, K,) and its grease adhering to the hand: (K:) and the smell of fish. (S.) Hence, minodiylu Algamari (S, Mgh) The napkin, or rough napkin, with which the hand is cleansed therefrom. (L, TA.) ＝ -A4- See also gumorN, in two places.

gamirN c
gamirN [part. n. of gamira]. You say yadN gamirapN A hand foul with the smell of flesh-meat, (S, K,) and with the grease thereof adhering to it. (K.) [See also sahikN.] ＝ -A2- See also gumorN, in two places. ＝ -A3- gamirapN as an epithet applied to a she-camel, see voce gabirN.

gumarN c
gumarN A small drinking-cup or bowl, (S, K,) with which people divided the water among themselves in a journey when they had little of it; and this they [sometimes] did by putting a pebble into a vessel, and then pouring into it as much water as would cover the pebble, and giving it to each man among them: (TA:) or the smallest of drinking-cups or bowls: (K:) [see qaEobN; and tibonN:] accord. to ISh, it contains twice or thrice the quantity of the measure called kiylajap: [but this seems to be a large gmr, used for watering a horse; and the words which here immediately follow are app. not added by ISh, but relate to the gmr used by a man for himself or for another man:] the qaEob is larger than it, and satisfies the thirst of a man: the pl. is OagomaArN. (TA.) El-Aashà of Báhileh says, in an elegy on his brother ElMunteshir Ibn-Wahb,
takofiyhi HuzRapu filocK Uino OalomRa bihaA
mina AlXRiwaMCi wayurowiI Xurobahu Algumaru
[A slice of camel's liver, roasted, if he lighted upon it, used to suffice him; and the gumar used to satisfy his thirst]. (S, TA.) And Mohammad is related, in a trad., to have said, laA tajoEaluwniI kagumari AlrRaAkibi SalRuwA EalaI OawRala AldRuEaMCi waOawosaTahu waMxirahu Make ye me not like the gumar of the rider: salute me in the beginning of prayer and in the middle thereof and in the end thereof: meaning that they should not make the salutation of him to be a thing of no great importance, and to be postponed: for the rider puts on his camel his saddle and his travel-ling-provisions, and last of all hangs upon his saddle his drinking-cup. (IAth, TA.)

gumurN c
gumurN: see gumorN.

gamorapN c
gamorapN Water that rises above the stature of a man. (Bd in xxiii. 56.) See also gamorN, first sentence. ― -b2- Hence, (Bd,) facarohumo fiI gamoratihimo, in the Kur xxiii. 56, (tropical:) Therefore leave thou them in [the submerging gulf, or flood, of] their ignorance; (Fr, Bd;) or in their error: (Jel:) or in their error and obstinacy and perplexity: (Zj, in explanation of another reading, fI gamaraAtihimo:) and in like manner, fiI gamorapN, in the same chap., verse 65, signifies in overwhelming heedlessness: (Bd:) or in ignorance: (Jel:) and in the Kur li. 11, in overwhelming ignorance: (Bd, Jel:) or gamorapN signifies [here] a state of obstinate perseverance in vain or false affairs: (Lth, Msb, TA:) and gamaraAtN is the pl. (Msb.) You say huwa fiI gamorapK mino lahowK, and XabiybapK, and sukorK, (tropical:) [He is in a submerging gulf, or flood, of frivolous diversion, and of youthful folly, and of intoxication]. (TA.)
And gamaraAtu jahanRama signifies [The fiery depths of Hell; or] the places, of Hell, that abound with fire. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence] gamorapu AlxuSuwmapi (assumed tropical:) The main part of the contention. (TA.) [And gamorapu AlHarobi (assumed tropical:) The main part, i. e. the thick, or thickest, of the fight or battle. (See also gamaraAtu AlHarobi in what follows.)] ― -b4- Hence likewise, gamorapN signifies also (tropical:) Difficulty, trouble, distress, or rigour, (S, Msb, K,) and pressure, of a thing: (K:) pl. gamaraAtN (S, Msb, K) and gimaArN (K) and gumarN. (S.) Hence, (Msb,) gamaraAtu Almawoti (tropical:) The rigours, or pangs, (XadaAYidu,) of death: (S, Msb:) or gamorapu Almawoti signifies the agony, i. e. the vehemence of the troubles or disquietudes, of death: (TA:) and gamaraAtu AlHarobi, and gimaAruhaA, (assumed tropical:) the rigours of war. (TA.) ― -b5- See also gamorN again, latter half, in three places.

gumorapN c
gumorapN A kind of liniment, made from [the plant called] waros, (S, TA,) used by a bride, for her person: (TA:) or [the plant] wrs [itself]: (TA:) or saffron; as also gumorN↓: (K:) or kurokumN [which also means saffron and bastard saffron]: or gypsum; syn. jiSRN: or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, a mixture of dates and milk, with which the face of a woman is smeared, to render her skin fine: and the pl. is gumarN. (TA.) [See also xumorapN.]

gmrp c
gmrp, [thus in the TA, app. gumarapN, of the class of SuraEapN &c.,] as an epithet applied to a man, Valid in judgment or opinion, in cases of difficulty. (TA.)

gamaArN c
gamaArN: see gamorN, latter half, in three places.

gumaArN c
gumaArN: see gamorN, latter half, in four places.

gamiyrN c
gamiyrN: see gamorN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A certain plant: (K:) or green herbage that is overtopped, or covered, and concealed, by what is dried up: (S, K: *) or herbage growing in the lower part, or at the root, of [other] herbage, (K, * TA,) so that the first [in growth] overtops, or covers, and conceals, it: (TA:) or any verdure that is little in quantity, (L, K, TA,) either ryHp [i. e. rayRiHap, meaning what becomes green after the upper parts have dried,] or nbAt [app. meaning herbage in general]: (L, TA:) or the grain of the [species of barley-grass called] buhomaI, (K, TA,) that falls from the ears thereof when it dries; so says AHn: or somewhat that comes forth in the buhomaI in the first of the rain, succulent, or sappy, amid such as is dry; and gamiyr is not known in anything but the buhomaI: (TA:) the pl. is OagomiraMCu. (K.) gamiyrapN↓ [is app. its n. un., but] is said by AO to mean Dry [trefoil, or clover, of the species called] raTobap and qatR, with which horses are foddered when they are prepared, by being reduced to scanty food, for racing or for a military expedition. (TA.)

gamiyrapN c
gamiyrapN: see what next precedes.

gaAmirN c
gaAmirN Much, or abundant: applied in this sense to property. (Ham p. 593.) [See also gamorN.] ＝ -A2- [In a state of immersion; immerged. (See OataAnN; and see also a verse cited voce Oano, p. 106, first col.)] ― -b2- And [hence, perhaps,] gaAmirapN signifies Palm-trees (naxolN) not requiring irrigation: (AHn, K:) but Az did not find this to be known. (TA.) [See also mugotamirN.] ― -b3- Applied to land, (S, Msb, TA,) and to a house, (TA,) [but written with p when OaroDN is mentioned, or daArN,] it signifies the Contr. of EaAmirN; (S, TA;) and thus, (TA,) waste; desolate; in a state the contrary of flourishing; in a state of ruin; syn. xaraAbN: (Msb, K, TA:) [land to which this term is applied is thus called] because overflowed by water, so that it cannot be sown; or because it is covered with sand or dust; or because water generally exudes from it, so that it produces only reeds and the barodiIR [i. e. papyrus or other rushes]: by gaAmirN is meant cuw gamorK; like as one says hamRN naASibN, meaning cuw naSabK: (TA:) or any land that is not tilled (lamo yusotaxorajo) so as to be fit for sowing (K, TA) and planting: (TA:) or land that is unsown, but capable of being sown: so called because the water reaches it and comes over it: of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; (S, Msb;) like the epithets in sirRN kaAtimN and maMCN daAfiqN; and made of the measure fAl only to correspond to EaAmirN as its opposite: (S, TA:) waste land which water does not reach is not called gaAmirN; (S;) but such is called qaforN. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., [which shows that the last two explanations given above are correct,] that 'Omar imposed a tax of a diroham and a qafiyz upon every jariyb [of land], both EaAmir and gaAmir: and this he did in order that the people might not be remiss in sowing. (Az, TA.)

Oagomaru c
Oagomaru [More, or most, abundant, copious, or deep: applied to water. ― -b2- ] More, or most surpassing, or excelling: so in the saying, huwa Oagomaruhumo biTuwli qawaAmihi He is the most surpassing of them by the tallness of his stature. (TA.)

mugamRarN c
mugamRarN A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with [gumorap, or] saffron. (M, TA.) ― -b2- mugomRarapN and mutagamRirapN↓ and mugotamirapN↓ A girl having her face smeared with gumorap. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also gumorN.

mugamRirN c
mugamRirN: see mugaAmirN.

magomwurN c
magomwurN [Overflowed, or covered, and concealed, by water, &c. ― -b2- ] Rained upon. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Overcome, subdued, or oppressed. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) An obscure man; of no reputation: (K, TA:) as though others surpassed him. (TA.) You say also, fulaAnN mgomuwru AlnReasabi (assumed tropical:) Such a one is of obscure race. (TA.)

mugaAmirN c
mugaAmirN (assumed tropical:) One who plunges, or rushes without consideration, into places of peril: (S:) one who throws himself into difficulties, troubles, or distresses; as also mugamRirN↓: (K:) or one who enters into difficulties, troubles, or distresses, and makes another, or others, to do so; like mugaAmisN. (Ham p. 338.) Applied to a courageous man as meaning (assumed tropical:) One who incurs the rigours, or pangs, of death. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) One who contends in an altercation, or a dispute: or who enters into the main part [or the thick or thickest] of an altercation or a dispute: and some say that it is from Algimoru, and means regarding, and regarded, with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (TA.)

mugotamirN c
mugotamirN Palm-trees (naxolN) imbibing water from a copious source. (AHn, K.) [See also gaAmirapN, voce gaAmirN.] ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A drunken man: (Sgh, K, TA:) as though intoxication had drowned his reason. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also mugamRarN.

mutagamRirapN c
mutagamRirapN: see mugamRarN.

1 gamazahu c
1. gamazahu, (S, A, K,) or gamazahu biyadihi, (Msb,) aor.
gamiza
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. gamozN, (TA,) He felt him, (namely, a ram,) to know if he were fat: (S, A, Msb, K:) and gamazahaA he put his hand upon her (a camel's) back, to see how fat she was. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) gamazahu biyadihi, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
gamiza
, (K,) inf. n. gamozN, (A, K,) He pressed, or squeezed, it, [with his hand,] namely, a limb, (A, K, TA,) and a man's back. (TA.) So in a trad. of 'Omar: daxala Ealayohi waEinodahu gulayomN yagomizu Zahorahu [He went in to him, and with him was a little boy pressing, or squeezing, or kneading, his back]. (TA.) And in a trad. respecting the ablution termed Algusol, it is said, AigomiziI quruwnaki, meaning Press thou, or squeeze thou, the locks of thy hair, in washing. (TA.) You also say, gamaza AlvRiqaAfu AlqanaApa The straightening-instrument pinched and pressed the spear. (A, * Mgh, TA. *) A poet (namely Ziyád El-Aajam, TA) says,
wakunotu UicaA gamazotu qanaApa qawomK
kasarotu kuEuwbahaA Oawo tasotaqiymaA
[And I used, when I pinched and pressed the spear of a people, to break its knots, or internodal portions, unless it became straight]. (S, TA. It is a prov., respecting which see remarks in art. Aw.) ＝ -A2- gamaza, (A, Msb,) and gamazahu, (S, Mgh, K,) aor.
gamiza
, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. gamozN, (Msb, TA,) (tropical:) He made a sign, (A, Msb,) and he made a sign to him, (Mgh, K, *) with the eye, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) or eyebrow, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) or eyelid [by winking]. (K.) So in the saying, in a trad., gamazaniI EaliIRN Oano qulo naEamo (tropical:) '4lee made a sign to me with the eye, or eyebrow, meaning, Say thou Yes. (Mgh.) The people of the West say, gamazahu fulaAnN bifulaAnK, meaning, (tropical:) Such a one blinked towards such a one, to instigate him against him, or in order that he should have recourse to him for protection or the like, or seek aid of him. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Hence, Algamozu biAlnRaAsi: (S:) you say, gamaza biAlrRajuli, aor.
gamiza
, (K,) inf. n. gamozN, (TA,) (tropical:) He calumniated, or slandered, the man. (K.) [See also 4.] ― -b3- You say also, gumizato XahaAdatahu
[(assumed tropical:) His testimony was suspected (see magomuwzN), or impugned]. (TA in art. zwr.) ＝ -A3- gamazati AldRaAbRapu, (K,) or gamaza fiI maXoyihi, (Msb,) or mino rijolihi, (S,) aor.
gamiza
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. gamozN, (S, Msb,) (assumed tropical:) The beast limped, or it halted, with its hind leg; had a slight lameness thereof: (K, * TA:) or he had what resembled Earaj [or natural lameness] in his gait: (Msb:) or, as IKtt says, gamazati AldRaAbRapu birijolihaA the beast gave an indication of a limping, or halting, or slight lameness, in its hind leg: whence it appears that this signification may be tropical. (TA.) ＝ -A4- gamaza said of a disease, or of a vice, or fault, of a man, It appeared. (AA, K.) ＝ -A5- See also 4.

3 gaAomaza
3: [This verb is mentioned by Golius as syn. with EAyb, a verb for which I find no authority: and Freytag renders it “ Vitii arguit, ” and refers to a passage in Har (p. 427 of the see. ed.) where (like as is done by Golius) AlmugAmiz and AlmuEAyib, as syn., are erroneously put for AlmagAmiz and AlmaEAyib.]

4 Oagomazato c
4. Oagomazato She (a camel) had fat, (O, K,) or a little fat, (ISd, IKtt, TA,) in her hump. (ISd, IKtt, O, K.) Hence the epithet gamuwzN↓, applied to her. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Agmz fiI fulaAnK (tropical:) He blamed, or found fault with, such a one; attributed or imputed to him, or charged him with, or accused him of, a vice, or fault; (S, IKtt, K, TA;) deemed him weak; (TA;) lessened his rank, or dignity: (S, IKtt, K, * TA:) he found in him that for which he should be deemed weak: (A, TA:) and Agtmzhu↓ he impugned his character; blamed him; censured him; or spoke against him. (K.) You say, fulaAnN faEalotu XayoYFA fQgotamazahu↓ (tropical:) I did a thing, and such a one impugned my character, or found in it that by which my character was impugned. (S, TA.) And samiEa minRiI kalimapF fiI Eaqolihi faQgotamazahaA↓ (tropical:) He heard from me a saying, and deemed it weak: (A, TA:) and in like manner, Oagomaza fiyhaA found in it that for which it was to be deemed weak. (TA.) ＝ -A3- OagomazaniI AlHarRu (tropical:) The heat remitted, or abated, to me, so that I became emboldened to encounter it, and went upon the road: (AA, ISk, S, IKtt, K, * TA:) Az says gamazaniI↓ AlHarRu, on the authority of AA: (TA:) and AA mentioned AgmrnI AlHrR in this sense, but afterwards doubted, and said, I think that it is with zAI. (TA in art. gmr.) ― -b2- And Oagomaza (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became gentle, so that others were emboldened against him. (IKtt, TA.) ＝ -A4- And Oagomaza [for which Oagomazah is erroneously put in the CK] He acquired cattle such as are termed gamaz [q. v.]: (O, K, TA:) like Oaqomaza. (O.)

5 tagamRaza
5: [This verb is said by Freytag to have a signification belonging to tagamRara.]

6 tgAmzwA c
6. tgAmzwA They made signs, one to another, with their eyes, (S, A, K, B,) or with the eyebrow, (A,) or hand, indicating something blameable or faulty. (B.) In this sense it is expl. as used in the Kur lxxxiii. 30. (S, B.)

8 Uigotamaza
8: see 4, in three places.

gamazN c
gamazN Cattle (i. e. camels, and sheep or goats, TA) of a bad quality. (As, S, O, K.) ― -b2- And A weak man: (S, O, K:) like qamazN: pl. OagomaAzN, like OaqomaAzN of qamazN. (TA.)

gamuwzN c
gamuwzN A she-camel of which one doubts whether she be fat or not and therefore feels the hump: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) pl. gumozN [or gumuzN, or both?]. (TA.) See 4, first sentence.

gamiyzN c
gamiyzN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

gamiyzapN c
gamiyzapN (tropical:) A thing for which one's character is to be impugned; for which one is to be blamed, censured, or spoken against; a vice, or fault; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also gamiyzN↓ (TA) and magomazN↓ (S, A, Mgh, K) or magomazapN↓: (Msb:) and weakness in work, and impotence of mind, (TA,) and ignorance: (T, TA:) the pl. of magomazN↓ is magaAmizu, (TA,) syn. with maEaAyibu. (S.) You say, layosa fiyhi gamiyzapN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and gamiyzN↓, (TA,) and magomazN↓, (A, Mgh, K,) or magomazapN↓, (Msb,) (tropical:) There is not in him anything for which his character is to be impugned; or for which he is to be blamed; &c.: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or there is not in it anything for which it is to be coveted: (K:) or maA fiyhi magomazN↓ has both of the above-mentioned significations. (A.) And fiI jamRapN fulaAnapa magaAmizu↓ (tropical:) In such a woman are many vices, or faults. (A.) [See magomazN, below.]

jaAriyapN gamRaAzapN c
jaAriyapN gamRaAzapN A girl who presses, or squeezes, or kneads, the limbs well with the hand. (A, K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- AimoraOapN gamRaAzapN (tropical:) A woman who makes frequent signs with the eye, &c.; who has a habit of doing so; syn. ramRaAzapN. (TA in art. rmz.) ― -b2- gamRaAzN One who blames, or finds fault with, others, much, or habitually. (TA in art. hmz.)

gaAmizN c
gaAmizN [meaning Limping, or halting, &c., and having a limping, or halting, &c.,] is like ZaAliEN: sometimes used as a possessive noun; and [therefore] one does not say gaAmizapN. (O and TA in art. ZlE.)

magomazN c
magomazN [should by rule be magomizN: its primary signification is A place of feeling, to know if an animal be fat: hence, a place of pressing or squeezing a limb &c.: and a place of pinching and pressing a spear, to straighten it]. ― -b2- nukotapN laAmagomaza liqanaAtihaA walaA maqoraEa liSafaAtihaA (tropical:) [lit. A nice or subtile saying, the spear of which has no place where it requires to be pinched and pressed to straiten it, and the rock of which has no rough place requiring to be beaten, or for the rock of which there is no beating,] means, (assumed tropical:) that has no crookedness: mqrE is an inf. n., or means “ a place of beating, ” and SfAp is “ a rock; ” and the above-mentioned use of these two words is borrowed from the phrase qaraEa SafaAtahu, meaning (tropical:) “ he impugned his character; blamed, or censured, him; or spoke against him. ” (Mgh.) ― -b3- See also gamiyzapN, in five places.

magomazapN c
magomazapN: see gamiyzapN, in two places.

magomuwzN c
magomuwzN (tropical:) A man (A, TA) suspected (S, A, * K) of a vice, or fault. (TA.)

1 gamasahu c
1. gamasahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
gamisa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. gamosN, (Msb, TA,) He immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him or it, (JK, TA,) syn. maqalahu, (S, A, K,) in water, (JK, S, A, Msb, K,) or other fluid; (JK, * TA;) as, for instance, a morsel of food in vinegar, and the hand in HinRaMC, (A,) and a garment, or piece of cloth, [for AlvRadoI in the TA, I read AlvRawob,] in water or in dye. (TA.) ― -b2- AixotaDabato gamosFA, so in the T and the Tekmileh; [and so in the JK;] but in the [O and] K, gamosFA Aigotasamato↓; (TA;) She (a woman, O, TA) immersed her hand, (K,) or, as in the [O and other] correct lexicons, her hands, (TA,) [in the HinRaMC] so as to dye [it or them] uniformly, without taSowiyr [or figuring], (O, K,) for which last word Sgh [in the TS] writes tSryr, and for which we find in the A naqoX [meaning the same as the word in the K]. (TA.) ― -b3- gamasahumo fiI AlbalaMCi (tropical:) [It (an event) plunged them into trial, or affliction]. (A.)
