[See also a similar usage of the verb below, voce gamuwsN.] ― -b4- gamasa HalifFA fiI Mli AlEaASi He took a share in the compact and confederacy of the family of El-'Ás, and swore to it: for it was their custom to bring, in a wooden bowl, some perfume or blood or ashes, and they inserted their hands into it on the occasion of swearing, one to another, that their compact might be completed by their sharing together in one thing. (TA, from a trad. respecting the Hijreh.) ― -b5- yagomisu AlsRinaAna HatRaI yanofuca [He thrusts in the spear-head so that it may pass through, or that its extremity may protrude]. (A.) ― -b6- gamasa Ealayohimu Alxabara (assumed tropical:) He concealed from them the news, or information. (TA.) ― -b7- gumisa AlnRajomu, (so in a copy of the A,) or gamasa, (so in the JK and O and K,) The star set. (JK, A, O, K.)

2 tagomiysN c
2. tagomiysN signifies The making a drinking to be little in quantity: (O, K, TA:) or, accord. to Kr, a man's watering his camels and then going away. (TA.)

3 gaAomasa
3: [gAmshu, inf. n. mugaAmasapN, He vied, or contended, with him in plunging, or diving, in water:] mugaAmasapN is syn. with mumaAqalapN. (S, TA.) ― -b2- mugaAmasapN also signifies (tropical:) The throwing one's self into the midst of war or fight. (S, TA,) or of an affair or a great affair or an affliction: (TA:) and the mixing, or engaging, in fight or conflict. (TA.) You say, gaAmasa fiI AlqitaAli (tropical:) He plunged, or threw himself, into the midst of fight or conflict; or he rushed headlong into it. (TA.) And gaAmasahumo (tropical:) He mixed, or engaged, with them in fight or conflict. (TA). [See also mugaAmisN].

6 tgAmsA c
6. tgAmsA They two vied, or contended, each with the other, in plunging, or diving, in water; syn. tamaAqalaA and tagaATasaA. (TA in art. gTs.)

7 Angms c
7. Angms (S, A, Msb) and Agtms↓ (S, A) He, or it, became immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, in water: or he immersed or immerged himself, plunged, or dived, in water: (S, A, Msb:) or he did so remaining long therein. (TA in this art. and in art. rms.) [See Artms.] ― -b2- [Hence,] ↓the latter also signifies, [and so app. the former,] (assumed tropical:) He hid, or concealed, himself. (T, O.)

8 Uigotamasa
8: see 7, in two places. ― -b2- Aigotamasato gamosFA: see 1.

gamasN c
gamasN, [like nafaDN in the sense of manofuwDN, &c., or perhaps a mistranscription for gamosN, like garosN in the sense of magoruwsN, and many other instances,] Immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk. (TA.)

TaEonapN gamuwsN c
TaEonapN gamuwsN (tropical:) A spear-wound, or the like, that passes through: (S, A, Msb, K:) the epithet properly applies to the person who inflicts the wound, because he thrusts in (yagomis) the spearhead so that it passes through, or so that its extremity protrudes: and it is such as cleaves the flesh: (A:) or wide, and passing through; that plunges into the flesh. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- OamorN gamuwsN (tropical:) A difficult, or distressful, affair; (S, A, Msb, K;) that plunges people into trial, or affliction. (A, K. *) ― -b3- Hence, (A,) yamiynN gamuwsN (tropical:) An oath that plunges its swearer (tagomisuhu) into sin, (S, K,) and then into the fire [of Hell]: (K:) or a false oath, (Mgh, Msb,) known by its swearer to be so; (Msb;) so called because it plunges its swearer into sin, (A, Mgh, Msb,) and then into the fire [of Hell]: (A, Mgh:) or a false oath which one purposely swears, knowing the case to be the contrary thereof, (K, TA,) in order to cut off the rights of others: (TA:) or an oath by which one cuts off for himself the property of another: (K:) or an oath in which there is made no exception [by saying Uino XaMCa QllRehu (if God will), or the like]. (TA.) [See also Algamiysap.] ― -b4- rajulN gamuwsN (assumed tropical:) A strong, courageous man; as also mugaAmisN↓: which latter epithet is also applied to a lion. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A man who, in journeying, does not alight to rest in the night until he enters upon the time of dawn or morning. (TA.) ― -b5- And naAqapN gamuwsN A she-camel whose pregnancy is not plainly known (S, O, K) until she is near to bringing forth (HatRaI tuqoriba). (S, O.) And (O, K) accord. to En-Nadr, (O,) A she-camel that has a young one in her belly and that does not raise her tail so that the case should become manifest: (O, K:) pl. gms [app. gumusN, agreeably with analogy, like SuburN pl. of SabuwrN, &c.]. (TA.) And (some say, TA) A she-camel respecting whose marrow one doubts whether it be in a corrupt and melting state or be fat, or thick and fat. (O, K.)

gamiysN c
gamiysN Such as is termed gamiyr [q. v.] of herbage; (S, O, K, TA;) i. e. such as has become green in consequence of rain, in the lower parts of that which is dry. (O.) See also gamiymN. ― -b2- And A thing that has not appeared to men, and that is not known, as yet: whence the phrase qaSiydapN gamiysN [an ode that has not become known: the epithet being masc. and fem.]. (O, K.) ― -b3- And i. q. OajamapN [A collection of tangled, or dense, trees or shrubs, or of reeds or canes; (see also gamiysapN;)] and anything tangled, confused, or dense, in which one hides, or conceals, himself: (T, O, K, * TA:) in the copies of the K, Oawo yusotaxofaI is erroneously written for OaIo ystxfI as in the T and O. (TA.) ― -b4- And A water-course, or channel in which water flows, (S, O, K, TA,) or (TA) such as is small, amid [plants such as are termed] baqol and nabaAt, (S, O, K, TA,) or, as in the L, combining (yajomaEu) [app. within it] trees, or shrubs, and baqol. (TA.) ― -b5- Also Night: (O:) or dark night. (K.) And Darkness. (O, K.) ― -b6- And AO is related by El-Athram to have said, Almajoru is what is in the belly of the she-camel; and the second [i. e. the offspring of the major] is [called] Habalu AlHabalapi; and the third is Algamiysu [i. e. this last signifies The offspring of the offspring of the major: see majorN and HabalN]. (TA.)

gamyisapN c
gamyisapN A collection of dense reeds or canes; or a bed, or place of growth, thereof. (TA. [See also gamiysN.]) ＝ -A2- Halafa EalaI Algamiysapi He swore a false oath. (TA. [See gamwusN.])

gamRaAsN c
gamRaAsN: see what next follows, in two places.

gamRaAsapN c
gamRaAsapN [A bird of the kind termed divers, or plungeons: thus called in the present day; expl. by Golius and Freytag as meaning “ mergus avis; ”] a certain aquatic bird, (O, K,) that dives, or plunges, much: (O:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] gamRaAsN↓: (K, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, gumRAsN:]) IDrd says, the gamRaAs↓ is a wellknown bird. (O.)

mugaAmisN c
mugaAmisN One who plunges into wars, or battles, (yagoXaI AlHuruwba,) and engages in them repeatedly: (Ham p. 27:) or one who enters into difficulties, troubles, or distresses, and makes another, or others, to do so; like mugaAmirN. (Id. p. 338.) See also gamuwsN.

1 gamaSahu c
1. gamaSahu, (S, A, Mgh, K,) aor.
gamiSa
inf. n. gamoSN; (S;) and gamiSahu, aor.
gamaSa
, inf. n. gamoSN; and gamiSahu, aor.
gamaSa
, inf. n. gamaSN; (K, * TA;) but the first is the most chaste; (TA;) He despised him; held him in contempt; (A, Mgh, K;) accounted him little, or vile; regarded him as nothing; (S;) as also AgtmShu↓. (S, A, K.) You say also, raMhu fagamaSatohu Eayonuhu He saw him and his eye despised him. (A.) ― -b2- He blamed him; found fault with him; imputed to him a vice, or fault; and despised his right. (A, K.) You say, wajadato AlnRaAsa yagomiSu baEoDuhumo baEoDFA [I found the people blaming one another, &c.]; as also yagotamiSu↓. (A.) And gamaSotahu bisuwoCK [Thou imputedst evil to him]. (TA, from a trad.) And gamaSotu Ealayohi qawolFA qaAlahu I blamed him, or found fault with him, for a saying that he said. (S.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) gamaSa AlnRiEomapa, (S, K,) and gamiSahaA, (K,) the latter is the form authorized by the T and the Deewán el-Adab, this verb and [its syn.] gmT being there said to be both with kesr to the m, (TA,) He was ungrateful, or unthankful, for the favour or benefit; (S, K, TA;) he despised it, and disacknowledged it. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence also, app.,] gamaSa QllRehu Alxaloqa God diminished the height, and breadth, and strength, and might in war, or valour, of mankind; and made them small and contemptible: occurring in a trad. of 'Alee respecting the slaughter of his brother by a son of Adam. (TA.) ＝ -A2- gamaSato Eayonuhu, (S, K,) aor.
gamaSa
, (K,) inf. n. gamaSN, (S,) His eye had in it what is termed gamaSN, q. v. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] gamiSa hecaA AlOamoru EalaIRa This thing, or affair, turned against me, and became attended with trouble. (JK.) ― -b3- [And hence, perhaps,] laA tagomaSo EalaIRa [in the CK tagomiSo] Be not thou angry with me: so accord. to the O [and the JK]: but accord. to the K, do not thou lie against me, or utter falsehood. (TA.)

8 UigotamaSa
8: see 1, in two places.

gamaSN c
gamaSN Fluid filth [or foul matter] in the inner corner of the eye: (Mgh:) or what is fluid of [the filth, or foul matter, or white filth, which collects in the inner corner of the eye, and which, when concrete, is called] ramaS: (S, K:) or a thing like froth, which the eye emits; a portion whereof is termed gamaSapN↓: (TA:) or what resembles white froth, in the side of the eye: but ramaSN is in the side of the eyelashes: (ISh:) or both these words signify dirt which the eye emits: or gamaSN is what is concrete. (M in art. rmS.)

gamiSN c
gamiSN, a possessive epithet, A great imputer of vices or faults. (TA.)

gamaSapN c
gamaSapN: see gamaSN.

yamiynN gamuwSN c
yamiynN gamuwSN i. q. gamuwsN. ― -b2- huwa gamuwSu AlHanojarapi He is a liar. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A2- AlgamuwSu: see AlgumayoSaMCu.

maA fiI fulaAnK gamiySapN c
maA fiI fulaAnK gamiySapN There is not in such a one anything for which his character is to be impugned, or for which he is to be blamed, censured, or spoken against; any vice, or fault; i. q. gamiyzapN. (A.)

OagomaSu c
OagomaSu Having, in his eye, what is termed gamaSN, q. v.: (Mgh, K:) or disordered in the eye; whose eyes are dim, or watery; like OaEomaXu: (L and TA in art. EmX:) fem. gamoSaMCu: and pl. gumoSN. (TA.)

huwa magomuwSN Ealayohi c
huwa magomuwSN Ealayohi He is censured, or blamed, or reproached, (S, K,) with respect to his religion, (S, A, K,) and with respect to his grounds of pretension to respect. (A.) It is said in a trad., UilRaA magomwSN Ealayohi AlnRifaAqu, meaning, Except one censured, &c., with respect to his religion; accused, or suspected, of hypocrisy. (TA.)

entry.key: OanaA musotagomiSN mino hecaA Alxabari wamutawahRimN

superEntry.entry:
OanaA musotagomiSN mino hecaA Alxabari wamutawahRimN c
OanaA musotagomiSN mino hecaA Alxabari wamutawahRimN [I am suspicious of this information, and opining;] is said by one when a piece of information rejoices him but he fears that it may not be true; or when he fears it and yet it rejoices him. (TA.)

1 gamaDa c
1. gamaDa, and gamuDa, aor. of each
gamuDa
, and inf. n. of each gumuwDN, It (a thing) was, or became, unperceived, unapparent, hidden, or concealed. (TA.) ― -b2- gamaDa AlHaqRu, aor. and inf. n. as above; and gamuDa; The way of attaining, or obtaining, the right, or due, was, or became, unapparent, or hidden. (Msb.) ― -b3- gamuDa AlkalaAmu, inf. n. gumuwDapN; (S, Sgh, K;) and gamaDa, aor.
gamuDa
, inf. n. gumuwDN; (IB, K; [but IB seems to express a doubt of the correctness of the latter form of the verb in this case;]) The speech, or language, was unapparent to the mind, not plain or perspicuous, obscure, recondite, or abstruse. (S, IB, Sgh, K.) ― -b4- gamuDa Ealayohi AlOamoru The affair was not easy to him; (L, TA; *) and you say also, gamaDa AlOamoru, inf. n. gumuwDN: and fiyhi gumuwDN [In it is a want of easiness]: but, Lh says, they scarcely ever, or never, say fiyhi gumuwDapN. (TA.) ― -b5- gamaDa AlmakaAnu, aor.
gamuDa
, inf. n. gumuwDN; and gamuDa, inf. n. gumuwDapN and gamaADapN; The place was, or became, low, or depressed; (S, K;) [because a place that is so is unseen from a distance.] ― -b6- gamaDa AlxaloxaAlu fiI AlsRaAqi, inf. n. gumuwDN, The anklet was, or became, depressed in the leg; lit., choked therein. (A, TA.) ― -b7- gamaDati AldRaAru, aor.
gamuDa
, inf. n. as above, The house was not upon a common thoroughfare-road or street. (Lth, L.) ― -b8- gamaDa AlsRayofu fiI AllRaHomi, (Ibn-'Abbád, A, K,) aor.
gamuDa
, (Ibn-'Abbád,) The sword became hidden in the flesh. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b9- gamaDa fiI AlOaroDi, (Lh, A, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K, fI AlOamori, which is a mistake, (TA,) aor.
gamuDa
and
gamiDa
, (K,) inf. n. gumuwDN, (A,) He went away in, or into, the land, or country: (Lh:) or he went away and disappeared therein: (A, L:) or he went away and journeyed therein. (K.) ― -b10- And gamaDa, aor.
gamuDa
, also signifies It (a thing) was, or became, small. (IKtt.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, under AgmS Enh, in four places.

2 gmRD AlkalaAma c
2. gmRD AlkalaAma, (S, K,) inf. n. tagomiyDN, (S,) He made the speech, or language, unapparent to the mind, not plain or perspicuous, obscure, recondite, or abstruse. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- gmRD HadRa AlsRayofi, (A, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He made the edge of the sword thin [so that it might become hidden in the flesh when one smote with it]; (A, TA;) as also OagomaDahu↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in twelve places.

4 AgmD HadRa AlsRayofi c
4. AgmD HadRa AlsRayofi: see 2. ― -b2- AgmD Eayonayohi, (Mgh,) or AlEayona, (Msb,) inf. n. UigomaADN; (S, Msb;) and gamRaDahumaA↓, (Mgh,) or gamRaDahaA, (Msb,) inf. n. tagomiyDN; (S, Msb;) He shut, or closed, (Mgh, Msb,) [his eyes, or] his eyelids, (Mgh,) or [the eye, or] the eyelids. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence,] maA OagomaDotu, (A, TA,) and maA gamRaDotu↓, (TA,) I have not slept; (TA;) and maA QgotamaDotu↓ [signifies the same]; (JK;) and so maA QkotaHalotu UigomaADFA, (ISd, K,) and tagomaADFA↓ (S, Sgh, K) and tagomiyDFA, (S, K,) [two inf. ns. of 2,] and gamaADFA↓, and gimaADFA↓, and gumoDFA↓ with damm, (S, Sgh, K,) [and app. gumaADFA↓, and gumuwDFA↓, and gamoDFA↓, for] IB says that gamoDN and gumuwDN and gumaADN are inf. ns. of a verb not used: (TA:) and maA cuqotu gumoDFA↓, [in a copy of the A gamoDFA↓,] and gamaA DFA↓, I have not tasted sleep. (JK.) [And hence,] Albaroqu AgtmD↓ (tropical:) The lightning ceased to gleam; as though sleeping. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, AgmD Tarofahu EanRiI, and gmRDhu↓, He shut, or closed, his eye, or eyes, at, or upon, or against, me: and AgmD Ealayohi, and gmRD↓, he shut, or closed, his eyes at, or upon, or against, him, or it. (TA.) ― -b5- And [hence,] AgmD Eanohu, and Ealayohi, (tropical:) [He shut his eyes at it, or upon it, or against it], namely a thing that he had heard: a metonymical phrase, denoting patience. (TA.) And AgmD Eanohu (tropical:) He connived at it; feigned himself neglectful of it; passed it by; (A, Mgh, Msb, TA;) as also Eanohu gmRD↓, inf. n. tagomiyDN; and gamaDa↓; and AgtmD↓; namely a thing that he had heard; and an evil action: (A, TA:) and Eayonayohi gmRD↓ Eanohu he feigned himself blind to it. (TA.) And AgmD Eanohu fiI AlbayoEi, (S, K,) or AlXRiraMCi, (S, TA,) (tropical:) He acted, or affected to act, in an easy, or a facile, manner towards him, (tasaAhala Ealayohi,) in selling, (S, K,) or buying; (S;) as also gamaDa↓ Eanohu, (S, K,) aor.
gamiDa
. (K.) And OagomiDo liI fiymaA biEotaniI, (S, A, K, TA,) in [some of] the copies of the K like AiDoribo, [i. e. AigomiDo↓,] but the former is the right reading, (TA,) [though the latter is perhaps allowable, as will presently be seen,] meaning, (A, TA,) or as though it meant, (S, K, TA,) (tropical:) Give thou to me more of what thou hast sold to me, on account of its badness; or [so in the A, but in the S and K “ and, ”] lower thou to me the price thereof; (S, A, K, TA;) as also liI fiyhi gamRiDo↓. (K, TA.) And AgmD fiI AlbayoEi (tropical:) He demanded that another should give him more of the thing sold; and that he should lower the price [thereof]; and he complied with his demand. (IAth.) And AgmD fiI AlsRiloEapi (tropical:) He demanded a lowering of the price of the commodity, on account of its badness. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 270], walasotumo biMxiciyhi UilRaA Oano tugomiDuwA fiyhi, (S, A, * K,) or, accord. to one reading, tagomiDuwA↓, (TA,) i. e. (tropical:) When ye do not take it unless ye lower the price; (Lth, Zj, * K;) meaning, EalaI UigomaADK, or biUigomaADK. (Fr.) ― -b6- [Hence also,] fulaAnN EalaI hecaA AlOamori gamRaDa↓ (assumed tropical:) Such a one executed, performed, or accomplished, this affair: or kept, or applied himself, constantly, or perseveringly, to it; (maDaI Ealayohi;) [as though he shut his eyes at it;] knowing what was in it. (O, K.) And AlnRaAqapu gamRaDati↓, (S, A, K,) inf. n. tagomiyDN, (K,) The she-camel, being driven away (rudRato, as in the K, and in some copies of the S, or ciydato, as in other copies of the S, and in the A, as is said in the TA,) from the watering-trough, (S, K,) rushed upon the driver, (AlcRaAYid, [in the CK, erroneously, AlzAYid,]) closing her eyes, and came to the water. (S, A, K.) tagomiyDN↓ also signifies The embarking [in an affair], or undertaking [it], blindly. (TA.) ― -b7- [Hence also,] OagomaDati AlmafaAzapu Ealayohimo (tropical:) [The desert concealed them;] they did not appear in the desert, (A, TA,) being concealed by the mirage, and in the depressed parts; (TA;) as though it closed its eyelids upon them. (A, TA.) ― -b8- AgmD AlnRaZara (tropical:) He considered, or judged, well, and gave a good opinion: (M, TA:) and AgmD fiI AlnRaZari (tropical:) he gave a right opinion: (A:) or (assumed tropical:) he considered, or judged, minutely. (IKtt.) ― -b9- OagomaDati AlEayonu fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) The eye despised such a one: (K, TA:) or you say OagomaDatohu EayoniI meaning I despised him: ― -b10- and likewise meaning I vied, or contended, in running with him, (HaADarotuhu,) and outstripped him, after he had outstripped me: (Ibn-'Abbád, O:) or AgmD fulaAnN fulaAnFA means Such a one vied, or contended, in running with such a one, (HaADarahu,) and outstripped him, after
having been outstripped by him. (K.) ― -b11- AgmD AlmayRita, (A, Mgh, TA,) inf. n. UigomaADN; (TA;) and gamRaDahu↓, (A, TA,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) He closed the eyelids of the dead man. (Mgh.)

7 AngmD AlTRarofu c
7. AngmD AlTRarofu i. q. AinogaDRa: (S, Sgh, K:) [or the former more probably signifies The eye, or eyes, became closed: and the latter, the eye, or eyes, became contracted. See also 8.]

8 maA QgotamaDato EayonaAIa c
8. maA QgotamaDato EayonaAIa My eyes slept not, or have not slept. (S, * Sgh, K.) See also 4, in the first half of the paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- OataAniI celika EalaI QgotimaADK (tropical:) That came to me easily, without trouble, or pains-taking. (As, A, K.)

gamoDN c
gamoDN: see gaAmiDN, in four places: ― -b2- See also 4, in the third sentence, in two places.

gumoDN c
gumoDN: see 4, in the third sentence; the first and second in two places.

gamaADN c
gamaADN: see 4, in the third sentence; the first and second in two places.

gumaADN c
gumaADN: see 4, in the third sentence; the first and second in two places.

gimaADN c
gimaADN: see 4, in the third sentence; the first and second in two places.

gumuwDN c
gumuwDN: see 4, in the third sentence; the first and second in two places.

gumuwDapN c
gumuwDapN: see what next follows.

maA fiI hecaA AlOamori gamiyDapN c
maA fiI hecaA AlOamori gamiyDapN, (S, O, L, K,) and gumuwDapN↓, (L,) There is not, in this affair, any fault, (S, O, L, K,) liI [to be imputed to me]. (TA, where this is added next after mA.)

gaAmiDN c
gaAmiDN [Unperceived; unapparent; hidden, or concealed. (See 1, first signification.)] ― -b2- Unapparent to the mind, not plain or perspicuous, obscure, recondite, or abstruse, speech, or language. (S, A, K.) You say also, maEonFI gaAmiDN A nice, subtile, or quaint, meaning. (TA.) And masoOalapN gaAmiDapN A question in which is matter for consideration, and subtility, or nicety. (TA.) And masoOalapN fiyhaA gawaAmiDu [A question in which are obscurities, abstrusities, subtilities, or niceties: the last word being pl. of gaAmiDapN↓, an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates]. (A.) ― -b3- Obscure; not well known: (A:) or not known: (Msb, K:) applied to rank or quality (Hasab), (A, K,) or to parentage or relationship (nasab): (Msb:) pl. OagomaADN, like as OaSoHaAbN is pl. of SaAHibN: or, as some say, this is pl. of gamoDN↓. (TA.) ― -b4- Obscure, or of no reputation; low, mean, or vile; (K, TA;) applied to a man: (TA:) such is termed cuw gamoDK↓, (S, O, TA,) also. (TA.) [And hence, perhaps,] A man remiss in the charge, or in rushing on the enemy: (Lth, K:) pl. gawaAmiDu [which is anomalous, like fawaArisu &c.]. (Lth.) ― -b5- Low, or depressed; applied to land, (S, A, K,) and a place; (A;) [because unseen from a distance;] as also gamoDN↓; (S, A, K;) applied to a place: (S, A:) or this latter signifies land very low, or very much depressed, so that what is in it is not seen: (AHn:) and in like manner magomaDN↓, a place more depressed (S, TA) than what is termed gamoDN: (TA:) pl. of the first, gawaAmiDu: (K:) and of ↓the second, OagomaADN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, K) and gumuwDN: (S, A, K:) and of the third, magaAmiDu. (S.) ― -b6- An anklet depressed, lit. choked, (gaASRN, [in the CK gADR,]) in the leg: (JK, A, L, K:) and, applied to an ankle-bone, concealed by the flesh: (TA:) or fat: (K:) and in this latter sense applied to a leg, or shank. (K, TA.) ― -b7- A house not upon a common thoroughfare-road or street; (Lth, A, L, K;) retired therefrom. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- A young camel; the young one of a camel: pl. gawaAmiDu: (TA:) which also signifies camels not accustomed to drawing water. (JK.)

gaAmiDapN c
gaAmiDapN; pl. gawaAmiDu: see the next preceding paragraph.

magomaDN c
magomaDN; pl. magaAmiDu: see gaAmiDN as applied to land, and a place.

mugamRaDaAtu AllRayoli c
mugamRaDaAtu AllRayoli The darknesses of night. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the following paragraph.

AlmugamRiDaAtu mina AlcRunuwbi c
AlmugamRiDaAtu mina AlcRunuwbi, (O, K, * TA,) or mugamRiDaAtu AlOumuwri, accord. to different relations of a trad. in which it occurs, (TA,) Sins, or offences, which a man commits knowing them [to be such]: (O, K, TA:) or enormities which a man commits knowing them [to be such]; as though he closed his eyes upon them, feigning himself blind while he saw them: (TA:) IAth says that accord. to one relation it is with fet-h to the second m, [mugamRaDaAt↓,] and means small sins, or offences; so called because minute and unapparent, so that a man commits them with a kind of doubt, not knowing that he will be punished for committing them. (TA.)

1 gamiTa c
1. gamiTa, aor.
gamaTa
; and gamaTa, aor.
gamiTa
; inf. n. gamoTN, (S, K,) of both; (S;) He despised men; held them in contempt; (S, K;) accounted them little, or vile. (TA.) It is said in a trad., UinRamaA celika mano safiha AlHaqRa wagamaiTa AlnRaAsa That (S, TA,) meaning transgression, iniquity, or injustice, (TA,) is only (S, TA) the action of (TA) such as regards the truth, or right, as foolishness, or ignorance, and despises men: (S, TA:) Sgh says that accord. to one relation, it is gamaSa: and Az relates it thus; Alkiboru Oano tasofaha AlHaqRa watagomiTa AlnRaAsa [Pride is thy regarding the truth, or right, as foolishness, or ignorance, and thy despising men]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also the former, (TA,) or both, (K,) He was ungrateful for health, and safety, (K, TA,) and a favour, or benefit, or blessing: (S, * TA:) and both, (S, K,) he held in light estimation, was ungrateful for, and despised, (S, K,) a favour, or benefit, or blessing, (K, TA,) and his life. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And the former, He denied, or disacknowledged, a right, or due. (TA.)

4 AgmT c
4. AgmT It continued; it kept, or clave; (K;) like AgbT. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) OagomaTato Ealayohi AlHumRaI, a dial. var. of AgbTt, q. v. (S, TA.)

8 AgtmThu baAlkalaAmi c
8. AgtmThu baAlkalaAmi He treated him contemptuously with speech: (O:) and (O) he overcame, and subdued, him therewith; (O, L, K;) and so AigotaTRapu. (O, L.) ― -b2- And AgtmThu He vied, or contended, in running with him, and outstripped him, after he had been outstripped (O, K) by him; mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád; (O;) and so AigotaTRahu; (TA;) and OagomaDahu. (Ibn-'Abbád and O in art. gmD.

samaMCN gamaTaI c
samaMCN gamaTaI i. q. gabaTaI, q. v. (IDrd, K.)

sayorN mugomaTN c
sayorN mugomaTN i. q. mugobaTN, q. v. (ISh.)

1 gamala Aljiloda c
1. gamala Aljiloda, (S, O,) or AlOadiyma, (K,) aor.
gamula
, inf. n. gamolN, He folded the skin, or hide, and buried it, in order that it might become soft, or flaccid, and pliant, when its wool was pulled: (S, O: *) if neglected for a while, it becomes spoiled, or marred: the epithet applied to it is gamiylN↓; (S, O;) and gamiynN also: (S:) or he spoiled, or marred, the skin, or hide: or he put it in the bottom of some receptacle (fiI gumRapK), [and left it a while,] in order that its wool might become detached: (K:) or he buried it, (K, TA,) having folded it, (TA,) in the sand, (K, TA,) after moistening [it], (TA,) in order that it might become stinking, and its hair [or wool] might be plucked off: (K, TA:) or, accord. to AHn, he folded it while it was moist, and left it folded longer than it required, so that it became spoiled, or marred: or, as some say, he folded it after it was tanned, then covered it a day and a night, so that its hair, or its wool, became loose, when it was plucked off: if left more than a day and a night, it becomes spoiled, or marred: (TA:) and Agml↓ signifies [the same: (see gaSaba Aljiloda:) or] he left his skin, or hide, [buried, or put in the bottom of some receptacle, &c., while moist,] until it became spoiled, or marred. (TA.) ― -b2- And gamala AltRamora, (S,) or Albusora, (O, K,) He did in like manner to the dates, or the unripe dates, in order that they might become ripe: (S, O, K:) and the epithet applied to them is magomuwlN↓; and magomuwnN. (TA.) ― -b3- And gamala AlEinaba, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He put the grapes together, in quantities one above another, (K, TA,) in the basket of palm-leaves. (TA.) ― -b4- gamala fulaAnaA He covered such a one, (K, TA,) with clothes, (TA,) in order that he should sweat. (K, TA.) ― -b5- gamala AljuroHa He put pieces of rag, one above another, upon the wound. (O, TA.) ― -b6- gamala AlOamora He hid, concealed, or covered, the affair, or case. (TA.) ― -b7- And gamala AlXRayoCa, (K,) inf. n. gamolN, (O,) He put the thing into a good, sound, right, or proper, state. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- gamala AlnRabaAtu, (O, K,) inf. n. gamolN, (TA,) The plants, or herbage, became accumulated, one, or one part, overlying another, (O, K, TA,) so as to become withered, and decayed. (TA.) [See also 5.] ＝ -A3- gamila AlnRabotu, the verb being like fariHa, The plant, or plants, or herbage, became in a bad, or corrupt, state. (TA.) ― -b2- And one says gamila hecaA AlmakaAnu
biAlnRaboti [app. meaning This place became, or has become, in a bad, or corrupt, state by reason of the herbage: or concealed, or covered, by herbage; as may be inferred from an explanation of OaroDN gamilapN]. (O.) ― -b3- And gamila AljuroHu, (TA,) inf. n. gamalN, (K,) The wound became in a bad, or corrupt, state, by reason of the bandage. (K, TA.)

4 Oagomala
4: see the preceding paragraph, former half.

5 tgmRl AlnRabaAtu c
5. tgmRl AlnRabaAtu The plants, or herbage, became accumulated, one, or one part, overlying another. (TA.) [See also gamala AlnRabaAtu.] ― -b2- And tgmRl He became, or made himself, ample, or abundant, syn. tawasRaEa, (O, K,) in wealth. (O.)

7 Angml c
7. Angml, said of a skin, quasi-pass. of gamala signifying as expl. in the first sentence of this art. [i. e. It was, or became, such as is termed gamiyl, or in the state denoted by the pass. part. n. of the latter verb]. (K.)

gimolN c
gimolN A certain tree of the [kind called] HamoD, that grows surmounted by a fruit, or produce, white like the [garments called] mulaMC. (AA, O, TA.)

gamilN c
gamilN [accord. to rule, part. n. of gamila, q. v.]. ― -b2- OaroDN gamilapN Land abounding with herbage, having its surface concealed, or covered, thereby. (TA.)

gamiylN c
gamiylN: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Applied to herbage, (S, * O, *) or to such as is called naSRiI, (K, TA,) Accumulated, one part above another, (S, O, K, * TA,) so as to be withered: (TA:) pl. gamolaI, (S, O, TA,) [which is also expl. as] meaning herbage tangled and dense, one part above another. (O voce XurobubN.) ― -b3- And Low, or depressed, land. (As, O, TA.)

gumoluwlN c
gumoluwlN A valley containing trees, (S, O, K,) or containing numerous trees, (TA,) and plants, or herbage, (S, O,) tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense: (S:) or such as is long, of little width, and tangled or luxuriant or abundant and dense [in its trees]: (K:) or a narrow valley having much of such produce: or a deeplydepressed tract of land: or, accord. to ISh, a tract having the form of a [road such as is termed] sikRap, in the ground, narrow, and having two [lateral] acclivities, each acclivity two cubits in height, extending to the measure of a bow-shot, producing an abundance [of trees or herbage], and narrower than what is termed a maliyE: (TA:) and [its pl.] gamaAliylu is said to signify low, or depressed, tracts of land, covered with herbage. (O.) ― -b2- And (in like manner, S, O) Anything that is collected together, (S, O, K,) obscure, and accumulated, one part upon another, (K,) of trees, or of clouds, or of darkness, (S, O, K,) or a raAwiyap, or zaAwiyap, (the former in the CK, and the latter in other copies of the K and in the TA,) [or] so that a raAwiyap, or zaAwiyap, (the former in my copies of the S, and the latter in the O,) is thus called: (S, O:) [but I think that these two words rAwyp and zAwyp are both mistranscriptions for raAbiyap, which is mentioned in the K as one of the meaning of gumoluwlN; i. e. a hill:] pl. gamaAliylu. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (O, K,) as is said by AHn on the authority of some other or others, (O,) A certain herb, or leguminous plant, (baqolapN, O, K,) likewise called qunRaAbiraI, [thus accord. to the O in art. qnbr, and there said in the TA to be correctly with teshdeed to the n and with kesr to the b, but in the present art. written in the O qunRaAbaraI,] in Pers. barogasot; a herb of the desert (baqolapN daXotiyRapN), which come forth early in the [season called] rabiyE; (O;) eaten (O, K) by men, (O,) cooked. (K.)

magomuwlN c
magomuwlN: see 1, near the middle. ― -b2- Also A man having clothes thrown upon him in order that he may sweat. (S, O.) ― -b3- And Flesh-meat covered over; whether cooked by roasting or the like or with broth or gravy; as also magomuwnN. (TA.) ― -b4- And Palm-trees (naxol) near together. (TA.) ― -b5- And A man obscure, unnoted, or reputeless. (As, O, K.)

1 gamana Aljiloda c
1. gamana Aljiloda, (S, K,) aor.
gamuna
, (S,) inf. n. gamonN, (TA,) i. q. gamalahu; (K;) [see the latter;] He put together the skin after it had been stripped off, and covered it over until its wool became loose, for the purpose of tanning: (TA:) or he covered over the skin (S, TA) for two nights, for the purpose of tanning, (TA,) in order that its wool might become loosened from it: (S, TA:) and the epithet applied to it is gamiynN↓, (S, K,) like gamiylN. (S.) ― -b2- And gamana AltRamora, (S,) or Albusora, (K, TA,) has the like meaning, (S,) i. q. gamalahu; (K;) He covered over [the dates, or] the unripe dates, in order that they might become ripe; (TA:) and the epithet applied to them is magomuwnN↓, like magomuwlN. (TA in art. gml.) ― -b3- And gamana fulaAnFA [like gamalahu] He threw his clothes upon such a one, in order that he should sweat. (K.) ＝ -A2- gumina fiI AlOaroDi means Oadoxila fiyhaA [app. It, or perhaps he, was put into the earth; or made to enter into it]. (K.)

7 Angmn c
7. Angmn It, or he, entered [into the earth: see gumina (immediately preceding); of which it is expl. as denoting the consequence]. (K.)

gumonapN c
gumonapN [A mixture of] white lead (UisofiydaAj) and [the cosmetic termed] gumorap [q. v.] with which a woman rubs over her face: (K:) pl. gumanN [meaning sorts thereof]. (TA.)

gamiynN c
gamiynN: see 1, first sentence.

magomuwnN c
magomuwnN: see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- Also, applied to flesh-meat, i. q. magomuwlN, q. v. (TA in art. gml.) ― -b3- And Palm-trees (naxol) near together; like magomuwlN. (TA.)

1 gamaA Albayota c
1. gamaA Albayota, aor. yagomuwhu, inf. n. gamowN: see 1 in art. gmI.

gamaA c
gamaA in the phrase gamaA waQllRehi, i. q. OamaA [expl. in art. AmA]; (K, TA;) as also with E. (TA.)

gamFA c
gamFA; dual gamawaAni: see gamFI in art. gmI.

1 gamayotu Albayota c
1. gamayotu Albayota, (S, K, TA,) aor. Oagomiyhi, inf. n. gamoIN, (TA,) I roofed the house, or chamber: (K, TA:) or covered its roof (S, K) with earth &c. (K) or with reeds, or canes, and earth, and the like: (S:) and gamRayotuhu↓ signifies the same: (K:) and gamaA Albayota, aor. yagomuwhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. gamowN, (TA,) signifies he covered [the roof of] the house, or chamber, [in like manner, or] with clay, or earth, and wood. (K, TA.) And gamaIi AlXRaIoCa He covered the thing. (Har p. 422.) ― -b2- gumiIa Alyawomu, and AllRayolu, The day, and the night, was constantly clouded, so that the sun was not seen therein nor the new moon: so accord. to Es-Sara- kustee: and he says that Ealayokumo faUino OugomiIa↓ means And if your day be constantly clouded, so that ye see not the new moon, then complete ye [the reckoning of the days of] Shaabán: (Msb:) or faUino gumRa Ealayokumo and gumiIa and OugomiIa↓, thus differently related, all mean, and if it, i. e. the new moon, be covered, or concealed: or and if there be a covering [of clouds] over you: (Mgh:) [see also 1 in art. gm:] or yawomunaA OugomiIa↓ means Our day was one whereof the covering of clouds was constant: and layolatunaA Ougomiyato↓, Our night was one whereof the new moon was veiled, or concealed. (K, TA.) ― -b3- See also 4.

2 gamRaIa
2: see the preceding paragraph, first sentence.

4 OagomaIa
4: see 1, in four places. ― -b2- One says also, OugomiIa Ealayohi Alxabaru The information, or narration, was dubious, confused, or vague, to him; such as was difficult to be understood; or such as was not to be understood; like gumRa: (S:) or was obscure, or unapparent, to him. (Msb.) ― -b3- And OugomiIa Ealayohi, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. UigomaMCN; (Mgh, Msb;) and Elyh gumiIa↓; (S, Msb, K;) said of a sick man, (S, Msb, K,) He swooned, i. e. became senseless, (guXiIa Ealayohi, S, * K,) and then recovered his senses: (K:) or UigomaMCN is a weakness of the faculties by reason of the overpowering effect of disease: (Mgh:) or it is an abstraction, or absence of mind, that overtakes a man, with languor of the limbs, or members, or organs, by reason of a malady; (Mgh, Msb;) thus it is defined by the scholastic theologians; and is the same as guXoIN: (Mgh:) or it is a repletion of the venters of the brain with a cold, thick, phlegm; (Mgh, Msb;) thus accord. to the physicians, who distinguish between it and guXoIN, as do the lawyers: (Mgh:) [see also guXiIa Ealayohi:] the patient is said to be Ealayohi mugomFI↓, (S, Mgh, and so in some copies of the K,) and Ealayohi magomiIRN↓, (S, Msb, and so in some copies of the K,) and gamFI↓, which
last epithet is applied to a single person, (S, K,) and to two persons, (S,) and to a pl. number, (S, K,) and to a female [as well as a male], (S,) or (if you will, S) you say humaA gamayaAni and humo OagomaMCN. (S, K.)

fiI AlsRamaMCi gamoIN c
fiI AlsRamaMCi gamoIN, (K,) or kaAna EalaI AlsRamaMCi gamoIN, (Msb,) and gamFI↓, (Msb, K,) mean [Upon the sky is, or was,] what veiled, or concealed, the new moon: (Msb, K:) not from gumRa: (K:) this addition in the K is meant as an indirect slur upon J, for his having mentioned [in this art.] the statement of Fr that one says SumonaA lilogumRaI and lilogamRaI, meaning We fasted when the new moon was veiled, or concealed, to us; and hiIa layolapu AlgamRaI [or AlgumRaI]; the [proper] place of which is [the section of words whereof the last radical is] m: (TA:) [see gamRN, in that art.: but accord. to Fei,] one says [also], SumonaA lilogumoyapi↓. (Msb. [It is there added that this noun is like mudoyap in measure: otherwise I should think that the right reading is lilogumRiyRap, which has been mentioned voce gamRN.])

gamFI c
gamFI and gimaMCN↓ (T, S, K) The roof of a house, or chamber: (T, K:) or the covering of the roof, (S, K,) consisting of earth &c., (K,) or consisting of reeds, or canes, and earth, and the like; (S;) and gamFA also signifies [the same, or] the covering of a house, or chamber, consisting of clay, or earth, and wood: (TA in art. gmw:) the dual [of the first and last] is gamayaAni and gamawaAni: and the pl. is OagomaMCN, (K, TA,) which is [of the same] like OanoqaMCN pl. of naqFI [and naqFA], (TA,) and OagomiyapN, (K, TA,) which is of gimaMCN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the first, [in the CK, erroneously, gamAC,] A covering that is put upon a horse in order that he may sweat. (ISd, K.) ― -b3- See also gamoIN. ＝ -A2- And see 4, near the end.

SumonaA lilogumoyapi c
SumonaA lilogumoyapi: see gamoIN.

gimaMCN c
gimaMCN: see gamFI, in two places.

gaAmiyaMCu c
gaAmiyaMCu One of the entrances to the burrow of the jerboa. (K.)

mugomFI Ealayohi c
mugomFI Ealayohi and magomiIRN Ealayohi: see 4, near the end.

1 ganRa c
1. ganRa, (MA, Msb, K,) originally ganina, (Msb, MF,) [sec. pers. ganinota,] aor. yaginRu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. gunRapN (MA, KL) and gananN, (MA, [and the same seems to be indicated in the Msb by its being said that the verb is of the class of taEiba,]) or ganRN, (TK, [but this I think a mistake,]) He spoke (MA, Msb, KL) in, (MA,) or from, (Msb, KL,) or [rather] through, (KL,) his nose, (MA, KL,) or his xayaAXiym [app. here meaning the innermost parts of the air-passages of the nose]. (Msb.) [The author of the K gives no indication of the proper signification of this verb but that of its implying what he states to be meant by gunRapN, which see below.] ― -b2- See also 4, in two places.

2 gnRnhu c
2. gnRnhu, inf. n. tagoniynN, It rendered him OaganR [q. v.]. (K.) One says, maA OadoriI maA ganRanahu I know not what rendered him, or has rendered him OaganR. (TA.) ― -b2- And gnRn Sawotahu He made his voice to have in it a gunRap [q. v.]. (Mughnee, art. Harofu AlnRuwni. [See muganRK, voce ganRaMCN, in art. gnI.])

4 AgnR c
4. AgnR said of a man, He made one to hear his gunRap↓, i. e. soft, or gentle, plaintive, and melodious, voice, in singing. (Har p. 645.) ― -b2- AgnR AlcRubaAbu The flies made a sound [or humming]. (K.) ― -b3- AgnR AlwaAdiI (tropical:) The valley had in it the sound [or humming] of flies, [or resounded therewith,] being abundant in herbs, or herbage: (S:) or abounded with trees; as also ganRa↓. (K, TA.) ― -b4- AgnRt AlOaroD (assumed tropical:) The land had its herbs, or herbage, tall, full-grown, or of full height, and in blossom. (TA.) ― -b5- AgnR AlnRaxolu (tropical:) The palm-trees attained to maturity; as also ganRa↓. (K, TA.) ― -b6- And AgnR AlsRiqaMCu (tropical:) The skin became filled (S, K, TA) with water. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- And [it is also trans.:] one says, AgnR QllRehu guSonahu (tropical:) God made its branch beautiful and bright. (K, TA.)

gunRapN c
gunRapN [mentioned above as an inf. n. of ganRa but generally expl. as a simple subst. signifying A sort of nasal sound, or twang:] a sound that comes forth from the nose; (Ham p. 339;) a sound (S, Msb) in, (S,) or that comes forth from, (Msb,) the xayoXuwm [app. here meaning the innermost part of the air-passages of the nose]: (S, Msb:) or a sound from the lahaAp [q. v., app. here meaning the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate, or the furthest part of the mouth,] and the nose, like [that which is heard in the utterance of] the n of minoka and Eanoka, for the tongue has not part in it: (Mgh:) or the flowing [or passage] of the speech in the lahaAp [app. here also meaning as expl. above]: (K:) or a mixture of the sound of the xayoXuwm [expl. above] in the pronunciation of a letter: (Mbr, TA:) n is that one of the letters in which it is greatest in degree: (Kh, Mgh, Msb, TA:) xunRapN is [a sound] greater in degree than gunRapN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also The roughness of the voice, of a boy, consequent upon the attaining to puberty; or, as Mtr says,] AlgunRapu signifies also what is incident to the boy on the occasion of his attaining to puberty, when his voice becomes rough. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And A soft, or gentle, plaintive, and melodious, voice, in singing. (Har p. 645.) See 4. ― -b4- And The sound [or humming] produced by the flying of flies; (TA;) and gunaAnN↓ [likewise] signifies the sound of flies. (K, TA.) [See muginRN and OaganRu. And see also an ex. voce vunRapN: and another voce EunRapN.] ― -b5- And the poet Yezeed Ibn-El-Aawar has used it in relation to the sounding of stones: (K:) [or rather] he has so used the epithet OaganR↓. (TA.)

EunaAnN c
EunaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, near the end.

OaganRu c
OaganRu One who speaks [with a nasal sound, or twang, i. e.] in [or rather through] his nose; (TA;) who speaks from his xayaAXiym [app. here meaning (as expl. before) the innermost parts of the airpassages of the nose]: (S, Msb:) or, accord. to AZ, (Mgh, TA,) whose speech flows, (Mgh, K, *) or passes forth, (TA,) in his lahaAp [app. (as expl. voce gunRapN) the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate, or the furthest part of the mouth]: (Mgh, K, TA:) fem. ganRaMCu, applied to a woman. (Msb.) ― -b2- It is also applied to a gazelle (ZaboIN), meaning Whose cry issues from his xayaAXiym [expl. above]: J has erred in saying that it is applied to Tayor [i. e. birds, or flying things]: (K:) or if by Tyr he mean flies (cubaAbN), his saying thus is not a mistake, for it is applied to them [as meaning making a humming sound]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] waAdK OaganRu (assumed tropical:) A valley abounding with herbs or herbage: for to such the flies constantly keep, and in their sounds is a gunRap. (S. [See also muginRN.]) And (for this reason, TA) one says rawoDapN ganRaMCu i. e. (assumed tropical:) [A meadow, or garden,] abounding with herbs or herbage: or in which the winds pass with a sound that is not clear, [i. e. with a confused, humming, or murmuring, sound,] by reason of the denseness of its herbs or herbage. (K, TA.) And [for the same reason one says] EuXobN OaganRu (assumed tropical:) Herbs, or herbage, tall, full-grown, or of full height, and in blossom. (TA.) ― -b4- And (hence also, S) qaroyapN ganRaMCu (tropical:) [A town, or village,] abounding with inhabitants (S, K, TA) and buildings (K, TA) and herbs or herbage [so that in it is heard the hum of men and women and of flies &c.]. (S, TA.) ― -b5- HarofN OagonRu means A letter from [the utterance of] which results what is termed gunRap [i. e. the nasal sound thus termed]. (TA.) ― -b6- See also gunRapN, last sentence.

waAdK muginRN c
waAdK muginRN (tropical:) A valley in which is [heard] the sound [or humming] of flies; these not being in any valley but such as abounds with herbs or herbage; (S;) a valley of which the flies are abundant, by reason of the denseness, or luxuriance, of its herbs or herbage, so that a gunRap [or humming] is heard, produced by their flying: the epithet being applied to it, but being properly applicable to the flies. (TA.) [See also OaganRu.]

1 ganijato c
1. ganijato, (S, A, MA, O, K;) aor.
ganaja
, (K,) inf. n. gunojN (S, MA) and ganaAjapN; (MA;) and gunijato; (MA;) and tgnRjt↓; (S, A, MA, K;) said of a girl, or young woman, (S, K,) or of a woman, (A, MA,) She used amorous gesture or behaviour, or such gesture or behaviour combined with coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition, (S, * A, * MA, O, * K, * TA,) and an affecting of languor. (TA.) [See gunojN below.]

5 taganRaja
5: see the preceding paragraph.

gunojN c
gunojN [mentioned above as an inf. n.] and gunujN↓ (S, O, K) and gunaAjN↓ and ginaAjN↓, (O, K,) in a girl, or young woman, (S, K,) Amorous gesture
or behaviour, or such gesture or behaviour combined with coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition, (Bkh, S, * O, * K, * TA,) and an affecting of languor: (Bkh, TA:) [in the present day generally used to signify lascivious motion, or a wriggling of the body or hips, under the excitement of sexual passion, or to excite such passion:] accord. to some, beauty of the eyes. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And gunojN and ginaAjN↓ signify also Smoke-black (duxaAnu AlnRaWuwri [see the latter of these two nouns in art. nwr] AA, O, K) which a woman performing the operation of tattooing puts upon her green colour in order that it may become black. (AA, O, TA.)

ganajN c
ganajN An old man: (S, K:) or a man: (TA:) in the dial. of Hudheyl. (S, K.) So in the saying ganajN EalaI XanajK (TA) meaning A man upon a camel: (Lth, IDrd, O, all in art. Xnj:) or a man or an old man, upon a heavy camel: (L in that art.:) a phrase of the tribe of Hudheyl. (TA.) [See EanajN.]

gunujN c
gunujN: see gunojN.

gunojapu c
gunojapu, (O,) or gunajapu, (TA,) without Aalo, and imperfectly decl., (O, TA,) The qunofuc [or hedge-hog], (O,) or the qunofucap [or female hedgehog]. (TA.)

ganijapN c
ganijapN (Bkh, S, A, MA, O, K) and magonuwjapN↓ (A, MA) and [in an intensive sense] migonaAjN↓, (O, K) applied to a girl, or young woman, (S, K,) or to a woman, (A, MA,) Using or who uses, amorous gesture or behaviour, &c., such as is termed gunoj. (Bkh, S, A, MA, O, K, TA.)

gunaAjN c
gunaAjN: see gunojN.

ginaAjN c
ginaAjN: see gunoj, in two places.

gawonajN c
gawonajN A quick, or swift, camel: mentioned by Kr, but said to be not known on the authority of any other. (TA.)

OagonuwjapN c
OagonuwjapN A gesture, or an action, of the kind termed gunoj: pl. OagaAniyju: Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
lawaI raOosahu EaniRI wamaAla biwudRihi
OagaAniyju xawodK kaAna fiynaA yazuwruhaA
[The amorous gestures or actions, &c., of a soft or tender, or goodly-shaped and young, damsel, whom he used to visit among us, turned his head from me, and diverted his love]. (TA.)

migonaAjN c
migonaAjN: see ganijapN.

magonuwjapN c
magonuwjapN: see ganijapN.

Algunodubu c
Algunodubu: see the paragraph here following.

Algunodubapu c
Algunodubapu A hard portion of flesh [app. a gland] around [or app. on either side of] the Huloquwm [which seems to mean here, as it often does, the Haloq, i. e. fauces, or upper part of the throat]; (O, K;) thus expl. by Lth; as also Algunodubu↓; (O;) or Algunoduwbu↓: (K:) pl. ganaAdibu: and it is said that the gunodubataAni are [two things] like two ganglions (Xibohu gudRatayoni) in the nakofataAni; (O, K;) in each nakofap [q. v.] is a gunodubap, and between the gndbtAn is the place of swallowing: (O:) the ganaAdib and the flesh that is upon them, or above them, around the lahaAp [app. here meaning the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate, or the furthest part of the mouth], compose the lagaAniyn [pl. of lugonuwnN, q. v.], which are also called the nagaAnig, pl. of nugonugapN [or nugonugN, q. v.]: (TA:) or the gndbtAn are two glands (EuqodataAni) in, or at, (fiI,) the root of the tongue: (K, TA:) and they are said to be the two amygdalæ of the fauces; i. e. the tonsils: (AllRawozataAni: TA:) or two portions of flesh which are situate on either side of the lahaAp [app. meaning as expl. above, i. e. the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate, or the furthest part of the mouth], (K, TA,) and between which is a space: (TA:) and gunodubataA AlEuroXayoni is expl. as meaning the two things that conjoin (AllRataAni taDumRaAni) the lagaAniyn [above mentioned (I read AllgAnyn instead of AlEyn, an evident mistranscription in my original, for I can only suppose the description to mean the tonsils, as lodged between, and thus conjoining, the anterior and posterior pillars of the soft palate,)] on the right and left. (TA.)

Algunoduwbu c
Algunoduwbu: see the preceding paragraph.

1 ganaZahu c
1. ganaZahu, aor.
ganiZa
(S, O, K, TA) and
ganuZa
, (TA,) inf. n. ganoZN, (S, O, TA,) It, (an affair, or event, S, O, K, TA,) and he, (a man, O, TA,) distressed him. (S, O, K, TA.) And It, or he, filled him with wrath. (TA.) And It (anxiety) clave, or kept constantly, to him; as also AgnZhu↓. (TA.) [See also ganoZN below.]

3 gAnZhu c
3. gAnZhu, inf. n. ginaAZN, He acted with him contrariously, or adversely, and inimically, each doing to the other that which was distressing, or grievous; syn. XaAqRahu. (TA.)

4 OagonaZa
4: see the first paragraph.

Q. Q. 1 ganoZaI bihi c
Q. Q. 1. ganoZaI bihi He reviled him; made him to hear that which was disliked, hated, or abominable; (S, O;) like EanoZaI bihi. (K.)

ganoZN c
ganoZN [an inf. n.: used as a simple subst.,] Grief, or distress, syn. karobN, (IDrd, S, O, K, TA,) as also ganaZN↓, (IDrd, O,) and maXaqRapN, (TA,) [or] such as is vehement, (TA,) [or] such as is most vehement: (S, TA:) and, (K,) accord. to IF, (O,) constant anxiety; (O, K;) as also ganaZN↓: (K:) and, (K,) accord. to AO, (S, O,) a man's being at the point of death (S, O, K) by reason of distress, or grief, and then escaping therefrom. (S, O.) It is related of 'Omar Ibn-'Abd-el-'Azeez, that he mentioned death, and said, ganoZN layosa kaAlganoZi wakaZRN layosa kaAlkaZRi [i. e. Distress, &c., that is not like other distress, &c., and grief, &c., that is not like other grief, &c.: see kaZRN]. (S, O.) [See also ginaAZN.]

ganaZN c
ganaZN: see ganoZN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A plant's becoming altered [for the worse] by heat. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O.)

ganaAZN c
ganaAZN: see an ex. of its dual in the next paragraph.

ginaAZN c
ginaAZN inf. n. of 3 [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And Distress; syn. jahodN, and karobN: El-Fak'asee says, [of a camel,]
tanotaHu ciforaAhu mina AlginaAZi
[His two protuberances behind the ears drip with sweat by reason of distress]. (TA.) [See also ganoZN.] faEala celika ginaAZayoka, as also ganaAZayoka↓, (K,) or, accord. to Lh, ganaAZayoka and EanaAZayoka, with g and E, (TA, [in which it is implied that ginaAZayoka is wrong, but this I think improbable,]) means He did that in order to distress thee time after time; (K;) like giyaAZaka and giyaAZayoka. (K in art. gyZ.)

ganiyZN c
ganiyZN Unripe dates that are cut off from the palm-trees, (AA, O, K,) after they have become yellow or red, or that are upon the racemes when the fruit of the palm-tree is cut off, (AA, O,) and are left (AA, O, K) upon the racemes (K) until they become ripe. (AA, O, K.)

ganRaAZN c
ganRaAZN an epithet applied by Ru-beh, or by El- 'Ajjáj, to a sword [app. as meaning That causes, or causing, much distress]. (IDrd, O, TA.)

ginoZiyaAnN c
ginoZiyaAnN A man foul, unseemly, or obscene, in speech; (As, O, K, TA;) coarse, rude, or rough: (O, TA:) or who mocks at, derides, or ridicules, others: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA:) and EinoZiyAnN signifies the same: fem. with p. (O, TA.)

huwa OagonaZuhumo c
huwa OagonaZuhumo He is the most vehemently grieved, or distressed, of them. (TA.)

magonuwZN c
magonuwZN Distressed. (S, TA.) [See also 1, of which it is the pass. part. n.]

rajulN mugaAniZN c
rajulN mugaAniZN (S, O) A man acting, or who acts, with another, contrariously, or adversely, and inimically, each doing to the other that which is distressing, or grievous; syn. muXaAqRN. (O.)

1 ganima c
1. ganima, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ganama
, (Msb,) inf. n. gunomN (S, MA, Msb, * K, KL) and ganomN, (K,) or, as some say, the former is a simple subst. and the latter is an inf. n., (TA,) and ganamN and ganiymapN and gunomaAnN, (K,) He, or they, (i. e. a man, Msb, or a party of men, S,) obtained, got, or took, (Msb, K, * TK,) spoil, (K, * TK,) or a thing [as spoil]. (Msb, TA.) [And He acquired, or gained, a thing without difficulty, or trouble, or inconvenience: or in this sense the inf. n. is gunomN,
which see below, voce ganiymapN.] maA ganimotumo in the Kur viii. 42 means What ye take by force [in war] from the unbelievers. (Bd, Jel.) [See also 8.]

2 ganRamotuhu c
2. ganRamotuhu, inf. n. tagoniymN, I gave him spoil, or a free and disinterested gift; syn. nafRalotuhu: (S:) or ganRamahu kacaA, inf. n. as above, he gave him such a thing as spoil, or as a free and disinterested gift; syn. nafRalahu UiyRaAhu. (K.)

4 Oagonamahu AlXRaIoCa c
4. Oagonamahu AlXRaIoCa He made the thing to be to him spoil. (TA.)

5 taganRama
5: see 8. ― -b2- One says also, huwa yataganRamu AlOamora, meaning He eagerly desires the affair like as one eagerly desires spoil. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And tgnRm, (TA in the present art.,) or tgnRm ganamFA, (AZ, T and TA in art. Abl,) He took for himself, got, gained, or acquired, sheep or goats or both: like as one says tObRl UibilFA. (AZ, T and TA in art. Abl; and TA * in the present art.)

8 Agtnmhu c
8. Agtnmhu, as also tgnRmhu↓, He reckoned it spoil: (S, K:) or both signify he took, seized, caught, or snatched, it as spoil. (KL.) ― -b2- And [hence] one says, Agtnm AlfuroSapa He took, or seized, or [availed himself of,] the opportunity; or he hastened to take it; syn. AinotahazahaA. (S and A and K in art. nhz.)

gunomN c
gunomN: see ganiymapN, in three places. ― -b2- It signifies also [The regaining (as is shown by an explanation of A 'Obeyd cited in the first paragraph of art. glq), and] the increase, and growth, and excess in value, of a pledge. (O in art. glq, and TA in the present art.) Thus in a trad., in which it is said, AlrRahonu limano rahanahu lahu gunomuhu waEalayohi guromuhu [The pledge pertains to him who pledged it; to him pertains the regaining of it, and its increase, and growth, and excess in value, if such there be, and upon him lies the obligation to pay the debt for it, without requiring any abatement thereof if the pledge have unavoidably suffered damage or total loss: see the explanation of A 'Obeyd mentioned above]. (TA.) Algunomu biAlguromi means The gunom is compensated (muqaAbalN) by the gurom [i. e. the regaining of the pledge, with the increase and the growth and the excess in value thereof if such there be, is compensated by the payment of the debt for it]; for like as the owner [of the pledge] is exclusively entitled to the gunom, no one sharing it with him, so he bears the gurom, no one bearing it with him: and this is the meaning of their saying, Alguromu majobuwrN biAlgunomi [which may therefore be rendered The loss suffered by the payment of the debt is repaired by the regaining of the pledge; app. a phrase of the lawyers, implying that such is to be considered as the case whatever be the state of the pledge at the time of its being restored unless it have suffered damage through the fault of the pledgee]. (Msb.) [See more in the first paragraph of art. glq.] ― -b3- See also gunaAmaAka. ＝ -A2- gnm [app. gunomN] is mentioned by Suh as the name of A certain idol. (TA.)

ganamN c
ganamN i. q. XaMCN, (T, Msb, K,) meaning Sheep and goats; (Msb;) [and both together;] a gen. n., (S, Msb, K,) of the fem. gender, (S, K,) applied to the males and the females, and to both together: (S, Msb, K:) it has no sing. from which it is derived, the sing. being XAp: the dual ganamaAni is used as meaning two flocks or herds [of sheep or of goats or of both together]; (Msb, K;) each flock or herd having its distinct place of pasture and its pastor: (Msb, TA: *) and hence it is said in a trad. that the poor-rate [meaning a portion thereof] is to be given to him to whom the year of drought has left a ganam, but not to him to whom it has left ganamayoni: (TA:) the pl. is OagonaAmN, (Msb, K,) [properly a pl. of pauc.,] sometimes used, (Msb,) meaning flocks or herds of ganam, (Msb and TA in art. Abl,) and also gunuwmN and OagaAnimu, (K,) the last used in an ode of Aboo-Jundab El-Hudhalee: (TA:) the dim. is gunayomapN↓, with p, because quasi-pl. ns. of the class having no sing. from which they are derived, when applied to what are not human beings, are constantly fem.; so one says xamosN mina Alganami cukuwrN [five of sheep, males], making the n. of number fem., though one means rams, when it is followed by mina Alganami, for the n. of number is masc. and fem. accord. to the word, not accord. to the meaning. (S.) ― -b2- In the saying laA Mtiyka ganama Alfizori i. e. HatRaI tajotamiEa ganamu Alfizori [I will not come to thee until the sheep, or goats, of El-Fizr congregate], gnm [with its complement] is made to stand in the place of AldRahor, [the meaning being, I will not come to thee ever,] and is [therefore] put in the accus. case as though it were an adv. n. [of time]. (TA. [This saying with miEozaI in the place of ganama is mentioned by El-Meydánee in his “ Proverbs, ” and thus in the S and K in art. fzr. For an explanation of its origin see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 484.]) ― -b3- AlOagonaAmu is the name of (assumed tropical:) Certain small stars between the legs of Cepheus and the star AljadoIu. (Kzw, in his descr. of Cepheus.) [See XaApN (in art. Xwh), last sentence.]

ganiymN c
ganiymN: see what next follows.

ganiymapN c
ganiymapN and magonamN↓ (S, Msb, K) and ganiymN↓ and gunomN↓ all signify faIoCN [as meaning Spoil, booty, or plunder]: and the acquisition of a thing without difficulty, or trouble, or inconvenience: or this is termed gunomN↓, and faIoCN is termed ganiymapN: (K:) or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, Alganiymapu signifies what is obtained from the believers in a plurality of gods, by force, during war; (Mgh, Msb:) and of this, a fifth is to be taken, [and applied in the manner prescribed in the Kur viii. 42,] and what remains after the fifth is for those who have obtained it, exclusively; (Mgh;) the horseman having three shares, and the foot-soldier having one share: (Az, TA:) and AlfaIoCu signifies what is obtained from them after the laying-down of arms, (Mgh, Msb,) when the country, or place, becomes a country, or place, of Islám; and this is for all of the Muslims, and is not to be divided into fifths: (Mgh:) or the faIoC is what God has given, or restored, of the possessions of the believers in a plurality of gods, to the Muslims, without war, such as the poll-tax, and that for which peace has been made with them; and of this also a fifth is to be applied in the manner prescribed by God, and the remainder is to be expended in the purchase of horses and weapons and other apparatus for the defence of the frontiers: (Az, TA:) and AlnRafalu is what is given to the warrior in addition to his share; and is when the Imám or the commander says, “ He who slays one shall have his spoil; ” or says to a detachment, “ What ye obtain shall be yours, ” or “ the quarter of it, ” or “ the half of it; ” and it is not divided into fifths; and it lies on the Imám to fulfil the promise: or, accord. to 'Alee Ibn-'Eesà, Alganiymapu is more general in signification than AlnRafalu; and AlfaIoCu is more so than Alganiymapu, because it is a name for everything of the possessions of the believers in a plurality of gods that becomes the property of the Muslims: accord. to the lawyers, everything that may be lawfully taken, of their possessions, is faIoC: (Mgh:) the pl. of ganiymapN is ganaAYimu; and the pl. of magonamN↓ is magaAnimu, (Msb, TA,) and gunuwmN occurs as pl. of gunomN↓. (TA.) ganiymapN baAridapN see expl. in art. brd.

guniyomapN c
guniyomapN dim. of ganamN, q. v. (S.)

gunaAmaAka Oano tafaEala kacaA c
gunaAmaAka Oano tafaEala kacaA (S, K, * TA) means The utmost of thy power, or ability, and of thy case, (S, * TA,) and that which thou eagerly desirest like as one desires spoil, (S, * JM, TA, *) [is, or will be, thy doing such a thing;] i. q. quSaAraAka: (K, TA: [see also EunaAnaAka, in art. En:]) and so gunomuka↓: (TA:) and [in like manner] one says, Oano yafoEala kacaA gunayomaAWuhu↓, like HusayonaAWuhu, meaning quSaAraAhu [The utmost of his power, &c.]. (TA in art. Hsn.)

gunayomaAWuhu c
gunayomaAWuhu: see what next precedes.

gaAnimN c
gaAnimN Taking, or a taker, of ganiymap [or spoil]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also two exs. voce XaAjibN.

magonamN c
magonamN: see ganiymapN, in two places.

ganamN mugonamapN c
ganamN mugonamapN and muganRamapN Sheep, or goats, collected together: (TA:) or many or numerous: (K, TA:) or, accord. to AZ, one of these two epithets, thus applied, [probably the latter, like muWabRalapN applied to UibilN, as he seems to say,] signifies [app. divided into distinct flocks or herds,] each [flock or herd] having its own pastor. (TA.)

gunowapN c
gunowapN: see the art. here following.

1 ganiIa c
1. ganiIa, (S, MA, Msb, K, *) from AlmaAl, aor. yagonaI, (Msb,) inf. n. ginFI (S, * MA, Msb, K *) and ganaMCN, (MA, K, * TK, [but the latter is app. held by some to be a simple subst.,]) He was, or became, free from want; in the state, or condition, of having no wants; and also, of having
few wants; or in a state of competence, or sufficiency; or rich, or wealthy; AlginaI being the contr. of Alfaqoru, as also AlganaMCu; (K, TA;) and thus denoting the absence, or non-existence, of wants, which is [properly, or strictly speaking,] attributable to none but God; and also the paucity of wants; (TA;) or syn. with AlyasaAru: (S:) and the epithet applied to him of whom this is said is ganiIRN↓, (S:) or gaAnK↓, (Msb,) [or both, for] both signify the same [as will be shown below]. (K.) One says ganiIa and AstgnI↓ and tgnRI↓ and tgAnI↓ and AgtnI↓, (K, TA, [but wanting in the CK, and app. in several copies of the K, though it is said in one place in the K, as it is in the S, that tgnRI is syn. with AstgnI,]) all having one and the same meaning, and followed by bihi [as therewith signifying He was, or became, free from want; in the state, or condition, of having no want, or need; or in a state of competence, &c.; by means of it, or him; i. e. he was, or became, sufficed by it, or him; and hence, he was, or became, content, or satisfied, with it, or him]. (TA.) layosa minRaA mano lamo yataganRa↓ biAlquroMni, (Msb, TA,) a saying of the Prophet, (Msb,) mentioned in a trad., (TA,) means mn lm yasotagoni↓ [i. e. He is not of us who is not content, or satisfied, with the Kur-án]: so says Sufyán Ibn-'Oyeyneh; not regarding it as meaning the utterance of the voice [in chanting]: and A 'Obeyd says that this obtains extensively in the speech of the Arabs; that they say taganRayotu↓ and tagaAnayotu↓ in the sense of Aisotagonayotu↓. (Az, Msb, TA.) And one says, ganiIa Eanohu, inf. n. ginFI and gunoyaAnN, meaning He was in no need of it [or him]: as also Enh AstgnI↓; and gnh OagonaI↓ [which seems to be rarely used in this sense]: and gunoyapN↓ signifies the state of being in no need: and gaAnKi↓, a man free from need. (MA.) [And maA Eanohu yasotagoniI↓ He is not without need, or not free from want, of it, or him.] And ganiIa bihi Eanohu, (S, Msb,) i. e. Eano gayorihi, (Msb,) inf. n. gunoyapN, (S,) or gunoyapN↓ is the subst., (Msb,) meaning AstgnI↓ [He was sufficed by it, or was satisfied, or content, with it, so as to be in no need, or so as to be free from want, of it, i. e. of another thing]: and the epithet is ganiIRN↓. (Msb.) And [in like manner] ganiyati AlmaroOapu bizawojihaA (S, Msb, K) Eano gayorihi, (Msb,) inf. n. gunoyaAnN (S, K) and ganaMCN also, (TA,) meaning Aisotagonat↓ [The woman was satisfied, or content, with her husband, so as to have no want of other than him]. (S, K) And ganiyato [alone], (K, TA,) inf. n. ginFA [for ginFI, or perhaps a mistranscription for ganaMCN, as in the next preceding sentence], She (a woman) was, or became, such as is termed gaAniyapN [q. v. voce gaAnK]. (K.) ― -b2- ganiIa, (TK,) inf. n. ginFI, (K, TK,) also signifies He married, or took a wife; [as also tgnRI↓; (see Ham p. 226 l. 1, where taganRato occurs said of a woman as meaning she married;)] syn. tazawRaja. (K, * TK. [In the K, only the inf. n. of the former verb in this sense is mentioned; AlginaI being there expl. in some copies as signifying AltRazawRuju; and in others, AltRazowiyju.]) Hence the saying, AlginaI HiSonN liloEazabi [Marriage is a bulwark to him who has no wife; protecting him from the attacks of seductive women by rendering him free from the want of them]: mentioned by Az. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, ganiIa, (S, K,) inf. n. ginFI, (TA,) He dwelt, or abode, (S, K,) biAlmakaAni in the place: (S:) or ganiIa Alqawomu fiI daArihimo The people, or party, dwelt long in their place of abode: (T, TA:) or ganiIa fiI makaAni kacaA He dwelt long in such a place, satisfied, or content, therewith, so as to be in no need of any other. (Er-Rághib, TA.) kaOano lamo yagonawoA fiyhaA, in the Kur [vii. 90 and xi. 71 and 98], means As though they had not dwelt therein. (TA.) [See also the last sentence but two in this paragraph.] ― -b4- And He lived; syn. EaAXa. (S, K.) ― -b5- And I. q. baqiIa: (TA:) one says, ganiytu laka minRiI biAlmawadRapi, meaning baqiytu [i. e. I remained, or have remained, constant to thee with my love, or affection]. (ISd, K, TA: in the CK [erroneously] ganayotu.) ― -b6- [And I. q. kaAna.] qado OagonaI AlHabiyba AlmuSaAfiIa, in a verse of Ibn-Mukbil, means Oakuwnu AlHabiyba [i. e. Certainly I will be, or shall be, the sincere friend]. (TA.) And ganiyato daArunaA tihaAmapa, (K, TA,) in a verse of another poet, (TA,) means kaAnato [i. e. Our place of abode was Tihámeh]. (K, TA.) And one says of a thing when it has perished, passed away, or come to nought, kaOano lamo yagona biAlOamosi, meaning kaOano lamo yakuno [i. e. As though it had not been in existence yesterday]. (Az, TA.) ＝ -A2- ganiIa also signifies laqiIa: (K:) [SM doubts this; saying,] thus in the copies; but perhaps it should be baqiIa, a signification of ganiIa accord. to ISd and the K [and mentioned above]: (TA:) [it appears, however, to be correct; for it is said that] maA ganiytu fulaAnFA means lamo Oaloqahu [i. e. I did not meet, or meet with, or find, or I have not met, &c., such a one]. (JK.) [Accord. to the TK, ganiIa followed by bihi signifies laqiI: but this is perhaps said conjecturally.]

2 ganRaIa
2: see 4. ＝ -A2- gnRI, (S, MA, Msb,) inf. n. tagoniyapN, (KL,) as syn. with tgnRI↓, (S, MA, Msb, *) He sang, or chanted, (S, * MA, KL;) or he trilled, or quavered, or prolonged his voice and modulated it sweetly, singing, or chanting. (Msb in explanation of the former.) You say gnRAhu AlXRiEora [He sang, or chanted, to him the poetry], and gnRI bihi [he sang, or chanted, it, i. e., the poetry], inf. n. tagoniyapN; and bihi tgnRI↓; tgnRI and gnRI having one and the same meaning. (K, TA.) biAlquroMni yataganRaI↓, in a trad. cited in the first paragraph of art. Acn, means, as expl. by EshSháfi'ee, Reciting [or chanting] the Kur-án with a plaintive and gentle voice. (Az, Msb, TA. [See also that trad. somewhat differently related voce taranRama.]) ― -b2- gnRI is also said of a pigeon, meaning It [cooed, or] uttered a cry; (K, TA;) and so tgnRI↓. (TA.) ― -b3- gnRI biAlmaroOapi means tagazRala bihaA, (K, TA,) i. e. He mentioned the woman [in amatory language, as an object of love,] in his poetry: (TA:) and gnRI bizayodK He eulogized Zeyd: or he satirized him: like tgnRI↓ in these two senses: (K, TA:) in that of eulogizing and that of satirizing: or, in the opinion of ISd, both of the verbs are used in these two senses and likewise in the sense mentioned immediately before them; meaning that he did thus after prolonging and modulating his voice; singing, or chanting, the same, i. e. the gazal and the eulogy and the satire. (TA.)

3 gaAonaIa
3: see ganaMCN. [From what is there said, it seems that gAnAhu signifies He was in no need of him, or it; like ganiIa Eanohu and AstgnI Enh: compare tagaAnawoA. ＝ -A2- And app. it signifies also He spoke, or talked, to him, i. e. to a child, or boy, saying to him what was pleasing to him; for it is said that] AlmugaAnaApu means takoliymuka AlSRabiIRa bimaA yahowaI. (JK.)

4 AgnAhu c
4. AgnAhu He (i. e. God, S, K, TA, [but wanting in the CK and app. in several copies of the K,]) rendered him, or made him to be, in no need, or free from want; (S, * MA, K; *) [or in a state of competence, or sufficiency;] or possessed of wealth; (S, * K, * TA;) [or rich, or wealthy; (see 1, first sentence;)] and gnRAhu↓ signifies the same; (K, TA; [but wanting in the CK and app. in several copies of the K;]) or, as some say, this latter is [used] in prayer [app. as meaning he said to him, May God enrich thee, or the like: compare saqRayotuhu (“ I said to him, May God send down rain to thee ”), and EaqRarotuhu (as expl. in art. Eqr), &c.]. (TA.) [And AgnAhu Eano kacaA He, or it, caused him to be in no need, or free from want, of such a thing. (See Ham p. 152.) And yugoniI Eano Oano tafoEala kacaA It renders needless thy doing such a thing: lit. it causes that there shall be no need of thy doing such a thing.] ― -b2- And AgnI Eanohu kacaA Such a thing sufficed him; or stood him in stead: whence the saying in the Kur [lxix. 28], maA OagonaIEanRiI maAliyaho [My property has not sufficed me, or stood me in stead]: and [in iii. 8 and lviii. 18 of the same,] lano tugoniIa Eanohumo OamowaAluhumo [Their possessions will not suffice them in lieu of God]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or this last means, will not defend them from God, i. e. from his punishment. (Jel in iii. 8.) And Oagonayotu Eanoka magonaI↓ fulaAnK and magonaAtahu↓, (S, Msb, K, *) and mugonaI↓ fulaAnK and mugonaAtahu↓, (S, Mgh, K,) and fulaAnK ganaMCa↓, (K,) I sufficed, or satisfied, or contented, thee, or I have sufficed, &c., as such a one; or I stood thee, or served thee, or I have stood &c., in the stead of such a one. (S, * Mgh, Msb, K.) And maA yugoniI Eanoka hecaA This does not suffice, or satisfy, or content, thee; or stand thee, or serve thee, in any stead; and does not avail, or profit, thee.
(S.) AZ mentions maA OagonaI fulaAnN XayoYFA, thus, and with E, [i. e. OaEonaI,] as meaning Such a one did not avail, or profit, at all, in a difficult, or an arduous, affair or case; and did not suffice for such an affair or such a case, or for the supply of what was necessary for subsistence. (Msb, TA.) And he says also that he heard a man chide his slave, and say to him, Oagoni EanRiI wajohaka balo XarRaka, meaning Free me from, and avert from me, [thy face, nay, rather,] thy evil, or mischief: and hence the phrase XaOonN yugoniyhi, [respecting which see the second sentence in art. EnI,] in the Kur [lxxx. 37]. (TA.) [Hence also,] wamaA OugoniI Eanokumo mina QllRehi mino XaIoCK, in the Kur xii. 67, means But I do not avert from you, by my saying this, anything decreed to befall you from God: the second mn is redundant. (Jel.) And one says, Oagoni EanRiI kacaA, meaning Put thou away from me, and remove far from me, such a thing: properly [OagoniniI Eano kacaA, originally meaning render thou me in no need of such a thing,] a phrase of the same kind as EaraDa AldRaAbRapa EalaI AlmaMCi [for EaraDa AlmaMCa EalaI AldRaAbRapi]. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- OagonaI Eanohu as intrans.: see 1, former half. ＝ -A3- maA OagonaAhu [How free from wants, or how rich, or wealthy, is he!]: this and maA Oafoqarahu are [said to be] anomalous; for their [respective] verbs are AstgnI and Aftqr, from either of which the verb of wonder may not properly [or regularly] be formed. (S in art. fqr. [But see ganiIa as syn. with AstgnI; and see also art. fqr.])

5 taganRaIa
5: see 1, former half, in three places: ― -b2- and again in the latter half: ＝ -A2- and see also 2, in five places.

6 tagaAonaIa
6: see 1, former half, in two places. ― -b2- tagaAnuwoA means They were, or became, free from want, one of another, or, as we say, of one another. (S, K.) El-Mugheereh Ibn-Habnà says,
Eano Oaxiyhi HayaAtahu kilaAnaA ganiIRN↓
wanaHonu UicaA mutonaA OaXadRu tagaAniyaA
[Each of us is free from want of his brother in his life-time; and when we die, we shall be more free from such want]. (S.)

8 UigotanaIa
8: see 1, second sentence.

10 UisotagonaIa
10: see 1, in seven places. ＝ -A2- AstgnI QllReha He asked, or begged, God to render him, or make him to be, in no need, or free from want; [or in a state of competence, or sufficiency;] or rich, or wealthy. (K, TA. [But wanting in the CK, and app. in several copies of the K.]) Hence the prayer, AallRehumRa UinRiIa Oasotagoniyka Eano kulRi HaArimK waOasotaEiynuka [O God, I ask Thee to render me in no need of any one who refuses to give, and I beg thine aid]. (TA.)

ganFI c
ganFI, (K, TA,) with fet-h, and maqoSuwr, (TA,) i. q. maYinRapN; so in the saying, makaAnu kacaA ganFI mino fulaAnK [Such a place is meet, fit, or proper, for such a one; as though meaning a place of freedom from want]; as also minohu magonFI↓. (K, TA.)

ginFI c
ginFI and ganaMCN↓ signify the same; (MA, K;) both are inf. ns. of ganiIa: (MA:) [see the first sentence of this art.: used as simple substs., they mean Freedom from need or want; competence, or sufficiency; or richness, or wealthiness:] or ginFI is the inf. n. of ganiIa; (Msb;) and ganaMCN↓ signifies competence, or sufficiency; (Mgh, Msb;) as in the saying, layosa Einodahu ganaMCN He has not competence, or sufficiency: (Msb:) or ganaMCN signifies profit, utility, or avail; (S;) and you say, rajulN laA ganaMCa Einodahu meaning A man who is not profitable to any one: (TA voce dadaAnN; [and in like manner this phrase, occurring in the S voce dadaAnN, is expl. in the PS:]) and gunowapN↓ signifies the same as ginFI in the saying liI Eanohu gunowapN [I have no need of it, or him]: (K and TA in art. gnw:) so says Ks: but, as ISd says, the word commonly known is gunoyapN↓; (TA in that art.;) which see in two places in the former half of the first paragraph of this art.: this last word [said in the S to be an inf. n.] and ginoyapN↓ and gunowapN↓ and gunoyaAnN↓ [which is said in the S and in one place in the K to be an inf. n.] are substs. having one and the same meaning [syn. with ginFI used as a simple subst.]: and maA lah Eanohu ginFI [in the CK erroneously ganFI] and gunoyapN↓ and gunoyaAnN↓ and magonFI↓ mean [lit. He has not freedom from need of it, or him; and hence,] he has not any means, or way, of separating himself from, or avoiding, it, or him; syn. budRN: (K:) and one says Eani fiI AlnRikaAHi gunoyapN↓ AlsRifaAHi [In marriage is freedom from need of fornication]. (A and Msb in art. sfH.) maA kaAna Eano Zahori ginFI, in a trad. respecting alms, means What is over and above that which suffices for the sustenance of the household, or family. (TA.)

gunowapN c
gunowapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

gunoyapN c
gunoyapN and ginoyapN: see ginFI; the former in three places.

gunoyaAnN c
gunoyaAnN: see ginFI, latter half, in two places.

ganaMCN c
ganaMCN: see ginFI, in two places; and see also 4, former half. A poet says,
sayugoniyniI QlRaciI OagonaAka EanRiI
falaA faqorN yaduwmu walaA ganaMCu
[He will render me free from need who has rendered thee free from need of me: for poverty will not always continue, nor competence, or richness]: or, as some relate it, ginaMCu, meaning thereby the inf. n. of gaAnayotu↓: [see 3, above:] but it is said that the proper reading is ganaMCu; because this has no other meaning than that of ginFI: so says ISd. (TA.) ― -b2- maA fiyhi ganaMCu caAka means There is not in him [ability for] the setting-up of that, and strength, or power, to bear it, or carry it, or to raise it upon his back and rise with it. (ISd, K, TA.)

ginaMCN c
ginaMCN is an inf. n. of 3. (TA, [See the next preceding paragraph.]) ＝ -A2- Also, (TA,) [Song, or vocal music; i. e.] an utterance of the voice with a prolonging and a sweet modulation thereof; (K, TA;) or a raising of the voice, and continuing it without interruption; (Nh, TA;) [a singing, and a chanting;] it is said in the S to be mina AlsRamaAEi [meaning that it is a sort of musical performance]: (TA:) being an utterance of the voice, its analogical form would be with damm [i. e. gunaMCN, like HudaAdN &c.]: (Msb, TA:) its pl. is OagoniyapN: (MA:) [and magonFI↓ signifies the same as ginaMCN; and a mode of singing; and any particular air, or tune; and a song, i. e. a composition in verse that is sung or to be sung: and its pl. is magaAnK: but perhaps it is post-classical: the pl. occurs in the K, in art. nSb:] ginaMCN [also] signifies [a song, i. e.] poetry, or verse, that is [sung, or chanted, or] uttered with a trilling, or quavering, or a prolonging and a sweet modulation, of the voice; (Har p. 286;) and OugoniyRapN↓ is syn. with ginaMCN (S, Har) in this sense; (Har;) or, as also UigoniyRapN↓, (Fr, K, TA,) and ↓each of them also without teshdeed, (K, TA,) as mentioned by ISd, but said by him to be not of valid authority, (TA,) signifies a certain sort of ginaMC (K, TA) which they sing or chant: (TA:) and the pl. is OagaAniIRu (S, TA) [and OagaAnK, this latter being the pl. of each sing. that is without teshdeed]. ― -b2- AlginaMC is also used by a poet in the place of an inf. n., meaning AltRaganRiI: he says,
taganRi biAlXRiEori UimRaA kunota qaAYilahu
UinRa AlginaMCa bhecaA AlXiEori miDomaAru
[Sing thou, or chant thou, the poetry, if thou be uttering it: verily the singing, or chanting, this poetry is a mDmAr (expl. in art. Dmr)]. (TA.)

ganiIRN c
ganiIRN and gaAnK↓: see 1, former half; each in two places: both signify [Free from want; or in a state of competence, or sufficiency; or rich, or wealthy; or] possessing much property or wealth: (K, * TA:) pl. of the former OagoniyaMCu. (Msb, TA.) See an ex. of the former in a verse cited above, conj. 6. One says, OanaA ganiIRN bikacaA Eano gayorihi [I am sufficed by such a thing, or satisfied, or content, with it, so as to be free from want of another thing]. (Msb.) ― -b2- AlganiIRu as a name of God signifies [The Self-sufficient; i. e.] He who has no need of any one in any thing. (TA.)

ganRaMCN c
ganRaMCN A singer; (MA;) [as also muganRK↓; and muganRiyapN a female singer, a songstress:] accord. to Ibn-Ya'eesh, a muganRK↓ is thus called liOanRahu yuganRinu Sawotahu, i. e. because he makes his voice to have in it a gunRap [or sort of nasal sound, or twang]; the word being, in his opinion, originally, muganRinN, with three n, the last of which is changed into I, when one says AlmuganRiI, for the purpose of alleviating the utterance. (Mughnee, art. Harofu AlnRuwni.)

gaAnK c
gaAnK: see ganiIRN. ― -b2- [The fem.] gaAniyapN signifies A young woman who is sufficed by her husband; or satisfied, or content, with him, (S, Msb, TA, *) so as to be in no need, or free from want, of any other: (Msb:) and sometimes, also, applied to a woman, (S,) such as is sufficed by her beauty, (S, ISd, K, TA,) so as to be in no need of decoration (ISd, K, TA) with women's ornaments: (ISd, TA:) or such as is sought, or desired, by men, but does not seek, or desire: (ISd, K, * TA:) or such as has abode in the house, or tent, of her father and mother, and whom captivity (sibaMC) has not befallen; (IJ, ISd, K, * TA;) which is the strangest of the explanations: (TA:) or such as is youthful and chaste, whether having a husband or not: (ISd, K, TA:) or, accord. to AO, one that is married: (Ham p. 226:) or, accord. to Az, such as pleases men, and is pleased by XabaAb [which means both youthfulness and youths or young men]: (TA:) pl. gawaAnK; (K;) with the article, AlgawaAniI; [and also gaAniyaAtN: (see an ex. in a verse cited in the second paragraph of art. zj:)] in the saying of Ibn-Er-Rukeiyát,
laA baAraka QllRehu fiI AlgawaAniIi halo
yuSobiHona UilRaA lahunRa muTRalabu
[May God not bless those young women that are sufficed by their husbands, or by their beauty, &c.: do they enter upon the time of dawn without their having desire (lit. a time or place, meaning an occasion, of seeking, or desire)?], the I is made movent by a poetic license: (S, TA:) and another poet uses AlgawaAni for AlgawaAniI. (TA.)

OagonaMCN c
OagonaMCN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] The OamolaAkaAt [meaning Goods and chattels, or paraphernalia,] of brides. (Az, K.)

OugoniyRapN c
OugoniyRapN and UigoniyRapN, and each of them also without teshdeed: see ginaMCN, latter half.

magonFI c
