magonFI: see 4, former half: ― -b2- and ganFI: ― -b3- and ginFI, near the end. ― -b4- Also A place in which were its occupants, or inhabitants: (S:) or a place of abode by which its occupants, or inhabitants, were sufficed, or with which they were satisfied, or content, and from which they then departed, or removed: or in a general sense; (K, TA;) a place of abode, absolutely; but this seems to be a distinct application: (TA:) pl. magaAnK; with the article, AlmagaAniI. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also ginaMCN.

mugonFI c
mugonFI: see 4, former half.

mugonK c
mugonK [act. part. n. of 4,] A man sufficing, or satisfying, or contenting. (TA.) ― -b2- AlmugoniI as a name of God signifies He who satisfies, or contents, whom He will, of his servants. (TA.) ― -b3- And mugoniyapN A woman who satisfies, or contents, her husband, so as to render him in no need of looking at other than her. (Har p. 451.)

magonaApN c
magonaApN and mugonaApN: see 4, former half.

muganRK c
muganRK; fem. muganRiyapN see ganRaMCN, in two places.

1 gahiba c
1. gahiba, [aor.
gahaba
,] inf. n. gahabN, He was unmindful, negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless. (S.) You say, gahiba Eanohu He was unmindful, &c., and forgetful, of him, or it; (K, TA;) as also Aghb↓. (TA.) And OaSaAba SayodFA gahabFA He hit an object of the chase, or objects thereof, inadvertently, unintentionally. (A 'Obeyd, S, K, from a trad.) ― -b2- And gahibahu He was ignorant of it; as also Eahibahu. (TA in art. Ehb.)

4 Oagohaba
4: see the preceding paragraph.

8 Agthb c
8. Agthb He (a man, TA) journeyed in the darkness: (K, TA:) and went far away therein. (TA.)

gihibRaI AlXRabaAbi c
gihibRaI AlXRabaAbi and gihibRaAWuhu, and likewise with the unpointed E, The first part, or state, of youth. (K, TA.)

gayohabN c
gayohabN Darkness; (S, A, K;) as also gayohabaAnN↓: (K:) pl. of the former gayaAhibu. (S.) ― -b2- And A horse, and night, intensely black: (K, TA:) or, instead of waAllRayoli in the K, we may read waAllRayolu; so that the meaning may be, a horse intensely black: and night: agreeably with the A, in which this latter meaning [as well as the former] is assigned to the word; and it is added that one says, OaHosanu mino bayaADi Alkawokabi fiI sawaAdi Algayohabi [More beautiful than the whiteness of the star in the blackness of night]: (TA:) or it signifies intense blackness of the night and of a camel and the like: you say jamalN gayohabN a deep-black camel: (Lth, TA:) and also Oasowadu gayohabN and gayohamN: (Lh, TA:) and rajulN gayohabN a black man; likened to the darkness of night: and layolN gayohabN a dark night: (Sh, TA:) and farasN Oadohamu gayohabN a horse intensely black: (Sh, S, TA:) and it is said in “ the Book of Horses ” by A 'Obeyd that Oadohamu gayohabiIRN↓ signifies [a horse] of the deepest black hue: that the fem. is gayohabapN; and the pl., gayaAhibu: and that dajuwjiIRN is less than gayohabN in blackness, signifying “ of a clear black hue. ” (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, applied to a man, Unmindful, negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless: (K, TA:) and weak, and timid: (TA:) or (K, TA, but in the CK “ and, ”) a heavy, troublesome man: or stupid, dull, or wanting in intelligence; or inert, or wanting in vigour. (K, TA.) And Lacking ability to seek his blood-revenge, or retaliation; as also EayohabN. (TA in art. Ehb.) ＝ -A3- And A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC having much wool; very woolly; (K, TA;) as also EayohabN. (TA.) ― -b2- And A male ostrich. (R, TA.)

gayohabapN c
gayohabapN A clamour, or confused noise, (K, TA,) and commotion, (TA,) in fight, or conflict. (K, TA.)

gayohabiIRN c
gayohabiIRN: see gayohabN.

gayohabaAnN c
gayohabaAnN: see gayohabN. ＝ -A2- Also The belly. (K.)

1 gawaI c
1. gawaI, aor. yagowiI, inf. n. gaIRN (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K, TA) and gawaAyapN; (A 'Obeyd, S, TA;) [respecting which latter see what follows;] and gawiIa (A 'Obeyd, K, TA, but not in the CK,) but this is not commonly known, (TA,) aor. yagowaI, inf. n. gawFI, (A 'Obeyd, TA,) accord. to the M and K gawaAyapN, mentioned above as of gawaI, (TA,) or this last, which is with fet-h, (Msb,) not to be pronounced with kesr, (K,) is a simple subst.; (Msb;) He erred; deviated from the right way or course, or from that which was right: (S, Msb, K:) and was disappointed; or failed of attaining his desire: (S, Msb:) and he laboured, and persisted, (IAth, Msb, TA,) in that which was vain, or false, (IAth, TA,) or in ignorant conduct: (Msb:) or he acted ignorantly from misbelief. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in two places. ＝ -A3- gawiIa, aor. yagowaI; (S, Msb, K;) and gawaI, aor. yagowiI; (K;) inf. n. [of the former] gawFI; (S, K;) said of a young camel, (S, Msb, K,) and of a lamb or kid, (S,) He suffered indigestion from the milk; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) he drank the milk until he suffered indigestion; and his belly, or chest, became in a corrupt state; (S, Msb, * TA;) or he drank much thereof, so that he suffered indigestion: (TA:) or, accord. to ISk, (S, TA,) he did not satisfy his thirst with the biestings of his mother, (S,) or he did not drink thereof, (TA,) nor satisfy his thirst with the milk [after it], so that he died of emaciation: (S, TA:) or he (a kid, AZ, TA) was withheld from sucking (AZ, K, TA) until hunger injured him (AZ, TA) so that he became emaciated, (AZ, K, TA,) and almost perished: (K:) or he obtained not sufficient milk to satisfy his thirst so that he almost perished: (T, TA:) or, said of a child, and of a young camel, he found not a sufficiency of milk, so that he did not satisfy his thirst, and was seen to be meagre, or emaciated; thus accord. to ISh; and Sh says that his companions held this to be the correct meaning: (TA:) the epithet applied to the young camel [&c.] is gawK↓. (K.) Z has mentioned the reading in the Kur [xx. 119], waEaSaI Mdamu rabRahu fagawiIa, expl. as meaning [And Adam disobeyed his Lord, and] suffered indigestion from much eating: but better than this is what Az and Er-Rághib say; that it is fagawaI; and that the meaning is, and his life became evil to him; or he was disappointed; or he acted ignorantly; or some other of the meanings mentioned by the expositors. (TA.)

2 1a2RaRa
2: see 4. ― -b2- gawRayotu AllRabana, (K, TA,) inf. n. tagowiyapN, (TA,) I made the milk to become such as is termed raAYib [i. e. thick, or coagulated, &c.]; (K, TA;) as though I spoiled it, so that it became thick. (TA.)

4 AgwAhu c
4. AgwAhu; (S, MA, Msb, K;) and gwRAhu↓, (K,) inf. n. tagowiyapN; (TA;) and gawaAhu↓, (K, TA,) mentioned by El-Muärrij; (TA;) [but] accord. to As, one should not say otherwise than AgwAhu; (S, TA;) He caused him to err; or to deviate from the right course, or from that which was right: (S,
Msb, K:) and caused him to be disappointed; or to fail of attaining his desire: (S:) or he seduced him, misled him, or led him astray; as also AstgwAhu↓. (MA.) A poet, cited by El-Muärrij, says,
wakaAYino taraI mino jaAhilK baEoda Eilomihi
AlhawaI jaholFA Eani AlHaqRi faQnogawaI↓ gawaAhu↓
[How many an ignorant dost thou see, whom, after his knowledge, love, or desire, has urged to turn, in ignorance, from that which was right, and who has turned: or has turned, in ignorance, from that which was right, and who has suffered himself to be turned; for,] accord. to Az, gawaAhu AlhawaI is most correctly rendered as meaning lawaAhu, and Sarafahu; and AngwI is quasi-pass. thereof. (TA.) The saying in the Kur [vii. 15], related as from Iblees, fabimaA OagowayotaniI means [Then by, or because of,] thy having caused me to err: or, as some say, invited me to [do] a thing whereby I have erred. (TA.) But the saying in the same [xi. 36], Uino kaAna QllRehu yuriydu Oano yugowiyakumo is said to mean If God desire to punish you for erring: or to decree, against you, your erring [i. e. that ye shall err]. (TA.)

6 tagaAwawoA Ealayohi c
6. tagaAwawoA Ealayohi They collected themselves together, or combined, and aided one another, against him; (S, TA;) originally, (TA,) in an evil affair; from AlgaIR and AlgawaAyap: (S, TA:) or they aided one another against him, and slew him; (K;) but this addition “ and slew him ” is from a trad. respecting the slaying of 'Othmán, in which it is said, fatagaAwawoA Ealayohi waQllRehi HatRaI qataluwhu [and they collected themselves together, &c., against him, by God, so that they slew him]: (TA:) or they came against him from this quarter and from that; though they did not slay him: (ISd, K, TA:) or they collected themselves together, and aided one another, against him, as do those who err, or deviate from the right way or course; thus expl. by Z. (TA.) [See also 6 in arts. gI and Ew.]

7 AngwI c
7. AngwI signifies AinohawaI and maAla [app. He declined from the right way or course; for all of these three verbs seem to be here used in one and the same sense, agreeably with a saying in the JK, AlmunogawiI Xibohu AlmunohawiI AlmaAYilu]: (K:) [or rather,] accord. to Az, [it signifies he was, or became, or suffered himself to be, made to decline, or to turn, from the right way or course, by love, or desire; for he says that] it is quasi-pass. of gawaAhu AlhawaI, which signifies OamaAlahu and Sarafahu: (TA:) or he fell into error by yielding to love and desire. (TK: there given as the meaning of the explanation in the K.) See also 4.

10 Uisota1o2a2a
10: see 4, first sentence.

R. Q. 2
R. Q. 2: if belonging to art. gw, or Q. Q. 2 if belonging to art. gwg. tagaAgaI Ealayohi AlgawogaMCu [as though originally tagawogaI]: see art. gwg.

gawFI c
gawFI Thirst. (TA.) ― -b2- And one says, bitRu gawFI, and gawiyRFA↓, and mugowiyFA↓, (K, TA,) in the T mugawRFI↓, (TA,) [in the CK magowiyRFA,] meaning muxoliyFA (K, TA) [in the CK muxalRayFA] muwHiXFA (TA) [i. e. I passed the night empty]: and so qawiyFA, and qaAwiyFA, and muqowiyFA. (TA.) [See also gawiIRN.]

gawK c
gawK: see gaAwK: ＝ -A2- and see also 1, near the end.

gaIRN c
gaIRN is an inf. n.; as also gawaAyapN↓; (A 'Obeyd, S, &c.; [see 1, first sentence;]) or the latter is a simple subst.: (Msb:) [both, used as substs., signify Error; &c.: gayRapN↓, of which the pl. (gayRaAtN) is mentioned by Freytag as meaning errors, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees, is an inf. n. of un., and signifies an error, &c.:] and gaIRN signifies also a state of perdition. (Ham p. 643.) See also gayRapN. ― -b2- Also A certain valley in Hell: or a river [therein]: (K, TA:) prepared by God for those who err: it is said that it has one or the other of these meanings in the Kur xix. 60: (TA:) or it there means (assumed tropical:) punishment; because it is the consequence of gaIR [properly thus termed]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it there means evil: or the recompense of gaIR [i. e. of error]: or deviation from the way of Paradise. (Bd.)

gawRapN c
gawRapN: see the next paragraph.

gayRapN c
gayRapN: see gaIRN. gawRapN↓ and gayRapN signify the same. ― -b2- [Hence,] waladu gayRapK, and giyRapK↓, (K, TA,) but the latter is said by Lh to be rare, (TA,) The offspring of fornication or adultery; (K, TA;) contr. of waladu riXodapK. (TA.) And one says also Aibonu AlgaIRi↓ [meaning The son of fornication or adultery]. (L in art. bhv.) And huwa ligayRapK, (S, Msb,) and ligiyRapK↓, said in reviling a person, He is, or was, unlawfully begotten; (Msb;) contr. of liriXodapK. (S.)

giyRapN c
giyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

gawiIRN c
gawiIRN: see gaAwK: ＝ -A2- and see also gawFI. You say of a hungry person, raOayotuhu gawiyRFA mina AljuwoEi [I saw him empty, or lean, from hunger]; like as one says qawiyFA and DawiyFA [or DaAwiyFA] and TawiyFA. (TA.)

gawaAyapN c
gawaAyapN: see gaIRN, above.

gayRaAnu c
gayRaAnu [as though originally gawoyaAnu]: see what next follows.

gaAwK c
gaAwK, and gawiIRN↓, (S, Msb, K,) and gawK↓, (S, TA,) and gayRaAnu↓, (K,) [or the first is an act. part. n., and the others are intensive epithets,] Erring; deviating from the right way or course, or from that which is right: (S, Msb, K:) and suffering disappointment; or failing of attaining his desire: (S, Msb:) [&c.: (see 1, first sentence:)] and the first signifies also perishing: (Ham p. 643:) the pl. of the first is guwaApN, (Msb, TA,) like quDaApN pl. of qaADK, (Msb,) and gaAwawna. (K.) AlgaAwuwna in the saying waQlXRuEaraMCu yatRabiEuhumu AlgaAwuwna [in the Kur xxvi. 224] means The devils: or those, of mankind, who err: (K, TA:) or those who love the poet when he satirizes a people, or party, (Zj, K, TA,) by saying that which is not allowable: (Zj, TA:) or those who love him for his praising them for that which is not in them. (Zj, K, TA.) ― -b2- And AlgaAwiI signifies The locust, or locusts collectively: (K, TA:) one says, jaMCa AlhaAwiI waAlgaAwiI, meaning The wolf and the locust, or locusts, came: (TA:) so says IAar. (TA in art. hwI, where, in the K, AlhaAwiI is said to signify “ the locust ” or “ locusts. ”) ― -b3- raOosN gaAwK is a tropical phrase, meaning, accord. to the K, A small head: but accord. to the A, a head that turns, or looks, aside, much, or often. (TA.)

gaAwiyapN c
gaAwiyapN i. q. raAwiyapN, (Sgh, K, TA,) [as meaning] A camel that carries water: pl. gawaAyaA: [the sing. and pl. being] like zaAwiyapN and zawaAyaA. (JK.)

gaAgN c
gaAgN and gaAgapN, the latter mentioned in the K in this art. as meaning A certain plant: see art. gwg.

gawogaMCN c
gawogaMCN and gawogaMCu: see art. gwg.

OugowiyRapN c
OugowiyRapN A [pitfall such as is termed] zuboyap; (K, TA;) or a hollow, or pit, dug in the ground, like a zuboyap, for the wolf, and in which a kid is put; and when he [the wolf] looks at it, he falls, desiring to obtain it, and so is taken: (TA:) and mugawRaApN↓ [likewise] signifies a zuboyap, (TA,) or a hollow, or pit, dug in the ground, like a zaboyap, (S,) for [catching] beasts of prey: (TA:) whence the saying, (S, TA,) which is a prov., (TA,) mano Hafara mugawRaApF OawoXaka Oano yaqaEa fiyhaA [He who digs a pitfall is near to his falling into it]: (S, * TA:) pl. mugawRayaAtN. (S.) ― -b2- And A cause, or place, of perdition or death; (K, TA;) as also mugawRaApN↓: (TA:) or a calamity, or misfortune; thus in the saying, waqaEa AlnRaAsu fiI OugowiyRapK [The people fell into a calamity, or misfortune]. (S.)

mugowK c
mugowK; whence the phrase bitRu mugowiyFA: see gawFI.

magowaApN c
magowaApN: see mugawRaApN, in two places.

mugawRFI c
mugawRFI, in the phrase bitu mugawRFI: see gawFI.

mugawRaApN c
mugawRaApN: see OugowiyRapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A land in which one errs from the right way; syn. maDilRapN; (K, TA; in the CK miDalRap;) as also magowaApN↓, like mihowaApN; (K, TA; in the CK migowAp, like mihowAp;) and so OaroDN mugawRaApN: (TA:) the pl. of mugawRaApN is mugawRayaAtN; (K, TA;) and that of magowaApN↓ is magaAwK. (TA.) ― -b3- Also Any well. (AA, TA.)

1 gaAva c
1. gaAva: see 4. ＝ -A2- [And see also gawiyvN.]

2 gwRv c
2. gwRv, (S, K,) inf. n. tagowiyvN; (K;) and AstgAv↓; (TA;) He cried out, (TA,) and said, (S, K,) waA gawovaAhu↓ (S, K, TA) [Alas! a cry for aid, or succour! also pronounced wA gawovaAhi (accord.
to one of my copies of the S) and wA gawovaAho]. You say, Duriba fulaAnN fagawRava Such a one was beaten, and cried wA gwvAh. (TA.) This is declared by the leading grammarians to be the primary signification of gwRv: then they used it as meaning He cried out, or called, desiring, or demanding, aid, or succour. (MF.) ＝ -A2- See also gawiyvN.

4 AgAvhu c
4. AgAvhu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UigaAvapN (Msb, K) and maguwvapN↓ [which is anomalous], (K,) He aided, or succoured, him; (Msb;) He (i. e. God, Msb) removed from him trouble, or affliction: (Msb, TA:) gaAvahu↓, aor. yagiyvuhu, is used in the sense of AgAvhu, but is rare, and is said [by some] to be from Algayovu, not AlUigaAvapu: gAvhu, aor. yaguwvuhu, is mentioned by Az as not heard by him from any one; but ISd mentions gAvhu, inf. n. gawovN and giyaAvN, though saying that AgAvhu is more approved. (TA.) And one says also, OagaAvanaA AlmaTaru (assumed tropical:) [The rain gave us relief]. (Msb.)

6 tagaAwavuwA c
6. tagaAwavuwA, accord. to Freytag, appears to be used in the Deewán of the Hudhalees as signifying They said, one to another, waA gawovaAhu: ＝ -A2- and tgAwv as syn. with OagaAva.]

10 AstgAvhu c
10. AstgAvhu, (S, O, Msb, K,) and AstgAv bihi, (O, Msb, TA,) the latter disallowed by some, but used by Sb, (TA,) He sought, desired, or demanded, aid, or succour, of, or by means of, him, or it; he sought, &c., [or called for,] his aid, or succour. (O, MF, TA.) ― -b2- See also 2. [Hence, AstgAv AlEuwdu (assumed tropical:) The lute sent forth plaintive sounds: a modern phrase.]

gawovN c
gawovN and guwaAvN↓ and gawaAvN↓, (S, K,) the last deviating from the common course of speech, (K, TA,) with respect to analogy, as will be seen from what follows, (TA,) A cry for aid, or succour. (S, K, KL, PS.) One says, OajaAba QllRehu duEaMCahu wguwaAvahu↓ and gawaAvahu↓ [God answered his prayer, and his cry for aid]. (Fr, S.) gawaAvN↓ is said by Fr to be the only word significant of a sound, or cry, having fet-h [to the first letter]; other words of this kind being with damm, as bukaMCN and duEaMCN, or with kesr, as nidaMCN and SiyaAHN. (S.) See also 2. ― -b2- And see giyaAvN.

gawaAvN c
gawaAvN: see gawovN, in three places: ― -b2- and see also giyaAvN. ― -b3- In the dial. of Himyer it signifies (assumed tropical:) Travelling-provision. (TA.)

guwaAvN c
guwaAvN: see gawovN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph here following.

giyaAvN c
giyaAvN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) in which the w is changed into I because of the kesreh preceding it, (S,) a form disapproved by some of the lexicographers, but several others assign to it priority, (MF,) a subst. from OagaAvahu, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) as also gawaAvN↓, ascribed by Ibn-Hajar to the majority, and guwaAvN↓, mentioned on the authority of Aboo-Dharr, (MF,) and gawovN↓; (Msb;) signifying Aid, or succour; (Msb;) or deliverance from difficulty, distress, or adversity, and [from] revenge; and aid to release from difficulties, distresses, or adverse circumstances. (MF.) In the T, AlgiyaAvu is expl. as signifying That with which God aids, or succours, one. (TA.) ― -b2- And giyaAvN signifies also An aider, or a succourer: you say, fulaAnN giyaAvunaA Such a one is our aider, or succourer; i. q. mugiyvunaA↓: (TA in art. nwr:) and God is said to be giyaAvu Almusotagiyviyna [The Aider of the seekers of aid]. (O.) ― -b3- [Hence,] OumRu giyaAvK is a name for (assumed tropical:) The cooking-pot. (T in art. Am.)

gawiyvN c
gawiyvN Food, or other succour, with which one aids a person in necessity. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- Also, (O, K,) in one copy of the K tagowiyvN↓, (TA,) [both perhaps inf. ns., the former like dabiybN &c.,] Vehemence of running (XidRapu EadowK). (O, K.)

mugiyvN c
mugiyvN: see giyaAvN, last sentence but one.

maguwvapN c
maguwvapN, an [anomalous] inf. n.: see 4.

magaAwivu c
magaAwivu Waters: (O, K:) said to be one of those plurals that have no singulars. (TA.)

yaguwvu c
yaguwvu A certain idol which belonged to [the tribe of] Medhhij: (Zj, ISd, K, TA:) or a certain good man, who lived between [the times of] Adam and Noah, and of whom, after his death, was made an image, which, after a long time, became an object of worship; like wadRN and suwaAEN and yaguwqu and nasorN, mentioned therewith in the Kur lxxi. 22 and 23. (Bd.)

1 gaAja c
1. gaAja, (S, O, K,) aor. yaguwju, (S, O,) said of a man; (TA;) and tgwRj↓, (O, K,) likewise, (TA,) or this is said of a horse; (O;) He affected a bending of his body, syn. tavanRaI and taEaTRafa, (S, O, K, TA,) and inclined from side to side, in his gait. (TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
EaXiyRapa qaAmato biAlfinaMCi kaOanRahaA
Eaqiylapu nahobK tuSoTafaI wataguwju
[In the evening when she arose, in the yard of the dwelling, as though she were the most excellent portion of booty, to be selected therefrom, and affecting a bending of her body, and inclining from side to side]: i. e. displaying herself to the chief of the army, in order that he might take her for himself. (S, O.)

5 tagawRaja
5: see the preceding paragraph.

gawojN c
gawojN, applied to a horse, Pliant, pliable, limber, or lithe; syn. layRinu AlOaEoTaAfi: pl. guwjN. (En-Nadr, TA.) ― -b2- And A man relaxed by reason of drowsiness. (TA.) ― -b3- And A broad-breasted camel. (TA.) ― -b4- And gawoju AllRabaAni A horse ample in the skin of the breast, (S, O, K,) but not unless he be saholu AlmaEoTifi [i. e. pliant, pliable, limber, or lithe]: (S, O, TA:) or a horse long in the qaSab [or bones of the legs]: or that bends, going and coming. (TA.) ― -b5- And gawojN mawojN, the latter word being an imitative sequent, A horse fleet, or swift; excellent in running; or that outstrips others. (TA.)

gawRaAjN c
gawRaAjN That goes with energy: an epithet applied by Aboo-Wejzeh to a camel. (O.)

1 gaAra c
1. gaAra, (As, Fr, IAar, S, Msb, &c.,) aor. yaguwru, (S, &c.,) inf. n. gaworN (S, K) and guWuwrN; (K;) and AgAr↓, (Fr, Msb,) inf. n. UigaArapN; (K;) but IAth says that this form of the verb is of rare occurrence, (TA,) and As disallows it; (S, Msb, TA;) and gwRr↓, inf. n. tagowiyrN; (S, K;) and tgwRr↓; (K, TA;) He came to the gawor, (As, Fr, IAar, S, Msb, K,) i. e., low land or country, (Msb,) [or the region so called, in Arabia:] or gAr signifies he journeyed in the region of the gwr: (As, TA:) or gAr and AgAr↓ signify he took his way towards the gawor. (TA.) There is a difference of opinion respecting the saying of El-Aashà,
nabiIRN yaraI maA laA tarawona wacikoruhu
laEamoriI fiI AlbilaAdi waOanojadaA OagaAra↓
[meaning, accord. to the first explanation of AgAr, A prophet who seeth what ye see not, and whose fame has come to the low lands, by my life, or by my religion, in the several regions, and has come to the high lands]: As says that AgAr signifies has gone quickly; and Anjd, has risen; and that the poet does not mean has come to the low lands nor to the high lands; holding gAr only to signify the coming to the low land: but Fr asserts that AgAr is a dial. var. of gAr; and cites this verse as authority: and some say AgAr wAnjd, but when they do not conjoin the two verbs they say gAr; like as they say hanaOaniI AlTRaEaAmu wamaraOaniI, but when they do not conjoin these two verbs they say OamoraOaniI: (S:) As also mentions another relation of the second hemistich, commencing AgAm [app. a mistake for OaqaAma or some other word]: (IKtt:) and there is another relation, accord. to which the second hemistich is maxoruwm, commencing with gaAra. (L.) You say also gaAra waOanojada meaning (assumed tropical:) He became famous in the low countries and the high. (A in art. njd.) ― -b2- gAr fiI XaIoCK, inf. n. gaworN and guWuwrN (K) and giyaArN, (Sb, K,) He, or it, entered [or entered deeply] into a thing. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence,] gAr fiI OamorK (tropical:) He examined minutely [or deeply] into an affair; (IKtt, Msb;) as also AgAr↓. (IKtt.) You say fulaAnN biEiydu Algawori (tropical:) Such a one is a deep examiner: (TA:) or acquainted [deeply] with affairs: or very rancorous, malevolent, malicious, or spiteful. (Msb.) [See also gaworN, below.] ― -b4- gAr AlmaMCu, (Lh, S, Msb, K,) fiI AlOaroDi (K,) inf. n. gaworN (Lh, S, K, &c.) and guWuwrN; (S, TA;) and gwRr↓, (Lh, TA,) inf. n. tagowiyrN; (K;) The water sank, (S, IKtt,) or went away, (Msb, K,) into the ground, or earth: (S, Msb, K:) or went away into the sources, or springs. (Lh.) ― -b5- gaArati
AlXRamosu, (S, K,) aor. taguwru, (S,) inf. n. giyaArN (S, K) and guWuwrN; (K;) and gwRrt↓; (K;) The sun set: (S, K:) and in like manner one says [gAr and gwRr↓] of the moon and of a star. (TA.) ― -b6- gaArato Eayonuhu, aor. taguwru, (S, Msb,) inf. n. gaworN (S, TA) and guWuwrN; (S, Msb, TA;) and gaArato, aor. tagaAru; (S, TA;) and gwRrt↓; (TA;) His eye sank, or became depressed, (lit. entered,) in the head; (S, TA;) i. q. Ainoxasafato. (Msb.) ― -b7- gAr AlnRahaAru (assumed tropical:) The day became intensely hot [app., like gawRara, meaning when the sun had declined from the meridian]: (K:) hence AlgaAYirapu [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b8- See also 2. ＝ -A2- gaAra XayoYFA, aor. yaguwru, He sought for, or after, a thing. (TA.) ＝ -A3- gaArahumo, and gaAra lahumo, [aor. yaguwru,] inf. n. giyaArN, He (God) bestowed upon them giyrap, (K,) i. e. miyrap [a provision of corn, or wheat, &c.]. (TA.) [See also art. gyr.] ― -b2- He benefited them; (S in art. gyr, and TA;) and so gaArahumo bixayorK: (S:) and gaArahumo, aor. yaguwru, (K,) inf. n. giyaArN; (TA;) or gaArahumo bixayorK; (TA;) He (God) bestowed upon them abundance of the produce of the earth, and rain: (K, TA:) and gaArahumo birizoqK He bestowed upon them means of subsistence. (TA.) You say also AallRehumRa guronaA bigayovK, (K,) and bimaTarK, and bixayorK, (TA,) and guronaA minoka bigayovK, (S,) O God, aid us, or succour us, with rain (S, K) from Thee, (S,) and with prosperity. (TA.) [See also art. gyr.] ＝ -A4- gaAra AlrRajula, aor. yaguwruhu and yagiyruhu, He gave the man the bloodwit [which is termed giwarN and giyarN]: (ISk, TA:) and so gayRarahu. (TA in art. gyr.) ＝ -A5- gaAra EalaI Oaholihi, aor. yagaAru, inf. n. giyrapN [or rather gayorapN (see art. gyr)] and gaArN, [He was jealous of his wife.] (IKtt.) gaArN and gayorapN, (S, so in my two copies,) or gaArN and giyrapN, with kesr, (K,) signify the same. (S, K.) You say fulaAnN Xadiydu AlgaAri EalaI Oaholihi i. e. Algyrp [Such a one is vehemently jealous of his wife]. (TA.) See also art. gyr.

2 gwRr c
2. gwRr, inf. n. tagowiyrN: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- Also He slept in the middle of the day; (S, * K, TA;) and so gaAra↓. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And He alighted (Lth, S, K, TA) to sleep (Lth, S, TA) in the middle of the day. (Lth, S, K, TA.) And gawRiruwA binaA Make ye the camels to lie down with us during the vehement midday-heat. (Jm and TA in art. rmD.) IAar says that mugawRirN↓ signifies One alighting in the middle of the day for a little while and then departing [i. e. resuming his journey]. (TA.) And maA bitRu hecihi AllRayolapa UilRaA tagowiyrFA occurs in a trad. as meaning [I did not tarry, or have not tarried, this night,] save in taking a nap [like the sleep in the middle of the day]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also He entered upon the middle of the day. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And He journeyed in the middle of the day: (Lth, K:) or he (a rider upon a camel, or upon a horse or other beast,) journeyed until the declining of the sun from the meridian, and then alighted. (ISh, TA.) ― -b6- And gwRr AlnRahaAru (tropical:) [app. The day became intensely hot when] the sun declined from the meridian. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA. [See also gaAra AlnRahaAru.]) ＝ -A2- gwRrhu, inf. n. as above, He put it, or made it to enter, into a low, or depressed, place: he hid, or concealed, it; or caused it to disappear. (Har p. 165.) ― -b2- And gwRr, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) signifies also He routed, defeated, or put to flight; and he drove away. (K, * TA.)

3 gaAowara
3: see 4; and see also 6.

4 AgAr Eayonahu c
4. AgAr Eayonahu [He made his eye to sink, or become depressed, in his head: see 1]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AgAr as intrans.: see 1, in four places. ― -b2- Also He went away in, or into, the country, or land. (K.) ― -b3- And, (S, K, &c.,) inf. n. UigaArapN (S, Mgh, Msb) and gaArapN, (Mgh,) or the latter is a simple subst., [or quasi-inf. n.,] (Msb,) He hastened, (K,) or was quick, (Msb,) in walking, or marching, or journeying: (Msb, K:) he was quick, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and pushed, or pressed, on, or forward, (dafaEa, S,) in his running; (S, Mgh, Msb;) said of a horse, (Mgh, Msb,) and of a fox: (S, Mgh:) he (a horse, K) ran vehemently, and was quick, (S, K,) in a gaArap [or raid, or sudden attack upon a people, or their dwellings,] &c. (K.) Hence the saying, (in a trad. respecting the pilgrimage, TA,) OaXoriqo vabiyro kayomaA nugiyro [Enter thou upon the time of sunrise, Thebeer, (the name of a mountain near Mekkeh,)] that we may proceed quickly, (S, K,) or push, or press, on, or forward, (Yaakoob, Msb,) to the sacrifice of the pilgrimage: (S, Msb, K:) or to the return from Minè: (Yaakoob:) or that we may plunder the meats of the sacrifices: or that we may enter into the low land. (TA. [See also 2 in art. Xrq.]) Hence also the saying, OagaAra UigaArapa AlvRaEolabi He was quick, and pushed, or pressed, on, or forward, like as does the fox. (S.) ― -b4- AgAr EalaI AlEaduwRi, (S, Msb,) and EalaI Alqawomi, (K,) inf. n. UigaArapN (S, K) and gaArapN, (K,) or the latter is a simple subst., [or quasi-inf. n., as in the case mentioned above,] (TA,) and mugaArN, (S, TA,) He made [a raid, or hostile or predatory incursion, into the territory of the enemy; or] a sudden, or an unexpected, attack [upon the enemy, or] upon the territory or dwellings of the enemy, [with a party of armed horsemen, generally meaning a predatory incursion,] and engaged with them in conflict; (Msb,) or he urged the horses upon, or against, the people; as also AstgAr↓: (K, TA:) and in like manner you say AlEaduwRa gAwr↓, inf. n. mugaAwarapN and giwaArN. (S.) See also 6. And AgAr AlcRiYobu fiI Alganamoi The wolf made an incursion among the sheep or goats; (K * and TA in art. XE;) as also AstgAr↓. (TA ibid.) ― -b5- Also AgAr Ealayohi He plundered it; took it by pillage. (TA.) ― -b6- And AgAr bibaniI fulaAnK, and sometimes UilaI bnI flAn, He came to the sons of such a one to aid, or succour, them: (IKtt, K:) or to be aided, or succoured, by them. (IKtt.) ＝ -A3- AgAr, (S, K,) inf. n. UigaArapN and quasi-inf. n. gaArapN, (TA,) signifies also He twisted hard (S, K) a rope. (S.) ＝ -A4- AgAr Oaholahu He married another in addition to his wife [and so caused her to be jealous: see 1]. (S.) [See also art. gyr.]

5 tagawRara
5: see 1, first signification.

6 tgAwrwA c
6. tgAwrwA They made [raids, or hostile or predatory incursions, into each other's territories; or] sudden attacks, one upon another, or one party upon the dwellings of another party, and engaged in conflict, one with another; or urged their horses one upon, or against, another; expl. by OagaAra↓ baEoDuhumo EalaI baEoDK: (S, K:) and so gAwrwA↓, inf. n. mugaAwarapN. (TA.)

8 AgtAr c
8. AgtAr He procured miyrap [or provision of corn, or wheat, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And He derived, or obtained, benefit, advantage, or profit. (K.)

10 Uisotagowara
10: He, or it, descended: (TA:) or he desired to descend into a low land or country. (K, TA.) ― -b2- See also 4, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also He became fat; and fat entered into him: (S, TA:) or you say, AstgAr AlXRaHomu fiyhi fat spread in him; and he became fat; (K, TA;) the pronoun referring to a horse, which is not mentioned in the K; but the explanation in the S is better: or, accord. to Az, AstgAr is said of the fat and flesh of a she-camel, meaning it became hard, and compact; like the rope of which one says yasotagiyru i. e. it is twisted hard: or, accord. to some, said of the fat of a camel, it means it entered his inside. (TA.) ― -b2- AstgArt said of a wound, (qaroHapN, S, in the K juroHap,) means It became swollen. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- Aisotagowara QllReha He asked, or begged, of God, giyrap, (K, TA,) i. e. miyrap [provision of corn, or wheat, &c.]. (TA.)

gaArN c
gaArN A cave, or cavern; syn. kahofN; (S, K;) in a mountain; (S;) as also magaArapN↓ and magaArN↓ (S, K) and mugaArapN↓ and mugaArN↓ and gaworN↓: (K: [but gaArN in this sense is omitted in the CK:]) or what resembles a khf in a mountain, [only differing in being less large,] like a sarab: (TA:) or what is hewn out in a mountain, resembling a magaArap: when it is large, or spacious, it is called khf: (Msb:) or what resembles a house, or chamber, in a mountain: (Lh, K:) or a low, or depressed, place in a mountain: (Th, K:) or any low, or depressed, land, country, or ground: (K:) see also gaworN [and xaworN]: or the hole, or burrow, to which a wild animal betakes itself: (K: [see an instance in art. smw, conj. 8:]) and sometimes magaArN↓ is applied to the coverts of gazelles, among trees: (S:) the dim. of gaArN is guwayorN: (S, K:) [of which see two exs. (a prov. and a verse) voce buWosN:] and the pl. (of pauc., TA) OagowaArN (IJ, K) and (of mult., TA) giyraAnN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also The portion of the upper part of the mouth which is behind the faraAXap [or thin bone of the palate]: or the hollow (Ouxoduwd) which is between the two jaws: or the interior of the mouth: (K: [for daAxila Alfami, in the CK, I read daAxilu Alfm, as in the TA:]) or, as some say, the two parts whereof each is called niToEN, [app. meaning the anterior part of the palate and the corresponding
part next the lower gums,] in the HanakaAni [or the palate and the part corresponding to it below]. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlgaAraAni signifies The [sockets of the eyes; or] two bones in which are the eyes. (ISd, K.) ― -b4- And The belly and the pudendum: (S:) or the mouth and the pudendum. (K.) Hence the saying of a poet, yasoEaI ligaArayohi [He works, or earns, for his belly, or his mouth, and his pudendum]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also (gaArN) An army: (S, K:) or a numerous army. (TA.) You say AilotaqaI AlgaAraAni The two armies met. (S.) ― -b2- And A company, or body, of men: (TA:) or a numerous company or body of men. (ISd, K.) ＝ -A3- And I. q. gayorapN, (S,) or giyrapN. (K.) [See 1, last signification.] ＝ -A4- And A kind of tree, (S, Mgh, K,) of large size, (Mgh, K,) having leaves longer than those of the xilaAf, (Mgh, TA,) and a fruit [or berry] smaller than the hazel-nut, which is black, and which, being divested of its covering, discloses a heart that is employed in medicine [that is designed to produce a narcotic or an intoxicating effect: the berries are called HabRu AlgaAri]: its leaves have a sweet odour, (Mgh, TA,) and are employed in perfume: (TA:) its fruit is called [in Persian] dahomasot: (Mgh, TA:) and it has an oil, (K,) which is called duhonu AlgaAri: (S:) [it is the bay-tree; or female laurel-tree; the laurus nobilis; also called the sweet bay; of which there are several sorts, as the broad-leaved bay, the narrow-leaved bay, &c.: it is commonly supposed to be the laurus of the ancients:] n. un. with p. (TA.) ― -b2- And The leaves of the grapevine. (K.)

gaworN c
gaworN The bottom, or lowest part, of anything; (S, Msb, K;) as also gaworaI↓: (K:) and its depth. (TA.) ― -b2- You say, Earafotu gawora hecihi AlmasoOalapi (tropical:) [I have become acquainted with the bottom of this question]. (TA.) And fulaAnN baEiydu Algawori (S) (tropical:) Such a one is deep and excellent in judgment; one who examines deeply. (TA.) [See also 1.] And hawa baHorN laA yudoraku gaworuhu (tropical:) [He is a sea whereof the bottom shall not be reached]. (TA.) And mano OaboEadu gaworFA fiI AlbaATili minRiI (tropical:) [Who is deeper in knowledge with respect to what is vain, or false, than I?]. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- Low, or depressed, land, country, or ground; (S, Msb, K;) [like xaworN;] as also gaArN↓. (K.) ― -b4- See also gaArN, in the first of its senses expl. above. ＝ -A2- Applied to water, i. q. gaAYirN [Sinking, or going away, into the ground, or earth]: (S, K:) an inf. n. used as an epithet, like maMCN sakobN, and dirohamN DarobN. (S.)

giwarN c
giwarN A bloodwit; syn. diyapN: (K, TA:) a dial. var. of giyarN: (TA:) or the latter is a pl., of which the sing. is giyrapN. (AA, K in art. gyr, q. v.)

gaArapN c
gaArapN, a subst. from OagaAra; A going away into a country, or land. (TA.) ― -b2- A quick running, (Mgh, Msb,) or vehement running, (TA,) of a horse, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) and of a fox; (Mgh;) as also gawiyrN↓, of a fox. (TA.) ― -b3- [A raid; or an incursion into the territory of an enemy; or a sudden, or an unexpected, attack upon an enemy, or upon the territories or dwellings of an enemy, with a party of armed horsemen, and engagement with them in conflict; an urging of horses upon, or against, a people; generally, a hostile, or predatory, incursion: or the making such an incursion:] a subst. [or quasi-inf. n.] from OagaAra EalaI AlEaduwRi. (S, TA.) ― -b4- And Plunder, or pillage. (TA.) ― -b5- And hence, (Mgh, Msb,) [Horsemen making a raid, or a sudden, or an unexpected, attack, upon an enemy, or upon the dwellings of an enemy, and engaging with them in conflict: horsemen urging their horses upon, or against, a people:] i. q. xayolN mugiyrapN↓: (S, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and one says also xyl migiyrapN↓, with kesr. (TA.) You say XanRa Ealayohimu AlgaArapa i. e. He scattered, (S in art. Xn, and Mgh * and Msb, *) or poured, (K in art. Xn,) upon them [the horsemen making a raid, or sudden attack, and engaging in conflict, or the horsemen urging their horses]. (S, K.) The poet (El-Kumeyt Ibn-Maaroof, TA) says,
wanaHonu SabaHonaA Mla najoraAna gaArapF
tamiyma bona murRK waAlrRimaAHa AlnRawaAdisaA
[And we gave as a morning-drink to the people of Nejrán a troop of horsemen making a raid, or sudden attack, upon them, or urging their horses against them, namely the tribe of Temeem Ibn-Murr, and the piercing spears]: he means, saqayonaAhumo xayolFA mugiyrapF: and tmym bn mrR is put in the accus. case as a substitute for gArp. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- HabolN Xadiydu AlgaArapi means A rope twisted hard; or hard in respect of the twisting; (S, TA;) gaArapN being in this case [as in that first mentioned above] a subst. standing in stead of the inf. n. UigaArap: (TA:) and so HabolN mugaArN↓; (S, TA;) applied to a rope that is twisted with another. (TA voce misoHalN.) ＝ -A3- And AlgaArapu signifies The navel: (Sgh, K:) app. so called because of its depth. (Sgh, TA.)

Algaworapu c
Algaworapu The sun. (IAar, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also gaAYirapN.

giyrapN c
giyrapN Abundance of the produce of the earth: and rain: and i. q. miyrapN [a provision of corn, or wheat, &c.]: belonging to this art. and to art. gyr. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [See also 1, last signification.]

gaworaI c
gaworaI: see gaworN.

gawiyrN c
gawiyrN: see gaArapN, second sentence.

gaAYirapN c
gaAYirapN i. q. qaAYilapN [app. as syn. with qayoluwlapN, i. e. A sleeping in the middle of the day; though the primary signification of qaAYilapN is that which here next follows]; (S, O, K;) as also gaworapN↓. (O, K.) ― -b2- And The middle of the day [itself]. (K.) ― -b3- And one says, buniIa hecaA Albayotu EalaI gaAYirapi AlXRamosi, meaning (tropical:) [This house, or tent, was, or has been, built, or set up,] facing the place of sunrise. (TA.)

magaArN c
magaArN: see gaArN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A place of entrance: and a place where a thing is sought for: you say, UinRaka gurota fiI gayori magaArK Verily thou hast entered into that which is not a place of entrance: and verily thou hast sought in that which is not a place where a thing is sought for. (TA.)

mugaArN c
mugaArN: see gaArN. ＝ -A2- Also A place of a gaArap [or raid, or sudden attack upon an enemy, or upon the dwellings of an enemy, with a party of armed horsemen, &c.]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also gaArapN, last sentence but one. ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) A horse strong, or compact, in make; as though twisted: (Az, TA:) or a horse strong in the joints: (Lth, TA:) or, applied to a horse, i. q. muDamRarN [made lean, or light of flesh; &c.: see 2 in art. Eyr: and see also miEaArN in that art.]. (Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer, TA in art. Eyr.) And A horse that runs swiftly. (TA. [But in this last sense, the word should be, accord. to rule, as here next follows.])

mugiyrN c
mugiyrN A horse swift in running: [see also what next precedes:] and migowaArN↓ [likewise] signifies a swift horse: or this latter, accord. to Lh, vehement in running: and its pl. is magaAwiyru. (TA.) ― -b2- xayolu mugiyrapN and migiyrapN: see gaArapN.

mugawRirN c
mugawRirN: see 2.

magaArapN c
magaArapN and mugaArapN: see gaArN, first sentence.

migowaArN c
migowaArN: see mugiyrN. ― -b2- Also A fighting man; and so mugaAwirN↓: (S:) or the former signifies one who occupies himself much in gaAraAt [or raids, or sudden attacks upon enemies, or upon the dwellings of enemies, with armed horsemen, &c., pl. of gaArapN]; (K, TA;) as also mugaAwirN↓: (TA:) pl. magaAwiyru: (S:) and magaAwiru may be a contracted pl. of migowaArN or a pl. of mugaAwirN. (TA.)

mugaAwirN c
mugaAwirN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

1 gaASa fiI AlmaMCi c
1. gaASa fiI AlmaMCi, aor. yaguwSu, (S, A, Msb,) inf. n. gawoSN (S, A, K) and magaASN and giyaASapN and giyaASN, (K,) He dived in, or descended beneath, the water; (S, A, K;) or entered into the water; (TA;) to fetch out what was in it. (Msb [in my copy of which, the particle fI is omitted, app. by a slip of the transcriber].) ― -b2- giyaASapN [also] signifies The diving in the sea for pearls; (S;) and gawoSN signifies [the same: or both signify] the fetching out pearls from beneath the water. (Mgh.) ― -b3- [Hence,] you say also, gaASa EalaI AlOamori, (K,) inf. n. gawoSN, (TA,) (tropical:) [He dived for the thing, or affair, so as to elicit it; or] he knew the thing, or affair. (K, TA.) And gaASa EalaI AlmaEaAniI HatRaI balaga OaqoSaAhaA waQsotaxoraja maA baEuda minohaA wadaqRa fahomuhu (tropical:) [He dived for the meanings so that he reached the uttermost of them, and elicited what was remote of them, and the understanding whereof was subtile]. (Msb.) And fulaAnN yaguwSu EalaI HaqaAYiqi AlEilomi (tropical:) [Such a one dives for the verities of science].
(A, TA.) And maA OaHosana gawoSahu EalayohaA (tropical:) [How good is his diving for them!]. (A, TA.) And maA gaASa gawoSapF UilRaA Oaxoraja durRapF (tropical:) [He did not dive a single diving but he fetched out what was like a pearl, or a large pearl]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- You say also, gaASa EalaI AlXRaIoCi, aor. yaguwSu, inf. n. gawoSN, He pounced, or came suddenly, or at unawares, upon the thing. (Msb.)

2 gwRShu fiI AlmaMCi c
2. gwRShu fiI AlmaMCi He made him to dive in, or descend beneath, the water; (A;) he immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him therein. (TA.)

gawoSN c
gawoSN [originally an inf. n.]: see magaASN, in two places.

gawoSapN c
gawoSapN [A single diving in, or descent beneath, water: see 1, last sentence but one]. (A.)

gawRaASN c
gawRaASN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

gaAYiSN c
gaAYiSN One who dives in, or descends beneath, or enters into, water; as also gawRaASN↓ [which, however, has an intensive signification, or implies the habit of so doing]: (TA:) and ↓the latter, (S, A, K,) or both, (Az, TA,) particularly one who dives in the sea for pearls, (S, A, K,) or for pearl-shells, and fetches them out: (Az, TA:) pl. guwRaASN, (A, TA,) of the former, (TA,) and gaASapN, (A, TA,) [also of the former,] and [of the latter] gawRaASuwna. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] hawa mino SaAgapi Alfiqari wagaASapi AldRurari (tropical:) [He is of the moulders of fiqar, lit., as thus used, ornaments fashioned in the form of the vertebræ of the back, but here meaning choice phrases or sentences; and of the divers for, and producers of, (expressions like) pearls, or large pearls]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence likewise,] gawRaASN↓ also signifies (tropical:) One who exercises art, craft, cunning, or skill, in ordering the means of obtaining subsistence. (TA.) ― -b4- And gaAYiSN also signifies One who pounces, or comes suddenly, or at unawares, upon a thing; (JK, S, Msb;) as also, (JK, Msb,) but in an intensive sense, (Msb,) gawRaASN↓: (JK, Msb:) pl. of the former gaASapN. (Msb.)

magaASN c
magaASN A place where one dives in, or descends beneath, water; (Lth, A, K;) as also gawoSN↓: (Lth, Mgh:) or ↓the latter signifies particularly a place [where one dives and] whence pearls are fetched out. (JK, Mgh. *) You say also, hecaA magaASu AllRuWoluWi This is the diving-place for pearls. (A.) ― -b2- Also The upper part of the saAq [or shank, &c.]. (JK, Sgh, K.)

1 gaATa c
1. gaATa, aor. yaguwTu, (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. gawoTN, (S, Msb, K,) It entered, or sank, (S, Msb, K, TA,) into (fiI) a thing; (S, K, TA;) as, for instance, the foot into sand; (S, TA;) and a man into mud, (TA,) or into water; (Msb;) and into a valley; (TA, in this art. and in art. gyT; in the former expl. by Ainogamasa;) and gaATa, aor. yagiyTu, (S, TA,) inf. n. gayoTN, (K,) signifies the same: (S, K:) both also signify he, or it, became hidden, (As, and K in art. gyT,) in the ground. (As.) You say also, gaATato OanosaAEu AlnRaAqapi, aor. and inf. n. as above, The plaited thongs of the she-camel clave to her belly, and so entered, or sank, therein. (TA.) And gaATati AlOanosaAEu fiI dafRi AlnRaAqapi The plaited thongs caused their impressions to be visible in the side of the she-camel. (TA.) ― -b2- It (a place) sank, or became depressed, in the ground. (ISh.) And It (anything) descended, or sloped downwards, in the ground. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He dug, excavated, or hollowed out. (TA: and in some copies of the K, AlgawoTu is expl. by AlHaforu; but the reading given in the TA, in that instance, is AlHuforapu.) ＝ -A2- guTo guTo means Be thou with the jamaAEap [i. e. the mass, or main body], (IAar, O, K,) who are termed the gaAT, (O,) [be thou with them, not with the factious,] when fitan [i. e. factions, &c.,] come. (IAar, O, K.)

2 gwRT c
2. gwRT, inf. n. tagowiyTN, He gobbled [food]: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K: *) or gobbled largely, or in large mouthfuls: (K, * TA:) from gawoTN meaning variyd. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And tagowiyTN signifies also The making a well deep. (K. [See also 4.])

4 OagowaTa c
4. OagowaTa He made deep a well. (Fr, O, TA. [See also 2.])

5 tgwRT c
5. tgwRT (tropical:) He voided excrement, or ordure. (S, Msb, K, TA. [In the CK, AanodIe is put by mistake for AbdI.])

6 tagaAwaTaA fiI AlmaMCi c
6. tagaAwaTaA fiI AlmaMCi They two vied, or contended, each with the other, in plunging, or diving, in the water. (K, * TA.)

7 AngAT c
7. AngAT It (a branch, or twig, or the like,) bent. (O, K.)

gaATN c
gaATN: see gaAYiTN. ＝ -A2- AlgaATu signifies also AljamaAEapu [meaning The mass, or main body, of the people]. (O, K.) One says, maA fiI AlgaATi mivoluhu [There is not in the mass, or main body, of the people, the like of him]. (O, TA.)

gawoTN c
gawoTN A hollow, cavity, pit, or the like, dug, or excavated, in the ground; syn. HuforapN. (So in the K, accord. to the TA, on the authority of AA: but in some copies of the K, AlgawoTu in this instance is expl. by AlHaforu: see 1, last sentence.) See also gaAYiTu. ＝ -A2- And i. q. variydN [Crumbled bread moistened with broth]. (O: in the K variydap.)

gayoTN c
gayoTN: see gaAYiTN, latter half.

gawoTapN c
gawoTapN A [low, or depressed, place, or hollow, such as is called] wahodap, in the ground. (ISh, K.) [See also gaAYiTN.]

guwTapN c
guwTapN A place comprising water and herbage: whence guwTapu dimaXoqa, (Har pp. 130, et seq.,) i. e. the city, or district, of Damascus, (K,) which is a place abounding with water and trees. (S.)

biYorN gawiyTapN c
biYorN gawiyTapN A deep well. (TA.)

gaAYiTN c
gaAYiTN A wide, depressed piece of ground or land, (ISh, S, O, Msb, K,) but not much depressed, and in some instances having acclivities [bordering it]; (ISh;) sometimes, as they assert, a league (farosax) in extent, and having in it meadows; (AHn;) and gaATN↓ and gawoTN↓ signify the same; (O, K;) or the last is more depressed than the gAYT: (IDrd, O:) and gAYT is also applied to a valley: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] is OagowaATN, (S, Msb, K,) or this is pl. of gawoTN, (IB,) and [of mult.] giyTaAnN, (S, Msb, K,) which is pl. of both these sings., (IB,) and guwTN (S, Msb, K) and giyaATN. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) A place in which one satisfies a want of nature; the custom being to do so in a depressed place, where one is concealed. (S, * Msb, * TA.) In the Kur [iv. 46, or v. 9], accord. to an extraordinary reading, it is written gayoT↓, [a form now commonly used, and signifying a garden, but there meaning a privy place,] the original form of which may be gayowiT, and then gayRiT, [and then gayoT,] it being contracted; or, accord. to Abu-l- Hasan, the I may be originally w, these two letters being in this instance interchangeable. (IJ.) You say, OataI AlgaAYiTa, (S, TA,) and Daraba AlgaAYiTa, (TA,) (tropical:) He satisfied a want of nature; (S, TA;) voided excrement, or ordure. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (S, TA,) (tropical:) Human excrement, or ordure: (S, K, TA:) because they used to cast it away in a gAYT: or because they used to go thither to satisfy a want of nature. (TA.)

Q. Q. 2
Q. Q. 2: if belonging to this art., or R. Q. 2 if belonging to art. gw. tagaAgaI Ealayohi AlgawogaMCu [as though originally tagawogI] i. q. rakibuwhu [i. e. The mixed multitude, or the low, base, vile, &c., of men, bore, or pressed, or crowded, (as though mounting,) upon him]. (TA in art. gw.)

gaAgN c
gaAgN The Habaq [q. v.], (IDrd, K, TA,) a species of sweet-smelling plants, (TA,) i. e. the fuwcanoj, (IDrd, K, TA,) an arabicized word from [the Pers. Puwdiynaho: (TA:) [accord. to the TK, the plant called in Turkish yArPwz, which is marjoram:] gaAgapN↓ [the n. un.] is said by Lth to mean a certain plant resembling the haronawaI [a word of which both the orthography and the application are disputed]. (TA.)

gaAgapN c
gaAgapN: see what here precedes: ＝ -A2- and see also the paragraph here following.

gawogaMC c
gawogaMC [i. e. gawogaMCN and gawogaMCu, as will be shown by what follows; mentioned in this art. in the Msb and K; and in the S, and again in the K and TA, in art. gw;] masc. and fem., [being] perfectly and imperfectly decl., (S and TA in art. gw,) in the former case like qamoqaAmN, the C being substituted for ,, and in the latter case like EaworaMCu, (S,) Locusts after the growth of their wings, (AO, T, Msb, K,) i. e. (AO, T, Msb) after the state in which they are called dabFA or dabFI; (AO, T, S, Msb;) before which earlier state they are called sirowap [or rather
siaroC]: (A'Obeyd, T, Msb: [see also jaraAdN:] or locusts when they become light, or active, so as to fly; thus accord. to AO, and IAth says the like thereof: (TA:) or locusts when they have wings, and almost fly, before they raise themselves and fly; thus says As: (S:) or locusts, when they have become divested of the [changing] colours, and are becoming in a state of transition to redness. (As, K, TA.) ― -b2- And A sort of insects resembling baEuwD [or gnats], that do not bite, (AO, S, Msb, K,) nor hurt, (AO, S, Msb,) by reason of their weakness. (AO, S, K.) ― -b3- And, (S, Msb, K,) accord. to As, (S,) or AO, (Msb,) as being likened to the locusts thus termed, (S, Msb,) applied to men, (S, Msb, K,) meaning (tropical:) A mixed multitude of men; as also gaAgapN↓: (S and K in art. gw:) or the safilap [i. e. low, base, vile, ignoble, mean, or sordid; or lowest or lower, basest or baser, &c.;] of men; and such as haste to do evil: and it may be from the signification here following, because of the muchness of their clamour, or confused noise, and vociferation. (TA.) ― -b4- [Like gawogaA in Pers., and probably from this latter, if the converse be not the case,] it signifies also Clamour, and a confusion of cries or shouts or noises. (TA.)

1 gaAlahu c
1. gaAlahu, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor. yaguwluhu, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. gawolN, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) He, or it, [accord. to the TA said of a thing,] destroyed him; (Lth, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also AgtAlhu↓: (K:) and (K) it (a thing, S, O) took him, seized him, or took him away, unexpectedly, at unawares, or from an unknown quarter; (S, O, K;) and so AgtAlhu↓: (S: [see also an ex. of this latter voce xaruwjN:]) and accord. to IAar, gAl AlXRaIoCu zayodFA signifies The thing took away Zeyd. (TA.) One says, gaAlatohu guwlN↓ A [cause of] destruction destroyed him: (K, TA:) or [destroyed him so that it was not known whither he had gone away; for] it is said of one who has fallen into destruction (S, TA) and it is not known whither he has gone away: (TA:) and it also signifies Death or the decree of death [destroyed him, or took him away]. (TA.) One says also when persons have perished in a land, gaAlatohumo tiloka AlOaroDu [That land caused them, or has caused them, to perish in it]: and AlOaroDu bifulaAnK tagawRalati↓ means The land caused such a one to perish; and to pursue a course that led him astray. (TA.) And one says of a land (OaroD), taguwlu AlsRaAbilapa, meaning It casts away the travellers, or wayfarers; causes them to fall, or drop down; and removes them far away. (TA.) ― -b2- gaAlati Alxamoru fulaAnFA means (assumed tropical:) The wine that he had drunk deprived such a one of his reason: or, of the soundness of his body: (AHeyth, TA:) [or corrupted, or vitiated, him; for] gaAlahu, aor. yaguwluhu, signifies Oafosadahu; (Ksh and Bd in xxxvii. 46;) as well as Oaholakahu: (Ksh, ibid:) and a poet, cited by AO, says,
wamaA zaAlati AlkaOosu tagotaAlunaA
(assumed tropical:) [And the cup of wine caused not to deprive us of our reason]. (S, O.) ― -b3- taguwlu AlvRiyaAba fataqoSuru EanohaA is said of a tall woman [app. as meaning She exceeds the measure of the clothes, so that they are too short for her]: such a woman is said to be caAtu gawolK↓. (TA.) ― -b4- And one says, maA gaAlaka EanRaA i. e. What withheld, or debarred, or has withheld or debarred, thee from us? (O.) ― -b5- And gulotuhu, inf. n. giyaAlapN and giyaAlN and guWuwlN, signifies I stole it. (O and TA in art. gyl [though belonging to art. gwl].)

2 falaApN tugawRilu c
2. falaApN tugawRilu, inf. n. tagowiylN, [A desert, or water-less desert,] of which the roads, or ways, are unapparent, so that it causes the people thereof [who traverse it] to go astray. (TA.)

3 mugaAwalapN c
3. mugaAwalapN is syn. with mubaAdarapN [The hastening, making haste, or striving to be first or beforehand, in doing or attaining or obtaining a thing], (S, O, K, TA,) [or] in journeying, &c. (TA.) Jereer says, (S, O,) or El-Akhtal, (so in the TA,) mentioning a man upon whom horsemen had made a sudden attack, (S, TA,)
EaAyanotu muXoEilapa AlriEaAli kaOanRahaA
TayorN tugaAwilu fiI XamaAmK wukuwraA
[I saw those that were spreading themselves of the small parties of horsemen, as though they were birds hastening to nests in (the mountain of) Shemám]. (S, O, TA.) And it is related in a trad. of 'Ammár, that he was brief in prayer, and said, kunotu OugaAwilu HaAjapF liI [I was hastening to accomplish a want that I had]. (TA.) And in a trad. of Keys Ibn-'Ásim, [it is related that he said,] kunotu OugaAwiluhumo fiI AljaAhiliyRapi i. e. I used to strive to be beforehand with them (OubaAdiruhumo) in making a sudden attack or incursion, and in doing mischief, [in the Time of Ignorance:] or, as some relate it, it is with r [i. e. kunotu OugaAwiruhumo I used to make sudden attacks or incursions upon them]. (TA.)

5 tagawRulN c
5. tagawRulN is syn. with talawRunN [which primarily signifies The becoming altered in colour; but here, the varying in state or condition, or in form or appearance; or, agreeably with explanations of its verb by Esh-Shereeshee, (cited in Har p. 480,) the becoming altered in state or condition; and the becoming of various sorts or species]. (S, O, K.) One says, tgwRlt AlmaroOapu, meaning tlwRnt [The woman varied in state or condition, or in form or appearance, &c.]: (S, O, TA:) and in like manner tgwRlt is said of the guwl [q. v.]. (TA.) And The woman made herself to be like the guwl. (TA.) And tagawRulu AlfalaApi means The dubious, and varying, state or condition, of the desert, or waterless desert. (TA.) And one says also, tgwRl AlOamoru (tropical:) The affair, or case, became altered so as to be unknown; [for tanaAkara, in my original, I read tanakRara;] and became dubious, or confused. (TA.) ― -b2- And tgwRlt AlOaroDu bifulaAnK: see 1, former half. ― -b3- And tagawRalatohumu Alguwlu is said of them who have been made to deviate from, miss, or lose, the right way [by the guwl; i. e. it means The gwl made them to deviate &c.]. (TA.)

6 tagaAwaluwA c
6. tagaAwaluwA i. q. tabaAdaruwA i. e. They hastened together; vied, or strove, one with another, in hastening; made haste to be, or get, before one another; strove, one with another, to be first, or beforehand, (comp. 3:) expl. by Freytag as meaning “ sese invicem studuerunt capere. ”]

8 AgtAlhu c
8. AgtAlhu: see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- Also (S) He slew him (S, Mgh, O, Msb) covertly (S, * Mgh, O *) or on an occasion of inadvertence; (S, * O, * Msb;) syn. qatalahu giylapF↓. (S, Mgh, O.) ― -b3- See also 1, latter half. ― -b4- laA yagotaAluhu AlXRabaEu, said of a hawk, (S, O, TA,) &c., (TA,) signifies (tropical:) Satiety will not deprive him of his strength, (S, O, TA,) and his vehemence of flight: meaning that he will not become satiated: (TA:) [it is said that] it occurs in a verse of Zuheyr, [but I do not find it in his Deewán,] describing a hawk. (S, O, TA.) ― -b5- hecihi OaroDN tagotaAlu AlmaXoIa means (assumed tropical:) This is a land that renders unapparent in it the footing, or marching, [of travellers,] by reason of its far extent and its width: an ex. of the verb [in this sense] occurs in a verse of El-'Ajjáj cited voce niyaATN, in art. nwT. (S, O.) ＝ -A2- [And Freytag adds, in art. gyl, the two following significations: the former, or both, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees: He overtook him in running: (compare 3 and 6 in this art.:) ＝ -A3- and He filled it so that the space became too contracted to take, or hold.]

gawolN c
gawolN Far extent of a desert, or waterless desert; (S, O, TA;) because it destroys him who passes along in it: (S, TA:) or of a land; because it casts away the travellers, or wayfarers, causes them to fall, or drop down, and removes them far away: and accord. to Lh, it is said of a land when one journeys in it without stopping. (TA.) One says, maA OaboEada gawola hecihi AlOaroDi How far is the extent of this land! and UinRahaA labaEiydapu Algawoli [Verily it is far in extent]. (ISh, TA.) And OaroDN caAtu gawolK A land far extending, though in the view of the eye of little extent: (IKh, TA:) and gayRilN applied to land is said to have the same meaning. (TA in art. gyl.) And OagowaAlu AlOaroDi [in which AgwAl is app. pl. of gawolN] signifies The extremities of the land. (TA.) ― -b2- AimoraOapN caAtu gawolK A tall woman. (TA.) See 1, last sentence but two. [And see also gayRilapN, voce gayRilN, in art. gyl.] ― -b3- [nAqp gwl AlnjMC is a phrase mentioned without any indication of the meaning in the TA: perhaps naAqapu gawoli AlnRajaMCi, and signifying A she-camel of an exceeding degree of swiftness.] ＝ -A2- In the saying in the Kur [xxxvii. 46], laA fiyhaA gawolN, [referring to the wine of Paradise,] it means The evil result of headache; because it is said in another place, [lvi. 19,] laA yuSadRaEuwna EanohaA: (S, O, TA:) or it [there] means [simply] headache: or intoxication: (K, TA:) thus some expl. it as used in that instance: (TA:) or, as expl. by AO, it there means privation of the intellectual faculties.
(S, O, TA.) ― -b2- See also guwlN, latter half. ― -b3- Also Distress, trouble, or molestation: (K, TA:) thus expl. by some as used in the Kur ubi suprà. (TA.) ― -b4- And Unfaithfulness; or unfaithful acting. (TA.) ― -b5- OataI gawolFA gaAYilapF↓ means He did a cunning, bad, action. (K.) ＝ -A3- Also Much earth. (S, O, K.) Hence the phrase gawolFA mina AlrRamoli, [app. meaning A large quantity of sand,] in a verse of Lebeed. (S, O.) ― -b2- And A collection of [the trees called] TaloH, (K, TA,) with which nothing participates. (TA.) ― -b3- And A low, or depressed, part of the earth, or of land. (K.)

guwlN c
guwlN A kind of [goblin,] demon, devil, or jinnee, which, the Arabs assert, appears to men in the desert, assuming various forms, causing them to wander from the way, and destroying them; (JM, and TA * on the authority of IAth;) but this the Prophet denied, saying, laA guwla; by which, however, accord. to some, he did not mean to deny the existence of the gwl, but only the assertion of the Arabs respecting its assuming various forms and its being able to cause any one to go astray: (IAth, JM, * TA:) i. q. siEolaApN [q. v.]: or a sort of siEolaAp: (S, O, Msb:) or a male jinnee; the female being called siEolaAp: (Abu-l-Wefee ElAarábee, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OagowaAlN and [of mult.] giylaAnN (S, O, Msb, K) and giwalapN: (O, TA:) and it signifies also an enchantress of the jinn: (K:) and a demon, or devil, that eats men: (En-Nadr, O, K:) or any jinnee, or devil, or animal of prey, that destroys a man: (TA:) or a certain beast, (K, TA,) terrible [in appearance], having tusks, or fangs, (TA,) seen by the Arabs, and known by them; and killed by Taäbbata Sharrà: (K, TA:) and such as varies in form or appearance, of the enchanters and of the jinn; (K, TA;) on his doing which, as is said in a trad., one should hastily utter the call to prayer, to prevent his mischief by the mention of God: (TA:) or anything by reason of which the intellect departs; as also gawolN↓: (K:) and anything that takes a man unexpectedly and destroys him: (S, O, Msb:) [whence] one says, AlgaDabu guwlu AlHilomi Anger [is that which] destroys, and does away with, forbearance, or clemency. (S, O.) ― -b2- Also Destruction: [or a cause thereof:] and death; or the decree of death. (K.) See 1, second sentence. ― -b3- And A calamity, or misfortune; (K, TA;) as also gaAYilapN↓; (TA;) of which latter the pl. in this sense is gawaAYilu; (K, * TA;) thus mentioned by Ks. (Msb.) ― -b4- And A serpent: pl. OagowaAlN: (K:) accord. to Az, the Arabs call serpents OagowaAl; and thus this word is said to mean in the verse of Imra-el-Keys,
liyaqotulaniI waAlmaXorafiIRu muDaAjiEiI
wamasonuwnapN zuroqN kaOanoyaAbi OagowaAli
[To slay me, while the Meshrefee sword was my bedfellow, and so were sharpened, polished arrowheads, like the fangs of serpents]: (O, TA: *) but AHát says that this is meant as an exaggeration: (TA:) and it is said that the poet here means devils. (O, TA.)

giylapN c
giylapN The slaying covertly, (Mgh,) or on an occasion of inadvertence; a subst. from AigotaAlahu: (Msb:) originally with w [i. e. giwolapN]. (S.) See 8: and see also art. gyl.

gawolaAnN c
gawolaAnN A plant of the [kind called] HamoD, (A'Obeyd, AHn, S, O, K,) like the OuXonaAn [i. e. kali, or glasswort], (K,) or, accord. to AHn, resembling the EunoZuwaAn [which is described as a plant of the HamoD, or, as some say, the best of the OuXonaAn], except that it is more slender; and it is a pasture. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also sing. of gawaAliynu, which signifies [The ribs of a ship or boat, i. e.] the things that resemble the DuluwE in a ship or boat. (AA, O, TA.)

gaAYilN c
gaAYilN [act. part. n. of 1]. ― -b2- [Hence,] OaroDN gaAYilapu AlnRiTaMCi A land that destroys its inhabitant by reason of its far extent. (TA.) ― -b3- And gaAYilapN [as an epithet applied to a fem. n.] signifies Caused to become absent, or to disappear; hidden, or concealed: or stolen. (ISh, TA.)

gaAYilapN c
gaAYilapN [as a subst.] Bad, or corrupt, conduct; and evil, or mischief. (Msb.) See also gawolN, last quarter. [And see art. gyl.] ― -b2- And [particularly] Wickedness, or disobedience, of a slave; and his running away; (Mgh in art. Edw, and Msb;) and the like thereof: pl. gawaAYilu. (Msb.) ― -b3- And [hence, perhaps, (as denoting a cause for reclaiming the price of a slave,) it is said that] it signifies A right which another than the seller has to the possession of a slave, whereby the sale is annulled, and the seller is obliged to return the price to the purchaser. (TA. voce xibovapN.) ― -b4- See also guwlN, latter half. ― -b5- [Its pl.] gawaAYilu also signifies Places of destruction. (TA.) ― -b6- And you say, OaxaAfu gaAYilatahu, meaning I fear the result, and the evil, or mischief, thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A hole, or perforation, of a watering-trough, or tank, (IAar, O, K, * TA,) that causes the water to pass away: (TA:) pl. gawaAYilu. (IAar, O, TA.)

EayoXN guwRalN c
EayoXN guwRalN: see Oagowalu.

OaroDN gayRilapN c
OaroDN gayRilapN A land far extending. (Lh, TA.) [Mentioned also in art. gyl.]

Oagowalu c
Oagowalu [More, and most, destructive]. One says, OayRapu guwlK Oagowalu mina AlgaDabi [What destroyer is more destructive than anger?]. (S, O: immediately following the explanation of the saying, AlgaDabu guwlu AlHilomi.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] EayoXN Oagowalu A soft, or plentiful and easy, life; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) as also guwRalN↓. (K.)

migowalN c
migowalN [primarily] An instrument with which a thing is destroyed. (Ham p. 648.) ― -b2- And [hence] used as meaning A knife: and in common acceptation, a knife that is put in the midst of a whip which is as a sheath to it: (Ham ibid.:) a knife to which a whip is a sheath: (Mgh:) or a slender sword, having a flat back (lahu qafFA), (S, O, Msb,) like the knife, (Msb,) the sheath of which is like the whip: (S, O:) or an iron [weapon] that is put within a whip, which thus becomes to it a sheath: (K:) or a whip in the interior of which is a sword: (A'Obeyd, TA:) said to be thus called because its owner destroys with it his enemy unexpectedly: pl. magaAwilu: (TA:) and a thing like a miXomal [or short and slender sword over which a man covers himself with his garment], except that it is more slender, and longer: (K:) and a long naSol [or blade], (AHn, K, TA,) of little breadth, thick in the maton [which generally means the part in the middle of which is the ridge, but may here mean the back]: (AHn, TA:) or a short sword which a man wears inwrapped beneath his clothes: (TA:) or a slender sword, having a flat back (lahu qafFA): (K:) or a slender iron [weapon], having a sharp edge and a flat back (waqafFA), which the assassin binds upon his waist in order that he may therewith destroy men. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] farasN caAtu migowalK (tropical:) A mare having a quality, or faculty, of outstripping: (O, K, TA:) as though she destroyed the [other] horses so that they fell short of reaching her. (TA.)

nazaluwA mugaAwiliyna c
nazaluwA mugaAwiliyna, occurring in a trad. respecting the lie [that was uttered against 'Áïsheh, to which allusion is made in the Kur xxiv. 11], means They alighted [after] going far in the journeying. (TA.)

1 gaIVIa
1: see what next follows.

2 gayRayotu gaAyapF c
2. gayRayotu gaAyapF, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. tagoyiyapN; (TA;) [in the CK gayayotuhaA↓, which is wrong, unless they said thus as well as gayRayotuhaA, like as they say rayayotu raAyapF as well as rayRayotuhaA;] and OagoyayotuhaA↓; (S, K, TA; but in the last as not found in the K;) I set up the banner, or standard; (S, K, TA;) from A'Obeyd. (S.) ― -b2- And gayRaI liloqawomi He set up a banner, or standard, for the people, or party: or he made it for them. (TA.) ― -b3- And gayRati AlTRayoru The birds flapped their wings, or fluttered, in the air, without moving from their place; or did thus around a thing, desiring to alight upon it; syn. raforafato. (TA.) [See also 6.] ＝ -A2- gayRayotu gaAyapF signifies [also] bayRanotuhaA [i. e. I made apparent, or manifest, or known, an utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, or the like; or I set it]. (Msb.)

entry.key: gaAyaA Alqawomu fawoqa raOosi fulaAnK biAlsRayofi

superEntry.entry:
3 gaAyaA Alqawomu fawoqa raOosi fulaAnK biAlsRayofi c
3. gaAyaA Alqawomu fawoqa raOosi fulaAnK biAlsRayofi [The people, or party, acted with the sword above the head of such a one] as though they shadowed him with it; [i. e., flourished it above his head;] from As; (S, K; *) inf. n. mugaAyaApN. (TA.)

4 OagoIaIa
4: see 2. ― -b2- OagoyaA AlsaHaAbu The clouds were, or became, stationary, (K, TA,) Ealayohi upon, or over, him, or it; shadowing him, or it. (TA.) ― -b3- AgyA AlrRajulu The man attained the utmost limit, or reach, in eminence, or nobility, and in command: and in like manner, Alfarasu fiI sibaAqihi [the horse in his contending in a race]. (IKtt, TA.)

6 tagaAyati AlTRayoru EalaI AlXRaIoCi c
6. tagaAyati AlTRayoru EalaI AlXRaIoCi The birds hovered, or circled, round about the thing. (TA.) [See also 2.] ＝ -A2- tagaAyawoA Ealayohi HatRaI qataluwhu signifies the same as tagaAwawoA. (TA.) [See the latter, in art. gw or gwI.]

gaIRN c
gaIRN: see art. gw or gwI.

gayRapN c
gayRapN and giyRapN: see art. gw or gwI.

gayRaAnu c
gayRaAnu: see art. gw or gwI.

gaAIN c
gaAIN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

gaAyapN c
gaAyapN, originally gyyp [i. e. gayayapN], (TA,) The utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, point, or reach; or the extremity; of a thing; (MA, KL, PS;) in respect of time and of place; (MA, PS;) syn. madFI, (S, Msb, K, TA,) and munotahFI: (M, TA:) pl. gaAIN↓, (S, Msb, K, *) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [the pl. properly so termed is] gaAyaAtN. (Msb.) [Hence, A goal to which racers run; as is indicated in the TA. And A scope; an object to be reached or accomplished, or that one has in view. And The ultimate object or intent of an action or a saying. And The ultimate import of a word: thus in the phrase, yuTolaqu biQEotibaAri gaAyatihi It is used with regard, or respect, to its ultimate import: opposed in this sense to mabodaON. And The utmost degree, maximum, climax, or acme, that is, or may be, attained.] And The utmost of one's power or ability, i. e., of one's deed: thus in the saying, gaAyatuka Oano tafoEala kacaA [The utmost of thy power or ability, or of thy deed, is, or will be, thy doing such a thing]. (Msb.) [And A person or thing, and persons or things, superlative, or consummate, in eminence or baseness, in goodness or evilness; that has, or have, attained the utmost degree therein. And, applied to a medicine, &c., Possessing the utmost efficacy, or efficiency, likacaA for such a thing.] ― -b2- [Also, like madFI, A space that is, or that is to be, traversed; or an extent, or the space between two points or limits: whence AibotidaMCu gaAyapK, and AinotihaMCu gaAyapK, The beginning, and the end, of a space between two points or limits.] ― -b3- And i. q. galowapN, meaning [A bow-shot; or] a shot of an arrow to the utmost possible distance. (Msb in art. glw.) ＝ -A2- Also A banner, or standard: (S, Msb, K:) pl. gaAyaAtN (Msb, TA) and [coll. gen. n.] gaAIN↓. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And A banner (raAyap) which the vintner used to raise [or set up] in order that he might be known to be a seller of wine. (TA.) [See an ex. voce EuqaAbN.] ― -b3- And A cloud that is alone; apart from others: or that is falling, or alighting. (TA.) ― -b4- And Birds flapping their wings, or fluttering, in the air, without moving from their place; or doing thus around a thing, desiring to alight upon it. (TA. [See 2.]) ― -b5- And The qSbp [app. qaSabap, generally meaning reed, or cane, but what is meant by it here I know not,] with which small birds (EaSaAfiyz) are taken, or caught, or sought to be taken or caught. (TA.)

gaAYiIRN c
gaAYiIRN [the rel. n. gaAyapN]. AlEilRapu AlgaAYiyRapu, with the scholastic theologians, means The final cause. (TA.)

gayaAyapN c
gayaAyapN The light of the rays of the sun; (S, K;) not the rays themselves: (S:) or, as some say, the shade of the sun [i. e. the shade that is cast by the sun] in the morning and in the evening: (TA:) pl. gayaAyaAtN. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And Anything that shades a man, over his head, such as a cloud, (AA, S, K,) and dust, and darkness, and the like. (AA, S.) ― -b3- And The bottom of a well; (S, K;) like gayaAbapN. (S.)

gayaAyaMCu c
gayaAyaMCu A man heavy in spirit; as though he were a dark, dense shadow, in which is no brightness. (TA.)

AlmugayRaA c
AlmugayRaA That to which a limit is set, or put: so in the saying, AlgaAyapu laA tadoxulu fiI AlmugayRaA [The limit shall not enter into, or be included in, that to which the limit is set]. (Mgh.) [And,] as used by the lawyers and the scholastic theologians, The end of the gaAyap [or space between two points or limits]: a post-classical term. (TA.)

1 gaAba c
1. gaAba, (S, O, Mgh, Msb, TA,) aor. yagiybu, (Msb,) inf. n. gayobapN [the most common form] (S, O, Mgh, Msb, K) and gayobN (S, O, Msb, K) and gayaAbN, (S, O,) or giyaAbN, (Msb, K,) and guyuwbN (S, O, Msb, K) and guyuwbapN (O, K) and gayobuwbapN, (O, K,) accord. to some of the measure faEoluwlapN, but accord. to others of the measure fayoEaluwlapN i. e. originally gayRabuwbapN, (MF,) and magiybN (S, O, Msb, K) and magaAbN; (K;) and tgyRb↓; (Msb, K;) He, or it, was, or became, absent; gaAba being the contr. of HaDara; (S and K in art. HDr;) or distant, or remote; (Mgh;) or hidden, concealed, or unapparent; (TA;) [or absent from the range, or beyond the reach, of perception by sense, or of mental perception: see gayobN.] You say, gAb Eanohu, inf. n. gayobapN (S, Mgh, TA) &c., as above, (S, TA,) He, or it, was, or became, [absent from him; or] distant, or remote, from him; (Mgh;) or hidden, or concealed, from him; [&c.;] as also tgyRb↓. (TA.) And OawoHaXatoniI gayobapu fulaAnK [The absence of such a one has made me to feel lonely]: and OaTalota gayobataka [Thou hast made thine absence to be long]. (A.) And OanaA maEakumo laA OugaAyibukumo↓ [I am with you: I will not be absent from you]. (A.) And banuw OaHoyaAnFA fulaAnK yaXohaduwna OaHoyaAnFA wayatagaAyabuwna↓ (ISk, S, TA) i. e. [The sons of such a one are present sometimes] and are absent (yagiybuwna) sometimes: but one does not say yatagayRabuwna↓ [unless with Eano following it]: (TA:) [it seems, however, that ytgyRbwn, here, is a mistranscription for yatagayRabuwnanaA or the like; for] one says, EanRiI fulaAnN tgyRb↓ [Such a one was, or became, absent from me; or absented himself from me]; (S, K, * TA;) and tagayRabaniI↓ also in a case of necessity in verse, (S, K, TA,) but not in any other case, (K, TA,) accord. to the generality of authorities except the Koofees: (TA:) Imra-el-Keys says,
faZalRa lanaA yawomN laciycN binaEomapK
faqulo fiI maqiylK naHosuhu mutagayRibiI
[thus in my copies of the S and in the TA; but we should read mutagayRibi, whether it mean mutagayRibiI or not, as is shown by what follows: the verse may be rendered, So a delightful day, with ease and comfort, betided us: and say thou, of a place of midday-sleep whereof the ill luck was absent from me,...]: but Fr says that the word mtgyRb is marfooa, [i. e. that the right reading is mutagayRibu, meaning simply absent,] that the verse is mukofaO [or made faulty in the termination], and that it is not allowable to make that word refer to maqiylK, like as it is not allowable to say mararotu birajulK Oabuwhu qaAYimK. (S, TA. [One might be tempted to suppose that we should read faqilo; but this would not suit the context, which see in Ahlwardt's “ Divans of the six ancient Arabic poets, ” p. 119.]) ― -b2- [gAb, inf. n. gayobapN, is also said of the mind (Alqalob), meaning (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, absent. The inf. n. (gayobapN) is often used as meaning (assumed tropical:) Absence of mind; and particularly, from self and others by its being exclusively occupied by the contemplation of divine things: see an ex. voce XawFI; and another voce sakiynapN.] ― -b3- maA gaAba Eanohu Qbonu OabiI quHaAfapa (assumed tropical:) [Ibn-Abee-Koháfeh was not a stranger to it, i. e. was not unacquainted with it,] occurs in a trad. respecting a satirical saying of Hassán against [the tribe of] Kureysh; meaning that Aboo-Bekr [the son of Aboo-Koháfeh] was skilled in genealogies and traditions, and that it was he who instructed Hassán. (TA.) ― -b4- And one says also, gAb AlrRajulu, inf. n. gayobN and magiybN; and tgyRb↓; The man journeyed; and went away, or far away. (TA.) ― -b5- And gAbt AlXRamosu, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) inf. n. giyaAbN and gayobuwbapN (Mgh, Msb, TA) and gayobapN (Mgh) and guyuwbN and guyuwbapN and magiybN; (TA;) and tgyRbt↓; (Msb;) The sun set: (S, Msb, TA:) and the like is also said of the moon, (Msb,) and of other celestial bodies. (TA.) ― -b6- And gAb AlXRaIoCu fiI AlXRaIoCi, inf. n. giyaAbapN and guyuwbapN and giyaAbN and gayaAbN and giybapN, [The thing became hidden, or concealed, in the thing.] (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 8, in two places.

2 gyRbhu c
2. gyRbhu (S, Msb, TA) He caused him, or it, to become absent, or to disappear; or he hid, or concealed, it, Eanohu from him. (TA.) See also gayaAbN. ― -b2- And see 8.

3 mugaAyabapN c
3. mugaAyabapN signifies The being absent, &c., one from the other. (KL.) See also 1, former half. ― -b2- Also The addressing words to another [in his absence,] not in his presence, not face to face; (KL;) contr. of muxaATabapN. (S, TA.) [You say, AgAbt, inf. n. as above, He held a verbal communication with him in his absence, i. e. by means of a letter or letters, or by a messenger or messengers.]

4 AgAbt c
4. AgAbt She (a woman) had her husband, (S,
Msb, TA,) or one of her family, (TA,) absent from her. (S, Msb, TA.)

5 tagayRaba
5: see 1, in seven places. ― -b2- The inf. n. tagayRubN occurring in a trad. respecting the contract for the sale of a slave means The selling a stray slave, or one who has been found and whose owner is not known. (L, TA.)

6 tagaAoyaba
6: see 1, former half.

8 AgtAbhu c
8. AgtAbhu [He spoke evil of him; or did so in his absence, i. e. backbit him; (the latter being obviously the primary signification;) not always, though generally, meaning with truth:] he spoke evil of him in his absence; (TA;) or said of him, in his absence, what would grieve him (S, TA) if he heard it; (S;) with truth: (S, TA:) he carped at him behind the back, or in absence, by saying what would grieve him, (bimaA tanaAwalahu biZahori Algayobi↓ yasuwWuhu,) of what was [reprehensible] in him: (TA:) or he spoke of him imputing to him what he disliked, of vices, or faults, with truth: (Msb:) when the charge is false, it is termed buhotaAnN: (S, Msb, TA:) or he attributed, or imputed, to him a vice, or fault, or the like; and mentioned him with what was in him of evil; (K, TA;) or said of him what would grieve him: (TA:) and gaAbahu↓ signifies the same: (K, TA:) [so does gyRbhu↓: (see Ksh in civ. 1:) that AgtAbhu does not always signify he spoke evil of him, or the like, in his absence, appears from several instances, such as the phrases AlmugotaAbu fiI Alwajohi (K in art. lmz) and AlmugotaAbuwna biAlHaDorapi (IAar, TA in that art.): nor does it always signify he spoke evil of him, or the like, with truth; for the verb is used in the Ksh and by Bd and Jel in civ. 1 having for its object the Prophet:] IAar says that gAb↓ is syn. with AgtAb, and signifies he mentioned a man with the imputation of good or of evil. (TA.) [It may also mean He expressed, or signified, an evil opinion of him by making signs with the side of the mouth, or with the eye, or with the head, or otherwise; as is indicated in the TA in arts. lmz and hmz.]

gaAbN c
gaAbN: see gaAbapN, in three places.

gayobN c
gayobN Whatever is absent, or hidden, from one; (S, A, Msb, K, TA;) as though it were an inf. n. used in the sense of the act. part. n. [in which the meaning of a subst. is predominant]; (TA;) and so gaAYibN↓, which [in this sense] is a subst., like kaAhilN, (K, TA,) or an act. part. n. used in the sense of a subst.: (MF:) anything that is absent, or hidden, from the eyes; invisible, unseen, or unapparent; whether it be, or be not, perceived in the heart, or mind: (IAar, TA:) [or anything unperceivable; absent from the range, or beyond the reach, of perception by sense, or of mental perception; or undiscoverable unless by means of divine revelation; a mystery, or secret, such as an event of futurity;] a thing that has been hidden from men, and with which the Prophet has acquainted them, of the events of the resurrection and of Paradise and of Hell &c.; thus in the Kur ii. 2; (Zj, TA;) and [hence] Zj explains Algayob as meaning, in the Kur lxxxi. 24, that which has been revealed: (TA in art. Dn:) pl. guyuwbN. (Msb.) [See also the Ksh and Bd in ii. 2.] [Hence, EaAlamu Algayobi The world of the unseen; the invisible world.] And [hence also] one says, rajama biAlgayobi [and qacafa biAlgayobi (see art. qcf)] He spoke of that which he did not know: (Ham p. 494:) and qaAla rajomFA biAlgayobi He said conjecturally, [or speaking of that which was hidden from him or unknown by him,] without evidence, and without proof. (Msb in art. rjm, q. v.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Doubt, or a doubting: (K:) but some disapprove this: some regard it as tropical: and some pronounce it correct: (MF, TA:) pl. giyaAbN and guyuwbN. (K.) A poet says,
