Oanota nabiIRN taEolamu AlgiyaAbaA
laA qaAYilFA UifokFA walaA murotaAbaA
[Thou art a prophet, knowing doubts, or things doubted; not saying a lie, nor a thing suspected: or, more probably, the meaning is, the things unseen]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A place, in the ground, that hides, or conceals, one: (TA:) a low, or depressed, place in the ground, or in a tract of land: (S, K, TA:) or any place such that one knows not what is in it: and a place such that one knows not what is behind it: (Sh, TA:) pl. guyuwbN. (TA.) Hence the phrase Eano Zahori gayobK in a verse of Lebeed cited voce ZahorN, q. v. (TA.) [Hence also] one says, samiEotu SawotFA mino waraMCi Algayobi i. e. [I heard a sound, or voice,] from [behind] a place that I saw not. (A, TA.) And tanaAwalahu biZahori Algayobi bimaA yasuwWuhu: see 8. And takalRama bihi Eano Zahori gayobK (A) or Eano Zahori Algayobi (TA, and A and O in art. Zhr) [app. He spoke of it by memory; in the absence of a book or the like; as one says in modern Arabic, EalaI AlgaAYib. See also ZahorN.] ― -b4- Also The xamoSap [i. e. pit, or depression, as is shown by what here follows, (thus in the A, and in the Ksh in ii. 2, in the TA Huforap, which has a similar meaning,)] that is in the place where the kidney is situate, (Ksh, A, TA,) and which swells up when the beast becomes big in the belly: so says ISh: (Ksh ubi suprà:) or the xamoSap that is next to the kidney: (Bd in ii. 2: [De Sacy doubted respecting its meaning, but conjectured that it might be thus: see his Anthol. Gramm. Arabe p. 55:]) pl. guyuwbN: one says, Xaribati AldRaAbRapu HatRaI waArato guyuwba kulaAhaA, (ISh, Ksh ubi suprà, A, TA,) meaning huzuwmahaA [i. e. The beast drank until it concealed the pits of its kidneys]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- And Fat: (K, TA:) i. e. the fat of the varob [q. v.] of a sheep or goat: so called because it is hidden from the eye. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also gaAYibN.

gayabN c
gayabN: see gaAYibN, in two places.

gaAbapN c
gaAbapN is originally [gayabapN] of the measure faEalapN, with fet-h to the E. (Msb.) It signifies A low, or depressed, place, or a hollow in the ground, (El-Hawázinee, K, TA,) before which, or in the way to which, (duwnahaA,) is an eminence. (El-Hawá- zinee, TA.) ― -b2- And (K) i. q. OajamapN: (S, K, TA:) [i. e.] A bed of canes or reeds: (AHn, Msb, TA:) and [a thicket, wood, or forest; like OajamapN;] a collection of trees, (AHn, ISd, TA,) densely disposed; so called because it conceals what is in it: (ISd, TA:) or a tall Oajamap, having high, or very high, extremities [app. to its canes or reeds]: (TA:) pl. gaAbaAtN (Msb, TA) and [coll. gen. n.] gaAbN↓. (S, Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A long spear (K, TA) that has extremities like those of the Oajamap [expl. above]: (TA:) [but I think that this addition in the TA correctly applies to gaAbapN signifying a number of spears, like a bed of canes or reeds, or like a forest; agreeably with two of the explanations here following:] or a spear that quivers in the wind: (K, TA:) or (tropical:) numerous spears, like abundant and dense trees: (A:) or an assemblage of spears; app. so called as being likened to a gAbp meaning an Oajamap of dense trees: (ISd, TA:) pl. gaAbaAt and [coll. gen. n.] gaAbN↓. (TA.) One says, OatawonaA fiI gaAbapK i. e. (tropical:) [They came to us] amid numerous spears, like abundant and dense trees: (A:) or gAbp may be used in this case in the sense here following. (TA.) ― -b4- And A company, or congregated body, of men: (Aboo-Jábir ElAsadee, K, TA:) pl. gaAbaAtN and [coll. gen. n.] gaAbN↓. (TA.)

gayobapN c
gayobapN an inf. n. [See 1, in several places.] ― -b2- Also, and gayaAbapN↓, A low, or depressed, piece of land or ground: so in the phrases waqaEonaA fiI gayobapK and gayaAbapK [app. meaning We lighted upon a low, or depressed, piece &c.; or perhaps the meaning may be we fell into &c.]. (S.) ― -b3- See also gayaAbapN.

giybapN c
giybapN the subst. from AigotaAbahu: (Msb:) it signifies [Evil speech respecting a person; or such speech in his absence; not always, though generally, meaning with truth:] evil speech respecting a person in his absence; (TA;) or a saying of him, in his absence, what would grieve him (S, TA) if he heard it; (S;) with truth: (S, TA:) or speech respecting a person imputing to him what he dislikes, of vices, or faults, with truth: (Msb:) when it is false, it is termed buhotaAnN: (S, Msb, TA:) or an imputing to a person a vice, or fault, or the like; and a mentioning him with what is in him of evil; (K, TA;) or a saying of him what would grieve him: (TA:) or it may be speech imputing good or evil. (K, * TA.)

gayibaAnN c
gayibaAnN or gayobaAnN, [accord. to different copies of the K, between which the TA does not enable us to decide with certainty, as it only states, with respect to the I, that it is muxafRafap, which may mean either the contr. of doubled or the contr. of movent, though the former is the more general meaning, (in the TA it is said to be erroneously written in a copy of the K with a final t instead of n,)] and gayRibaAnN↓, The roots of trees, (K, TA,) that are hidden from view: or, accord. to AHn, the gybAn and gyRbAn↓ and gayaAbap↓, of plants, or herbage, are, with the Arabs, what the sun has not shone upon: and accord. to Aboo-Ziyád ElKilábee, the gybAn and gyRbAn↓ of plants, or herbage, and also of their roots, are what is con-
cealed from the sun, so as to be not shone upon by it. (L, TA.)

gayRibaAnN c
gayRibaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

gayaAbN c
gayaAbN A thing that hides, or conceals, a thing from one: (Meyd:) and hence, (Meyd, TA,) a grave; (S, Meyd, TA;) and so gayaAbapN↓: (TA:) one says, gayaAbuhu gayRabahu↓ (S, Meyd, TA) and gayaAbatuhu↓ (TA) meaning dufina fiI qaborihi (S, Meyd, TA) [i. e. May he be buried in his grave]: an imprecation of death against the man. (Meyd.)

gayaAbapN c
gayaAbapN The part of anything that veils, or conceals, one. (K.) And hence, (K,) The bottom of a jubR [or well]; (S, K, * TA;) or this, accord. to some, is the primary signification; as also gayobapN↓, accord. to one reading, in the Kur xii. 10; (TA;) [and gayaAyapN;] and of a valley; (S, TA;) &c.: (TA:) pl. gayaAbaAtN. (K, TA.) [And A covert, or place of concealment, of birds. (See ZilaAlapN.)] See also gayaAbN, in two places: and gayobapN. ― -b2- And see gayibaAnN.

gaAYibN c
gaAYibN act. part. n. of 1 [signifying Absent; distant, or remote; and hidden, concealed, or unapparent; or absent from the range, or beyond the reach, of perception by sense, or of mental perception]: pl. (applied to men, K, TA) guyRabN and guyRaAbN (S, Msb, K) and gaAYibuwna (K) and gayabN↓, (S, Mgh, K,) or rather the last is a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) and gayobN↓, [which is also properly speaking a quasi-pl. n.,] like SaHobN: (Msb [in which gayabN is not mentioned]:) the I in gayabN↓ remains unchanged, notwithstanding the two fet-hahs, because it is likened to SayadN, and, although it is a pl. [in signification] and SayadN is an inf. n., it may be used as meant for an inf. n. (S, TA.) ― -b2- See also gayobN, first sentence. ― -b3- Also A run in which a horse reserves [somewhat of his force for the time of need]. (A in art. Xhd: see XaAhidN.)

magiybN c
magiybN [an inf. n.: ― -b2- and also a n. of place and of time, signifying] The place [and the time] of setting of the sun and of the moon [&c.]. (Msb.)

mugiybN c
mugiybN and mugiybapN, (Mgh, Msb, K,) or you say mugiybapN [only], with p, and [in the contr. sense] muXohidN, without p, (IDrd, S,) and mugoyibN (K) and mugayRibN↓, (TA,) A woman having her husband (or one of her family, TA) absent from her. (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA.)

mugayRbN c
mugayRbN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 gaAva QllRehu AlbilaAda c
1. gaAva QllRehu AlbilaAda, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor. yagiyvu, inf. n. gayovN, (S, O, Msb,) God watered the country, or countries, with rain. (O, Msb, TA.) And gaAvanaA He (God) sent down rain upon us. (TA.) And gAv Algayovu AlOaroDa, (aor. and inf. n. as above, Msb,) The rain fell upon the earth. (S, O, Msb, K.) And giyvati AlOaroDu, aor. tugaAvu, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, O,) The land was watered with rain. (S, O, Msb, K.) giyva Alqawomu The people were rained upon; rain fell upon the people [or upon their land]. (TA.) And givanoA maA XiYonaA [We were rained upon as much as we desired]: (S, O, Msb, TA:) originally guyivonaA. (TA.) ― -b2- gAv AlnRaworu (tropical:) The blossom shone. (O, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4 in art. gwv.

2 gyRv c
2. gyRv, said of a blind man, He sought, or searched, [or groped, with the hand,] for a thing: (Kr, TA:) also written [EyRv] with [the unpointed] E, and thus correctly, though ISd thought this latter to be a mistranscription. (TA.)

5 tgyRv c
5. tgyRv He became fat: (K:) said of a camel. (TK.)

gayovN c
gayovN inf. n. of gaAva [q. v.]. (S, O, Msb.) ― -b2- And [a subst.] signifying Rain: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) or rain that occupies the space of a bariyd [i. e. six miles, or twelve miles,] in width: (AA, O, K:) or rain that is productive of much good; [supposed to belong to art. gwv, for it is added,] because mankind are aided thereby; thus expl. in the “ Sharh esh-Shifè: ” pl. OagoyaAvN [a pl. of pauc.] and guyuwvN. (TA.) [Hence a tropical usage in a saying mentioned voce vajRaAjN.] ― -b3- And [hence] cubaAbu gayovK [or cubaAbu Algayovi (see cubaAbN) lit. The fly of rain or the fly of the rain] signifies (assumed tropical:) the bee, or bees collectively: so called because the bee seeks after herbage and flowers, which are consequent upon the rain: (IAth, TA:) [for] ― -b4- gayovN signifies also (tropical:) Herbage (Lth, S, A, O, Msb, K) which grows by means of the water of the sky: (Lth, A, O, K:) called thus by the name of its cause. (Msb.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) Clouds. (S, O, TA.) [See an ex. voce faruwqapN.]

giyaAvN c
giyaAvN, originally giwaAvN, see in art. gwv.

gayRivN c
gayRivN i. q. Eayolamu maMCK [i. e. Water that is beneath a stratum of rock]. (TA.) [Hence] biYorN caAtu gayRivK A well having a constant accession of water. (O, K.) ― -b2- And [hence] farasN cuw gayRivK (tropical:) A horse that performs, (O,) or that increases [his running], (K, TA,) run after run. (O, K, TA.)

OaroDN magiyvapN c
OaroDN magiyvapN, and magoyuwvapN↓, (the latter being the original form, TA,) Land watered with rain. (S, O, Msb, K.)

gayovN mugiyvN c
gayovN mugiyvN A general rain. (TA.) [But the epithet mugiyvN evidently belongs to art. gwv; and the phrase properly signifies A rain that gives aid, or succour.]

OaroDN magoyuwvapN c
OaroDN magoyuwvapN: see magiyvapN.

1 gayida c
1. gayida, aor.
gayada
, (L, K,) inf. n. gayadN, (L,) He had a bending neck, and limber sides: (L, K:) or he had a lax, or limber, neck. (L.) ― -b2- [And gayidat is app. said of a young woman as meaning She was soft, or tender; or soft, or tender, and limber in the sides. (See gayadN below.) ― -b3- And gayida He was, or became, drowsy; or drowsy and with a bending of the neck. (See, again, gayadN below.)]

6 tgAyd c
6. tgAyd He affected a bending of his body, or he bent his body, from side to side, in his gait. (A.) And tgAydt She (a woman, L) affected a bending of her body, or bent her body, (L, K, TA,) from side to side, (TA,) in her gait, by reason of softness, or limberness. (L, K, TA.)

gaAdN c
gaAdN A fresh, tender, juicy twig: (L:) and so gaAdapN applied to a tree (XajarapN). (L, K.) ― -b2- And the latter, A soft, or tender, goodly, thin-skinned, plump, and fresh, or flourishing, young woman: (L:) or, (S, A, L, K,) as also gayodaMCu↓, (S, A, K,) a woman, soft, or tender: (S, A:) or soft, or tender, and limber (L, K, TA) in the sides. (TA.)

giydi giydi c
giydi giydi, or giydo giydo, (accord. to different copies of the K,) Hasten thou; make haste; be quick: (K:) a word of the people of Esh-Shihr. (TA.)

gayadN c
gayadN [mentioned above as an inf. n.], in a woman, (S, K,) or in a young woman, (L,) Softness, or tenderness, (S, L, K,) and limberness (L, K) of the sides. (L.) ― -b2- And Drowiness: (A:) [or drowsiness with a bending of the neck: see Oagoyadu.]

gayodaAnN c
gayodaAnN The prime, spring, or first part, of youth. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA.)

Oagoyadu c
Oagoyadu A plant, or herbage, soft, or tender, and bending. (L, K.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) A place abounding with plants, or herbage, (O, K, TA,) bending by reason of softness. (O.) ― -b3- Also A man, and a gazelle, having a bending neck, and limber sides: or having a lax, or limber, neck. (L.) And [the fem.] gayodaMCu (L, K) A woman (L) who bends her body, or affects a bending thereof, by reason of her softness, or limberness. (L, K.) See also gaAdN. ― -b4- Also Drowsy, and having a bending of the neck: (S, A, L, K:) fem. gayodaMCu: (TA:) and pl. giydN. (L.) AlkaraI AlOagoyadu, occurring in a verse cited voce SubaAbapN [q. v.], means (tropical:) Drowsiness that makes one to bend the neck from side to side. (L, TA.)

1 gaAra Oaholahu c
1. gaAra Oaholahu, (S, Msb,) and gAr lahumo, (TA,) aor. yagiyru, inf. n. giyaArN (S, Msb) and gayorN, (Msb, TA,) i. q. maArahumo, (S, Msb, TA,) i. e. He brought, or conveyed, to his family, miyrap [or a provision of corn, or wheat, &c.] (Msb.) [See also art. gwr.] ― -b2- And He benefited them. (S, K, * TA.) 'AbdMenáf Ibn-Riba El-Hudhalee says
maA caA yagiyru QbonataIo riboEK EawiyluhumaA
[What will their loud weeping benefit, or avail, the two daughters of Riba?] meaning that their weeping for their father will not avail them aught in lieu of seeking his blood-revenge. (S, TA.) You say gaArahumo bixayorK, (S, K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as
above, (TA,) He (God) bestowed upon them abundance of the produce of the earth, and rain; (TA in art. gwr;) like as you say OaEoTaAhumo xayorFA: (S, K:) and so gArhm birizoqi [He bestowed upon them means of subsistence]. (TA.) And AallRehumRa gironaA bixayorK (S, Msb) O God, benefit us with prosperity. (Msb.) And gaArahumo bimaTarK He (God) watered them with rain, (S, K, TA,) and bestowed upon them abundance of the produce of the earth. (TA.) And gaAra AlOaroDa Algayovu The rain watered the land. (Fr, S.) [See also art. gwr.] ＝ -A2- gaArahu, aor. yagiyruhu, (AO, S, K,) inf. n. gayorN, (TA,) He gave him the bloodwit; (AO, S, K;) as also gArhu, aor. yaguwruhu; (AO, S, TA;) mino Oaxiyhi [for his brother]: and so gyRrhu↓. (TA.) [See giyrapN.] ＝ -A3- gaAra EalaI Oaholihi, (S,) or ElI QmoraOatihi, (Msb, K,) aor. yagaAru, inf. n. gayorapN, (S, Msb, K,) with fet-h, (S, Msb, TA,) and gayorN and gaArN (S, Msb, K) and giyaArN, (K,) [He was jealous of his wife:] he was jealous for her (mino fulaAnK of such a one: Mgh): [he was careful of her, to avoid suspicion: or he regarded her conduct with disdain, scorn, or indignation: (see gayorapN, below:) or] he was angry at the conduct, or action, of his wife. (Msb.) And gaArati QmoraOatuhu Ealayohi [His wife was jealous of him: &c.]. (M, b, K.) [See also art. gwr.] And you say also, fulaAnN laA EalaI Oaholihi yatagayRaru↓, meaning laA yagaAru [Such a one is not jealous of his wife: &c.]. (TA.)

2 gyRr AlXRaIoCa c
2. gyRr AlXRaIoCa, (S, Msb, K, *) inf. n. tagoyiyrN, (Msb,) He made the thing other than it was; (K;) made it cease to have the quality which it had; (Msb;) altered it; changed it. (K.) He, or it, altered, or changed, the thing in odour, or otherwise, for the worse; corrupted, tainted, or infected, it; rendered it ill-smelling, stinking, fetid, rancid, rank, fusty, or frouzy. (The lexicons passim.) It is said in the Kur [viii. 55], celika biOanRa QllReha lamo yaku mugayRirFA niEomapF OanoEamahaA EalaI qawomK HatRaI yugayRiruwA maA biOanofusihimo [This was because God changeth not favour which He hath conferred upon a people until they change what is in themselves: or] until they change what God hath commanded them to do. (Th, TA.) ― -b2- [And He exchanged the thing for another thing.] ― -b3- gyRr AlXRayoba He plucked out the white, or hoary, hairs. (TA.) ― -b4- gyRr Eano baEiyrihi He put down the saddle from his camel, and put it to rights, or adjusted it, or repaired it. (TA.) One says taraka Alqawoma yugayRiruwna He left the people putting to rights, or adjusting, or repairing, the camels' saddles. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, latter half.

3 gaAoyara
3: [gaAyaraA, inf. n. mugaAyarapN, They differed, each from the other.] You say bayonahumaA mugaAyarapN Between them two is a difference. (Msb.) [See also 6.] ＝ -A2- gAyrhu, (S, K,) inf. n. mugaAyarapN, (S,) He bartered, or exchanged, with him, in buying and selling. (S, K.) And gAyrhu biAlsRiloEapi, inf. n. as above, He bartered, or exchanged, the article of merchandise with him. (TA.) And gAyr AlsRiloEapa, (TA,) inf. n. giyaArN, (S, K, TA,) He exchanged the article of merchandise. (S, * K, * TA.) El-Aashà says
falaA taHosibanRiI lakumo kaAfirFA
walaA taHosibanRiI Ouriydu AlgiyaAraA
[Therefore do thou by no means think me ungrateful towards you; and do thou by no means think I desire the making an exchange]. (S, TA.)

4 AgAr Oaholahu c
4. AgAr Oaholahu [He made his wife jealous;] he married another in addition to his wife, so she became jealous (gArt): (As, A'Obeyd, Msb, K:) belonging to this art. and to art. gwr. (TA.)

5 tgyRr c
5. tgyRr quasi-pass. of gyRr, (S, Msb,) [It became other than it was;] it ceased to have the quality which it had; (Msb;) it became altered, or changed, Eano HaAlihi, from its state or condition. (K.) It became altered, or changed, in odour, or otherwise, for the worse; turned, or turned bad; became corrupted, spoiled, tainted, infected, illsmelling, stinking, fetid, rancid, rank, fusty, or frouzy. (The lexicons passim.) ― -b2- [And It became exchanged for another thing.] ― -b3- See also 1, last signification.

6 tgAyrt AlOaXoyaMCu c
6. tgAyrt AlOaXoyaMCu The things differed, one from another. (S.)

8 AgtAr c
8. AgtAr He procured miyrap [a provision of corn, or wheat, &c.]. (K.) You say xaraja yagotaAru liOaholihi He went forth to procure myrp for his family. (Fr, Sgh.) ― -b2- He derived, or obtained, benefit, advantage, or profit. (TA.) See also art. gwr.

gayorN c
gayorN signifies i. q. siwFI [Other]: and the pl. is OagoyaArN: (S:) [but gayor itself often has a pl. meaning, as will be seen in what follows:] or [accord. to general usage, as will be seen below,] gayoru signifies i. q. siwaI [other than; exclusively of; or not, as used before a substantive or an adjective]. (Msb, K: in the CK [erroneously] siwFI.) It is used to qualify a subst.; [governing (as a prefixed noun) the noun that follows it in the gen. case;] and when so used, it is put in the same case as the noun preceding it. (S.) It qualifies an indeterminate noun: (Mughnee, Msb:) you say jaMCaniI rajulN gayoruka [A man, other than, or not, thou, came to me]: (Msb:) and naEomalo SaAliHFA gayora QlRaciI kunRaA naEomalu [We will in that case do good, other than, or not, what we used to do: (Kur xxxv. 34:)]: (Mughnee:) and mino maMCK gayori MsinK [Of water other than, or not, altered in taste and colour]. (Kur xlvii. 16.) It is a noun necessarily prefixed, as to the sense, to a noun which it governs in the gen. case: but sometimes it is without the latter, when the meaning is understood and it is preceded by layosa, (Mughnee, K,) or by laA: (K:) [in which case it signifies Any other person or thing; any person or thing beside, or else:] you say qabaDotu EaXarapF layosa gayoruhaA [I received ten; not other than they was received by me; i. e., not any other thing; or not anything beside, or else]; (Mughnee, K;) the enunciative, maqobuwDFA, being suppressed: (Mughnee:) and lys gayorahaA, (Mughnee, K;) the noun [of lys] being understood; i. e., layosa AlmaqobuwDu gayorahaA: (Mughnee:) and lys gayora; in which the affixed noun [for AlmDAf, in the K, I read AlmDAf Alyh, as in the Mughnee,] is suppressed, and the noun [of lys] is also understood: (Mughnee, K:) and lys gayoru; (Mughnee, K;) in which, accord. to Mbr, and the later authors, gyr is indecl., being likened to qabolu and baEodu, so that it may be either the noun or the enunciative [of lys] or, accord. to Akh, it is decl., because it is not a noun of time like qabolu and baEodu, nor of place like fawoqu and taHotu, but like kulRN and baEoDN, so that it is the noun [of lys], and the enunciative is suppressed; (Mughnee;) or it may be either indecl. or decl., (Mughnee, K,) accord. to Ibn-Kharoof: (Mughnee:) and lys gayorFA, and lys gayorN; (Mughnee, K;) in both which cases it is decl., as though the affixed noun were mentioned: (Mughnee:) and laA gayoru; for the saying, [which we find in the Mughnee,] app. taken from a statement of Seer, that this is incorrect, is not good, since it occurs in the following verse, cited by Ibn-Málik;
jawaAbFA bihi tanojuw QEotamido fawarabRinaA
laEano EamalK Oasolafota laA gayoru tusoOalu
[Aim thou at having an answer by which thou mayest be safe; for, by our Lord, respecting an action which thou shalt have done before, not any other thing, or not anything beside or else, thou wilt be asked]. (K.) ― -b2- It does not become determinate by its being prefixed to another noun, because it is very vague: but it is also applied as an epithet to a determinate noun which is near to being indeterminate; as in SiraATa QlRaciyna OanoEamota Ealayohimo gayori QlomagoDuwbi Ealayohimo [The way of those upon whom Thou hast conferred favour; the other than, or those who are not, the objects of anger; (Kur i. 6 and 7;)] because the noun rendered determinate by the art. Al denoting a genus is near to being indeterminate, and because when gyr occurs between two contraries its vagueness becomes weakened, (Mughnee, K, *) or altogether departs: (K:) or it is here applied as an epithet to a determinate noun because it resembles a determinate noun in its being prefixed to such a noun: (Msb:) Az says that gyr is here in the gen. case because it is an epithet to Alcyn; and that it may be an epithet to [what is technically termed in this instance] a determinate noun [as having the article Al prefixed to it] because Alcyn has not [in itself] a direct meaning (liOanRa AlRaciyna gayoru maSomuwdK Samoduhu), [it being merely a conjunct noun, the meaning of which is determined by what follows it,] notwithstanding it has the art. Al prefixed to it: Abu-l-'Abbás says that Fr holds Alcyn to have the office of an indeterminate noun; and gyr to be an epithet of it; not of any other noun; but that gyr, accord. to some, may be an epithet relating to the nouns implied in AnEmt Elyhm, these not having a direct meaning: Akh says that gyr [with what follows] is a substitute [for Alcyn with what follows], as though the meaning were SiraATa gayori AlmagoDuwbi Ealayohimo [the way
of those who are not the objects of anger]. (TA.) The reading gayora is also related, on the authority of Ibn-Ketheer, in the accus. case, as a denotative of state, [meaning they being not the objects of anger,] relating to the pronoun governed in the gen. case by the prep. [in Elyhm]; or by OaEoniI [I mean] understood; or as an exceptive, [accord. to a usage to be explained below,] if the favours be interpreted as conferred in common upon the two classes of persons. (Bd.) ― -b3- As it resembles a determinate noun in its being prefixed to a determinate noun, [as AlmgDwb in the above-cited passage of the Kur,] some have presumed to prefix to it the article Al: but against this it may be urged, that its prefixion to a determinate noun is not to render the expression determinate, but for specification; and Al does not imply specification. (Msb.) ― -b4- In the following verse of Hassán,
OataAnaA falamo naEodilo siwaAhu bigayorihi
nabiIRN badaA fiI Zulomapi AllRayoli haAdiyaA
the meaning is, [A prophet came to us, who appeared in the darkness of night, a director in the right way,] and we did not weigh another than him with another than the other, i. e., with him. (Mughnee.) ― -b5- [wagayoru celika is a phrase of frequent occurrence, meaning Et cœtera.] ― -b6- gayoru is also used in the sense of layosa [He, or it, is not]; as in the phrase kalaAmu QllRehi gayoru maxoluwqK [The word of God is not created], syn. layosa bimaxoluwqK. (Az, TA.) ― -b7- It is also used in the sense of laA [meaning Not, as used before a participle]; (S, K;) and then it is in the accus. case, as a denotative of state; (S;) as in the phrase famani QDoTurRa gayora baAgK, (S, K,) in the Kur [ii. 168, and other places], (S,) i. e., jaAYiEFA laA baAgiyFA [But whosoever is necessitated, being hungry, not transgressing the due bounds]. (S, K.) ― -b8- It is also used as an exceptive, (S, Mughnee,) in the sense of UilRaA [Except; save; or but]; (Msb, K;) and then it is put in the same case in which the word following UilRaA would be put in the same phrase, (S, Mughnee, Msb, K,) because it is originally a qualificative, and its use as an exceptive is adventitious: (S:) therefore you say jaMCa Alqawomu gayora zayodK [The people came, except Zeyd]; and maA jaMCaniI OaHadN gayora zayodK and gayoru zayodK [Not any one came to me, except Zeyd]: (Msb, K:) or its case depends upon the governing words, so that you say maA qaAma gayoru zayodK [No one stood, except Zeyd], and maA raOayotu gayora zayodK [I saw not any, except Zeyd]: (Msb:) but Fr says that some of the Benoo-Asad and Kudá'ah put gyr in the accus. case, when used in the sense of UilRaA, whether the phrase before it be complete or incomplete; saying maA jaMCaniI gayoraka [Not any one came to me, except thou], and mA jACnI OaHadN gayoraka [Not any one came to me, except thou]: (S, Msb:) and AA says that when gyr has the place of UilRaA, it is put in the accus. case. (Msb.) In the saying laA Uileha gayoru QllRehi [There is no deity other than God], gyr is in the nom. case because it is the enunciative of lA; but it may be put in the accus. case, as meaning UilRaA. (Msb.) When, as an exceptive, it is prefixed to an indecl. word [and not preceded by a prep.], it may be itself indecl., with fet-h for its termination; as in the following verse;
lamo yamonaEi AlXRuroba minohaA gayora Oano naTaqato
HamaAmapN fiI guSuwnK caAti OawoqaAli
[Nought prevented the drinking from it, except that a pigeon cooed, upon branches having AwqAl, which app. means stumps of cut shoots]. (Mughnee, K.) [See also an ex. (of gayora OanRa) in a verse cited voce bayoda.] ― -b9- [It is often used with a prep.; as in bigayori HisaAbK Without reckoning; (Kur ii. 208, &c.;) and mino gayori suwoCK Without leprosy. (Kur xx. 23, &c.)] ＝ -A2- gayorN (JK, K) and (JK) giyarN↓ (JK, S) signifying The act of altering, or changing, i. q. tagoyiyrN, (JK,) are substs. from gayRarahu; (S with respect to the latter, and K with respect to the former;) not inf. ns., as having no unaugmented verb. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AldRahori giyaru↓, the former of these two words being of the same measure as Einab, The accidents, or casualties, of time or fortune, which alter, or change, things: (K:) [or alteration, or change, of time or of fortune; for] IAmb says, with respect to the saying laA OaraAniI QllRehu bika giyarFA [May God not show me, in thee, alteration of state], that giyarN is from tagayRuru AlHaAli, a subst. like qiTaEN [as meaning “ a portion of the night ”]; or that it may be a pl., of which the sing. is giyorapN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] banaAtu gayorK [or giyarK↓, as in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 309,] (tropical:) Lying: or a lie, or falsehood: syn. kacibN: (TS, K:) or [rather] lies. (JK, A.) You say jaMCa bibanaAti gayorK [or giyarK↓] (tropical:) He uttered lies. (A.)

giyarN c
giyarN: see gayorN, last quarter, in four places: ― -b2- and see also giyrapN.

gayorapN c
gayorapN [Jealousy;] a man's dislike of another's participating in that which is his [the former's] right: (Kull p. 268:) or care of what is sacred, or inviolable, to avoid suspicion: or disdain; scorn; or indignation: syn. HamiyRapN and OanafapN: (TA:) or anger at the conduct, or action, of a wife. (Msb.) [See 1, last signification.]

giyrapN c
giyrapN A provision of corn, or wheat, &c., which a man procures for himself; syn. miyrapN; (S, Msb, K,) as also giyaArN↓: (TA:) [or the latter is probably syn. with miyrapN used in the sense of an inf. n.:] pl. of the former giyarN. (Msb.) [See art. gwr.] ＝ -A2- See also gayorN, last sentence but two. ― -b2- Also A bloodwit; (AA, S, K;) syn. diyapN: (AA, S: *) and giwarN is a dial. var. thereof: (TA in art. gwr:) pl. giyarN↓: (AA, S, K:) or, as some say, this is a sing., (S, TA,) of the masc. gender; TA;) and the pl. is OagoyaArN: (S, TA:) and the diyap is said to be termed giyarN because it is a substitute for retaliation. (TA.)

gayoraAnu c
gayoraAnu; fem. gayoraI: see gayuwrN, in two places.

giyaArN c
giyaArN The cognizance, or badge, of the free nonmuslim subjects of a Muslim government; such as the zunRaAr [or waist-belt] (Mgh, K) to the Magians, (Mgh,) and the like: (Mgh, K:) or, as some say, the cognizance, or badge, of the Jews. (TA.) ― -b2- kalAmN bigiyaArihi (assumed tropical:) Speech, or language, having its own proper guise; not altered therefrom. (Msb in jlf.) ＝ -A2- See also giyrapN.

gayuwrN c
gayuwrN and gayoraAnu↓ (S, Msb, K) and gayRaArN↓ (TA) and migoyaArN↓ (S, K) epithets [all of which are intensive] from gaAra EalaI Oaholihi, (S, Msb, K,) i. e., from Algayorapu: (TA:) [Very jealous: &c.: see gayorapN:] and gayuwrN and gayoraI (S, Msb, K) and gayRaArapN (TA) signify the same applied to a woman: (S, Msb, K:) the pl. of gayuwrN is guyurN, (S, Msb, K,) masc. and fem., (S, K,) and he who says rusolN [for rusulN] says guyorN [or giyrN?]; (TA;) and of gayoraAnu↓, gayaAraI and guyaAraI; (S, Msb, K;) and of gayoraI, also, gayaAraI (S, Msb, K) and guyaAraI; (Msb;) and of migoyaArN↓, magaAyiyru. (S, K.)

gayRaArN c
gayRaArN: see the next preceding paragraph.

Oagoyaru mina AlHumRaI c
Oagoyaru mina AlHumRaI [More jealous than fever:] because a fever cleaves fast to its patient, like as a very jealous woman cleaves to her husband. (TA.)

OaroDN magiyrapN c
OaroDN magiyrapN and magoyuwrapN↓, Land watered: (S, K:) or rained upon: (TA:) the former [like the latter] is with fet-h to the m. (S.)

mugayRirN c
mugayRirN One who puts down the furniture of his camel from off him, to relieve and ease him. (TA.)

migoyaArN c
migoyaArN: see gayuwrN, in two places.

ArD magoyuwrapN c
ArD magoyuwrapN: see magiyrapN.

1 gaADa c
1. gaADa, aor. yagiyDu, inf. n. gayoDN (S, A, Msb, K) and magaADN (Msb, K) and magiyDN, (TA,) It (water) became scanty, or little in quantity, and sank into the earth, or disappeared in the earth: (S, and so in some copies of the K:) or became scanty, or little in quantity, and decreased, or diminished, or became deficient: (A, and so in some copies of the K:) or sank into the earth, and went away: (TA:) or went away into the earth; (Msb;) [contr. of faADa, aor. yafiyDu;] as also AngAD↓, (S, K,) which is of the dial. of El- Hijáz. (TA.) ― -b2- It (a thing, Msb, a flow of milk, TA, and (assumed tropical:) the price of a commodity, S, Msb, K) decreased, or diminished, or became deficient. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b3- wamaA tagiyDu QloOaroHaAmu wamaA tazodaAdu, (S, * K, * TA,) in the Kur [xiii. 9], (S,) means And the wombs' falling short [of completion or of what is usual], (Akh, S, Bd,) and their exceeding [therein], in respect of the body [of the fœtus], and the period of gestation, and the number borne: (Bd:) or, as some say, in respect
of the menstrual blood: (Bd:) or the wombs' falling short of the nine months (Zj, O, L, and so in copies of the K, but in others seven months,) of gestation, and their exceeding the nine [or seven] months: (Zj, O, L:) or the wombs' falling short of completion, so that the fœtus dies, and their exceeding so that the gestation becomes complete: and accord. to this explanation, the reading of seven months in the K may be correct: see also Katádeh's explanation of gayoDN, below, which favours this reading. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, gaADa AlkiraAmu wafaADa AllRiYaAmu (S, A) (tropical:) The generous became few, (S, TA,) and failed, or perished, (TA,) and the mean became many. (S.) ＝ -A2- gaADahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. gayoDN, (TA,) He (God, S, Msb) made it (i. e. water) to become scanty, or little in quantity, and to sink into the earth, or disappear in the earth: (S:) or made it to decrease, or diminish, or become deficient: (K:) or made it to go away into the earth: (Msb:) and AgADhu↓ signifies the same; (S, A, K;) and so does gyRDhu↓, inf. n. tagoyiyDN: (TA:) thus the first of these verbs is trans. as well as intrans. (S.) [It is said in the Kur xi. 46,] wagiyDa QlomaMCu (S, A) And the water was made to become scanty, &c.: (S:) or was made to decrease, or diminish. (A, * Bd.) And hence the saying of 'Áïsheh, describing her father, wagaADa naboEa AlrRidRapi (assumed tropical:) And he did away with what appeared of apostacy. (TA.) You say also, damoEahu gyRD↓, (S, * K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He made his tears to diminish, (S, K,) and restrained them: (S:) or he took the tears from his eye and dashed them away. (Th.) A poet says, (TA,) namely, Jereer, (O and TA in art. gbD,)
mino EabaraAtihinRa waqulona liI gayRaDona↓
maA caA laqiyta mina AlhawaI walaqiynaA
meaning They made their tears to flow until they exhausted them [and they said to me, What is it that thou hast experienced, of love, and we have experienced?]: ISd says that mn here denotes some; or it may be redundant, accord. to the opinion of Abu-l-Hasan; for he holds that it may be so in affirmative [as well as negative] phrases, mentioning, as an instance, qado kaAna mino maTarK, meaning qado kaAna maTarN. (TA.) One relation of this verse gives gabRaDona; but the former is the right. (O and TA in art. gbD.) ― -b2- Also He opened a way, passage, or channel, for it (namely water) to flow forth to a magiyD [q. v.]. (Msb.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He diminished it, namely the price of a commodity; (Ks, S, Msb, K;) as also AgADhu↓. (K.) ― -b4- And He caused him to suffer loss, or detriment; and wronged, or injured, him. (ISd, TA.)

2 gyRDhu c
2. gyRDhu: see 1, latter half, in three places. ＝ -A2- gyRD said of a lion He frequented, or kept to, the gayoDap [q. v.]. (S, Sgh, L, K.)

4 AgADhu c
4. AgADhu: see 1, latter half, in two places.

7 UinogayaDa
7: see 1, first sentence.

gayoDN c
gayoDN An abortive fœtus, not completely formed; (Katádeh, K;) i. e. less than seven months old. (TA.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) Little; or a small quantity: as in the saying, or in OaEoTaAhu gayoDFA mino fayoDK (tropical:) He gave him little from much. (S, A, K.) ＝ -A3- An abundance of the trees called OaEolaAv; i. e. TarofaMC and Oavol and HaAj and EikoriX and yanobuwt. (TA.) [See also gayoDapN.]

giyDN c
giyDN The TaloE [or spadix of a palm-tree]; (IAar, IDrd, O, K, TA;) like gaDiyDN and UigoriyDN: (TA:) or the Eajam (AA, O, K) [thus correctly (in the CK Eujom) evidently, I think, here meaning the heart (commonly called jumRaAr q. v.) of the palm-tree (the only produce that is eaten except the dates)] that comes forth, or coming forth, (K,) or that has not come forth, (O,) from [amid] its [membranous fibres termed] liyf [q. v.], and all of which is eaten. (AA, O, K.)

gayoDapN c
gayoDapN A thicket; syn. OajamapN; i. e. a collection of tangled, or confused, or dense, trees: (Mgh, Msb:) or an Oajamap; i. e. a magiyD↓ [q. v.] of water collected together, in which, in consequence thereof, trees grow: (S:) or an Oajamap: and a place in which is a collection of trees in a magiyD of water: (K:) or particularly, of [trees of the willow-kind called] garab; not of all trees; (AHn, O, K;) accord. to the first Arabs of the desert; but this is at variance with what we find in the poems of the Arabs; for Ru-beh, for instance, makes it to consist of fruit-bearing trees and trees not fruit-bearing, and makes it to be a gaAbap: (AHn, O:) [see also gayonapN:] pl. [of pauc.] OagoyaADN (S, K) and [of mult.] giyaADN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and gayoDaAtN: (Msb:) the first of these being formed with disregard of the augmentative [p]; not being a pl. pl., for this is not so formed: (TA:) any garab in Nejd adjacent to the garab of the cultivated lands, when they are collected therein, are termed giyaAD. (O, TA.) [See also gayoDN.]

gaAYiD c
gaAYiD as used in the following verse,
UilaI QllRehi OaXokuw mino xaliylK OawadRuhu
valaAva xilaAlK kulRuhaA liIa gaAYiDu
is said by some to mean gaAYiZ, the D being substituted for Z; [so that the verse should be rendered, To God I complain of three qualities, or habits, of a friend whom I love, every one of which is to me such as angers;] thus says IJ: but ISd says that it may be without substitution, from gaADahu as expl. in the last sentence of the first paragraph of this art.; and thus the meaning may be, such as causes me to suffer loss, or detriment, and such as wrongs, or injures, me. (TA.)

magiyDN c
magiyDN is an inf. n. (TA. [See 1, first sentence.]) ― -b2- And also the pass. part. n. of gaADahu; applied to water. (Msb, TA. *) ― -b3- And a n. of place, signifying A place where water sinks, or goes away, into the earth: (Msb, TA:) or magiyDu maMCK signifies a place where water enters [into the earth]: and a place where water collects: (Mgh:) see also gayoDapN: pl. magaAyiDu. (Mgh.)

1 gaATa c
1. gaATa, aor. yagiyTu, inf. n. gayoTN: see gaATa, aor. yaguwTu, inf. n. gawoTN, in art. gwT.

gayoTN c
gayoTN: see gaAYiTN in art. gwT.

1 gaAZahu c
1. gaAZahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yagiyZu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. gayoZN, (Msb, TA,) He, or it, affected him with gayoZ [or anger, wrath, or rage; &c.; i. e. angered him; or enraged him; &c.]; (S, Msb, K, &c.;) as also gyRZhu↓; (IAar, Th, K; [in a copy of the Msb, tgyRZhu, which is doubtless a mistranscription;]) and gAyZhu↓; (S, K;) and AgAZhu↓; (IAar, Th, Msb, K;) but this last is not common; (Zj;) or it is not allowable. (ISk, S.) [See also gayoZN below.]

2 gayRaZa
2: see the preceding paragraph.

3 gAyZhu c
3. gAyZhu, inf. n. mugaAyaZapN: see 1: [originally, He angered him, or enraged him, or the like, being angered, or enraged, or the like, by him. ― -b2- And hence, because emulation, or the like, often causes mutual anger,] (tropical:) He emulated him, vied with him, or strove to overcome or surpass him, and did like as he did. (TA.) ― -b3- mugaAyaZapN also signifies (assumed tropical:) An acting in a leisurely manner: or it is [a] mutual [acting in that manner]. (TA.)

4 OagoyaZa
4: see the first paragraph.

5 tagayRaZa
5: see 8. ― -b2- samiEuwA lahaA tagayRuZFA, in the Kur [xxv. 13] means (tropical:) They shall hear it to have a sound of boiling, (Zj, Bd, Jel,) like the boiling of the breast of an angry man. (Bd, * Jel.) ― -b3- tagayRaZati AlhaAjirapu (tropical:) The midday, or summer-midday, became [ragingly or] vehemently hot. (K, TA.)

8 AgtAZ c
8. AgtAZ He was or became, affected with gayoZ [or anger; or rage; &c.; i. e. he was, or became, angered; or enraged; &c.]; (S, Msb, K;) mino kacaA by reason of such a thing; and sometimes one says, mino laA XaIoCK by reason of nothing; (Msb;) as also tgyRZ↓. (S, K.)

gayoZN c
gayoZN Anger; wrath; syn. gaDabN: (K) or [rage, or vehement anger; for] it has a more intensive signification than gaDabN: (IDrd:) or the former is latent [anger]; and the latter is apparent: or the former is that which affects a person who has not power to exercise it; and the latter, that which affects a person who has power to exercise it: (TA:) or the former, latent anger affecting one who has not power to exercise it: (S:) or most vehement anger, (Msb, K,) encompassing the liver, by reason of some event that is disliked or hated, and sometimes by reason of nothing: (Msb:) or the outbreak, and commencement, of anger. (IDrd, K.) ― -b2- takaAdu tamayRazu mina QlogayoZi, in the Kur
[lxvii. 8], means (assumed tropical:) It shall almost burst asunder by reason of vehemence of heat. (TA.)

faEala celika giyaAZaka c
faEala celika giyaAZaka, and giyaAZayoka, (K, * TA,) [in the CK giyaADayoka,] i. q. ganaAZayoka, (K,) i. e. He did that in order to distress thee, [or anger thee, or enrage thee,] time after time. (K in art. gnZ.)

gaAYiZN c
gaAYiZN Affecting with gayoZ [or anger; or rage; &c.; i. e. angering; or enraging; &c.]: (TA:) pl. gaAYiZuwna. (Kur, xxvi. 55.)

OagoyaZu c
OagoyaZu [comparative and superlative of gaAYiZN]. OagoyaZu AlOasomaMCi Einoda QllRehi maliku AlOamolaAki means The most severely to be punished, of persons bearing names, is he who is named the king of kings: (TA:) [lit. the most angering, or enraging, of names, is the king of kings.]

magiyZN c
magiyZN Affected with gayoZ [or anger; or rage; &c.; i. e. angered; or enraged; &c.]. (S, Msb.)

HaliymapN mugotaAZapN c
HaliymapN mugotaAZapN (tropical:) [lit. Calm, angry; or the like; because what it contains is sometimes still and sometimes boiling;] is an appellation given to a stone cooking-pot. (A, TA.)

1 gaAfati AlXRajarapu c
1. gaAfati AlXRajarapu, (S, O, K,) aor. tagiyfu, (O, K,) inf. n. gayafaAnN; (S, O, K;) and tgyRft↓, (S, O, K, *) in the copies of the K erroneously tgyRf; (TA;) as also Oagoyafat↓, inf. n. UigoyaAfN; (TA;) The tree inclined, (S,) or had its branches inclining, (O, K,) to the right and left. (S, O, K.)

2 gyRf c
2. gyRf, (O, K,) inf. n. tagoyiyfN, (K,) He fled, or turned away and fled; and drew back, or drew back in fear; (O, K;) and was cowardly. (K.) You say, Hamala fulaAnN fiI AlHarobi fagayRafa i. e. [Such a one charged, in war, or battle, and] was cowardly; or retreated, and was cowardly. (S.) ― -b2- See also 5.

4 Oagoyafa
4: see 1. ＝ -A2- AgAf AlXRajarapa, (O, K, *) inf. n. UigaAfapN, (TA,) He made the tree to bend, or incline, (O, K, * TA, *) by reason of softness, or tenderness. (TA.)

5 tagayRafa
5: see 1. ― -b2- tgyRf said of a horse, He inclined, or bent, (S, O, K, TA,) towards one side, (S, O, TA,) in running. (TA.) And He [app. a man] walked with an elegant and a proud and selfconceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side, and in the manner of the tall: or he passed along easily and quickly: or, accord. to AHeyth, he affected an inclining of the body from side to side, by reason of width of step, and gentleness of pace: accord. to El-Mufaddal, he was proud, or haughty, in his gait. (TA.) The phrase marRa AlbaEiyru yatagayRafu, mentioned by As, but not expl. by him, is said by Sh to mean [The camel passed along] going quickly. (TA.) ― -b3- One says also, tgyRf Eani AlOamori, meaning He refrained, or drew back, from the affair, in fear; as also gyRf↓; this latter mentioned by Th. (TA.) ― -b4- And tagayRufN signifies also The being, or becoming, creased, or wrinkled: like tagaDRufN. (TA in art. EDf.)

gaAfN c
gaAfN A species of trees, (AHn, S, O, K,) growing in the sands, and becoming large, the leaves of which are smaller than those of the apple, which it resembles in character, or form, (AHn, O,) having a very sweet fruit, (AHn, O, K,) of the kind termed EulRaf, like the pods (quruwn) of the bean, and its wood is white; so, says AHn, I have been informed by some of the Arabs of 'Omán, which is the place of its origin: n. un. with p: (O:) accord. to some of the Arabs, the species of trees called yanobuwt, [see this word, of which one description agrees exactly with that given above,] (O, K, * TA, *) which is found in 'Omán: (TA:) accord. to AZ, it is of the [trees called] EiDaAh, and is a tree like the qaraZ [q. v.], thorny, of the region of El-Hijáz, growing in the [high, or high and rugged, grounds called] qifaAf [pl. of qufRN]. (TA.)

gayofN c
gayofN A flock of birds. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

gayofaAnN c
gayofaAnN and gayRafaAnN↓, (O, K, TA,) the latter like hayRabaAnN, (K, TA, in the CK hayRibAn,) i. q. maraHN; (O, TA;) in the Tekmileh mariH, like katif; and in the copies of the K marox; but the first of these is the right; meaning [A proud and self-conceited carriage, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side,] in pace, or [manner of] going. (TA.)

gayofaAniIRN c
gayofaAniIRN: see Oagoyafu.

gayRafaAnN c
gayRafaAnN: see gayofaAnN.

gayRaAfN c
gayRaAfN One whose beard is long, (O, K, TA,) and wide on every side, (O, TA,) and very large. (K, TA.)

Oagoyafu c
Oagoyafu Having a bending of the neck, (like Oagoyadu,) but without drowsiness. (O, K.) ― -b2- And, applied to trees (XajarN), quivering, or playing loosely, succulent, or sappy, soft, tender, or supple; as also gayofaAniIRN↓; and so gayofaMCu [the fem. of the former] applied to a tree (XajarapN). (TA.) ― -b3- And EayoXN Oagoyafu A soft, or an easy, and a a plentiful, life; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) like OagoDafu. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

gaAqN c
gaAqN A certain aquatic bird; as also gaAqapN↓. (Lth, O, K.) ― -b2- And The crow, or raven: (ISd, K:) so sometimes called because of his cry. (ISd, TA.) ＝ -A2- gaAqi is a word imitative of The cry [i. e. caw] of the crow, or raven: when indeterminate, [meaning a caw,] it is with tenween, (IJ, S, O, K,) i. e. gaAqK. (IJ, TA.)

gaAqapN c
gaAqapN: see the preceding paragraph.

1 gaAlato waladahaA c
1. gaAlato waladahaA, inf. n. gayolN [q. v.]: see 4. ＝ -A2- gaAla fulaAnFA kacaA Such a thing brought evil to such a one. (TA.)

4 OagaAla c and Oagoyala
4. OagaAla Oagoyala, (Mgh,) or OagaAla waladahu (S, Msb) and Oagoyalahu, (Msb,) He compressed the mother of his child while she was suckling it. (S, Mgh, * Msb.) ― -b2- And OagaAlato and Oagoyalato, (Mgh,) or OagaAlato waladahaA and Oagoyalatohu, (S, Msb, K,) She gave her child to drink what is termed gayol, (S, K, TA,) i. e. the milk of her who was compressed, or the milk of her who was pregnant: (TA:) or [accord. to common usage] she suckled her child while she was pregnant: (Mgh, Msb:) and waladahaA gaAlato↓, aor. tagiylu, inf. n. gayolN, signifies [the same, or] she suckled her child while she was being compressed, or while she was pregnant. (TK.) [See also 10.] ＝ -A2- Oagoyalato said of sheep or goats, (O, K,) and of cows, (O, TA,) They brought forth twice in the year. (O, K, TA.) ＝ -A3- See also the next paragraph.

5 tgyRl AlXRajaru c
5. tgyRl AlXRajaru The trees became tangled, or abundant and dense, (As, S, K,) in their branches, having leafy coverings or shades; as also Oagoyala↓ and Aisotagoyala↓: (K:) or all signify the trees became large, and tangled, or abundant and dense. (TA.) ― -b2- And tgyRlwA They became many: (O, K:) and (so in the O, but in the K “ or ”) their cattle, or possessions, became many. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- tgyRl He entered the giyl [i. e. thicket, or covert]. (O.) And tgyRl AlXRajara He (a lion) entered among the trees, and took them as a giyl [or covert. (TA.)

8 AgtAlhu c
8. AgtAlhu He did evil to him without his knowing whence it came so that he might prepare himself. (TA.) It is said in a trad., OaEuwcu bika Oano OugotaAla mino taHotiI i. e. [I seek protection by Thee from] my being the object of an event's befalling me whence I shall not know; meaning thereby the sinking [into the ground] and being swallowed up. (TA.) AlAigotiyaAlu and Algiylapu are syn. in a sense expl. below. (S, O, K.) See the latter word below: and see also 8 in art. gwl. One says, Augotiyla, meaning He was deceived, and taken to a place, and [there] slain. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AgtAl said of a boy, He became thick and fat. (S, K.)

10 Aisotagoyalato c
10. Aisotagoyalato, said of a woman, a verb of which the subst. is giylapN [q. v.]: (K:) [accord. to the context in the K, in which the meaning is not clearly indicated, it seems to signify She suckled her child while being compressed, or while pregnant; like OagaAlato for OagaAlato waladahaA; and this I believe to be the right meaning: or] it signifies she was compressed while suckling a child, or while pregnant. (TK.) ＝ -A2- See also 5, first sentence.

gayolN c
gayolN: see giylapN, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- As some say, (Msb,) it signifies The milk with which a woman suckles while she is being compressed, (S, Msb, K, TA,) or while she is pregnant: (S, K, TA:) you say, saqatohu gayolFA, (Msb,) or Algayola, (K, TA,) i. e. She gave him to drink such milk. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Water running upon the surface of the earth; (S, Mgh, O, Msb,
K;) thus correctly, with fet-h; but giylN↓, with kesr, is a dial. var. thereof, mentioned by ISd: (TA:) both are said to signify water running amid trees: (Ham p. 555:) IB says that the former signifies thus; and that its pl. is guyuwlN: and it is also said to signify water running in rivers or rivulets, and in streamlets for irrigation: (TA:) and by some, to signify water running amid stones, in the interior of a valley. (Ham ubi suprà.) It is said in a trad., that in the case of that [produce] which is irrigated by the water thus termed (maA suqiIa baAlgayoli, S, Mgh, O, Msb, TA, or gayolFA, Mgh) there shall be [given for the poor-rate] the tenth; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, TA;) and in the case of that which is irrigated by the bucket, half of the tenth. (S, TA.) [See also an ex. voce SubaAbapN.] ― -b2- And Any valley in which are flowing springs: (K:) or a place in a collection of tangled, or abundant and dense, trees, in which is water running upon the surface of the earth: (Lth, TA:) and any place in which is water, (K, TA,) such as a valley and the like: (TA:) and giylN↓, with kesr, signifies any valley in which is water; and the pl. of this is OagoyaAlN [a pl. of pauc.] and guyuwlN. (K.) ― -b3- See also giylN. ＝ -A3- Also A plump, full, saAEid [or fore arm]; (S, O, K;) and so mugotaAlN↓: (K:) the latter said by Fr to be applied to a wrist as meaning full because from Algawolu; but this saying is not valid, as gayolN is found in the same sense. (IJ, TA.) [See an ex. of the former in a verse cited voce TafolN.] And A fat, big, boy; as also mugotaAlN↓: (K:) fem. of the former gayolapN; (TA;) which is applied to a woman as meaning fat; (S, K;) or a fat, big, woman. (AO, TA.) ― -b2- See also gayRilN, in two places. ＝ -A4- Also The ornamental, or figured, or variegated, border (syn. Ealam) in a garment: (AA, K:) pl. OagoyaAlN. (AA, TA.) ― -b2- And A line that one makes, or marks, upon a thing. (K.)

giylN c
giylN A thicket; or trees in a tangled, confused, or dense, state: (As, S, O:) or an abundance of such trees, (K, TA,) not thorn-trees, amid which one may conceal himself: (TA:) and gayolN↓ signifies the same: (K:) and the former, a collection of reeds or canes, and of [the kind of high, coarse, grass called] HalofaMC: (K:) and i. q. OajamapN [i. e. a collection, or an abundant collection, of tangled, confused, or dense, trees, or of reeds or canes]: (S, O, K) [and in like manner gayolapN↓, occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, is expl. by Freytag, as signifying “ saltus: ”] and the place [meaning covert] of the lion: it may not have the termination p: the pl. is guyuwlN; (S, O;) and gayaAyiylu is said to be an anomalous pl. of giylN. (O and TA in art. Eyl, voce EayRaAlN, q. v.) ― -b2- See also gayolN, in two places.

gayolapN c
gayolapN: see giylapN. ― -b2- Also A single act of AigotiyaAl [q. v. voce giylapN]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also giylN. ＝ -A3- It is also fem. of the epithet gayolN [q. v.]. (TA.)

giylapN c
giylapN and gayolN↓ signify the same; (Mgh, O, Msb); i. e. The compressing one's wife while she is suckling: (Mgh, Msb:) thus expl. by AO as stated by A'Obeyd: (Mgh:) and thus the former signifies accord. to El-'Alkamee; and so says Málik: or, accord. to El-Munáwee, it signifies the compressing one's wife while she is suckling or pregnant: or, accord. to ISk, a woman's suckling while pregnant: (from a marginal note in a copy of the Jámi' es-Sagheer of Es-Suyootee, in explanation of a trad. mentioned in what here follows, commencing with the words laqado hamamotu:) and gayolN↓ has this last signification (Mgh, TA) accord. to Ks: (Mgh:) giylapN is the subst. from Aisotagoyalato: (K:) and IAth says that gayolapN↓ is a dial. var. thereof; or, as some say, this denotes a single act [of what is termed giylap]; or the pronunciation with fet-h is not allowable unless with the elision of the p. (TA.) One says, OaDarRati Algiylapu biwaladi fulaAnK, meaning His mother's being compressed while she was suckling him [injured the child of such a one], and likewise his mother's being pregnant while she was suckling him. (S, O.) [But] in a trad. is related the saying, (of the Prophet, O) “ Verily I had intended to forbid Algiylap (S, Mgh, * O, Msb, K) until I remembered that the Persians and the Greeks practise it and it does not injure their children. ” (Mgh, O, Msb.) [See also 4 in art. fsd.] ― -b2- Also The act of deceiving, or beguiling: (K:) and i. q. AigotiyaAlN↓: (S, O, K: [see 8, and giylapN, as expl. in art. gwl:]) accord. to Aboo-Bekr, in the language of the Arabs it signifies the causing evil, or slaughter, to come to another from an unknown quarter. (TA.) One says, qatalahu giylapF, meaning He deceived, or, beguiled, him, and went with him, or took him, to a place, and slew him (S, O, K) when he reached it: (S, O:) or he slew him at unawares. (Abu-l- 'Abbás, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The XaqoXiqap [or faucial bag of the he-camel]. (IAar, K.)

OumRu gayolaAna c
OumRu gayolaAna [in Pers. mugayolaAn] A species of the [trees called] giDaAh; (Mgh, Msb;) the [species of lote-] trees called sidor; (S, O, K, TA;) the fruit of which is said to be sweeter than honey: the saying, of some, that it is with kesr to the g, and that it is thus called because the giylAn [pl. of guwlN] are often found before it, is rejected and false: (TA:) Lth and ISh say that it is the same as the TaloH [q. v.]. (TA in art. TlH.)

gayuwlN c
gayuwlN, as stated by IJ, on the authority of Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, who had it from his grandfather, is sing. of guyulN, (TA,) which is an epithet applied to oxen, or bulls and cows, (AO, IJ, O, K, TA, [nafarN in the CK being a mistake for baqarN,]) and to camels, (K,) signifying Numerous: and also [in the K “ or ”] fat. (AO, IJ, O, K.) ― -b2- And, applied to anything, Alone; solitary: pl. guyulN. (AA, TA.)

gayRilN c
gayRilN, like sayRidN, (O, TA,) in the K gayolN↓, but this latter is said by ISd to be of weak authority, (TA,) applied to a garment, Wide, or ample. (O, K, TA.) And so gayRilapN applied to a land: (O, TA: [mentioned also in art. gwl:]) or, as some say, gayRilN, thus applied, (O, TA,) but accord. to the context in the K gayolN↓, (TA,) signifies Such as one judges to be of little extent, though it is far extending: (O, K, * TA:) and caAtu gawolK, so applied, has been mentioned in art. gwl as having this meaning. (TA.) And gayRilapN applied to a woman signifies Tall: (O, TA:) and so does caAtu gawolK. (TA in art. gwl.)

AlgayRaAlu c
AlgayRaAlu The lion: (K) or the lion that is in the giyl [or covert]. (O.)

gaAYilN c
gaAYilN Much, or abundant, dust or earth. (TA.)

gaAYilapN c
gaAYilapN Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, that is covert, or concealed. (K.) And Evil, or mischief; as also magaAlapN↓: (S, K:) thus in the saying fulaAnN qaliylu AlgaAYilapi and AlmagaAlapi↓ [Such a one is a person of little evil or mischief]. (S.) ― -b2- See also the same word in art. gwl.

Oagoyalu c
Oagoyalu Full; big, or large. (TA.)

mugaAlN c
mugaAlN (Mgh, K) and mugoyalN↓ (S, Mgh, K) A child given to drink what is termed gayol: (S, * K: [See 4:]) or suckled while its mother is pregnant. (Mgh.)

mugoyalN c
mugoyalN: see the next preceding paragraph.

mugiylN c
mugiylN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and mugoyilN (Mgh, Msb, K) A woman giving her child to drink what is termed gayol: (S, K: [see 4:]) or suckling it while she is pregnant. (Mgh, Msb.)

magaAlapN c
magaAlapN: see gaAYilapN, in two places.

mugayRilN c
mugayRilN [in the CK mugayRal] and mutagiyRilN↓ Continuing, or remaining fixed, or stationary, in the giyl [meaning thicket, or covert, in the CK gayol]: and entering therein. (K, TA.)

migoyaAlN c
migoyaAlN A tree (XajarapN) having tangled, or abundant and dense, branches, with leafy coverings or shades. (K.)

mugotaAlN c
mugotaAlN: see gayolN, latter half, in two places.

mutagayRilN c
mutagayRilN: see mugayRilN.

1 gaAmati AlsRamaMCu c
1. gaAmati AlsRamaMCu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. tagiymu, inf. n. gayomN; (Msb;) and tgyRmt↓; and gayRamat↓, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tagoyiymN; (K;) and OagaAmat↓ (S, Msb, K) and Oagoyamat; (S, K;) all signify the same; (S;) The sky was, or became, clouded, or covered with clouds. (S, * Msb, K. *) ＝ -A2- gaAma, aor. yagiymu, (S, K,) inf. n. gayomN, (KL,) He was, or became, thirsty, (S, K, KL, * [like EaAma,]) and affected with internal heat. (S, K) ― -b2- And gAm UilaI AlmaMCi, aor. as above, inf. n. gayomapN and gayamaAnN and magoyamN, is mentioned by IAar [as signifying He thirsted for water, or the water: or he thirsted for it vehemently, accord. to an explanation of gayomapN given below]. (TA.)

2 gayRama
2: see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] gyRm AllRayolu, (K,) inf. n. tagoyiymN, (TA,) (tropical:) The night became like the gayom [or clouds]; (K;) became dark, and came like the clouds. (TA.) ― -b3- And gyRm AlTRaAYiru (assumed tropical:) The bird fluttered over one's head, not going to a distance; on the authority of Th: mentioned by IAar as with gyn and tAC [evidently mistranscriptions for Eyn and vAC: see EayRava]. (TA.)

4 OagaAmati AlsRamaMCu c and Oagoyamat
4. OagaAmati AlsRamaMCu Oagoyamat: see 1. ― -b2- Oagoyama Alqawomu [The people, or party, had a clouded sky;] clouds came upon the people, or party. (S, K.) ― -b3- And Oagoyama He (a man, TA) became stationary (K, TA) like the clouds. (TA.)

5 tagayRama
5: see the first paragraph.

gayomN c
gayomN, originally an inf. n., from gaAmati AlsRamaMCu [q. v.], (Msb,) Clouds; (S, Msb, K, TA;) n. un. with p: (Msb:) or [an expanse of clouds covering the sky,] when one sees not a sun (Kr, TA) by reason of much covering of the sky: (TA:) [and often meaning mist:] pl. guyuwmN and giyaAmN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Thirst: and internal heat. (AA, S, K.) [See also gayomapN.] ― -b2- And Anger, wrath, or rage, (K, TA,) which is from internal heat. (TA.) ― -b3- And a certain disease in camels, like that called qulaAb [q. v.], except that it does not kill: (K, TA:) it is said that the asterism of the Pleiades (AlvRurayRaA, q. v.,) does not rise nor set aurorally without there being sickness, mostly in the camels, which are then affected with the disease thus called. (Az, TA.) ＝ -A3- XajarN gayomN Dense, or tangled, trees: like gayonN [which is a dial. var. of gayomN in other senses]. (TA.)

gayomap c
gayomap Thirst; so says A 'Obeyd: or vehemence of thirst: thus in the trad. cited under EayomapN [q. v.]. (TA.) [See also gayomN.]

gayomAn c
gayomAn Thirsty: and affected with internal heat: fem. gayomaI: (S, K:) the latter applied to a woman. (S.)

yawomN gayuwm c
yawomN gayuwm [A cloudy day;] a day having gayom [or clouds, or clouds covering the sky]. (Th, TA.)

magoyuwmN c
magoyuwmN A camel affected with the disease termed gayom: (Az, K, TA:) such scarcely ever, or never, dies. (Az, TA.)

1 gaAna Ealayohi kacaA c
1. gaAna Ealayohi kacaA, [aor. yagiynu, inf. n. gayonN,] Such a thing covered, veiled, or concealed, him, or it: (Ham p. 574:) [and so OagaAnahu↓; whence] one says, Algayonu AlsRamaMCa AgAn↓ The clouds covered, or overspread, or wholly covered, the sky. (S, K.) And giyna EalaI kacaA Such a thing was covered over. (S.) [Hence,] giyna EalaI qalobihi, inf. n. gayonN; as also Ougiyna↓ [in the CK (erroneously) Aagoyana]; (assumed tropical:) His heart was invaded by desire, or appetite, as by a thing that covered it: or was covered [so as to be rendered unsusceptible]: or was enveloped by the like of rust [or clouded or rendered dull]. (K, TA. [For AlrRayon, meaning “ the like of rust ” covering the heart, the CK has AldRayon.]) The saying, in a trad., UinRahu layugaAnu EalaI qalobiI (S, Msb, TA) HatRaI Oasotagofira QllReha fiI Alyawomi saboEiyna marRapF (TA) is from the phrase giyna EalaI kacaA signifying as expl. above, (S,) and means (assumed tropical:) Verily my heart is invaded as though it were covered, by unmindfulness from which mankind will not be free so that I beg forgiveness of God in the day seventy times: (TA:) or it means, being used metonymically, verily I become diverted from AlmuraAqabap [meaning the fear of God, or, as a conventional term, the constant knowledge of God's cognition of me in all my states or circumstances,] by the affairs that are for good relating to the present world; for these, though matters of importance, are, in comparison with the affairs relating to the other world, as idle sport, in the estimation of the people who follow the rule of AlmuraAqabap. (Msb.) ― -b2- One says also, giynati AlsRamaMCu, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. gayonN; as also gaAnat, inf. n. gayonN; [like gaAmat;] (TA;) The sky became covered (Msb, TA) with gayon (Msb) or gayom (TA) [i. e. clouds, or an expanse of clouds]. ＝ -A2- ginotu, aor. Oagiynu, [inf. n. gayonN,] I was, or became, thirsty. (S, K.) And gaAnati AlUibilu i. q. gaAmat (S, K, TA) i. e. The camels were, or became, thirsty. (TA.) ― -b2- And gaAnato nafosuhu, (S,) or nafosiI, (K,) aor. tagiynu, (S, K,) inf. n. gayonN, (TA,) His, or my, soul [or stomach] heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. gavato. (S, K.)

2 HasanapF c
2. HasanapF gayRana gayonFA↓ and HasanFA He wrote a beautiful g. (TA.)

4 Oagoyana
4: see the first paragraph, in three places.

gaAnN c
gaAnN: see gayonapN.

gayonN c
gayonN [mentioned above as an inf. n. is also a subst., as such] i. q. gayomN, (K, TA,) a dial. var. of the latter word, (S, Msb, TA,) signifying clouds; (TA;) [or an expanse of clouds;] as in the phrase fiI yawomi gayonK in a day of clouds: (S, * TA:) or, meaning “ clouds, ” it is from gaAna Ealayohi kacaA signifying as expl. in the beginning of this art. (Ham p. 574.) ― -b2- And XajarN gayonN Dense, or tangled, trees: (TA:) like gayomN. (TA in art. gym.) ＝ -A2- Also [like gayomN signifying] Thirst. (S, K. [See also 1.]) ＝ -A3- And [The letter g;] one of the letters of the alphabet: (S, K:) pl. [of mult.] guyuwnN and [of pauc.] OagoyaAnN and gayonaAtN. (TA.) See 2, and art. g.

gaAnapN c
gaAnapN The ring at the head of the bow-string. (K.) [See EunotuwtN.]

gayonapN c
gayonapN i. q. OajamapN; [like gayoDapN, q. v.;] so in the M; (TA;) [and it is said that] Algayonapu AlXRajoraMCu is like AlgayoDapu AlxaDoraMCu: or, accord. to Abu-l- 'Ameythel [or 'Omeythil], (S, TA,) gayonapN signifies [A collection of] tangled, or confused, or dense, trees, (S, K, TA,) in the mountains, and in the plain, or soft, land, (TA,) without water; (S, K, TA;) if with water, called gayoDapN: (S, TA:) [and Golius states, as on the authority of Yákoot, that gaAnN↓ signifies the same as gayonapN.]

giynapN c
giynapN The fluid that runs from a carcass, or corpse, (S,) or from the dead: and [the humour, or matter, termed] Sadiyd, q. v. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

Oagoyanu c
Oagoyanu Green: (S, TA:) or green inclining to blackness: (so in one of my copies of the S:) and [its fem.] gayonaMCu is applied to a tree (XajarapN) as meaning green, (AO, S, K, TA,) abounding with leaves, having tangled, or dense, branches, (AO, S, TA,) and soft, or tender: and sometimes it is thus applied to herbs: (TA:) or [applied to a tree] it signifies great, having wide shade: from the phrase gaAna Ealayohi kacaA, expl. in the beginning of this art.: (Ham p. 574:) and Oagoyanu signifies [also] such as is tall, (K, TA,) of trees, or, by way of comparison [thereto], of men: (TA:) the pl. is giynN: (S, TA:) which is expl. by Kr as meaning the abundance, and collected state, and beauty, of [the trees called] OaraAk and sidor; but what is well known is that it is pl. of gayonaMC applied to a tree; of which giynapN↓, with kesr, has also been mentioned as a pl., though, as ISd says, this is not known in the [genuine] language, nor is it agreeable with the analogy of Arabic. (TA.)

mugoyin c
mugoyin, in the original form, [for mugiyn, act. part. n. of OagaAna,] is used by Ru-beh in the following verse:
OamosaI bilaAlN kaAlrRabiyEi Almudojini
OamoTara fiI OakonaAfi gayonK mugoyini
[There was, or came, in the evening, a moisture like the continual rain of winter that has rained in the tracts of overspreading clouds]. (S.)
